preamble.titlePage:
NATIONAL AERONAUTICS AND SPACE ADMINISTRATION
APOLLO 13
TECHNICAL AIR-TO-GROUND VOICE TRANSCRIPTION
Prepared by Test Division Apollo Spacecraft Program Office
MANNED SPACECRAFT CENTER
HOUSION,TEXAS April 1970
introductionText: This is the transcription of the technical air-to-ground (TAG) voice communications of the Apollo 13 mission. The primary communications net (GOSS net l) will be in continuous operation for the duration of the mission. An alternate communications net (GOSS net 2) may be activated when separate, simultaneous communications links with both spacecraft are desired.

The transcript is divided into three columns -- time, speaker, and text. The time column consists of four two-digit pairs for days, hours, minutes, and seconds (e.g., 04 22 45 12). The speaker column indicates the source of a transmission; the text column contains the verbatim transcript of the communications.

The primary communications net (GOSS net l) comprises the bulk of the transcript. However, when GOSS net 2 is activated, the communications on that net will be integrated with the GOSS net 1 communications. A heavy dark line alongside the time column will indicate GOSS net 2 communications.

A series of three dots (...) is used to designate those portions of the text that could not be transcribed because of garbling. A series of three asterisks (***) is used to designate those portions of the text that could not be transcribed because of clipping caused by the VOX mode. One dash (-) is used to indicate a speaker's pause or a self-interruption and subsequent completion of a thought. Two dashes (- -) are used to indicate an interruption by another speaker or the point at which a recording was abruptly terminated.
Speakers in the transcript may be identified as follows. [see speakers acronym list metadata.acronyms.speakers]

When the CDR and LMP are in the undocked lunar module or on the lunar surface, their speaker designations will be suffixed by either LM or EVA to indicate their status (e.g., CDR-EVA or LMP-LM). Voice calls during this mission were assigned in accordance with the following station operating procedures:

For all phases when only the CSM is manned, the AS-508 call sign will be Apollo 13. When both vehicles are manned, the call sign will be Odyssey for the CSM and Aquarius for the LM. The call signs for the CDR and LMP during lunar surface operations will be the individual crew's first names.
Transcription of these tapes was managed by David M. Goldenbaum, Test Division, Apollo Spacecraft Program Office, to whom questions regarding this document should be referred.

Because specialized readers of the Apollo 13 transcription, such as the principal investigators, may not be thoroughly familiar with the acronyms used during the mission, the decision was made to define those acronyms that probably will be encountered. For obvious reasons, no effort was made to include every acronym that conceivably could be used; only those acronyms that are considered likely to be used are included here. [see equipment acronyms list metadata.acronyms.equipment
preamble.fullText:
NATIONAL AERONAUTICS AND SPACE ADMINISTRATION







APOLLO 13

TECHNICAL AIR-TO-GROUND VOICE TRANSCRIPTION






Prepared by Test Division Apollo Spacecraft Program Office






















MANNED SPACECRAFT CENTER
HOUSION,TEXAS April 1970















INTRODUCTION

This is the transcription of the technical air-to-ground (TAG) voice communications of the Apollo 13 mission. The primary communications net (GOSS net l) will be in continuous operation for the duration of the mission. An alternate communications net (GOSS net 2) may be activated when separate, simultaneous communications links with both spacecraft are desired.

The transcript is divided into three columns -- time, speaker, and text. The time column consists of four two-digit pairs for days, hours, minutes, and seconds (e.g., 04 22 45 12). The speaker column indicates the source of a transmission; the text column contains the verbatim transcript of the communications.

The primary communications net (GOSS net l) comprises the bulk of the transcript. However, when GOSS net 2 is activated, the communications on that net will be integrated with the GOSS net 1 communications. A heavy dark line alongside the time column will indicate GOSS net 2 communications.

A series of three dots (...) is used to designate those portions of the text that could not be transcribed because of garbling. A series of three asterisks (***) is used to designate those portions of the text that could not be transcribed because of clipping caused by the VOX mode. One dash (-) is used to indicate a speaker's pause or a self-interruption and subsequent completion of a thought. Two dashes (- -) are used to indicate an interruption by another speaker or the point at which a recording was abruptly terminated.

Speakers in the transcript may be identified as follows.
Spacecraft:
CDR                Commander            James A. (Jim) Lovell, Jr.
CMP                Command module pilot    John L. Swigert, Jr.
LMP                Lunar module pilot    Fred W. Haise, Jr.
SC                Unidentified crewmember
MS                Multiple speakers
Mission Control Centers:
CC                Capsule communicator (CAP COMM)
LCC                Launch Control Center
F                Flight director
S                Surgeon
Remote sites:
AB                Airboss (Recovery aircraft)
CT                Communications technician (COMM TECH)
IWO                USS Iwo Jima
P-l, P-2, etc.            Photographic helicopters
R-l, R-2, etc.            Recovery helicopters

When the CDR and LMP are in the undocked lunar module or on the lunar surface, their speaker designations will be suffixed by either LM or EVA to indicate their status (e.g., CDR-EVA or LMP-LM). Voice calls during this mission were assigned in accordance with the following station operating procedures: For all phases when only the CSM is manned, the AS-508 call sign will be Apollo 13. When both vehicles are manned, the call sign will be Odyssey for the CSM and Aquarius for the LM. The call signs for the CDR and LMP during lunar surface operations will be the individual crew's first names.
Transcription of these tapes was managed by David M. Goldenbaum, Test Division, Apollo Spacecraft Program Office, to whom questions regarding this document should be referred.
ACRONYM LIST

Because specialized readers of the Apollo 13 transcription, such as the principal investigators, may not be thoroughly familiar with the acronyms used during the mission, the decision was made to define those acronyms that probably will be encountered. For obvious reasons, no effort was made to include every acronym that conceivably could be used; only those acronyms that are considered likely to be used are included here.

GDC        Gyro display coupler

LM         Lunar module

LOPC       Lunar orbit plane change
LOS        Loss of signal/line of sight
LPD        Landing point designator
LTC        Lunar topographic camera
MCC        Mission Control Center/midcourse correction
MESA       Modular equipment stowage assembly
MSFN       Manned Space Flight Network
MTVC       Manual thrust vector control
OPS        Oxygen purge system
ORDEAL     Orbital rate display earth and lunar
PDI        Powered descent initiation
PGA        Pressure garment assembly
PGNCS      Primary guidance, navigation, and control system (CM)
PGNS       Primary guidance and navigation system (LM)
PIPA       Pulsed integrating pendulous accelerometer
PLSS       Portable life support system
PRD        Personal radiation dosimeter
PSE        Passive seismic experiment

REFSMMAT   Reference to stable member matrix

SM         Service module

TEC        Transearth coast

transcript.text: The clock is running.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: 13; Roger.

transcript.text: MARK.

transcript.speaker: CDR

transcript.speaker: CDR

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, 13, you are GO for staging.

transcript.speaker: CDR

transcript.speaker: CDR

transcript.speaker: CDR

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Mode II.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Guidance initiate.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. Guidance is good, and the CMC is GO.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Thank you.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: 13; Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. You are GO at 1+ minutes. The little red lines are right on the little white lines down here.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Sounds good.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. Coming up 5 minutes. You're looking perfect. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: 13; Roger.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Inboard.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. We confirm inboard out. capability.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. Stand by for S-IVB to COI capability.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: S-IVB to COI. Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. You've got it now, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: We've got S-IVB to COI.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: You're GO at 6 minutes, 13.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: GO at 6.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And, Houston, what's the story on engine 5?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jim, Houston. We don't have the story on why the inboard out was early , but the other engines are GO and you are GO. 00 00 06 21 CDR Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. Still looking good. Your gimbals are good; trim is good. 00 00 06 45 CDR Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. Level sense arm time 8 plus 38 nominal; S-II cut-off time 9 plus 48. Over. 00 00 07 02 CDR Roger. Nominal on the level sense arm, 9:48 on the S-II cut-off.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative, and stand by for S-IVB to orbit .

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: MARK.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: You have S-IVB to orbit, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger. We have S-IVB to orbit.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. Looking good at 8 minutes. 00 00 08 05 CC 13; Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston. Mark level sense arm.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Mark level sense arm. Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston. At 9 minutes, you are GO; the CMC is GO.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Joe.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: 13; Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. You are GO for staging.

transcript.speaker: CDR

transcript.speaker: CC

transcript.speaker: CDR

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Staging.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And S-IV ignition, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger that, Jim. Thrust looks good.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. You're looking good. Trajectory, guidance , CMC are all GO .

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Thank you, Joe.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Housto. At 11 minutes, you're GO. Predieted cut-off on the S-IVB is 12 plus 34. Over.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston. You're GO at 11-1/2, and predicted cut-off time is 12 plus 34. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: understand; 12 plus 34 predicted cut-off time.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirm.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: SECO.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Copy SECO, Jim. We're looking at the DSKY.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston. You have a GO orbit all sources, and the booster is safe. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: GO orbit and the booster is safe. Thank you, Joe.

transcript.speaker: CC

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. We copy your NOUN 44.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Joe.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston. Your preliminary orbit down here is 102.5 times 100.3, and everything is looking good.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger, Houston. And it looks good to be up here again.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: I'll bet.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. I have your Z torquing angles. You ready?

transcript.speaker: CDR

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. It's plus 0.26. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Joe. Plus 0.26.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Couple minutes to LOS, Jim. Everything is looking real good. Your AOS time at Carnarvon will be 52:36, and we don't have too much of a handle on why the inboard cut off early except that it apparently was an engine problem and not a switch-select function. But we are certain that you'll be able to make TLI based on what we are looking at now.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger. There's nothing like an interesting launch.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That' s right.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston. Canary LOS in 30 seconds. Request COMMAND RESET, please.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger. COMMAND RESET coming on.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Thank you.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston. Request LOW BIT RATE, please. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: LOW BIT RATE.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Houston, how do you read 13?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. Loud and clear.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Joe. Everything's going good. We're proceeding on the time line in good fashion. I've got a P52 done. I can give you the torquing angles.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: I'm ready for them, Jack.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Use NOUN 26; stars 26 and 33. The star angle difference was all balls. NOUN 93: minus 067, minus all balls, plus 0.162. The time of torquing was 45 minutes 35 seconds.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Well, that sounds marginally acceptable.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: For a new CMP, it ain't too bad.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes. Okay, 13. We've got nothing for you at the moment. Everything's looking good. We're looking at your data now.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston. LOS Carnarvon in about 30 seconds. Honeysuckle on the hour, and verify your S-band is up for Honeysuckle. Over.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: That's verified.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And, Houston, we're beginning to see a beautiful sunrise here.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger that , Jim.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston through Honeysuckle.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston through Honeysuckle.

transcript.speaker: CDR

transcript.speaker: CC

transcript.speaker: CC

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR

transcript.speaker: CC

transcript.speaker: CC

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. 13, Houston. LOS Honeysuckle in about 30 seconds, and we'll see you over the States a l plus 28 plus 43.

transcript.speaker: CC

transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston through Guaymas. Over.

transcript.speaker: CC

transcript.speaker: CMP

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Hello there. We thought you were still up there.

transcript.speaker: CMP

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: I don't think we require it just yet, Jack, but we'll command it when we're ready. I believe they are dumping the tape now. The booster looks good. The spacecraft looks good on the few minutes' data we've had.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: That sounds good.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Jim finally let me look out.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: (Laughter) How do you like it?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Chained me to the LEB down there stowing things and unstowing things , and I finally got a chance to look out and see the world.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston. I have the TLI plus 90, and liftoff plus 8 pads whenever you're ready.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Go ahead with the TLl pad, Joe.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. This is the TLI plus 90 pad. SPS/G&N, 63825, minus 1.54, plus 1.32, 004:06:45.53, minus 0491.7, plus 0000.1, plus 6634.0, 180, 228, 001; HA is N/A; HP is plus 0017.9; 6652.2, 7:37, 6626.5, 26, 155.4, 15.7. Boresight star is Zeta Sagittarii; up, 08.0; right, 2.1; minus 22.81, minus 025.00, 1140.7, 34087, 013:32:14. Set stars Arcturus , Denebola; roll 044; pitch 012, yaw 025; no ullage. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. TLI plus 90: SPS/G&N, 63825, minus 1.54. plus 1.32, 004:06:45.53, minus 0491.7, plus 0000.1, plus 6634.0, 1.80, 228, 001; N/A; plus 0017.9, 6652.2, 7:37, 6626.5, 26, 155.4, 15.7; Zeta Sagittarius; up, 08.0; right 2.1; minus 22.81, minus 025.00, 1140.7, 34087, 013:32:14. Set starts: Arcturus, Denebola; roll 044, pitch 012, yaw 025; no ullage. Over.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Fred, Houston. Stand by 1.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Fred, Houston. Over.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's correct. We would like you to go the S-BAND AUX TV switch to TV, please.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. It's set to TV.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We're not getting a signal.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. I'll go to TRANSMIT, Joe.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. You can continue reading back.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Roll 180, pitch 228, yaw 001; N/A; plus 0017.9, 6652.2, 7:37, 6626.5 and 1 missed sextant shaft - trunnion - trunnion, 15.7, Zeta Sagittarius, up, 08.0; roll 2.1; minus 22.81, minus 00 - correctien, minus 025.00, 1140.7, 34087, 013:32:14. Set stars: Arcturus and Denebola; roll aline 044, pitch 012, yaw 025; no ullage.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, Fred. Readback correct. The sextant star is 26, and the shaft is 15.54. Over.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Sextant star 26 and 15.54.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. And we have a picture now; however, it's moving around quite a bit , if you could hold the camera a little steadier. And I have your - - 00 01 38 54 LMP - - Okay, Joe. There's nothing but clouds outside, and when we get some land down there coming up, I'll switch back to the window. I thought I'd just show you Jim here, to make sure he ' s still here .

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay; real fine. We had a good picture of Jim there for a minute. I have the liftoff plus 8 pad, Fred. If you're ready.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Go ahead, Joe.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. GET I , OO8:00; DELTA-VT 7835; longitude, minus 165; GET 400 K, 022:36. Over.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, then. And I have a TLI pad for you.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. I'm ready.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. TLI: 2 plus 26 plus 05, 179, 108, 000, 5 plus 47, lO4l6.9, 35587, 358, l39, 320, 302, 3l9, 040, and ejection time, 4 plus 01 plus 00.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, Fred. Readback correct, and we're getting a nice coder TV picture now. lf you have any commentary to go with it..

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Joe. I'll tell you I'm just trying to figure out where we are here.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's your job, not mine.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: You know, I've just been up out of the LEB for a short time here, and I'm trying to find out which country we're over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I have to keep telling Jack that blue stuff down there is water.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: I'll give you a hint. You're in the western hemisphere .

transcript.text: And you are GO for TLI. Huntsville reperts that you have a 6-second propellant pad which is 3 seconds more than a 3-sigma case; so you're good on consumabies . The IU is so good that we're not going to update it. The only change we have for you is in the TLI checkiist. At 57 minutes where you slew the FDAI to 18 degrees, we recommend 20 degrees there, and we recommend that you look for 8 degrees instead of 6 degrees at ignition. The S_IVB is riding on the top of its deadband.

transcript.text: And, l3, Houston. We'll be commanding the evasive maneuver in about l7 seconds. 00 04 18 4l CMP Okay, Joe. We van see it start to move. However, it doesn't seem to be a lot of debris or vapor coming out of it.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger that, Jack. Booster says that's great. He says the booster's doing its thing normally. Concur. We don't see much on the television at all.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, Apollo 13, Houston. We'd like to change the S-band and antenna configuration. Like you to go OMNI Delta. Like you to go MANUAL mode on the high gain with pitch of minus 60 and yaw of 90. Over.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. You want us to 0MNI Delta and MANUAL on the high gain to minus 60 and plus 90. Is that correct? 00 04 l9 44 CC That's affirmative. 00 04 20 06 CMP Okay, Houston. How much longer would you like the television?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Stand by on that. We'll get a word.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, 13, this is Houston. You can turn the TV off anytime you?re ready. We?ve enjoyed the show.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. Before you secure the TV, we?d like to know whether that was maximum zoom, just for information-

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: That?s affirm. Jim had it in MAX zoom.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Good deal. That was real good picture.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, 13, Houston. The APS evasive maneuver appeared to be nominal. The LOX dump time is now 4 plus 39 plus 20, abot 3 minutes late.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Joe. We are right now opening the WASTE STOWAGE VENT.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. We copy.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Houston. We are charging battery B.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, 13. We see it. Looks good.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo l3, Houston. Request OMNI Alfa now. Over.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo l3, Houston.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Go ahead, Joe.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. They are having trouble verifying that the high gain is doing its thing. Like to verify that the pitch is minus l0, the Y is plus 350, you're in WIDE BEAM WIDTH and AUTO.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Minus l0 pitch, plus 350 yaw, and WIDE BEAM WIDTH and going into AUT0. You want HIGH GAIN, Joe?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirm.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Here, it's coming at you.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: All right, Houston; 13.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Is the S-IVB doing something different now?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Well, I don't know. It should be - let's see, it should have started the LOX dump at least quite a while ago. I guess that's complete. Why do you ask, Fred?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: I'm looking out window 5 at what I think is the S-IVB, and I'm seeing what looks to be double plumes, going in two very narrow bands maybe about 3 degrees that are streaming out from it. And then there is a less dense band that covers maybe a 40-degree swath through the sky that continues out, also, in two directions.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Hey, Joe, what it looks like, kind of, is if you pull up behind a guy that's pulling a contrail, and you get in his contrail, like he's going away from you - there's a long contrail -

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay; stand by. Let me see what Frank's got to say about that.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Except we're between - Looks like we're between two contrails, one guy above and one below.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: It's a very pretty sight.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, 13; Houston. The booster says that the propulsive dump is concluded; he now has the nonpropulsive vents open and what you see is a normal phenomenon and it should go oh for another 5 minutes or so.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, while I've got you, 13, at your convenience, we'd like to have the results of the EMS bias tests that you did pre-TLI and pre-SEP.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Stand by.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Joe. The TLI - the DELTA-V no bias test prior to TLI, we had a O.8, and post-TLI, it was 1.0.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jack, Copy that. Thank you very much. Incidentally, as your tracking gets better and better, the size of MCC-2 is getting lower and lower and figures to be somewhere between 20 and 30 feet per second now.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Sounds good.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes, sure does.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Go ahead, Joe.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We have a PTC REFSMMAT ready, if you're ready to go POO and ACCEPT, we'll stick it in there.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Stand by.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. I'm P00 and ACCEPT, Joe.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Roger that.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston. We'll have a handover in half a minute or so. You may get a momentary loss of strength.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Joe.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston. The computer is yours. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Going to BLOCK.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Houston. Do you copy 13's torquing angles on the P52?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. Leave them up just a second, and we'll get them down.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. Okay. We got them.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. The time of torquing was 5 hours 30 minutes and 40 seconds.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. We copy.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Hello, Houston; Apollo 13.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. I just got all hooked up to get in my COMM system here, and I just wanted to check out. I've got my suit stowed, a few other odds and ends done, and I'm back in business again.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Good deal. We're kind of hanging loose down here. I've got a lift-off plus 15 pad. There's no hurry to read it up, so let us know when you're ready.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Houston. Go ahead with the pad.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. Lift-off plus 15 pad: GETI 015:00, DELTA-VT 5622, longitude minus 165, and GET 400K 047:04. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Houston. Lift-off plus 15: GETI 015:00, 5622, minus 165, 047:04. Is that correct?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's right, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Go ahead, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. We'd like to have the ATTITUDE SET switch back to GDC, if you're finished with your aline. It gives G&C down here a telemetry problem.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Yes; okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Thank you.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: I'm just going to give them one more aline here.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. No rush.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Would you please verify or tell us what S-band antenna configuration you're in, please?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Stand by.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: We're in HIGH GAIN.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Stand by a minute, Jim. Our signal strength is getting a little low. We may have a recommendation.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. Are you in MANUAL or AUTO in HIGH GAIN?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Stand by. We're in AUTO TRACK, Joe, and HIGH GAIN.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Houston, you copy 13?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Hello, Houston; Apollo 13. Over.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Hey, were you copying my P23 results?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative, Jack. We followed you through the whole thing. You're ahead of schedule.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And, Joe, we confirmed there is no midcourse-1. Over.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That is affirmative as far as I know. Let's get a final check on it, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Because we're standing by. We want to do a fuel cell purge and a waste water dump.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. We confirm there will be no midcourse-l.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. It sounds good.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, 13, Houston. You can go ahead with the purge and dump at your discretion.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger, Houston. What we're going to do is, we're going to get rid of Fred's suit here. Fred's suit has been right in the commander's slot here for the last half hour. So we're going to try and get it stowed.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: You did a pretty good job.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston. We'll have a handover in about 1 minute.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Hello, Houston. Apollo 13.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, Jim. We'll have a handover from Hawaii to Goldstone in about 30 seconds.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Say again, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We'll be handing over from Hawaii to Goldstone in a few seconds. You may get a temporary loss of COMM.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Houston. We've got a whole bunch of noise, too.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Houston, 13.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Hey, Joe. Do you want to dump waste water down to 25 percent. Is that right?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirm.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, in work.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Do you know we're also purging fuel cells O2 now.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jack.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Houston. The fuel cell purge and waste water dump are complete.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, Apollo 13. And this is your relief CAP COMM shift on now.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Well, good evening, Vance.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Boy, you sure made it back fast.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes. You guys had a beautiful launch, there. Really nice.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Could you follow it all the way up, Vance?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: No, I didn't see staging. It was too hazy for that, but we could see it for a few miles anyway.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: I'll tell you, it's sure an interesting ride.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Right.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Apollo 13.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Go ahead, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger. We're at that stage now where we're going to take some Earth weather photography. If you're standing by, I have the camera aimed at the Earth right now, and I'll give you a mark when I take this first picture.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. We copy, Jim. We'll be standing by for the mark.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Houston. 3, 2, 1 -

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: MARK.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, copy.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And Apollo 13, Houston. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: For the PTC recommend that you disable quads A and B. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Disable quads A and B, will do; and soon as Jack gets finished thrashing around, we'll be going to that PTC mode.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Houston. We're starting PTC. We're disabling quads A and B now.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, Apollo 13. Houston copies.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jim, we'd like to verify that the high gain is secured, that the S-BAND antenna is on OMNI, and OMNI B should be the right antenna. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. You want the high gain secured and you want the OMNI on OMNI Charlie, huh? Or Baker?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirm. And this'll be maintained in the PTC.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And the high gain angles for stowage - or for stowing - are pitch minus 52, yaw 270.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Apollo 13.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Stand by for another Earth weather picture. I'll give you a mark.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Standing by, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: MARK.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Houston copies.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Houston here. Your rates look very stable. It looks like your rates are damped out completely here. As far as we can see, it would be alright to start the PTC.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. We'll give it a try.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Hello, Houston. This is 13. How do you read?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Hello, 13; Houston. Loud and clear. 13, Houston is reading loud and clear. How do you read?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. And do you have any estimate, Vance, on how long we'll be charging battery B?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Stand by 1, Fred.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We'll be charging for 4-1/2 to 5 hours yet, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Fred, recommend that, when your window comes around facing the Earth again, that you catch another one of those pictures, and at the same time, you should probably start PTC again. We might have sent a confusing bit of info up to you. The "disable two quads" only applies to an early step in the procedure. We didn't mean that for the latter part of the procedure where we have the statement "enable all jets." Over.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Houston, Apollo 13.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Vance, Fred said that you had some more informa- tion about PTC and a different way of establishing it or something, huh?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, Referring to the procedure on G/8-2, if you have that open, I'll tell you what we had to give you.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Stand by and I'll get it out.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Go ahead. Van.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. On checklist G/8-2 under Step 5, there's a statement, "disable all jets on two adjacent quads," and that's what we were referring to when we called up saying "disable quads A and B." So that's all fine; however, going down now to step 7 where it says "enable all jets," we hoped that you didn't think we meant leave A and B disabled there. In that case, it's as written. All jets should be enabled. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Our checklist has "all jets" scratched out, and it says "enable couples on all axes." So what we'll do is - we'll reestablish this thing and come down to that step 7, and we'll enable all jets. That means enable quads A and B. Is that right?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirm. You'll have A, B, C, and D enabled for step 7.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, real fine. I'll start on it now.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Understand you're going to reestablish it.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: And Vance, on that picture, I was all set to shoot it just a little before you called, and the Earth hasn't showed up in the window yet. I don't know if we got too far off the bellyband or what.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Copy, Fred.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Go ahead, Vance.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. On the photo, you'll probably have to reestablish the attitude for PTC and then when- ever it comes into the window again, why we'll just be standing by for the photo.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Go ahead, ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. You're coming in a little weak. Have a recommended roll rate for this PTC, if you could copy.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Alright. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Recommend that you put in Rl the following: 03750, and that should give you exactly a rate of 0.3 degrees per second. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Enter 03750. Is plus or minus our choice?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. The same direction you rolled the last time, which I believe is plus.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Hey, Vance, would you monitor our rates and kind of give an idea of when you think they're stable enough to start PTC.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, Jack. We'll take a look and let you know as soon as they look stable enough.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. I've got quads A and B disabled here.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Have they come up with an idea of how much fuel I used on the docking and also the P23 session at 5 hours or 6 hours.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: I think we can give you something. Stand by a minute.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. It's looking good so far as RCS consum- ables are concerned, Jack. You're standing about 20 pounds above the curve right now. Looking at the TD&E, you expended 65 pounds or - Stand by - 55 pounds, correction on that.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: How much?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And 14 pounds on P23s. You used a little more out of quad A than out of the others.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Thanks, Vance.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Hey, could you say again the TDB&E fuel? We've got a different - we all heard different things.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: I said 65 and then corrected that t0 55 pounds.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. Your rates look good. It's okay to start the roll again, if you'd like. 00 08 31 50 CDR

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Hello, Houston; Apollo 13.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, go ahead.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Ready for a little count here, Vance, and I'll shoot another picture. We found the Earth again.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We'll be standing by, Fred.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: MARK.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Copy.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Hey, Houston, 13.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Stand by for a mark on another picture.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Standing by, Fred.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: MARK.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, we got it.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jim, Houston here. Two items: first of all, your PTC is looking very good and it should carry you through the night; second point , have a procedure to give you, if you're ready to copy. We'd like to set three bits in the computer, and I'll explain why.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Go ahead, Vance, we're ready to copy.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, The procedure is as follows: VERB 25, NOUN 07, ENTER; 1331, ENTER; 7, ENTER; and ENTER. Explanation as follows. During the P23s, there was one time when VERB 37 was entered into the computer at about 16 seconds after the OPTICS ZERO switch was flicked to ZERO. This is a very uncommon anomaly in that, if you do this during - 0.4-second interval at around 16 seconds after you zero the optics, some OPT-mode bits are reset; and this would mean that, if you had a 0CDU fail, it wouldn't be indicated; so all this procedure is doing is setting these three bits back again where they should be.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Vance, and I guess I'll try to be slower on that VERB 37.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes. Actually slower or faster, either one, I guess. Well, yes, slower. It's a very unusual thing to have that happen.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. And, Houston, stand by for a mark on another picture.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Standing by.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: MARK it.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. We copy, Fred.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Vance; we've completed that procedure, and let me know if everything was okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, thank you. We'll let you know if anything isn't okay. I'm sure it's good now.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Tell G&C and GUIDO thanks a lot for keeping good track of me, there.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. They're right on the ball.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, 13, Houston. If you would like, we can let you know about every 2 minutes before the Earth should be coming into your window. We think we've got it pegged down pretty well now, and you won't have to look for it so much. You want that?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes. That would be fine, Vance.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, 13, Houston. GUIDO says the bits are reset - rather, are set.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, thanks much.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: It's time for Fred to start looking for the Earth, should be coming by in about a couple of minutes.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. He's got his head out there right now.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes. You've got that pretty well pegged, man. There it be.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Doesn't that give you confidence?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes. I guess so. In a minute, you're going to hear my kitchen timer ding, and that also says the Earth is there.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Stand ... countdown.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: MARK.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. We copy.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. We're enjoying Fred's music there.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Yes, ... up here.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes, I kind of like it too, Vance.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes, we didn't hear much of it, though.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Houston, Apollo 13.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Vance, we did another EMS null bias test and the - it went from 100.0 to 101.8 in 100 seconds.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. We copy.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Go ahead, Vance.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jack, like to verify, was that 100 to 100.8 or 101.8?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: It was plus 100 to plus 101.8.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: The Earth's coming up in the window again in 1 to 2 minutes.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: He's got it. You're right again.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, stand by for a mark here. ? I

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, ready? 3, 2, 1 -

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: MARK.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, copy your mark.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston. We have a CSM state vector to send you. Request P00 and ACCEPT at your convenience.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Vance. There's P00 and ACCEPT.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, it,s coming up.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, the comPuter is yours again.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, going back to BLOCK.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Looks like picture-taking time again.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Go ahead, Van.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Earth should be coming into view.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. I got it.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. stand Vance. 3, 2, 1 -

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: MARK.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. We got it.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Earth starting to look pretty small now?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Well, looking at here, Vance, it's hard to be convinced it's even the Earth. All we see is water and clouds.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Well, I guess that's what we want. We want pictures of weather, right , clouds.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Yes, about half of it's covered with clouds.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Hello, Houston. Houston, Apollo 13. Over.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Good morning, 13. This is Houston- How are you?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Read you loud and clear. We had a fairly good night's sleep.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Real fine. At your leisure, you can give us radiation reports, I guess. We are getting a consumables update together for you, and a few other little details whenever you are ready to talk. About the only major thing on the spacecraft is that it's been getting farther away.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Well, that's to be expected, I guess.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: And we're starting to charge battery A, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger on battery A, Fred. EECOMM says battery B looks real good.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, 13.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. For information, Fred was on C0MM last night; and he was over in the left-hand seat, and if you want our radiation readings, we just goofed. We left them all in the suits which are now nicely tucked away. We are going to get out Jack's suit in an hour or so anyway, and we'll get his dosimeter out if you wanted to get the reading on that one.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. That will be satisfactory.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And in exchange for that, the surgeon would like to have a rough number of hours each of you slept and a qualitative verb to describe whether it was good, fair, or poor.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Stand by.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Houston. We had an average of around 5 or ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jim, Houston. Your COMM got pretty garbled there just as you started to talk.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Houston, Apollo 13.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, 13. You're loud and clear again.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: We averaged about 5-1/2 hours' sleep apiece, and we are estimating that the sleep was good.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Copy that. Let's see what else we have for you, Jim. Midcourse-2 looks like about 23 feet per second, approximately retrograde and on time. And it's holding real firm now. For your information, and you don't need to copy this down, because it's still pretty soft, but ve have an S-IVB impact of about 8.57 south and about 33.9 west, which is a little west and a little south of the flight plan value. We have it at a GET of about 77 plus 51 which is just before AOS, and the L0I pads are a little bit late, and as I say, it's still pretty soft, and we'll be updating you with firm numbers.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: That's fine, Joe. Just as long as it doesn't hit Cone Crater.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, And I'll have a consumables update for you in a little while, and I have a small flight plan update for you sometime a little later on when you're ready to copy. There's no big deals in it.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, 13, Houston. We'd like to verify that you cycled the 02 cryo fans. We saw the H2, but we didn't see the 02 get stirred up.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Yes, Joe. We did, and it kind of looked like we might have had a little stratification because right after we put them on, we had a CRYO PRESS light.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. EECOMM told me that might happen, and he was right.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Joe. We're ready to copy a flight plan update and your consumables.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. The flight plan update has a couple of items in it, and the first one we'd like to do is to update the Tephem values in the G&c check- ephem list on page G/9-2. These are fairly small changes, but in case you need them, we'd like you to have the exact numbers. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Just a minute. I'll get it out.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Joe, was that the G&C checklist, page 9-2?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative. G&C, page G/9-2.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. On that page in line 04, column B, change the number from 03366 to 05253. Over.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. And in line 05, column B, change from 11000 to 33661. Over.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. That's right. The only other thing I've got for you. Jack, is three additional questions for the booster systems debriefing, which is to take place at about 25 hours, and we thought we'd pass these questions up to you early so you can consider them. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. We're ready to copy.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. The first extra is, and let me get the original question because this question says, "More specifically on item 2," and item 2 says, "Were there any significant changes in the noise vibration level during the single stage of powered flight?" Specifically, describe your observations during the early S-II center engine cut-off, and approximately 90 seconds prior to TLI cut-off, you reported a high vibration in the S-IVB. We'd like you to describe the buildup of this vibration and its behavior through cutoff. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Essentially, what you'd like us to talk about is vibration sequence during the early S-II cut-off of the center engine and also describe the vibrations that we encountered during the S-IVB TLI burn. Is that correct?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's it. Okay. The second extra question is for you, Jim, and it says, "Comparing this flight with your ride on Apollo 8, were there any significant differences in the powered flight environment?"

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. We'll describe a comparison with 8 and 13 as far as powered flight goes.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. And the last additional question is what did the ORDEAL ball look like during TLI? As you know, we passed you an update to that setting, and we'd like to know whether it was riding right on zero or what during the burn. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Will do. We'll describe the 0RDEAL ball.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. That's it, and that's the whole flight plan update. I have a consumables update now if you want to'listen to that.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Joe. We're ready to copy.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. At 23 hours the total RCS is 1121, quad A is 274, quad Bravo is 286, quad Charlie is 274, quad Delta is 237, and the cryos are as follows: H2 tank 1, 83 percent; H2 tank 2, 86 percent; 02 tank 1, 87 percent; 02 tank 2, 87 percent. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Joe. We got all those, and hol do we compare them with where we should be in the time line?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: As I understand it. Jack, you're running slightly ahead of nominal in both those areas.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay; real fine.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: No problem.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, 13, Houston. That's all the business I got right now. I have a little news and plan of the day for you, if you feel like listening to that a little later on.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Just hold off a little bit there, Joe, if you don't mind.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Stand by one, Jim. You're coming in garbled again.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Houston, 13.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, 13; Houston. Loud and clear again. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Joe. On the news, Jim would like to hold off a little bit on that, and I want to make a request to FAO, if he will at sometime during the day, when we get a flight plan update with those activities we agreed to make optional during lunar orbit and the few activities we were going to delete, I think that I forgot and left that card back during the press of suiting, I left it in the suit room.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Wilco.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. I understand FAO's working on that and we'll have something for you later on.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. We're not in any hurry.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Houston; 13.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Jack. We copy the angles. You can go ahead and torque them.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Joe. The time of torquing will be 23 hours 47 minutes 30 seconds.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We copy.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, 13.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: For information, Joe, we're all configured back again now to our regular seating positions, if you're monitoring us.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Thank you, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Hello there, Houston; 13.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: l3, Houston. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Gosh, we had forgotten, but we'd like to hear what the news is.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. There's not a whole lot to it. Well, let's see, we'll start with the - Let's start with sports, what the heck. The Astros survived 8 to 7, the Braves got five or six runs in the - five runs in the ninth inning, but they just made it; and in the other important game of the day, the Cubs were rained out. I have all the rest of the scores, you can tell me if you want any of them. They had earthquakes in Manila and other areas of the island of Luzon. There were three tremors and they kept the buildings shaking for about a half an hour or so, and it was about a 5 on the Richter scale. Okay, let's see. The Beatles have an- nounced they will no longer perform as a group. The quartet is reported to have made in excess of a half billion dollars during their short musical career. However, rumors that they will use this money to start their own space program are false.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Maybe we could borrow some.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: (Laughter) Okay. Okay; West German Chancellor Willy Brandt, who witnessed your launch from the Cape yesterday, and President Nixon will complete their round of talks today. Brandt reportedly came to the U.S. to seek assurance from the President to go ahead with talks with the eastern European nations, especially East Germany, Poland, and Russia. Many air traffic controllers are Still out, but reports indicate that they are slowly returning to work, and you'll be happy to know the controllers here in the MOOR are still on the job.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I said thank goodness for that.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Some truck lines are being struck in the Midwest, and the school teachers have walked off the job in Minneapolis. Today's favorite pasttime across the - Uh oh; have you guys completed your income tax?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: How do I apply for an extension?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: (Laughter)

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Yes, Joe. I got to - hey, listen - It ain't too funny; things kind of happened real fast down there, and I do need an extension.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: (Laughter)

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: I didn't get mine filed. And this is serious; would you - -

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: You're breaking up the room down here.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: - - because I may be spending time in a - -

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We'll see - -

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: I may be spending time in a - I may be spending time in another quarantine besides the one that they are planning for me.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We'll see what we can do, Jack. We'll get with Recovery and see if we can get the agent out there in the Pacific when you come back. By golly, let's see. In professional basketball, the Nicks beat the Milwaukee Bucks 110 to 102, and Billy Casper is leading the Masters after 54 holes with a 208, and spring football practice is in full swing. And that's about all the news we got; the updated plan of the day for you guys, the uniform will be service dress inflight coverall garments with swords and medals, and tonight's movie shown in the lower equipment bay will be John Wayne, Lou Costello, and Shirley Temple in the "The Flight of Apollo 13." Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Outstanding.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, this is 13. Is it true that Jack's income tax return was going to be used to buy the ascent fuel for the LM?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Well, considering that he's a bachelor and hasn't got that deduction to take, yes.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Hey, Joe. I'm glad you brought that up, because I was really serious about that.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. We'll - We'll take care of it. Tom Stafford says he'll get an extension for you.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And Jim McDivitt says, "yes, now that you mention it, he forgot to fill the ascent stage."

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: (Laughter) Suspicions confirmed.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Should give you very good performance on descent.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: We should have a lot more hover time, huh?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's right.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, crew. About the only other thing I've got for you right now is an update to your P37 pad for lift-off plus 35. This is a change to the pad we gave you yesterday. The reason for the update is for weather avoidance in the mid-Pacific landing area at 70 hours, which is the return time for this pad, and in case the question arises in your mind, we don't expect any problem there for the end of the mission. The weather area is 20 degrees south of your end-of-mission landing point, and it appears to be moving to the south.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Joe. I'm ready to copy the pad.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. GET of ignition is 035:00, DELTA-VT 7883, Longitude minus 155, and the GET 400K 069:54. Over.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And, Houston, Jack's going to try donning his suit now for practice, himself, and when he gets it out, we'll give you a dosimeter reading.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Real good.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Apollo 13.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. Go.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. We've retrieved Jack's dosimeter, and it's reading 02022.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We copy 02022 on the dosimeter, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: That's affirm.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. At your convenience, we'd like the LM/CM DELTA-P reading.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: That reading is 0.65 psi.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Copy 0.65. Thank you.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Apol ... Roger. We're thinking together. And we're here waiting for your call.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, you were a little broken up there, Jim, hut I think it's getting better. We are ready for the launch-vehicle-systems debriefing whenever you are.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Houston; Apollo 13. You were cut out again; say again, please.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, Jim. We are ready for the launch-vehicle- systems debriefing whenever you are. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Stand by 1.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Houston; 13. In answer to question 1, the changes in noise level occurred mainly between the first stags and the other stages - the other stages were about the same in noise level, very quiet, with the first stage, of course, making quite a bit of noise in the beginning but - which built up during the high Q, and then ... went quiet just after high Q.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, copy that, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I might mention that the noise level during the first stage was not sufficient to be uncomfortable at all.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. And I assume COMM was okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: That's affirm. COMM was very good all during - throughout the entire flight. Much better than I expected.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Now, in answer to question 2, there was, of course, a vibration transient in the second stage that - due to the number 5 engine going out - which occurred shortly before the engine went out, and slightly after that then the S-II stage was very smooth.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. I guess the significant point there is that you didn't notice the vibration before you saw the engine light.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: That's right. We - we noticed the vibration but it wasn't such that we thought something cata- strophic was going to happen; it just started vibration and then the EN light came on, and then the vibration went away and the stage itself was smooth.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, copy that.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Yes, and that - it was all pretty - pretty short in span - just a second or so before and like a second afterwards, Joe.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Oh. Roger.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And on the S-IVB, the vibration of the vehicle itself wasn't what ... second ... powered flight - a very-high-frequency vibration.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That was - was that during - just during TLI , or did you notice that at insertion?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Well, it was a high-frequency viola - vibration but more noticeable during the TLI burn than it was during the ... flight.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, I - understand.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: I guess the S-IVB vibration during TLI was there all the time although it seemed to - to grow to us as the burn progressed, although that may have been just due to the boost weight decrease.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, you called this about 3-1/2 minutes, but I guess the thing was slowly building up throughout the whole burn. Right?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: That's right.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, was it uncomfortable or did it cause your vision to degrade or anything like that?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: No, it - it was not uncomfortable at all but I was recalling the ride on 8, and the S-IVB was more - much more smooth than even it was on 13.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Copy that.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, now, in answer to number 3, we did not ex- perience any unexpected transients except that all of us noticed the PU shift. We thought it was more pronounced than we had expected it to be.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Understand.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Joe, on that. I guess most of every time that PU shift occurred we all - almost all of us glanced at the engine light. We could feel definite acceleration change.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Understand, Jack.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And, during the high-Q portion of the flight, the Alfa meter, to my knowledge, nearly went above 25 percent.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: In answer to number 4, we got a pretty good look at the thermal shroud and the IU after taking the LM away, and from our viewpoint, the shroud was completely intact. I saw no loose particles or parts of it floating at all.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. Understand.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And, I guess we answered number 5. I don't think at any time did we have any communication problem during powered flight.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: In answer to number 6, the answer is essentially no. We saw no venting or suspected leak on the LM or the CSM ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. I guess you described to us the non- propulsive venting on the S-IVB after the APS maneuver and we copied that at the time.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Fred saw the S-IVB venting.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes, we had already talked about that, Joe. And that was also visible when it - of course, when it did its evasive maneuver when we were looking at it right close up.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Joe. The last time we saw the S-IVB posi- tively was when Fred saw it venting at about - at about 5 hours. We think we might have picked it up later on. We saw a particle or something out there that was tumbling which might have been the booster or one of the SLA panels.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And when was that, Jim?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: We're - we're debating. It was somewhere between - say 7:30 and 9 hours.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: But, Joe, assuming the S-IVB is still stable. The object I was looking at was definitely tumbling.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Fred. As I recall, it was stable then, although it's tumbling now.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. It probably was the SLA panel I picked up.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Right. Incidentally, I guess the guys in building 6 - -

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Oh and I think we -

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I -I think we answer to number 9. We - at around 5:32, I think, was when we think the number 5 light came on in the S-II, and a definite vibration which was more than just a high-frequency vibration we got with the normal S-IV burn, and then the light came on. I called ECO thinking from the training that it was 7:42 and looked up at the time and realized it was early. And then, soon after the light came on, the vibration stopped and the engine or the booster smoothed down. It was very smooth from there on.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. This may be a stupid question, but do you have any idea what the frequency of it was?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Only to say that it was much higher - I couldn't really guess, now. It was rather a rapid longi- tudinal vibration.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. Stand by now for a minute, we're going to switch OMNI.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, 13, ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. 1 read you. We still have quite a bit of noise on the loop.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I'll stand by. Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. It should be pretty good now. We copied you answering question number 9.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Do you want any more comments on the S-IVB vibrations?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: I don't think so. When you get all done, I'll - I'll make a quick check to see if the booster people have any - any additional questions. You skipped number 8, Jim; could you go back to that for a second?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, stand by.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Our only comment there, Joe, was that the burn on TLI, to our knowledge, was about 3-3/4 second longer than had been predicted and that was the only thing that we really noticed; otherwise, looked like PI [?] was nominal at cut-off.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, understand.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, on comparing the flight of 13 to Apollo 8, lift-off was about the same amount of vibration as I noticed on 8, but at the beginning of the flight, there was less of the sideways motion than we experienced on Apollo 8. The S-IC separa- tion felt more violent on 13 than it did on 8, maybe that's because I was in a different seat, I don't know. But there was about three sharp transients of the cut-off and a couple of big bangs where we were thrown backwards longitudinally on our straps before the S-II went off. And the S-II was, of course, just as smooth on 13 as 8 except for the number 5 engine. And we did not experience the vibration that we experienced on 8 towards the end of the S-II burn. And the S-IVB was - had more vibration than we had on 8.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim, got all that.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: The up - the update on the ORDEAL ball was a good one. At the burn, we were about - just about 8 degrees. We had to pitch down. The yaw was right on all the way through the entire burn, and just towards the end of the burn, the ball started going black in pitch a little bit.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, sounds good, we'll give Mike Wash a gold star on that one. Okay, Jim, stand by 1 while I see if we have any extra questions.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jim, while we're waiting to see if they have any more questions, I'd like to read you the booster people's preliminary analysis on the - the S-II cut-off. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: That would be very interesting. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, preliminary analysis of the data indicates that the center S-II engine vibrated at a some- what higher amplitude than we've seen on previous flights, and it started at about 160 seconds into the S-II burn. As a result of these vibrations, the engine chamber pressure decreased to the level where the two low-level thrust sensors, the thrust- okay sensors, initiated center engine cut-off. Early evaluation of data indicates that no damage occurred to the engine, and the cause of the increased vibration amplitude is still under investigation. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I thought it was the center engine.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes, right.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Joe, do you have any word on what marks we had for TLI?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: At the time of TLI, as I recall, you had 6 seconds longer than the nominal burn which was 3 seconds longer than the 3-sigma low burn, and you were also GO for a second-opportunity TLI if we had re- quired one.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, we were just wondering because it appeared to us that we had a longer TLI burn than had been predicted.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes, you did. We confirmed that - that - that cut-off time just about as you saw it, and I don't have an explanation for it, but it was within the 3-sigma margin.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, we have no further questions. All the answers were clear and satisfactory, and we thank you very much. You can press on with the rest of your busy day.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Right-o.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: And, Houston; 13.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Joe. Out window 5, I just picked up the tumbling object again so, for sure, it must have been a SLA panel. I don't think we could still be in the proximity of the S-IV at this time.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: I don't think so, Fred. It's several hundred miles aft of you. 700 miles is - is the number, I'm told. And since the SLA panel didn't make the midcourse correction, that might be it.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes, it's, I can't really tell for sure even through the monocular that it is, but it looks the same relative position to the stars. And the best I can tell about the same intensity and still about the same distance from us.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Can you see it tumbling. Does it have a shape, or is it a point?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: No. I can tell it's tumbling; I guess the flat side not only is facing me, it's not only much brighter, it also grows larger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Very interesting. We'll see if we can figure out where that's relative to you. They keep updating the S-IV impact on us a little bit.
