The last guess we had was that it will impact about the same longitude we gave you but close to zero latitude and a little bit later. You still won't be able to see it. And they're saying it might make a - -

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: - - they're saying it might make a 100 to 120 foot crater, too.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: It'll still be past the terminator for us for awhile.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Right. It will be at about the REV 20 terminator, so it will be late in your lunar orbit activities before you will be able to photograph it, and FAO is looking at whether we can work that in or not.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Houston, 13.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Hey, Joe? Is FAO ready to - do you - or are you ready to give me those items that we made optional and deleted in the solo book?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jack, we are not quite ready with that yet, but we will be before too long. Can you wait awhile?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Sure can. Got lots of time.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Hello, Houston; Apollo 13.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13? Houston. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Just a passing comment, Joe. We're having lunch right now, and I just made myself a hotdog sandwich with catsup. Very tasty and almost unheard of in the old days.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's correct, 13. As I recall the flight plan, you're supposed to put mustard on the hot dogs and not catsup, but I guess we'll overlook that.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: We blew it.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Right. How's everything going?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: It's going pretty good. We have about four dif- ferent methods of spreading catsup, right now.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Jack, we'll have your update to you before too long.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Fine, Joe. We did a pit check on the Hycon camera and everything works okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Beautiful. We don't have anything else for you at the moment.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Houston, 13.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. We'd like to get the FM up now to look at some inside pictures there.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Stand by and I'll get a GO on this.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's acceptable, Fred, and meanwhile, when you guys are ready to copy, we've got an MCC-2 pad for you.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Standby 1.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger that. And also if you can go to POO and ACCEPT conveniently, we'd like to uplink.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. You've got it.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Joe. You can go ahead with the P30 pad.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Here we go. MCC-2, SPS/G&N: 63634; plus 0.96, minus 0.23; 030:40:49.00; minus 0021.7, minus 0001.7, minus 0008.0; 080, 164 326; N/A N/A; 0023.2, 0:03.5 - We'll give you half'a second on the burn time because it's so short - 0018.5; 44, 135.9, 28.1; and the rest is N/A. Comments: set stars 31 and 23; roll aline 288 pitch 205, yaw 034; no ullage, LM weight 33499! and over.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. MCC-2, SPS/G&N: 63634; plus 0.96 minus 0.23, 030:40:49.00; minus 0021.7, minus 0001.7, minus 0008.0; 080, 164, 326; N/A N/A; 0023.2, burn time 0:03.5, 0018.5; 44, 135.9, 28.1; and the rest N/A. Set stars 31, 23; roll aline 288, pitch 205, yaw 034; no ullage, LM weight 33499.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Readback correct. I have two more short comments on them, but I want to wait just a second and make sure I understand them before I pass them to you.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Fred; Houston.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: The two additional comments were just that, first of all, they biased DELTA-Vc by minus 0.34 feet per second based on your EMS null bias checks. That's just for information. And the second one also for information is that your targeted pericynthion is 60 miles after this correction.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, understand. For Jack's information the EMS DELTA-V bias is 3.4, and our targeted pericynthion after this maneuver is 60 miles.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's correct on the pericynthion. The EMS bias is 0.34, very small.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. 0.34 on the EMS DELTA-V bias.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. And--

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Hey, Joe, we'll give - -

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead, Jack - -

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: We'll give you - we'll give you the read - we'll give you the results of another null bias test for comparative purposes right before the - oh, at the proper time.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Real fine; and the computer is yours.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Thank you. Going BLOCK.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Houston; 13. Are you copying the torquing angles on the P52?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. Give us a second.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, 13, Houston. We have them. You can torque them.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Joe. Time of torquing 29 hours 0 minute 30 seconds.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger that.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Go ahead, Joe.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Hey, you've got a new CAPCOM on now with the Black Crew, and we have about three items to give you. Jack.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Stand by 1. Are these updates or what?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: I'm going to give you some high gain antenna angles for TV and the rest is just information, general words.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Burn attitude for TV, your pitch and yaw angles are as follows: PITCH minus l - minus 69 YAW 180, HIGH GAIN.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Second point is that you're GO for MCC-2 Everything's looking good here.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Real fine.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And the last item's for Jack. Jack, the preliminary indications are that you can get a 60-day extension on your - filing your income tax if you're out of the country.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: That's good news. I guess I qualify.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes, we were just looking at the map, and you're south of Florida so you're not in the country now. But we wondered how about your car tags. Have you taken care of those?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Yes, I did, as a matter of fact. I think I did!

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Known as, "plan ahead."

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Good.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, Apollo 13, Houston. Recommend OMNI Alfa until you get to the burn attitude.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Oay. OMNI Alfa.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Houston; Apollo 13.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Vance. The EMS DELTA-V pass passive, the results of the no-bias pass in 100 seconds, have been from 100 to 101.5.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Copy plus 100 to plus 101.5, and that agrees fairly closely with the last one, as I recall.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Fine.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Houston. We're at P40 burn attitude. Jim is on the sextant star check, and we do have a star in the sextant.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, Jack. Copy. Very good.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: But we could't tell you whether it's 44 or not.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Whoops.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Houston; 13. We're a little bit ahead of ourselves. Do we have a GO to do the fuel cell purge and the waste water dump?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jack, that's affirm. You have a GO for those.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. We're on our way.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jim, battery A is charged now. Whenever you want to unhook it will be fine with us.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Houston, 13. Are you still planning to have TV at the scheduled time?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, 13; Houston. That's affirm. At the flight- plan-scheduled time.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. All right. We've got a beautiful sight we want to show you.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Right.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. You can go ahead with the TV now- We're standing by.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Here it comes.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Jack. It's coming in, and it's right in the center of our screen.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Vance.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Can you - Think you could guess what that might be, Vance? Better than Charlie?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: I don't want to start flipping coins at this point.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Vance. We're pointed just a little ways off from looking directly at the Moon. Jim is holding the camera through window 3. The Sun is coming at about 40 degrees off our left side, and what we are going to show you in just a minute is about 30 seconds of waste water dump and just show you just what it looks like. It's really fantastic.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We'd like to see that.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We saw some droplets speeding out for a little while, Jack. Now we don't see anything.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Actually, Vance, what you're looking at is solid water droplets coming out just about all the time. It lights up the whole sky around the Moon. It's just far too fine for you to see. Now I think they're coming out a little thicker.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Yes, we see those.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Jack's complaining about seeing stars.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: FIDO says he can understand why that would perturbate a trajectory now.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: It's amazing watching these little frozen droplets maneuver. They seem to go in all directions, but finally after they get out a certain ways, settle down and they all seem to be traveling in the same direction.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Right. That's coming in real well.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: The objects in the foreground are parts of the LM that you're looking at.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: The camera is now going to ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We can just barely see those parts of the LM. They must be in a shadow.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Now you are looking at a thruster quad at the lower part of your screen.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: I've got the f-stop all the way open now, Vance; that' s quad - quad 1 you' re looking at with the LM should - The Moon should be in view just over the top of the quad.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Right. We see the nozzle of the quad, but it's dark and it's not easy to see.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. INCO suggests you try AVERAGE if you're in PEAK to see if that gives us a better picture.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. We're in AVERAGE now.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: I think that helps out. We can see it better.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Now, 13, request you either move it away from the bright area or else move it back to PEAK. Over.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Vance. I cranked the focus down a little bit. Is the quad coming in any better now?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: It's coming in about the same, Fred, and you're a little weak now on the COMM.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We could see when you went back to PEAK.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: And I'm now ... all the way out.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We could see you zoom in on the Moon, and it's near the center of our screen, just a little to the left. Very clear.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes. I show it just about at 38.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We can't tell if it's gray or light brown, though.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Do you have your grid down there, Vance?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's negative, Fred.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: I don't know if you can make out the features there, Vance, on the Moon, but it looks like the terminators are at central plains area somewhere around Descartes, maybe.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We're - We see it just as a bright portion of the lunar disk, and it looks a lot like you see it from Earth. Very bright. We are unable to see any features at all.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: It's pretty much the same with the eyeballs in here, and it looks a little bigger now. But the only way I could see it very good at all was with the monocular, a little while ago.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Fred. Very good. We'd be interested to seeing the cabin when you get ready for that, too.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. I'll set up now.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And, Vance, we're counting down to midcourse-2, we're up to, in our checklist, to minus 6 minutes to go.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Minus 6 minutes. Understand you're about ready to turn on the gimbal motors and all that sort of thing. Okay. We see the computer now in the upper middle part of the - the panel. I think we see somebody's checklist in the center couch. It must be Jim holding the checklist.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Right. And what Jim's holding now, he's got a pen in his hand we've rigged on a string, as sort of a simple-minded accelerometer. This burn's pretty short and I'm not sure even that's going to show very much. But we'll see if it'll stretch out at the end of its string.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes. We see the pencil at the top of the picture floating around. And Jack's coming into view now.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: And I've gone back - Okay, I've gone back to AVERAGE now and ... pitch up.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Now in a few minutes, Vance, I guess we'll see how about the only system we haven't used yet works. Everything else sure has worked mighty fine.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Right. The spacecraft's really working nicely. Okay. We're picking up panel 2 now. Still a little bit of the checklist.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Wondering if you can pick up the caution array there?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Right. We just saw your - your testing of the caution and warning system at the left-hand side of the panel on our TV. See the lights all flash on. You're doing it again.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: You mission timer's showing up as a - a brilliant green in the upper left-hand part of the picture.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Roger. I got the camera kind of canted on you here, Vance.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Vance, Jim's going to go to VOX now.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Vance, how do you -

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Read you loud and clear, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. We'll - what we'll do - We'll be on VOX for the remainder of the burn and preburn countdown.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: ... And what we're waiting for is 54 minutes on our counter or 20 which would be minus - -

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jim, we hear clipping on your VOX. Could you adjust it so that you're coming in continuously all the time?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Stand by 1.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5. How's that, Vance?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. That's better.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Vance, how do you read the CMP on VOX?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jack, read you loud and clear.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Fine.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: We show minus 8-1/2 minutes.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Houston copies. 01 06 32 44 SC Close

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Is that too close, Vance, or can you make out the SPS engine panel now?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We can see your fuel and oxidizer gages and hydrogen/oxygen gages at the top of the picture and the PUGS, but it isn't coming in in focus too well. It's a little dim.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes. I think the problem is I'm about 2 feet and it doesn't go down but to 4.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Right. We understand that's the panel right in front of your face.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Vance, stand by for the main ...

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. We're minus 7 minutes.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Fred, the focus is good enough that we can see the position of your four ball valves at the top of the picture for the big SPS engine.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: What would you like to watch, Vance?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Hopefully, you'll see the - or we'll see the two on the left here, set A, go on here directly - -

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Minus 6 minutes.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: MAIN BUS TIES, two, ON, Fred. Okay. SPS HELIUM VALVE, two, AUTO and checked AUTO barber pole. TVC SERVO POWER is 1, ACl/MAIN A; 2, AC2/MAIN B.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: ACl/MAIN A, AC2/MAIN B.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: MAIN BUS TIES, ON.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. ROTATIONAL POWER NORMAL no. 2, AC.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Number 2, AC.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: DIRECT, two, OFF.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: DIRECT, two, OFF.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: BMAGs, three, ATT l/RATE 2.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: ATT l/RATE 2.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: SPACECRAFT CONTROL, SCS.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: SCS.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And arm your hand controller.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: RHC armed.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Let's do a primary TVC check.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Fred, are you ready to start primary?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Go ahead on primaries.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. PITCH 1, START. 01 06 35 40 IMP Good.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: YAW 1, START.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: That one's good.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Thumbwheel control. 0.96 plus O.96 minus 0.23.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: That's affirm. Check MTVC.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: MTVC checked. Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: THC - -

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: - - TRIM returns to NEUTRAL.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Clockwise on the translation controller. ^

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Mine? No MTVC.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: No MTVC. Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Starting ...

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. 01 06 36 10 IMP Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: PITCH 2, START.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Good.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: YAW 2, START.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Both good.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Good. Good trim control. Minus O.96, plus 0.96, minus 0.23.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Good.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: MTVC. TRANSLATION CONTROL, NEUTRAL. MAX trim up to zero.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Good. No MTVC.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: No MTVC.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: BMAGs MODE, RATE 2.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: ROTATIONAL HAND CONTROL POWER, two, NORMAL, AC/DC.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: AC/DC.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: RATE 2, MAIN A/MAIN B.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: B.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. BMAGs, you got three, RATE 2? Okay, we'll proceed for final trim.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: MAG's where we are.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. BMAG MODEs, three, ATT l/RATE 2.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: ATT l/RATE 2.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: ... ENTER. Okay. We'll do the GIMBAL TEST OPTION.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. PROCEED.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Proceeding.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Plus 2, minus 2,0, plus 2, 2, 0.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes. We can hear and feel the engine gimbal as we do the test.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Roger. Good - -

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: FDAI SCALE - -

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: - - ... relay cut in and TRIM is set.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: FDAI SCALE, 5/5?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: RATE, HIGH and update the DET.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Time?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Let's check it.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. We're coming up on 3 minutes. I'll give you a Mark.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Fair enough.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: MARK.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Three minutes. DET is good.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. We're set.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: At 58, we want DELTA-V THRUST A to NORMAL.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Jim, Houston. You're looking good down here. G) for the burn.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Right, Vance.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Two minutes. DELTA-V thrust - -

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: DELTA-V THRUST A to NORMAL.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: NORMAL.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: TRANSLATION HAND CONTROLLER armed. Arm your ROTATIONAL HAND CONTROLLER. I've already got mine armed. Okay, Fred, TAPE RECORDER, HIGH BIT RATE, RECORD, FORWARD, COMMAND RESET. Standing by for 59.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: It's running.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Minus 1 minute.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. .. .

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: AVERAGE G.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: EMS mode to NORMAL.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: MODE NORMAL.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Standing by for ENTER ENABLE.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: ENTER ENABLE.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Two balls.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Shutdown.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Let's get the residuals. Okay, Houston, there are the residuals.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay; gimbal motors.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Copy residuals.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: ... secondaries.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Go.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. YAW 2. 01 06 41 18 IMP Good.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: PITCH 2.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: That's good.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Primary.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: On LOW BIT RATE. Start. Go with the primaries.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. YAW 1.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: That's good.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: PITCH 1.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: TVC SERVO POWER, OFF.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: - - is OFF. Okay. Record the DELTA-Vc. You got that?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. You got the - You got the DELTA-V in minus 3.7.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. FUNCTION, OFF. MODE, STANDBY.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Proceeding now.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: OFF. MODE, STANDBY - -

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: TRANSLATION HAND CONTROL POWER, OFF.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. POWER OFF.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: ROT POWER DIRECT, two, OFF.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Two OFF.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: RATE 2.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: BMAGs, RATE 2.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: I'm already in low bit rate.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes, we were on those ... so that we had less than 0.2.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Houston copied your residuals, very low.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Fuel is l.O; oxidizer 0.25; the OX unbalance is reading on the decrease, which doesn't mean very much, and I guess that wasn't too much for a push there, Vance. I didn't see the accel- erometer do a whole lot and it was a little surprising how slowly the injector valves opened, at least on the indicators.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Roger. That was a very short burn. Request you give us a sweep across the panel when you get a chance, Fred. Let us see Jack and Jim again. Over.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Vance, I was going to show you on - wonder if the folks might - down there might be interested in how we find out how far we're away from the Moon. Going to do that right now in program 21 here.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: I'm asking the computer how far away we are. And the computer is telling me we're 121 490 miles out.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. That agrees fairly closely with our map on the wall.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: I'm glad. That means you're tracking us too.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: And if you didn't see our residuals, it was 0.1 X, 0.2 on Y, and 0.1 Z, and DELTA-Vc was minus 3.8.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Jack, Houston. We show you down here 121 thou- sand miles 520 out. So I guess we all agree.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Real good, Vance. What I'm going to do is give you a shot of Fred.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: If we can get all the wiring out of the way.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: The big problem here is, when you move the TV around, this wire follows you like a snake here.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes, we have Fred now. Looks like he has a lariat there, getting ready to rope the checklist.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: That's only half of it. We have most of it hidden away. It's been pretty interesting doing all the camera work here to get a little extra training running the TV here, hopefully for when we get on the ground at Fra Mauro. The monitor does make it pretty easy though.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Right. That's a real advantage in the cockpit. You're just a little bit dark. It looks like it might help to have the f-stop run down about one increment. See how it comes out - -

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Can't do it, we're wide open.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Are you?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: I think we're wide open - -

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes. We're wide open, Vance.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Does that help any, Vance?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. It's reasonablly good. We can make out Fred fairly well. Looks like he's in a shadow. Hey, that helps. You just turned up the lights, huh?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes. We went fixed on the - -

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. You're on candid camera.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: We did notice one thing, Vance. You know that new fad with long hair? It won't work too well up here in space.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: What was that one again?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: I say, you know the new - the new fad with long hair?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Right.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: It doesn't work too well up in space, you can't comb your hair up here.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Well, I guess you have to give up something.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Well, at least it - it helps to try. We can see you trying to comb your hair there, Jim. It looks like your - your beards haven't come along to the point where you've had to use the razor though.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Well, we've been debating that. We thought we'd take care of our beards tomorrow and make that one of our daily routines.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: I take it that was a subtle hint, Vance.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: No, no. We're not commenting on your appearance, Fred. I mean nothing derogatory, understand.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: And, Vance, thought we'd get a picture of Jack just so that all the girls know that he's still here.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: (Laughter)

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes, we - we appreciate that. There he is. Big Jack.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Jack, you're in the shadow right now; we have a little bit of interference from your window, which is very bright, so we can't - I think you're smiling, but it's a little hard to tell. 01 06 48 11 CDR ...

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Hey, there we go. Incidentally, we've been getting all kinds of bits of information to pass up to you. We've had baseball scores coming in, basketball. Somebody said there's 220 days, shopping days left until Christmas.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes. Who won the Masters, Vance?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: It was a tie in the Masters and stand by. It was a tie between Littler and Casper after 72 holes, and there is going to be a playoff Monday, we understand.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Oh. Sounds good.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: One thing the world might be interested in knowing is what you do after the burn in the way of configuring switches back. We - We heard you go through the checklist. But, I guess right now, basically, you probably have all the switches back in position and you're in the mode to con- tinue on with - Okay. What does the flight plans say? You're going to be doing cislunar naviga- tion. So, Jack you're going to be down in the LEB. Is that correct?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: That's right, Vance. Be going down there shortly.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. The TV now is all but black. Looks like it must be pointing into a shadow.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: What he's doing, he's trying to give you one more shot of the Moon, and right now I'm setting to maneuver pad and the optics calibration attitude.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: And what I wanted to point out, I don't know if it's apparent, but ... to show the advantage of doing all the dumps just before the burn, we're looking again at the same scene over quad 1 at the Moon. And now you don't see all the sparkly frozen particles outside there any more. We've sort of run off and left them.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Roger. We - We don't see anything out there any- more in the way of particles leaving the spacecraft. We'd suggest, maybe you zoom the Moon in a little bit again so we can see the shape of it better.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. That brings the Moon in. We can see the terminator at the top of the melon-shaped disk.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Now you can see a few of the spark - sparkling particles going across the screen. Those are being emitted from the thrusters. Jack's maneuvering the spacecraft now.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. We can see those very poorly. Well, actually, they are coming in better now. It looks like little specks going from the upper left part of the screen across to the right, and understand those are from the thrusters.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: That's affirm.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, 13; Houston. Just as an item of interest, advise your speed with respect to the Earth is now 4667 feet per second.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Thanks, Vance.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Apollo 13; Houston. The Moon has been in and out of the - the - our screen here. Right now it's off at the bottom side, but we can still see the particles coming off of the spacecraft.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. I am going to have to pull it out the window now, Vance. The Sun's coming up on the right side.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Roger. Understand. You - -

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Do you want to see any shots down in the LEB, Vance?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Say again.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Do you want to see any of the photographs or do you want the TV down in the LEB?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: That's right, Jim. It would be good to see what you are doing down in the LEB or the far corner of the spacecraft where the optics are. Might be interesting to describe what you will do in the next few minutes in the way of sighting.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Vance. First we are going to give you a shot of the sleep station.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. The camera's bounced around a little, but we can see the green computer come in every once in a while.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: While Jack is getting the sleep station rolled up, I thought I would show you one interesting corner. We've got a temporary stowage bag here and that's where all our wastepaper and all that goes while we're - after every meal. It's in the right-hand corner down by our dump system.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Roger. Understand. We're looking at the wastebasket.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: And the age-old question that is always asked us is how do we get rid of liquid waste and that line that you see, I think you can see it now, it goes right outside where we open up the overboard drain dump, and all of our waste products, liquid waste products, go out through that line and get dumped overboard.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Roger. Understand, and we can see somebody's foot, as well.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Fred is now going down there, and he is going to try to get underneath the sleep station on his side where we have a sleep restraint. And the whole object of that is to ... to position the body between the - between the bottom of the spacecraft and - so it doesn't float up between that and the bottom of the couch.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Roger. The sleep restraint of the hammock is corning into view underneath the couch. It's the white object.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: You perhaps can see the zipper of the hammock right now. It's the black lines in that white object.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Right. We can see it.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: These hammocks, by the way, are very comfortable. When we first heard about them in the design of Apollo, we thought they weren't necessary, but they turned out to be very nice devices to sleep in.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: I'm trying now to get down there with Fred to show you how it works. I keep floating up, though, but maybe we can get a little shot here.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. We have somebody upside down in the photograph now. Realizing, of course, in - in space there is no really rightside up or upside down. It still looks that way to us.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. That's - That's Fred now- I'm trying to put him rightside up, for you folks back there in the sleep station. Fred, would you move your hands there so the folks back home can see you?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. That's coming in real clear, Jim. We see Fred in the sleep restaint - restraint.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: As a matter of fact, Vance, I find my - I find Fred down there all the time.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes. I can see he appreciates that. Looks fairly comfortable.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Looks like there is a lot of room down there, considering all the boxes on the floor and underneath the couch.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: It's surprising. There still is quite a bit of room down there even with the Hycon camera box down. And now, I'm going to bring the camera back up.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Vance. If there is no more that you would Ike to see right now, we'll terminate our little TV for you today.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Thank you very much, Jim. Appreciated seeing inside the spacecraft and getting a look at the Moon that you're rapidly approaching.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Roger. This is Odyssey saying goodby.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Go ahead, Houston.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. At your convenience we have an item to give you which will have to be copied. It's information on how to photograph Comet Bennett at time 32 hours GET. Over.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Stand by 1 minute.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Vance. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Time 32 hours 00 minutes GET. Instructions at completion of P23, maneuver to following attitude: roll 101.0, pitch 090.0, yaw 000.0. High gain antenna angles will be: pitch minus 23, yaw 93. Use normal PTC procedures to dampen rates. After vehicle's stable, and before spinup, take photographs of Comet Bennett. Use the DAC on the sextant with magazine G. That is, very high-speed black-and-white film, right? That's the dim-light film. Take three photos, one each at 5-, 20-, and 60-seconds' time exposure. Use AUTO optics. NOUN 88 values are Rl plus 34717, R2 minus 08028; plus 35075. Take three photos one each at 5-, 20-, and 60-second time exposure using manual optics. Shaft will be 000.8 degrees, trunnion 12.5 degrees. Comment: Strip off about 50 frames; that is, 2 seconds of - at 24 feet per second before the first frame and after the last frame of the photos. That is, 2 second - 2 seconds at 24 frames per second - before the first frame and after the last frame of photos.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Is that it, Vance?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And that's all.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. The time is - The event will be at 32:00; and we're to maneuver to the following attitude; roll 101.0, pitch 090.0, yaw all zips. High gain angles will be pitch minus 23, yaw 93. And we're to use normal PTC procedures to damp the rates. And after damping the rates and before spinup, we're to put the DAC on the sextant with the magazine G, very high-speed black and white film. Then, we're to take three photos, one each at 5-, 20-, and 60-seconds' time exposure using audio - AUTO optics. Our NOUN 88 values Rl plus 34717, R2 minus 08028, plus 35075. Thence, three more photos, one each at 5-, 20-, 60-seconds' time exposure using manual optics. Shaft 0.8 degrees, trunnion 12.5 degrees. And we're to take 2 - second bursts at 24 frames per second, before and after these pictures.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Your readback is correct, Fred.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jim, for PTC tonight, request that you disable quads C and D. That's the opposite of last night. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. For PTC tonight, disable quads C and D.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. And advise in approximately an hour, we'll have some read-ups whenever you're ready to take them regarding solo book changes.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. We'll be standing by for it.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Houston, 13.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead, 13.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Have you all got a chance to look at the data on the SPS yet?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Stand by 1, Fred.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Fred, it looks good, but they haven't had a chance to evaluate everything. They'll probably be finished with looking at strip charts in about 15 minutes, and after that we'll try to get back with you.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Thank you.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: On the P33, just like to verify that you changed the NOUN 88 values for this last star. It looks like they haven't been changed. Over. F

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Vance.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: That's better. Let's read you what we - what ve have. We have what they had in the flight plan, and if it's been changed from the flight plan, we don't have it.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Stand by 1.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: We think you're right, Vance. It looks like they used the same set of NOUN 88 for both stars by mistake.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, very good.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Vance. That ought to complete the P23s, right?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Very good, Jack.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Go ahead, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We have some results on your - your first star, if you'd like to hear them. The rest of the stars we'll - we'll have to give you in a couple of hours. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, the first star: the corrected altitude, 15 kilometers plus or minus 4; effective altitude, 12 kilometers plus or minus 7. As far as the substellar point, the value is arc-minutes - 2 arc-minutes, and that's very good. And, like I said, we'll get back with you in a couple of hours for the rest.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We have several items, here. First, is a reminder on the PTC that P^ should be 375 - 0.375 degrees as last night, to get 0.3-degree rotation rate. The second one - -

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Copy that.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. The second one, at 32 hours looking at Bennett's Comet - we want the pictures taken when the spacecraft is as stable as it's going to be before starting PTC. The stability requirement is very high. We weren't sure if you understood that from what we passed up. In addition, the photographs might not show as much as the eye can see of the comet, so if you see anything interesting about the structure of the comet, why, sketching it is in order and is encouraged. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Vance. What we'll do is, when we get to attitude, we'll disable the quads and do like we did last night; we'll let GUIDO and you people down there tell us when you think we are stable enough; then we'll do all this work with the DAC on the sextant, first; and then when we get that done, we'll go back and put the sextant eyepiece back on and see what we can observe visually.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. That sounds good. Also, while you are waiting for the vehicle to stabilize, it might be interesting to have the eyepiece on and be looking at it visually. Okay. Next item: your SPS burn had no anomalies whatsoever. It was a very good burn.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Very good.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Next item: request hydrogen tank 1 HEATER OFF for balancing purposes.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And Apollo 13, another item: something that we have observed and you might be seeing is a slight TCE fluctuation on fuel cell 3. This fluctuation has been going from about 152 to 160 over a 37-second period. It has been seen on other flights in the past. No one is worried about it, but the usual fluctuation is about 1-1/2 degrees instead of 7 seconds, so I thought you should be aware of it.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Vance. And one other slight distinction we've noted is the flow of hydrogen versus the oxygen is not exactly matched on fuel cell 3 either.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We copy. And the last item: we'd like to send you an IRIG update, so at your convenience, request P00 and ACCEPT.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. We are in P00 and ACCEPT, Vance.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Quad C and D are disabled, Vance.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Disabled. And down here, we see that your hydrogen and oxygen on the fuel cell are exactly matched, so we suspect it's purely a spacecraft read-out problem.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Vance, let us know when you're through with the DSKY so we can load NOUN 88?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. We'll let you know, Jack.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston. The computer's yours, again.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. You're go for the pictures.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Vance. We tried our AUTO OPTICS and couldn't pick it up there. We're pointing pretty much right into the Sun, and things are pretty well washed out. And I've gone to MANUAL OPTICS and I'm trying to get 0.8, 12.5 on the shaft and trunnion, and I still can't pick it up. So - it's very light in the sextant, so I kind of think maybe we're too near the Sun to see it.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: That's right, Vance. The sextant is all - it's - it's all milky and it - any comet that could be seen through there is just going to be missed in the background.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, we copy that. We got some discussion. Stand by.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Vance, it isn't - we're not looking into the Sun - what we are getting is a large reflection from the Sun behind us off the LM; and it is - it is coming on that quad 1 there, and that quad is reflecting back into the sextant.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. Understand. Just a question: if you look through the telescope, can you see the comet at all? Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: No, I can't, Vance. It's - it's still too light.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Stand by.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Say, Vance?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Are the flowers blooming yet?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Gee, I sure haven't seen any.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Hey, we've - we've got quite a discussion down here on your trying to observe the comet, and this reflection is not unexpected. And give us another minute, and we'll be back with you on something on that.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. I doubt very seriously though, if we take any photographs with high-speed black and white with the light coming into the sextant that you're going to get anything out of it.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Unanimous opinion is that you're right, and we'll scratch all of this Bennett Comet stuff on the way out, with the hope that conditions will be more favorable after TEI. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Sounds good. Without the LM, we may have a better chance.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And Apollo 13, you're GO for PTC. Your rates are very low according to what we can read.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger, Vance.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Are you going to give a call on OMNI B, Vance?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Do you read, Vance?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Go ahead. Request OMNI B, Fred, and secure the high-gain antenna.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. You got it.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Just something to think about. In about 30 minutes, we can generate the pads that we have yet to send up before the sleep period, so we could support an earlier sleep period if you so desired. And - but, it will take us 30 minutes to get that stuff. The other thing is any time you're ready to copy, I can read up the solo book changes. Over - And, also, two pages in the flight plan.

transcript.speaker: CDR

transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC

transcript.text: No - -

transcript.text: No. You know - you know how the FIDOs are. They like to load in their own data, no matter what.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes, that's -

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston. It's your computer again.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Going to BLOCK.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Maybe that gives us a little more confi- dence that if we had to do P23s on the way home, we'd make it.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: No doubt about it.

transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston.

transcript.text: Go ahead, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CMP

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: He says, seriously, it's looking probably like you won't have any more.

transcript.text: Hey, that's real fine.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: FIDOs never guarantee anything, however.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Yes. That's right.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead, Vance.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jim, just an item for you and Fred to be thinking about in case you haven't been briefed on this, something that's now being talked about a little bit. These conservative people would like to have you read the SHe tank pressure when you go into the LM for the LM familiarization at 58 hours. If there's no midcourse-3, and it looks like there's a good chance that there will not be, why, they might want to move the LM familiarization up from $8 to 55 hours. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. If we don't have a midcourse-3, then we'll probably move LM FAM up to 55 hours, in which case we'll go in there and read SHe tank pressure.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Along with the other FAM stuff, and it's not certain that we want to do this, it's just being talked about, so this is just the informa- tion for you.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. This is beginning to sound like the SIM that we ran not too long ago.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: I don't think it will be a very big deal.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Houston, 13.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: This is Houston. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Vance. Our LM/CM DELTA-P is 0.9.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. 0.9.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Go ahead, Vance.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Are you guys hacking into your presleep checklist yet?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Oh, we just finished eating and cleaning up a bit afterwards. Jim's going around collecting debris off of all the inlet hoses. And, I guess you might say we're kind of thinking about getting ready to go to sleep.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Well, I hope you had a good meal.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: It wasn't too bad.

transcript.speaker: SC
transcript.text: (Music)

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Sounds like you guys are really living it up up there. All that music, food. I didn't say drink.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes, it is pretty nice. Not bad at all. You're . right; you didn't say it. This PTC we're in is a pretty - pretty nice merry-go-round, Vance. Every 10 minutes alternately I get to look at the Earth and the Moon.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: You couldn't ask for anything more than that. Just so it isn't so fast you - -

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: No, it's a lot - a lot better. I remember from 8 when they didn't hardly ever get to look at either one.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's right. They were tumbling about another axis, weren't they.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: It's pretty cloudy down there tonight. About the only land I can see again is a portion of Australia and Korea and looks like a part of China. Just about clouds covering everything else.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Can you still see that clearly with the naked eye, or do you have to look through a glass?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: I can see Australia with the naked eye and the China landmass, but I - It took the monocular to pull out the Korean Peninsula.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: How about the Moon? Is it looking very big yet?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: No, not really. Bigger, but we've got a ways to go.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: I understand that they're estimating your pericynthion - lunar pericynthion is now 62 miles.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Well, that's not bad.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's supposed to be just right.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Houston; 13.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead. Jack.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. We're into the presleep checklist now. As far as the crew status report, as far as medication goes, we've had no medication. And we're all feeling really good. I've given you the onboard readouts. Jim is chlorinating the potable water now. I'm ready for an E-memory dump whenever you're ready.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Stand by 1 on the E-memory dump, Jack. I think we'll be ready in about a minute.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And EECOMM says that as soon as you stir your cryos, request you go back to AUTO on that one tank.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. We'll do that.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Hello, 13; Houston. We're ready to take your E-memory dump.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Corning down.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston. Were you trying to call?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, 13.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston. We thought you were trying to call. Were you?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I don't believe so unless we inadvertently hit the microphone button. 01 13 07 48 IMP Must have been some other guy trying to call, Jack.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Just trying to get some words in, eh Jack?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. We saw the downvoice subperiod come on. We thought maybe you were trying to call. Sorry. I hope we haven't disturbed you and from where I sit, it looks like you're running a rest home up there. Good night.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: We're all going to bed now just after we play the last rendition of "With Our Eyes on the Stars."

transcript.speaker: SC
transcript.text: (Music)

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. And we'd like you to check your S-BAND NORMAL voice switch, OFF.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: S-BAND NORMAL, OFF.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, 13. We'll be off COMM; so if you need us, send a crew alert, please.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. If we need you, we'll send a crew alert, and we'd like to know who's got the duty tonight on the BIOMED. Is that you?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Yes. I'll be on the BIOMED.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We copy, and you're spoiling my good record of two watches without saying anything.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Just want to keep you busy, Jack.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: You're waking me up.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Houston, Apollo 13. Over.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Good morning, 13, You're early.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Ah so. I just thought I'd be waking up. And we are awake and getting the spacecraft shipshape.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Spacecraft is in real good shape as far as we're concerned, Jim. We're bored to tears down here. We do have a few little items for you, like a P37 update and a couple of flight plan updates. But there's no rush about them. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Gig us again in a few minutes. We're breaking out some food, and we'll copy them then.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. And the surgeon will be ready for your sleep report whenever you get that together.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Righto. If he's listening, LMP had a solid 9 hours of sleep; I couldn't wake him up this morning. The CMP had 6 hours, and the commander about 5 intermittent.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay - -

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Jack's dosimeter - Jack's dosimeter is reading 02026.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We got it.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: It might be interesting that just after we went to sleep last night we had a MASTER ALARM and it really scared us. And we were all over the cockpit like a wet noodle.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: (Laughter) Sorry it wasn't something more significant. I've also got a procedure for you on that H2 tank; simple thing after you get done stirring up the cryos.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: SC
transcript.text: (Music - With Their Eyes on the Stars)

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That was beautiful. What was it?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: A little of "With Their Eyes on the Stars" to wake up to.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Sounds like all the comforts of home. Have you guys got a flower on your breakfast table?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Yes. Jack!

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Apol.lo 13. Over.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, this is Houston. Go.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger, Joe. We're standing by for that P37 block data if you have it for us.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Got it right here, Jim, and it follows. This is the P37 pad for lift-off plus 60. The reason for the update is for weather avoidance in the MPL at 119 hours. It's the same one we passed you yesterday, and it's the same weather, but we still don't expect a problem at the end of the mission. GETI is 060:00, DELTA-Vt, 6079, longitude minus 153, GET 400K 118:04. Over.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. That's correct. I've got a consumables update for you, Jim, if you're ready for that.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Ready to copy.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. As of 47 hours, RCS total 1096, quad Alfa 270, Bravo 278, Charlie 270, Delta 278, and the H2 - - They gave me the H2s in percent, 76 percent; and on the 02 we have 81 percent. However, we show the O2 tank 2 reading off-scale high now. We're quite sure it's a sensor failure. We'd like you to verify it with your onboard reading.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Stand by.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Joe, we confirm. Our gage reading is - on the number 2 O2 tank is reading off-scale high now, but Jack just tells me that it was okay when we first looked at it this morning.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We verify that. At 46:4 5 we had 82 percent and . apparently when he stirred the, the cryos, the sensor broke.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. 01 23 41 19 So it's no problem. You're above nominal on all your consumables. On the H2 tank problem, we have a procedure that we'd like you to carry out which is simply turning the H2 tank 2 heaters to OFF at this time, and we want to see whether that won't solve the problem of the tank pressure setting off caution and warning. We want to look at it that way for a few hours.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. You want both tank 2 heaters to OFF. Is that correct?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's negative; just tank 2. We want tank 1 to stay in AUTO.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Tank 2 heaters off at this time.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Good deal. That's been the high tank and apparently while waiting for that pressure switch to close, to start the heater cycle, the tank 1 pressure has been dropping even a little bit lower and just setting off caution and warning, so we feel if we turn off the tank 2 heater and let tank 1 activate the heater cycle, we won't get into the caution and warning range.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim- At your convenience we'd like P00 and ACCEPT. We're ready for - to uplink your state vector now since we will not do midcourse 3. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger. You're in P00 and ACCEPT, no midcourse 3, and we're all set for a state vector update and I'm giving you the LM/CM DELTA-P here shortly.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Good deal. And I have flight plan updates for you later, at your convenience.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Apollo 13. The LM/CM DELTA-P is 1.0 psi.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Copy, 1-0, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Apollo 13. I'm about ready for any flight plan updates that you have.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, 13- To start off with, got a minor Procedural change for Jack on his next P52, if he's ready to listen to that.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Jack's still off COMM. We'll hold off on that a little hit and then we'll pick it up when he gets on COMM.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay; fine. I've got two updates for you, Jim. One is a procedure for looking for Comet Bennett at about 49:45, and I'll wait till Jack gets up before passing you the details on that. The other update is concerned with going into the LM 3 hours early, and I think Vance mentioned to you last night that this was a possibility, that we'd like to look at the SHe tank pressure early. And since we're not going to do midcourse 3, we'd like LM entry at 55 hours. Is that okay with you?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Right, that's fine with us. We'll move up LM entry to 55 hours.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. I've got some details on the flight plan for you as follows. Of course, since there's no MCC-3 you'll be deleting all the midcourse 3 stuff including the - the P52, which is called out at about 54-1/2, and we'll be slipping that until later, which I'll - which I'll tell - which I'll tell - which I'll tell you in a minute. Okay. Then you - we want to move the battery charge up 3 hours to about 52:30. And we want to move the - moving the LM tunnel vent valve to LM/CM DELTA-P up 3 hours to 52:45, and at that point you can simply go to the 57-hour point in the flight plan and change your number from 57 hours to 54 hours and start through that. In the remarks section at about 57:50 it says, "O2 fuel cell purge and waste water dump," here. If not performed earlier, we want you to do that at 54 hours and 50 minutes. The TV pass then, will be at 55 hours to 55:30. You'll go right through the LM Activation checklist stuff. I'm losing you; let's wait a minute.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. How do you read me?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. You back with us?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston. Are you back with us?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: We're back with you.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. I've gone through the battery charge, the LM vent valve, the fuel cell purge, and then stop PTC at 55 hours, and your roll attitude there will be 285 degrees, which is per the flight plan. The high gain antenna angles are slightly different, pitch 23 and yaw 267 degrees The TV pass till 55:30, the standard LM activation except for some special steps we'll give you to take a look at SHe tank pressure, which I don't have yet. Restart PTC at about 56:30 or whenever you're through with the LM activities, and after that, at your convenience, we'd like you to - to do the P52 option 3 that we cancelled at 54-1/2 hours. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. That last comment was that we'll do the P52 after we start PTC at about 56:30.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's right. Any time after that; it's not time critical.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Let's see if I have some of this, Joe. Around 52:30 we're to do the battery charge on BAT - battery B.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's correct.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And then about 52:40 we're going to do the LM tunnel vent valve, and the LM/CM DELTA-P which has been written up at 55:40.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's correct.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: We're deleting midcourse-3 and we've moved up 'FS the LM entry to 55 hours. So we'll merely follow all the - We'll follow all the procedure that leads up to LM entry that was originally scheduled for 58.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's correct. You can start at 57 in the flight plan; call it 54 hours and Press right on.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Then whenever we're finished with the LM, which we anticipate around 56:30, we'll commence PTC and sometime after that we'll do a P52.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative. And did you copy the new high gain angles for 55 hours? The ones we had - - 01 23 52 12 CDR Okay. We're going to stop the PTC for LM entry at roll 285, and high gain angles are pitch 23 and yaw 267.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's correct, Jim. And, 13, Houston. The computer is yours.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: The computer is ours. We're in BLOCK, and exactly when do you want the TV to be cranked up?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: You can crank it up sometime prior to 55 hours at your convenience just to set it up. We'll be expecting transmission at 55 hours.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And, Houston, Apollo 13. One thing I missed about the O2 fuel cell purge and waste and water dump.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. We'd like the the O2 fuel cell purge and waste water dump at 54:50.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger. We'll pick up those items at 54:50.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Go ahead, Joe.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: All right, Jack. One thing we'd like to have done sometime soon is to have you cycle the cryo fans in 02 tank 2 one more time. We'd like to see if we can get that sensor back.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. 02 tank 2 fan on now.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, 13.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: We - We have just one question, the LM tunnel vent valve. We're questioning why we're venting until the DELTA-V is greater than 1.7 if we are going to open up the tunnel, then pressurize the LM usually.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Right. Stand by on that.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. The word on that, Jim, is that thcy want to insure the proper 02 concentration in the LM when you get to the surface, and this is a method of doing that by bleeding out additional nitrogen. 01 23 57 12 CM Okay. Thank you.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, 13, Houston. If Jack is up, I'd like to talk to him about the P52, briefly.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. He's here.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Go ahead, Joe.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. What they'd like you to do on this P52 at 49 hours, they've been observing a slight jitter in the optics shaft angle of about 0.2 of a degree plus or minus. Before you come out of the OPTICS ZERO position, at the start of this P52, they'd like you to just observe the shaft readout, and see if the jitter occurs on your direct readout there, and also they'd like you to briefly call up a VERB 16, NOUN 91 so we can look at the shaft and trunnion angles.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Let's see if I got it right. On the P52 at 49 hours, before coming out of ZERO on the OPTICS, observe the shaft and also call up 16, 91 and let you look at the shaft and trunnion angles to observe a possible jitter. See whether it occurs in the ZERO position as well as out of ZERO.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, Jack. That's correct; and if you have time, now, I've got a flight plan update for you on looking for the Comet Bennett.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Stand by 1, Joe. And the commander's going off the air briefly.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger that.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Joe. I'm ready to copy the ... now.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. I'm going to read it to you, and then add some comments and we'll talk about it a little. This should occur sometime after 49:30. After the P52 realine at 49 hours, if time permits we would like the crew to investigate while in PTC if there is a roll angle in which the comet can be observed for photos. If there is, record the optimum roll angle for possible photography, prior to reinitiating PTC at 56:30 or so, whenever the guys are done in the LM, use P52 planet option, and the following half-unit vectors for tracking Comet Bennett at about 49:46. Are you ready to copy half-unit vectors? Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Go ahead, Joe.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Rl plus 0.34202, minus 0.07374, R^ plus 0.35719. Read back.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Copy Rl plus 0.34202, R2 minus 0.07374, R3 plus 0.35719.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. That's correct and the last sentence on the update is that you can expect AOS of the comet at a roll of 45 degrees and LOS at a roll of 155 degrees. Now, the deal here. Jack, according to the plots they showed me is, the comet appears to be about 10 degrees away from the Sun, and due to the geometry of the LM there shadowing the Sun, it would appear that you will be able to see the comet through the sextant without getting Sun shafting between roll angles of about 45 degrees and 75 degrees. It appears that as your roll gets higher than 75 degrees, although the comet is still in the field of view, the Sun is also in the field of view, and you probably will not have any success between 75 and 155 if you haven't got it from 45 to 75. If you do find that you can see the comet somewhere between 45 and 75 or 80 degrees, just note that roll angle and then if it's feasible we'd like you to photograph it after the LM entry part of the checklist. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Joe. Let me give it back to you and see if I've got it here. After the P52, during our PTC you want us to use P52 and observe Bennett's Comet through the sextant; note a roll angle if we can find it visible. It would be visible somewhere between - ideally between 45 and 75 degrees, and we should lose it about 155 roll, and if we do see it, make an observation of whether it is photographable, note the roll angle for photographs to be taken after or prior to initiation of PTC at 56:30.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's exactly right. Jack.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Real fine.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Go ahead, Joe.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We're ready to have to 02 tank 2 fan off, and thank you.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Doesn't look like we got it back, huh?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: No, it doesn't. Jack.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Houston, Apollo 13.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Houston, Apollo 13.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Hey, 13; Houston. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Joe. I've started into P52 here. I've proceeded on option 3, and on the dis - 1520 - 1525 display, I've called up 1691. I'm going to let you observe and see while the - the shaft angle while the OPTICS are still in ZERO.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Roger that, Jack. We're looking at it, and I'll give you a mark as soon as G&C is happy.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Real fine.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. Jack, could you give us a readout on your counter now?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. I'm showing a shaft of 0.2 and a trunnion of 359.92.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Copy that. Is there any jumping around on the shaft?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: You mean on the TPAC readout?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: As a matter of fact, it went from 0.2 to 0.21.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Copy that. Stand by 1.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Now it went down - It went down as low as 0.15.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jack, Houston. Let us watch that for another minute or so.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. I'm in no hurry. It looked like it burned between 0.14 and 0.8 with an occasional spike up to 0.2.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston. You can press on with P52 now. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Joe.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Hey, Houston, are we clear to torque? Are you reading the torquing angles?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. Go ahead and torque.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Time of torquing will be 49 hours 8 minutes 35 seconds.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger that.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. For Jack, we missed the star angle differ- ence on the P52. Would you read us that?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger, Houston. It was all balls.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Thank you.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Hey, Houston; 13.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Joe. I got into P52 about 49:34. We loaded the planet - or Bennett Comet vectors into the planet option, and P52 tracked it all the way across except that it was always occulted by the LM, and we're in a roll angle of 155 now.

transcript.speaker: CC
