transcript.text: Roger. We're copying your roll angles. At what roll angle were you able to start tracking it, Jack?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. At the time we entered it there, we were about 66 degrees roll, so either we started too late, or maybe somehow we got a wrong calculation on the roll angle.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Let me have G&C comment on that. I sus- pect that the roll angles we gave you were calculated for exactly 90 degrees pitch, and you're probably wobbling enough that they're not exactly correct.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Yes, I think you - You probably got thf right idea.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. Notice you've secured from that, and that was going to be our recommendation, anyway. We're going to have the guys in the back room look at it and see if they can come up with some - with some better numbers based on the cone angle that - that you're traveling through, whether there are any roll angles that - that are available to you. And if there are, and we have time, we might give it another try; if not, we just will forget it.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Go ahead, Joe.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. I'd like to pass you a switch configuration on the CRY0 02 TANKS and give you the reason. Right now, we'd like you to go to HEATERS tank 1, OFF; tank 2, AUTO, which is the opposite of the way you've got them now. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Is this 02 or H2?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: This is 02, and stand by for a minute and we'll have a - Excuse me. This is H2, Jack; it's H2.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: ... is AUTO, ... 2 OFF.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Joe. Do we have you back again?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. We're getting you back, and I hope you copied my - my correction of my mistake. I'm talking about the H2 CRYO TANKS. We'd like the tank 1 HEATER to OFF; tank 2 to AUTO. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. We lost you again. Here's our heater configuration now. H2 HEATERS 1, OFF; 2, AUTO. Both O2 HEATERS are in AUTO.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. That's the configuration we want you in, and here's what we're thinking about. When we went to tank 1 AUTO, tank 2 OFF; we found that the heater cycle had a tank 1 pressure of about 233 psi, which is well above the caution and warning limit, and if we go to that configuration for sleep, we'll keep from getting CAUTION AND WARNING lights during the sleep cycle. Okay. In order to do that comfortably, we want to spend the rest of the day using more H2 out of tank number 2, so as to get an unbalance in favor of tank 1, so at the end of the sleep cycle it'll all come out even. And that' s why we have you in tank 1 OFF, tank 2 AUTO, now. We expect to get about a 3-percent unbalance over the next 10 hours; and prior to sleep, we'll call you to reverse the configuration again. Now the only disadvantage here is that, during the day, you will probably get a few CAUTION AND WARNINGS, and we just figured it would be better to get them now than while you were sacked out. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I'll buy that 100 percent.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Good deal. One other detail for you. Jack; G&C tells us that the OPTICS jitter is very similar to what we had on Apollo 12. It's no problem, but when you're not using the OPTICS, we recommend that you turn the OPTICS POWER switch to OFF to guard against a possible degradation as the flight progresses. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Will do.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Apollo 13, Houston. I have one more little update for you, and it's another update to the erasable memory onboard crew charts on page G/9-2. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, 13. We're ready to copy.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. These are gyro compensation terms. They've already been uplinked, and we're just updating your onboard charts now. In column A, number 11, change from 77646 to 00114; number 12, change from 77332 to 77546; number 13, change from 76617 to 77201. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: The changes are as follows, and all in column A: number 12, the new change is 77546; number 11, the new change is 00114; and 13, the new change is 77201. Over.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Readback correct.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: And, Joe, do you know - Are you going to try and let us spot the Bennett Comet on this next revolution there? Or do you want me to turn the OPTICS power off now?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Stand by 1, Jack. Okay, Jack. We don't have confidence in those roll angles yet, so why don't you turn the OPTICS off, and we'll update you later.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Going off now.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, Jim. If you've got a couple of minutes now, I'd like to read uP to you the change to the LM entry procedure that we'd like you to observe at 55 hours, and the rationale for it. 0ver.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, stand by.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead, Joe.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Before you start copying, this procedure is - is basically simply to activate the supercritical helium pressure gaging so that you can read it. And the concern here is lest this supercritical helium pressure reach 1800 psi by 103 hours, at which point we'd be within a Possibility of rupturing the burst disk when you activate the DPS. Now, based on the pressure at launch, and based on a nominal rise time of about 6-1/2 psi per hour between then and now, the Pressure should read about 710 psi. Stand by, 13, until we get better COMM.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, you were cut out. Would you say again about the helium pressure.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Based on the prelaunch pressure in the SHe tank and the nominal rise time of about 6-1/2 psi per hour, the pressure should be about 710 at 55 hours. Are you reading? Over.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jim, Houston. Did you read that last?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Joe. I'm on OMNI C now. How do you read?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. You're loud and clear now. INCO tells me he's having a little problem at Goldstone and wants me to stand by for a minute.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. How do you read now, Joe? I'm going from OMNI C to D now.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: You're still loud and clear on - on D, Fred. Stand by 1.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. I'll Put her back to OMNI B if you all want to take command again?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: And the Iast thing we heard, Joe, was that the SUPERCRIT should be reading about 710 psi.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. That's the last thing I passed up. And while we're waiting for INCO to decide here, let me continue. The deadband that is considered acceptable is between 660 and 770 psi. In other words, any rise time that'll give you one - a pressure between those two, will keep you below the critical pressure at 103 hours or so. So, we expect it to read in that - in that band and if it does, there will be no problem. If it reads between 770 and 800 psi, we will want you to check the pressure again at about 59 hours, and I'll get the detailed procedures in a minute. If the pressure is equal to or greater than 800 psi, we're going to have to go into some more detailed procedures; we're going to try to - to get PCM data on it, for one thing. We may have to have you sit there and stare at the gage for a while to find out when it clicks up and get an accurate rise time on it, and then in extreme case, we are even thinking about a DPS burn, but we don't really think that will happen. Now, if you are ready to copy, what I have for you is a change or an addition to the LM Activation checklist between pages TLC-1 and TLC-2, which consists of seven steps, and if you can find a blank side to write it down on, I would like to pass it up. Over.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. How do you read on OMNI C, now?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. You're loud and clear on OMNI C Stand by 1 while we get INCO synced up.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. The rest of your update was that it's okay if it is anywhere between 660 and 770 psi. If it's above 770, you are going to ask us to consider going back in at 59 hours and either get PCM going or sit there and give you gage reading changes on the basis of that. And you said something about an extreme measure. We may have to consider some sort of DPS maneuver.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's correct, Fred. We don't have procedures for that yet, and we don't have any real expectation of getting into it. The procedure I'd like to read up to you now is simply the steps required to get the supercritical helium pressure reading at 55 hours. Over.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We're calling this TLC-lA, step 6, "Transfer to LM power."

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: All right. Stand by 1, Joe. 02 02 35 25 GC Okay.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Joe. He's ready to copy.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Step 6, "Transfer to LM power (floodlights blank), CAUTION WARNING POWER CAUTION light ON. Report GET to MCC. Panel 11, CIRCUIT BREAKER EPS TRANSLUNAR BUS TIE, CLOSED. Circuit breaker panel 16, EPS THANSLUNAR BUS TIE, CLOSED. Circuit breaker panel 11, LIGHTING UTILITY, CLOSED. And activate utility lights." Over. And, 13, Houston. Select OMNI Bravo, please.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Joe. I've created a new page here called TLC-lA, item 6, Transfer to LM power and the usual check that the floodlight's blank and that I've got the CAUTION WARNING POWER light ON; I get a GET from Jack, and I will pass that on down to you. Item 7, CIRCUIT BREAKER EPS TRANSLUNAR BUS TIE, panels 11 and 16, CLOSED. Step 8, circuit breaker lighting and utility on panel 1, CLOSED, and turn on the utility lights. However, the lighting is such that I don't really need those. They are in stowage, right now, I guess, in the ISA, and I'll probably just leave them there.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. That's optional. The way we had page TLC-lA written, that was all part of step 6. You haven't even gotten to step 7 yet. Step 7 is as follows.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Fred, Houston. Are you with me?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston. Are you reading me now?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Houston, 13. How do you read?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. Loud and clear. What OMNI you on now?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: I'm going to stay OMNI B, if you all want to take command back and you can let INCO jockey them around between B and D. And how many steps we got, so I know whether to write big or small here, Joe?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We got steps 6 through 12, but step 7 is the same size as 6, and 8 through 12 are short. They're only one line each.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Step 7 follows: "Circuit breaker panel 11, AC BUS B, HELIUM PQGS PROPELLANT DISPLAY, CLOSED. Circuit breaker 11, AC BUS B, NUMERIC LIGHTING, CLOSED. Circuit breaker 11, AC BUS B, BUS TIE INVERTER 1, CLOSED. Circuit breaker panel 11, EPS INVERTER 1, CLOSED. Circuit breaker panel 16, INSTRUMENTATION SIG SENSOR, CLOSED. INVERTER 1" - -

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Hold on a minute, Joe.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: My shorthand is rather poor today.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay I'm now up to circuit breaker panel 11, INVERTER 1, CLOSED.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Next was "Circuit breaker panel 16, INSTRUMENTATION SIG SENSOR, CLOSED. Then INVERTER 1, SELECT. Then HELIUM MONITOR to SUPERCRIT PRESS. Report SUPERCRIT PRESS to MCC." Over.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Houston, 13. How do you read?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. You're coming through. We still have some background noise. Do you want to read back step 7?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Hello, Houston; 13.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Joe. The last thing I got was HELIUM MONITOR to SUPERCRIT PRESSURE.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. The last part of step 7 is, "Report SUPERCRIT PRESSURE to MCC," and read back step 7.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Step 7. Circuit breaker panel 11, AC BUS B, HELIUM PQGS DISPLAY, CLOSED. Main - Circuit breaker panel 11, AC BUS B, NUMERIC LIGHTING, CLOSED. CD panel 11, AC BUS - Is that AC BUS B? BUS TIE INVERTER 1, CLOSED?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: And CB - CB EPS INVERTER 1, panel 11, CLOSED. CB panel 16, INSTRUMENT SIGNAL SENSOR, CLOSED. INVERTER 1, SELECT. HELIUM MONITOR to SUPERCRIT PRESSURE. Report pressure to MSFN.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. That's correct. Now step 8 is, "On MCC request, perform step 9." In other words, you wait for us to decide what to do and that's according to the gouge we've already given you. And step 9, I'll give you now, is "HELIUM MONITOR to OFF, INVERTER to OFF." Over.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Step 8 says, "Set in an MCC hold." Step 9 says, "On MCC's words, HELIUM MONITOR OFF, INVERTER OFF."

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. That's correct. Step 10 is, "Configure circuit breaker panels per Activation 3 and 4."

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Configure - step 10, "Configure circuit breakers per Activation pages 3 and 4."

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. That's correct. Step 11 is, "Deactivate the utility lights if you activated them," and step 12 which is the last one is, "Transfer to CSM power, usual observations, and report time to MCC."

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Step 11, "Deactivate utility lights." 12, "Transfer to CSM power and note the usual observations and report the GET."

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. That's it. And, of course, Houston will be requesting you to go to step 9 if the pressure is less than 770. If the pressure is between 770 and 800, we will be asking you to do the following, if you're ready to copy.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Stand by. I've got to find some more blank paper.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Ye. Thin is going to be page TLC-3, but it's very short.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Go ahead with TLC-3.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Stand by 10 seconds, Fred.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Fred, Houston.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: All right. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. We'll hold off on that. It was a short three-step procedure which said, "Repeat activation pages 1, lA, and 2," but there was another step in it that nobody understands. So, essentially what we'd recommend in that case would be that you would repeat the procedure that we just passed up for reading the SUPERCRIT pressure. If we need to, we'll clarify it later on. And that's all we've got.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, 13.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. One thing, Joe; I just want to doublecheck again. All the stuff that normally was going to start at 57 hours, which the first item was pressurize CSM to 5.7 psia, we're going to move that up to 64 now, so we have our LM entry which was nominally at 58 at 55. Is that correct?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's correct, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, 13. Because of the 02 tank 2 quantity sensor drop out, EECOM wants to keep a little closer track of the cryo quantities, and he's going to be asking you to stir all the cryo tanks at slightly more frequent intervals than had been planned, and the first time is now, and we will be calling you probably every 5 or 6 hours, except during sleep period and high activity periods. We'd like you to do it now. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. We'll start it ... now.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Thank you.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, 13, Houston. For your information, a normal 1-minute or so stir will be fine.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead, Houston-

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jim, just an advisory; expect a CAUTION AND WARNING on H2 tank 1 pretty quick. No problems; just warning you about it.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. A zero pressure light on H2 tank 1 coming on shortly, huh?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Right.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Well, you're pretty close. It just came on.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Any other predictions you'd like?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Well, there's - I guess there's all sorts. Could you go to the horse races with me?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: I'm sorry; you were garbled. Say again?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I said I'd like to invite you to the horse races with me.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Right. We'll - We'll send EECOMM.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Well, it's time for a little grits again here, Vance.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Understand. Some grits, huh? Chow. Bon apetit.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Just expect that same CAUTION AND WARNING to come on again. And you want us to keep warning you of that thing?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, Jim. Just expect a CAUTION AND WARNING to come on the same as it did about an hour ago.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead, Houston. We've lost ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. How are you reading me now, Jim?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Apollo 13.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. How do you read now?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Read you good now. Seems like we've had a little trouble with the COMM today.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes. I guess it's partly because you are further out. We just wanted to tell you that you were going to get that CAUTION WARNING that you just got.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Right. We just got.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And I won't bother you with those calls anymore, unless you especially want them.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: That's okay, Vance. You don't have to call us about that, unless it's something serious.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: We just ate a can of ham salad and that was an experience.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Copy.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: It's really kind of like eating on the sly. Chasing it around.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Right. Copy.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: But good. 02 05 19 28 SC

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Apollo 13.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Right, we're not doing anything right now, Vance, we're just getting curious, we could start the LM entry procedures, and get everything squared away, and then when the TV comes up at 55 hours, we can just use it for the TV, and we wouldn't be worrying about checking out the SHe tank pressures and everything like that.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, let us mull that one a minute here, and I'll get right back with you.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Also, Houston, Apollo 13. We'd like to move up the waste water dump and maybe the 02 fuel cell purge a little bit early, if we could.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, stand by.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jim, you're clear to go on into the LM, and just advise though that the TV time is still fixed at 55 hours, and - so we'll be standing by to support your entry and we'll get back with you on a minute - in a minute on the 02 fuel cell purge and the waste water dump.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Sounds good.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And also request your LM/CM DELTA-P which was on the flight plan for 53 hours. What did you vent it down to? Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: We have 1.7 now. We vented it down to that figure.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, you vented down to 1.7, and what did it start at?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: It was about 1.1, Vance.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, copy.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Houston, 13.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead, 13.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: What do you read for suit pressure down there?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We're reading 4.3, Fred.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, 13.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead, Apollo 13.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: We'd like another confirmation, when we closed the tunnel vent valve back to LM/CM DELTA-P, we were reading about 1.7 - 1.75, and it slowly went up now to about - oh, I'd say a little less than 2.2. Seems to be holding there - Is there a lag in the gaging system?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We'll - we'll ask that question. Stand by.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, to answer your question, Jim, that increase in pressure is normal, because it was just tracking an increase in cabin pressure.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: We're not thinking today.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, 13, from Houston, it's okay with us if you want to move the 02 fuel cell purge and the water dump up to this time. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. We'll work it in shortly. Thank you.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Right.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jim, recommend you stay in the PTC until we stop it for the TV at 55 hours, in case you were thinking of - -

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Recommend you continue PTC until 55 hours. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: You were calling, Houston?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmed, Jim. How do you read now?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. We read you loud and clear.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. The only comment that we just made was that, in case you were thinking of stopping PTC, there's no need to stop it until 55 GET when TV starts.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Right. We'll stop it when we're setting up our TV.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Houston, the waste water dump and 02 fuel cell purge are complete.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Houston. Roger.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Houston, the LM/CM DELTA-P is constant. We're going to go ahead with hatch removal.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Houston. Roger.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Is that you. Jack?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: No, this is Jack's replacement.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Houston; 13.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Houston, go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead, 13.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Houston, Apollo 13.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: This is Houston. Go ahead, 13.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Houston; Apollo 13.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Go ahead, 13.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. The LMP has entered the LM.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Is that Big John?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: It sure is. How're you doing?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Fine.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes, you're doing great, man.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Thank you. I had a good CDR.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: You're doing it on your own now.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes, it feels like I'm back at home, again, John, down in here.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: I hope you did a good job, John.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Houston, we want to take the FM and bring up TV here for our own use. Then we'll go to TRANSMIT 1 - at 55 hours.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, 13.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Houston, we've transferred to LM power; the time was 54 hours 46 minutes 15 seconds.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, Jack. Transfer to LM power. Thank you.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: And the docking-tunnel index, Jack, was minus 2 degrees.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Say again, Fred, you're coming in with a lot of background noise.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. The docking-tunnel index mark was minus 2 degrees.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Minus 2 degrees.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Jack, how do you read?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Fred, Houston is reading you loud and clear.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. I've got up through step 7 now, and I'm not getting much of a light in the helium indicator here. Why don't I review for you how we've proceeded, and you look at the procedure you gave me, and see if we've missed anything.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. We transferred to LM power and that looked okay. I'm staring at a CAUTION AND WARNING POWER light, and all the red flags; and we got both X LUNAR BUS TIE breakers IN. The UTILITY LIGHTING breaker is IN; then AC BUS B HELIUM PQS DISPLAY; the AC BUS B NUMERIC LIGHTING, and AC BUS B INVERTER 1 is - BUS TIE is CLOSED. Then I closed the INVERTER 1 breaker, and I've selected, on panel 16, and the SIGNAL C0NSENS0R breaker is in; I've selected INVERTER 1 and put the HELIUM MONITOR switch to SUPERCRIT and I have no lights.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Fred, let us take a look at it.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: I was wondering, do we need an A - do we need, possibly, in the - one of the ANUN/D0CK/ COMPONENT breakers in?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Stand by 1.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. Hold the phone. I forgot the rheo- stat was cranked all the way down on the ANUN/ NUM and it's shoving 720, which looks like a pretty good - pretty good number.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. We copy 720. Thank you, Fred - -

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Flashed to 7 - Okay, and it just flickered down to 710. It's kind of flickering between 710 and 720.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. 710 to 720.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Fred. Those are good numbers, and we're not going to have to crank up the TM. That's the number we were looking for. 02 06 52 26 IMP Very good. Okay. Do you want me to back out of this in reverse at least as far as getting this part of it powered down?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Stand by 1.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Fred, this is Houston. Go ahead and back out of this little test and proceed.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. We're back on CSM power. The time was 54 hours 58 minutes 50 seconds.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, Jack. 54:58:50. Thank you.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Houston, we'll try to pick you up on the high gain.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, 13, we're ready on the TV when you are.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: This is 13. Say again, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, we're ready on the TV when you are. Any time.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, sounds good. With you in a minute, we're just cranking up high gain now.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Houston. How do you read us in the high gain?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We're hearing you 5 square, Jim, how me?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. You're coming through okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: As you were on that, Jim. We don't have you on high gain yet. We're still looking at you.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. In this attitude, we'd suggest pitch 5, yaw 237 on the high gain. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Pitch 5, yaw 237. Roger.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. Can you - can you read the high gain now?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Affirmative, Jack. We've got you on a high gain and it appears to us that we're in wide beam - wide beam width.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Yes. We can't get it to come down to narrow. We tried to switch to AUTO track or REACQ, and it - yaw drives around from 270 to 0. And pitch goes from about 6 degrees around to 90. I'm trying - we're fitting it manual now at the angles that you gave us, and I'll try and get you in medium and narrow beam widths picking it up manually here.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, Jack. Meanwhile, we'll look at the situation you describe there.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. And it does it on both sets of servo electronic power.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Jack, what it looks like is that, when we hit 239 degrees at this attitude, it hit some sort of scan limit or something and drops off.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, Jack; thank you.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, I'm trying you in wide or medium beam width now.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Can you pick up the TV in this condition here at all?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Negative, Jack. We'll have to have the narrow beam width.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Can you give us, maybe, a slight maneuver?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jack, we'd like you to check two high gain circuit breakers down in panel 25. Check your high gain group 2 and your high gain in the flight bus. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Okay, Jack, they're both IN.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, we've got an attitude suggestion for you. We suggest that you go to roll 285 and try pitch 90 and yaw 0. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Houston; Apollo 13. I think we've got high gain locked up now. Do you confirm?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We confirm that, Jim, we've got you locked up on the high gain and narrow beam.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, sounds good. We'll get the TV started right away.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. We'd like to disable quads C and D; use Alfa and Bravo. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay - -

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: - - Disable quads C and D. Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, 13. We've got Fred-o on TV.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger, Houston. What we plan to do for you today is start out in the space shipper [sic] Odyssey, and take you on through from Odyssey in through the tunnel into Aquarius. And show you a little bit of the landing vehicle, and your TV operator is now resting on the center couch, looking at Fred Haise, whose head is now just about at the beginning of the tunnel, and his back is against the lower-equipment-bay optical area. And Fred will now transport him- self into the tunnel, and into the spaceship Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: You know one thing I noted. Jack, when I first came across here, that starting upright in the command module and heading down in Aquarius , there's a little bit of an orientation change that, even though I'd been through it once in the water tank, it still pretty unusual. I find myself, now, standing with my head on the floor when I get down inside the LM.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's a great picture, Jim. You got the light just right.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: And one of the nice things, Jack, particularly for a novice like myself, is the - the ease of moving around in here. It's, of course, as you know from working in the command module simulator, it's really quite a boon to have zero gravity as an aid. Because you get - pretty confining, really, at one g, to move around very much in there, and it's quite easy in this environment. The LM, as you can see, it looked pretty clean, I found a couple of loose washers about it and the - a little plastic cap off the sequence camera had come loose and I found it lodged over by the ED panel. Okay. Right under Jim, now, he's actually standing on a - what looks to be a can here. And, for the sake of all the people back there, housed inside this can is the - the LM ascent engine where, hopefully, you can see my hand resting on top of right now - the engine that we use to get off of the Moon. Immediately adjacent to the engine cover here, I have my hand on a white box now, which has been shown before. This happens to be Jim's PLSS, or the backpack which'll supply oxygen and water for cooling while on the lunar surface. This device we hope to make use of for - a planned 4 hours and possibly up to as much as 5 hours. Right - right behind the PLSS, a couple of little square packages I now have my hand on here, one here and one right below, are our OPSs, which are, in essence, the emergency oxygen supplies, which are good for some 40 to 45 minutes. These are - when we get ready to mount up and head outside, will be placed up on top of the PLSS.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: The second backpack is mounted down on the LM floor, I hope, positioned right between the two of us. I have my hand on it at this time.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, Fred. We see it. The picture's coming through real good, and your description is good. We see Jim's got the camera oriented the way we like to look at it. So, keep talking.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. I guess everybody has pretty much envisioned the space program as being all a lot of exotic electronics, and, certainly, a lot of it is. But I thought I'd bring out a couple of items here in conjunction with the PLSS. After the first EVA, you get a very accurate measure- ment of the amount of water that's left in the PLSSs. We're going to make use of this bag I'm showing now to collect the remaining water out of the PLSS and see just how much we really did have left, and hopefully, on future missions, to be able to extend safely the allowable time on these units even a little further. And, my other hand, I have the mechanism by which we determine just how much water we really have in this bag. And I guess this - an apt description for this device would be a fish scale. And you can see I'm weighing myself right now, and it says I weigh actually less than zero right now. Guess its calibration isn't too good.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That'll be the day.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: I think even you'd weigh zero here, Jack.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Touche.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, this is Jim. Since Fred's been in the lunar module, and since he's the lunar module pilot, this is the first time that he's felt that he's been right-side up.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I might tell you that we're looking at right now, that round bag that's just behind Fred holds our vacuum hose; and when we get back inside the LM we'll hook the vacuum off our suits, and it's resting or it's attached to the hatch which will - we will open to go on to the lunar surface, and, of course, to come back in. The hatch which we have come to now is a round hatch, which is our docking hatch between the - between Odyssey and Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, and we see Fred looking in the vacuum cleaner there now.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, what I have out now. Jack, is LEVVA, has also been shown before. It's a head garmen.. for wearing out on the surface, and I - I'm bringing Jim's out here to show a couple of MODs. One problem before is that the cast of characters down on the surface haven't been able to be distinguished apart very well. So, not only Jim's suit has some red stripes on it, but as you can see his LEVVA also has a - a red stripe. And now you can see one other MOD here too. Jack. which I hadn't really seen myself before. I guess on 12, Pete and Al had commented about the - commented about having trouble with sunlight in the eyes , so on our LEVVAs they put on a new center section which you can pull down and use sort of like a baseball cap.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. Who fixed up our LEVVAs?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: How's the detail on this one. Jack?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Say again, Fred.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Can you see any detail in this picture now, or am I blocking out too much of the sunlight?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative. We've got a good picture of the LEVVA there, and it's coming through loud and clear.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Jack, while Fred is putting away my helmet, you are looking over into Fred's station now. How's this picture, is it okay before - or do I have to adjust it?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We have a hunch that the setting might be in PEAK but we recommend AVERAGE on the ALC if you haven't got it there already.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: We're in AVERAGE, Jack.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. And we're getting a good picture of the LMP side with the DEDA over there.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Hey, Jack, one question on the command module here. Do I - l have the DAP right now 'wide deadband. Do you want me to begin setting up nar deadband and nulling the rates to start PTC a-

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Stand by, Jack.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: What I'm fishing out now, Jack, is another new piece of hardware that we are taking along this time as a result of some comments made on the Apollo 12 flight.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: What Fred is opening up - is a drink bag that we place inside of our neckring that will allow us to drink while we are on the lunar surface. They - Pete and Al - did not have that on Apollo 12 and they, consequently, got very thirsty. But we hope to alleviate that situation by having our own little bag of water which, with very little effort, we can have a sip or two while we are looking around and doing our geology work.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: So if you hear any funny noises, it is just probably the drink bag.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Fred, the bag's empty.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Fred is now looking through our optical device. It's an instrument in which to aline our platform, and Fred is now looking into it just to see what kind of an outside picture he might be able to get. We might be able to use a TV camera to look through our optical instrument to the outside of the command module. A few minutes ago while we first came in, we did manage to look to the outside of the side hatch of the command module through our optical instrument. Stand by. We'll try to see what we can do here.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, Jim. Break, Jack, we'd like you to stay in the deadband you are now in, and we'll make a change when the TV is over. Another thing we would like you to do is check your pitch and yaw on your high gain meter so we can compare it with what we're seeing down here.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, it's showing about - say 28 degrees and 267.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack, have you got that picture now?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Fred, about one-quarter of our screen in lighted, and it's impossible to determine what you arce looking at right now. Maybe you could give us a little verbal description.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. It's looking through the A0T in position 4, right rear. And we're looking back toward the - over the side hatch at the aft side of the service module.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Is - is it too dark a picture. Jack? You think the f-stop open may help?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: No, Fred, it's got to be centered up a little bit. That's primarily what you have to do.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Jack, we can't center it up any more, because the side hatch is only one part of the A0T. The rest of that blackness you see is really space.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. We'll try another one, and it's a little better centered. In fact, the only other one we have that shows the whole picture. We're in the forward D-10 of the AOT now, position 2, and you should be seeing something familiar like a radar antenna.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, we see you moving the camera up to the AOT lens, and we got a real good picture now.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And -

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack, I'm looking out the right window now, and not too far off in the distance now, you can see the objective, and I'll zoom in on it here a little and see if it brings it in better.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: And it's actually beginning to look a little bigger now. You can see quite distinctly some of the features with the naked eye. And so far, I guess I have to even agree with Jim that it's still looking pretty gray with white spots.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Fred. We're getting a good picture of your destination there.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Jack, you've been looking at the - at Fred's workshop now, and you can see the abort guidance computer. And over there on the - tucked away in his armrest, is our activation checklist, which we'll be using very shortly. Up on the top of the window, we have our camera already mounted ready for photographing the descent. And now Fred's engaged in his favorite pastime, I found out on this flight so far.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: He's not in the food locker, is he?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: That's his second favorite pastime. He's rigging his hammock for sleep on the lunar surface now to find out - to see what it's going to be like.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Sleeping and then eating.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: It's kind of difficult here. Jack, getting into a hammock in zero g. I'm not sure if I keep floating away from it or it keeps moving away from me.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: If you notice a few things floating around, we found just about one or two washers occasionally.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: And for the benefit of those that may wonder where Jim sleeps. Be a little difficult to rig his hammock in here right now with the hatch open, but his runs laterally in this direction, fore aft. So he has the upper berth and I get the lower berth.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And now while Fred's taking his hammock down and restowing it, I might give you some idea of what sort of confusion of attitudes since there is no up or down, and I'm situated on top of the ascent engine just at the entrance to the tunnel. I'll reverse the camera 180 degrees and go from Fred, look through the tunnel again back at Odyssey, and we might pick up part of Jack.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: There he is. We see him.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Houston. For the benefit of the television viewers, we've just about completed our little inspection of Aquarius, and now we're proceeding through the hatchy-gap into the tunnel and going back toward the Odyssey.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. It's been a great show so far.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And finally, Jack'n let me back into [???] Odyssey as we slide on through the tunnel here.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, 13. Are you still on TV?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes, we sure are. We've got a good picture of the skipper there.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. What we can show you now, a little added benefit, we've got the drogue on Fred's couch in the command module right now. We stowed it temporarily while we're checking out the - out Aquarius and underneath his couch, we've got the probes stowed. Quite a big cumbersome device, and we'll get a shot of it for you.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: You're looking now at our probe, the place on the nose of Odyssey. It's a very heavy thing but I suppose in zero gravity it weighs nothing, and it's much easier to move around. As a matter of fact, both Fred and Jack commented, as many people in the past have, of how much bigger the spacecraft appears in actual flight when you have such ease in moving compared to our simulator which make training rather difficult.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We're seeing a good picture of the probe there, Jim, and looks like the characters shaved before the show this time.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Well, Fred said he had to keep up his TV image.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes. That may be my first and last time though. Jack.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: It took Fred 1 hour to shave.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: We might give you a quick - a quick shot of our entertainment on board the spacecraft, which has been keeping us company for some time. 02 07 43 57 (Music - Willow Weep For Me)

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: This little tape recorder has been a big benefit - has been a big benefit to us in passing some of our time away on our transit to the Moon, and it's rather odd to see it floating like this in Odyssey while it's playing the theme from "2001." And, of course, the tapes wouldn't be complete without "Aquarius."

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. We're seeing the tape recorder now, and just - by the way, how long do you expect to keep the TV on this evening?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Well, when we - Stand by 1.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes, I got them with the cabin repress valve again there, Jack.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Every time he does that our hearts - our hearts jump in our mouth. And, Jack, any time you want to terminate TV, we're all set to go.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. It's been a real good TV show. We think we ought to conclude it from here now. What do you think?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger. Sounds good. And this is the crew of Apollo 13 wishing everybody there a nice evening, and we're just about ready to close out our in- spection of Aquarius and get back for a pleasant evening in Odyssey. Good night.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Thank you, 13.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston. The next thing we'd like you to do is to - -

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: - - we'd like you to roll right to 060 and null your rates for photography of the Comet Bennett. To do that, we would like you to enable quads C and D. For the maneuver, use all your quads. And in precisely 1 minute, we'd like you to terminate the battery charge on battery B. One other request, we'd like to have you verify - -

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Will do.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: One other request, we'd like you to verify your high gain configuration. We'd like to know what track mode, what SERVO, and what beam width.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack, during the TV, we were AUTO TRACK, NARROW BEAM WIDTH, and the PRIMARY ELECTRONICS. And we had a good lockup. Just after we started the maneuver, I was able to lock you up and get real good signal strength, and it just seemed that right there at about 239 degrees in yaw, that the signal strength would just drop off and yaw would go to zero and pitch would go to 90.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. We copy, and the TV show was great.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, real fine. Okay, I'm going to maneuver to 060, 090, and 0.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, 13, we'd like you to check C-4 thruster.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. The battery charge has been terminated on the battery B.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. We see it, Jack. And we got a reading of minus 2 degrees on the docking index. We'd like to know it that's 2.0 precise or if it's 2.1 or 1.9.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: No. It's a minus 2.0 precisely.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Thank you.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, we've got one more item for you, when you get a chance. We'd like you to stir up your cryo tanks. In addition, I have shaft and trunnion - -

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: - - for looking at the Comet Bennett, if you need it.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Stand by.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Houston - -

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I believe we've had a problem here.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: This is Houston. Say again, please.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, we've had a problem. We've had a MAIN B BUS UNDERVOLT.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. MAIN B UNDERVOLT.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, stand by, 13. We're looking at it.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Right now, Houston, the voltage is - is looking good. And we had a pretty large bang associated with the CAUTION AND WARNING there. And as I recall, MAIN B was the one that had had an amp spike on it once before.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, Fred.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: In the interim here, we're starting to go ahead and button up the tunnel again.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes. That jolt must have rocked the sensor on - see now - 0^ QUANTITY 2. It - was oscillating down around 20 to 6O percent. Now it's full- scale high again.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And, Houston, we had a RESTART on our computer and we had a PGNCS light and the RESTART RESET.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. RESTART and a PGNCS light. RESET on a PGNCS, RESET - -

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. And we're looking at our S - SERVICE MODULE RCS HELIUM 1. We have - B is barber poled and D is barber poled, HELIUM 2, D is barber pole, and SECONDARY PROPELLANTS, I have A and C barber pole. BMAG temperatures?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, AC 2 is showing zip. I'm going to try to reconfigure on that, Jack.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes. We got a MAIN BUS A UNDERVOLT now, too, showing.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: MAIN A UNDERVOLT.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: It's reading about 25-1/2, MAIN B is reading zip right now.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And, Houston, Odyssey.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Stand by 1, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. We'd like you to attempt to reconnect fuel cell 1 to MAIN A and fuel cell 3 to MAIN B. Verify that quad Delta is open.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Houston. I'm showing - I tried to reset and fuel cell 1 and 3 are both showing gray flags, but they are both showing zip on the flows.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We copy.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Houston. Are you still reading 13?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative. We're reading .you. We're tryinp to come up with some good ideas for you.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Let me give you some reading ... in the interim to help MAIN A voltage. Jack. I've got BUS TIE AC on.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Say again, Fred.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: In the interim, to help out MAIN A voltage, I've got MAIN BUS TIE BAT AC on. Or would you rather accept the 25 volts we are seeing on MAIN A?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. BUS TIE AC on.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. We need OMNI Charlie, please.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: You got it.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. We'd like you to verify couple of readings for us. We would like the nitrogen pressure on fuel cell 1. We need the oxygen pressure on fuel cell 2.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Nitrogen on 1 and oxygen on 2. Is that correct?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Negative. Oxygen on 3.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. The systems test 1-A says zip.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: And 2 Baker, which is 3 oxygen, says 0.6.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 2 Baker says 0.6, and say again the other one.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Fuel cell 1 nitrogen reads zero.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Zero.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. We'd like you to open circuit fuel cell 1; leave 2 and 3 as is.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. I'll get to work on that.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And, Jack, our O2 quantity number 2 tank is reading zero. Did you get that?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 02 QUANTITY number 2 is zero.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: That's AC, okay. Yes, that's good AC and it looks to me, looking out the hatch, that we are venting something. We are venting something out into the - into space.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. We copy your venting.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: It's a gas of some sort.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Fuel cell 1, you just wanted it off the line now. Jack, is that right?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We just wanted you to open the circuit on fuel cell 1.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. She's off the line.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. We see you getting close to gimbal lock there. We'd like you to bring up all quad Cs on MAIN A, quad C-l, C-2, C-3, C-4 on MAIN A, and also bring B-3 and B-4 up on MAIN A.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. Do you read?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes. We got it.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Affirm.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Can you tell us anything about the venting, where it is coming from, what window you see it at.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: It's coming out of window 1, right now, Jack, and could you give me the thrusters again?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, the thrusters - -

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: What buses?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We'd like - on MAIN A, we'd like Charlie 1, 2, 3, and 4. Also Bravo 3 and 4 on MAIN A.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Got it.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, we need OMNI Bravo.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: 0MMI Bravo.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, 13; this is Houston. We'd like you to to your G&C checklist, the pink pages, 1-5. To powerdown until we get a Delta of 10 amps. Over.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: All right. Roger.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Jack, say again that - ... for the power- down; it's not in the pink pages, the 1-5.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We'd like you to go down that powerdown procedure until you get a Delta of 10 amps. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger. ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. Did you copy our powerdown request?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Roger, Jack. We're - yes, we're doing it right now.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Where did you say that was located. Jack?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's in your systems checklist, page 1-5.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, 13, you might also check for those pages in your launch checklist. They're emergency pages; pink pages, 1-5, and we'd like you to power down until you get - -

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. That was in the launch checklist, Jack.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Power down until you get an amperage of 10 amps less than what you got now. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Jack. Are you happy with the amps we have now?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Stand by 1, Fred.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack, and on this page 1-5, we proceeded right down the list, all the way down; we're right now at BMAG number 2 is in WARM UP.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. We copy BMAG 2 in WARM UP. We'll follow you through.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, and something is giving us a reach. Jack, both in pitch and roll, so I'm suspecting that maybe it's whatever it is that's venting back there. I've had to use DIRECT in order to stabilize this, and as soon as I do, we're starting to pick up rates again. Can you pick up any jets firing?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Stand by. What direction are your rates in. Jack?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: It's negative pitch and negative roll.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. We need to get some more instrumentation up. We'd like you to put INVERTER 1 on both AC BUSES. Over.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Okay, you got INVERTER 1 on both AC BUSES now. And Jack, one of the items that we turned off was the - all the fuel cell pumps. Okay, and you might let us know when fuel cell 2 needs its pump back; we ought to take care of that guy.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Okay, Fred, we want FUEL CELL 2 PUMPS to ACl, please.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: FUEL CELL 2 to ACl. Roger.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, it's on ACl.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: OMNI Charlie, please, 13.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: OMNI Charlie.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, 13. We've got lots and lots of people working on this; we'll give you some dope as soon as we have it, and you'll be the first one to know.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Oh, thank you.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack, and the weird configuration we're sitting in now is we have the hatch installed, we still have the probe and drogue inside the command module, and we're going to stay in this situation until you - kind of give us an okay to reinstall the probe and drogue.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. We'll give you an answer.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Or, if necessary, to use the LM consumables.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, we'd like to have you put thrustsr Alfa 3 on MAIN A, please.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Alfa 3 on MAIN A.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack, are you monitoring the quad temps in quad A - package temps?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Affirmative.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, this is Houston. We'd like to power down just a little bit more, so let's get BMAG 2 OFF; and make sure your lights are down. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. The lights are down, and BMAG 2's going from STANDBY to OFF.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston - -

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack, now I've got a rate -

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: - - we'd like you to open circuit fuel cell 3.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Open circuit fuel cell 3.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead, Jack.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, fuel cell 3 is off the line now.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And 13, Houston. We'd like you to turn all your Bravo thrusters OFF; and put all your Delta thrusters on MAIN A, please.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: All Delta thrusters on MAIN A and all Bravo thrusters OFF. Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. Turn BATTERY A OFF - -

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Jack, ...

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: That's right; we were pulling current all the time.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: BATTERY A OFF. Roger.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Now you're ... up.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I'm transmitting. I don't have any current now.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Hey, it's off - it's off. They - they killed the bus completely now.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. We'd like you to isolate your 02 surge tank. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Surge tank off now. Jack? Okay, Jack, are you copying - 02 tank 1 cryo pressure?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative. And we're trying to get power to that tank. Stand by; we're working on it.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. We had a - SERVICE MODULE RCS B light. Jack, due to package temperature.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: SERVICE MODULE RCS B. We copy. No problem.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Let's read you the lights we got on now; CRYO PRESS, FUEL CELL 1, FUEL CELL 3, MAIN BUS B UNDERVOLT, SUIT COMPRESSOR.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, we copy them and we'd like to build up the pressure in 02 tank 1, so turn the heaters on manually; we'll watch the pressure for you.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, do you want to see - -

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: - - We're going to get a MAIN BUS A UNDERVOLT, probably.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. We realize that; we feel we can stand 5 more amps on it.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, heater on tank l's ON.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. We'd like you to additionally bring on the fans in 02 tank 1, and we can stand the additional amperage on that.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay - bring up the fans on 02 tank l.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. We'd like you to check some circuit breakers on panel 226. CRYO O2 HEATER number l MAIN A, and check the three CRYO FAN MOTORS, TANK l, three phases.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. 226 is configured just like it should be. I got three REACS breakers and three RAD breakers open. All the rest are closed.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Fred. Thank you.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Jack, looking outside, the number of particles has diminished greatly, almost ceased now, which indicates maybe what was venting has almost stopped.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, Jack. Thank you. We copy.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: I'm still getting some rates in negative pitch, though.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, 13, we'd like to verify that both BMAGs are off, please.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Negative. We just have one BMAG. BMAG number 1 is still on.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. Let's take BMAG 1 off.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. BMAG number 1 off now.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, this is Houston. We'd like you to give us a survey of your displays on MDCs 1 and 2. Give us gage readings and talkbacks. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. We'll start with display number 1.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. On MDC 1, there's nothing abnormal. All the rate indicators are zero. Ball number 2 is frozen, of course; we lost MAIN B. I've got - Ball number 1 appears to be working normally. Right now I'm sitting at roll 0, pitch 180, and yaw about 13 degrees. I'm going to try and hold 0, 180, and 0.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Houston. The center panel - I'm looking at the RCS indicator A. We have a package temperature of about 180. Our helium pressure is 3900. I'm looking at fuel pressure of about 180 and percentage of about, I'd say 85 percent. B is about the same, except that that package pressure is 190. On quad C, we're looking about the same, except that the package temperature is 100. On quad D, we're looking at package temperature of 160. All other indications are about the same. CM pressure - RCS pressure is looking nominal. Helium pressure's up around 4000. And package temperature is about - a little less than 80 on ring 1 and about the same on ring 2.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And the - talkbacks on the SM RCS, I've not HELIUM 1 now are all gray. HELIUM 2 are all gray. PRIMARY PROPELLANT all gray. SECONDARY PROPELLANT, I've got two barber pole, and A is barber pole, B gray, C barber pole, and D gray. Okay. On the ECS RADIATORS, barber pole is gray. 0n the - On the ECS, PRIMARY INDICATOR.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. Starting at the top. Okay. The CRYO TANKS; H2 1 is reading 230 and the same for 2. Our 02 CRYO TANK l is - looks like it's barely holding its own at 300. And, CRYO TANK 2 is reading zip. Our quantities: H2 1 is reading 73; 2, 74. On the Og side, we're reading O2 1 at quantity, 76; Og 2 pegged to full scale high. RAD TEMPs PRIMARY INLET, we're reading about 55; RAD OUT is reading about 30, and the SECONDARY OUTLET is reading - reading 52 degrees. And the EVAP OUT TEMP is 45, STEAM PRESSURE 0.17, and GLYCOL DISCHARGE 48. SUIT COMPRESSOR is reading zip. The ACCUM is reading 30; H2O WASTE is reading about 34; POTABLE'S reading about 98; SECONDARY RAD INLET is reading about 71; and the RAD OUT is about 30; GLYCOL EVAP TEMP is reading 65, STEAM PRESSURE pegged full scale high; DISCHARGE PRESSURE 9 psi.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Excuse me, Fred; I'd like to butt in here a min- ute. We'd like to have THRUSTER C-1 off.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: C-1 is off.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And proceed - -

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay - -

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: - - my last copy is SECONDARY RAD IN.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Your SECONDARY RAD IN, I gave to you 70 - about 72 degrees; the RAD OUT is about 30; the GLYCOL EVAP TEMP is reading about 65; STEAM PRESSURE full scale high, GLYCOL DISCHARGE PRESlSURE about 9 psi. The ACCUM - SECONDARY ACCUMULATOR is about 30 - 34 percent. Our temperatures: SUITS showing about 52 degrees; CABIN about 58 degrees; pressures, SUIT reading 4.1, CABIN at 5. PARTIAL PRESSURE CO2 is up to little over l, about l.l. On the SPS side of the house, the temperature is 72 degrees, helium's reading 3500; A is reading 2300; N2 B about 2450. And our ullage pressures: FUEL is reading about 165; OXIDIZER 170. Fuel cells: FUEL CELL 1, both CLOSED, they're zip; SKIN TEMP 405 degrees; CONDENSE EXHAUST is lower scale. FUEL CELL 2 - right now we've got an O2 or an H2 FLOW reading of 0.13 to 0.14, and the O2 FLOW is right now pegged full scale high although it has been varying depending on thruster activity which has also given us MAIN BUS A under volts from a steady reading of about 1.1 up to full scale high. The Tskin is about 445 and the CONDENSOR EXHAUST 17, correction, 180. Let's see if you want it on the DC indicator: FUEL CELL 1 is 0 amps; 2 is reading somewhere between 44 and about - oscillating 44 to 48 again depending on thruster activity.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Stand by.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: - - is 0 amps. Say again, Jack.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, 13.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Hello, Houston; Apollo 13. How do you read?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, 13. This is Houston. It appears to us that we're losing O2 flow through fuel cell 3. So, we want you to close the REAC valve on fuel cell 3. It looks like fuel cell 1 and 2 are trying to hold up okay. You copy?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Are you saying fuel cell 1 and 2-1 and 2 are trying to hold up but we're leaking O2 out of fuel cell 3? And you want me to shhut the REAC valve on fuel cell 3? Did I hear you right?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative. Close the REAC valve on fuel cell 3.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. I'll go to the SSR page. Do you want me to go through that whole smash for fuel cell shut- down? Is that correct?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Stand by.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, 13. We want you to turn the inline heaters off on fuel cell 1. Then we want you to go through the fuel cell shutdown procedure on fuel cell 3. Read back.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Shut down the inline heater on fuel cell 1. We're proceeding with the shutdown, special subroutine, for fuel cell 3.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13. OMNI Bravo, please.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. You got OMNI Bravo and we'd like to have you verify that the tape recorder is off please.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: That's verified. Okay, Jack. I'm sitting here with an 0618 showing and I can't get rid of it. Oh, stand by just a - -

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Fuel cell 3 REACs off, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, Jim. Thank you.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. Step 2, special subroutine 1 for the fuel cell procedure, has been completed.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Thank you.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Jack. I'd like to bring on jet A-4 I've got null on negative pitch control, and - negative pitch control, and right now neither DIRECT or AUTO coils.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. You say no pitch in either DIRECT or AUTO? You want to bring on A-4?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Yes. I've got a positive pitch rate and I can't stop it.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. Bring A-4 on; stop the pitch rate.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. That got it.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, 13, we need OMNI Charlie, please.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: OMNI Charlie.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, Fred, we would like to have you verify fuel pell reactants talkback is barber pole.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: That's affirm. I watched it and it went barber pole as I threw the switch.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Jack. Let me give you a thruster config- uration right now. Able 1, Charlie 1, Able 2 are off. Charlie 2, MAIN A, all the thrusters that I call that are on are on MAIN A. Baker 1 off. Dog 1 on. Baker 2 off. Dog 2 on. Able 3, Charlie 3, Able 4, Charlie 4 on. Baker 3 off. Dog 3 on. Baker 4 off. Dog 4 on.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. That thruster configuration looks pkay.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: All right. Okay. Do you want some readings from the systems test meter regarding fuel cells?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Stand by 1 on that. Jack. Let me ask the EEC0M.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: We've got some incompatibilities here.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, 13. We'd like to have you give us those systems test readings on fuel cell 1 and 3, please.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. 1 and 3 coming up.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Jack, 1-A is reading. Lower scale, 0; 1-B is reading 3.45. Okay. You only want fuel cells 1 and 3. Okay. Ignore that 1-B reading. 1-C is reading 3.4. Now, 1-D is reading 2.4. 2-D is reading 0.25.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Is that 2 Bravo, Fred?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: That's 2 Bravo is reading - oh, about 0.25 to 0.3.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. 2-C is reading 4.1.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: And 3-A is reading 4.0.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. 4.0. Say again what it is, please.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: 3 Able, 3-A.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: 3-B is reading 1.8.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: And 3-D is reading 1.95.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: And, Houston, 13. O2 tank pressure number 1 is less than 300 now.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. We're seeing that. We confirm it.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. We're going to have to have you go through the shutdown procedure on fuel cell 1. Our 02 pressure is going down as you note and the temperature confirms it. Did you copy?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Well, what bus configuration - What main bus do you want powered?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. We want you to leave the bus configuration as it is. Fuel cell 2 on MAIN A, and we need OMNI Bravo.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. We're proceeding on the shutdown procedure for fuel cell 1.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, 13, Houston. We'd like you to isolate the REPRESS package, please.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Isolate the REPRESS package. Roger.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: 1 can confirm REPRESS package is off.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. So now you've got the REPRESS package and the surge tank isolated. Is that affirm?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: That is Charlie.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Now, this is - We're ready to close the REACs on fuel cell 1; is that right?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jack, stand by on the fuel - -

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: On that last - confirmation. Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. We're - We're giving you one last - -

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: We want to just get one last confirmation.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. We're getting that last confirmation. Stand by, please.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, 13. We verify that we want you to close down - shut down fuel cell 1, close REACs valve.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger - -

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: - - fuel cell 1; close the REACs valve.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Fuel - -

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: REACs valve on fuel cell 1 is closed.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. I can confirm step 2. The fuel cell shutdown procedure is complete for fuel cell 1.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, we recommend that you enable BD roll in the DAP. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Will do - -

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: BD roll in the DAP.

transcript.speaker: CC
