transcript.text: 13, Houston. We're working on the big dish now, so turn the HIGH GAIN POWER switch off, please.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. When we got the loud bang, we got also a restart. Did you copy that? Is - does GUIDO want anything, a VERB 74 or anything done with the CMC?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Stand by.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. We're ready with a VERB 74 now, please.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Coming down at you.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. It looks like 02 tank 1 pressure is just a hair over 200.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We confirm that here and the temperature also confirms it.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Does it look like it's still going down?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: It's slowly going to zero, and we're starting to think about the LM lifeboat.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Yes. That's what we're thinking about, too. You want me to do a quick P52? It kind of looks like - We've been talking it over, and it kind of looks like we'd probably aline our plats - LM platform with our platform and then power down the CM, and keep the LM powered up doing a DPS - whatever DPS burns you give us?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, we're not going to concern ourselves at the moment with a DPS burn. It's going to be some time before we'd get to that; but we're working on other procedures to give you, which will allow us to use the LM systems. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Real fine.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston. We'd like to charge battery A now.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Charge battery A. Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, Jack, in regard to your question about the P52 and LM platform, it's - There's no need to worry about that now. We wouldn't be using the LM platform for - until about 79 hours, so let's go as is on the platform for now. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. We understand.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: And, Jack, we've turned off the waste dump heater. If you're going to consider dumping any more waste water, we probably ought to do it while the duct is warm there.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Stand by, Jack.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. Let's keep the water; no need for a dump right now.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: All right.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. We see the PROP ISOL valve on RCS quad Charlie closed, so we'd like to also disable AUTO RCS feature in quad Charlie.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: You want to isolate the AUTO RCS features in quad Charlie?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Affirmative.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. I didn't plan to reset that quad Charlie DROP ISOL valve. Do you want me to do that? Okay. We just tried it and quad Alfa and Charlie barber poles are showing.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Stand by, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. That's the sec - secondary propellant barber poles on Alfa and Charlie.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston. It won't do any good to try to power the propellant valves on A and C, so we want you to disable the AUTO on RCS Charlie. And we have a procedure for getting power from the LM we'd like you to copy down.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Stand by, Jack.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: That sounds like good news. 02 09 36 05 IMP Okay, Jack. About how long is it?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: It's not a very long procedure, Fred. We figure we've got about 15 minutes' worth of power left in the command module, so we want you to start getting over in the LM and getting some power on that. And, you ready to copy your procedure?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. In the CSM.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Stand by.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. In the CSM on panel 5, circuit breakers LM POWER 1 and 2, OPEN. Then LM POWER switch, reset and release. In the LM, on panel 11 and panel 16, TRANSLUNAR BUS TIE. Both circuit breakers CLOSE. On panel l6, circuit breaker ASCENT ECA CONTROL, CLOSE. On 16, DESCENT ECA CONTROL, CLOSE. On panel 14, put your BAT 5 NORMAL feed ON. BATs 1, 2, 3, and 4 LOW VOLTAGE taps, ON. BAT 5 NORMAL feed, OFF. ASCENT ECA CONTROL, OPEN. You copy?

transcript.speaker: LMP

Then ASCENT ECA CONTROL breaker OPEN.

The only advantage doing it early is you can do a big burn now and a midcourse and then power the LM down. Otherwise, we got to keep the LM powered up clear until we get around the Moon. Plus it would be inside on the burn. I just hope the G&N hangs up on - hangs in on this one - I'd sure hate to do that one manual.

transcript.text: Okay, Aquarius. We also have the 14 backup crew over in the simulators looking at dock burns and also trying to see what kind of alinement procedures they can come up with for looking at stars out the window. So if you ever are able to see any stars out there and think you can do an alinement out the window, why let us know.

transcript.text: Okay. Jack, right now we're not able to. transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative. We'd like to correlate the information we get with your's, so that if we can use it to update the platform, we can. What we're really trying to do, Jim, is see if we can do a COAS aline so we can power down the platform.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Fred, go to DESCENT 02.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: DESCENT 02. Roger.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Hello, Houston; Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Hello there, Aquarius. How do you read me now?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Hello, Houston. Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Go.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. That's the first clear word we heard from you, Jack. Do you think it could be my pitch attitude that's breaking up your incoming? I guess you've been hearing us.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We have been hearing you, and the problem is on the ground. I hope we have it corrected now.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. That sounds good.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We 're considering powering down the PGNS but we want to know what capability you have to do a coarse and fine aline. We read your conversation about being unable to see out the window very good. How about out the ACT?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: He's looking now.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. And the other thing we thought you might try is to put the service module between you and the Sun and then to see if you can see anything out the window in that attitude.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: The reason that we think that that would work is that it worked on Apollo 10. It made the constellations all recognizable when we put the the service module - in our case a LM, between us and the Sun.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: AFT OMNI, Fred.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: You're down in the mud again. Jack. It appears that some other circuit is feeding through on there with you.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. AFT 0MNI.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, AFT OMNI.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. You're down in the mud again. Jack. Lots of background static.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: AFT OMNI, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Houston; Aquarius. How do you read?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. How do you read?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Hello, Houston; Aquarius. How do you read?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Hello, there, Aquarius. Loud and clear. How me, now?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, we're reading you loud and clear, Jack. I hope it stays this time.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We'd like to brief you on what our Plan is. We're, at this time, water critical in the LM. So we'd like to use as little as possible. To do this, we're going to plan to make a free- return maneuver of l6 feet per second at 6l hours, which is 37 minutes from now. Then we're going to power down the PGNS, and then we'll - at 79 hours, we'll go ahead and make .another abort maneuver to kick what we got. But we'd like to get that PGNS powered down as soon as possible. That would be after the midcourse and - so how do you feel about making a l6-foot-per-second burn in 37 minutes?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Well, we'll give it a try. Jack, if that's all we've got. That's a l6-foot-per-second DPS burn in 37 minutes?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. We're working up a pad for it, but we'd want to know what you think about doing it at that time.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Well, we'll do it. Could you give us a little bit more time?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. We'd like to get a suggested time from you. We can figure out a free-return maneuver for any time you want to give us, so if you'll give us the time you'd like to shoot for, we'll figure out a pad.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, that sounds good. I think if we have a little bit more time; we want to do it right. Stand by 1.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Let's shoot for an hour if we can, Jack. How's that.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. How about 61 hours and 30 minutes? That's an hour and 5 from now.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. We'll do it and we want to be sure we talk back and forth now to make sure we get this burn off right.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Affirm.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, in the interim. Jack, I looked around again and I saw that we have a radar and a landing- radar heater breaker in. Can I pull those out?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Affirmative. Pull them both out.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And now we want to ask you a question about alinements, and so forth. We wanted to know if you can see any stars out of the AOT. We also wanted to know if you could use the service module to cast a shadow on the LM windows and then look out the windows to see stars for a P51 COAS alinement.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, in this attitude, Jack, that we're pitching around, I cannot use the AOT to see stars. We - we're just not able to see them at all. Now we may be able to maneuver off in yaw or - and/or roll and see stars. Right now, we haven't been able to. The AOT is useless. The command module structure is just radiating too much light into the - into the telescope.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, and how about using the service module to cast a shadow on the commander's window? If you do that, can you see stars for a COAS alinement?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: We could give that a try. Jack, although I don't know how successful it will be. We tried to do it - The light shines off our quads which makes it difficult to see stars. We do have the Earth and the Moon, if that can be of assistance.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Another problem - Right now, Jack, I'm looking out the right window and it's pretty dark out that window but there are about a thousand or so false stars out here from - left over from some of the debris. It's hard to discern what's real and not real.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. That's good information and during the time that we see you're continuing to pitch, if you ever get in a position where you think the AOT might be of some use, we'd like you to periodically look out of it and see if you can see some stars that would enable us to get a P52.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, will do. And also, let me ask you a ques- tion. In this configuration, docked, we have to use the TTCA to control pitch and roll. And, just how much can we use that without really changing our trajectory? We only have 60 miles to play with.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, we'll put that to them.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack, are you ready to go to work with me on the 2-hour DPS activation and contingency book, page 1?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, we're ready to go.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Item one, we can - one through five, we can scratch off, as done. Is that correct?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Stand by 1, Fred.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Fred, let's go ahead. Step 1, page 1. Everybody's listening.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, I've looked around, and I've essentially done steps 1 through 5 with the exception of floodlights and utility lights and I think we'll just do without those.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Your choice. 02 12 30 47 IMP Okay, on EPS activation, we're through step - we're through that - bottom of that page. That's all done.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We concur, page 2. 02 12 31 13 IMP Okay, in essence, we've circumvented step 4, and we're not sitting with all 4 aps - descent BATs on high-voltage taps, so I'll scratch off step 4.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, and in step 5, we want to leave INVERTER 1 circuit breaker OPEN.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Roger. In step 5, we'll leave INVERTER 1 CB OPEN.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Omit step 6.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, for the time being, our mission timer is the computer so, mission timer activation scratch off.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. 02 12 32 09 IMP Okay. We've done the primary glycol loop activation.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We verify it.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, we recommend you leave the caution and warning off on page 3.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. I was going to say that next. Page 3, we'll just scratch item 1. And item 2, I've already got the RCS heaters on. And I don't know if I gave you the time or you got the time on the PRIMARY EVAP FLOW number 1, OPEN.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We got the time.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Let's go to the CB pages now.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Fred-o, did you close the engine control breaker in panel 11?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: What control is that, Jack?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Did you close the S and C engine control breaker on panel 11? As we got step 1 there on page 3.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Okay, yes, the EPS DESCENT ECA CONTROL breaker is CLOSED on 11.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, and how about the - on panel 11, S and C ENGINE CONTROL, CLOSED? AFT OMNI, Fred.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. We're AFT OMNI, and we have the S and C ENGINE CONTROL breaker CLOSED.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Let's go on with the circuit breaker panel checkout.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. I'll just give you - I think it'll be easier to give you what I got in. Okay, in the top row on 11, we have the four AC BUS TIE breakers IN and the AC BUS VOLTS breaker IN, and that's it. Second row, we have the four TCA breakers IN. We have the GASTA under FLIGHT DISPLAYS and COMMANDER'S FDAI. And likewise under AC BUS A, we have a GASTA and a COMMANDER FDAI breaker IN. That's it. On row 3, we have a SIGNAL CONDITIONER 1. We have the ATCA (PGNS). We have the ENGINE CONTROL breaker, ATTITUDE DIRECT CONTROL breaker, and the - under LIGHTING, ANUN/DOCK/COMPONENT breaker IN. And one other, ED LOGIC POWER A - ED LOGIC POWER A is also IN.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Copy.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, under the fourth - fourth row, we got all the QUAD HEATER breakers IN, SUIT FAN 1. Under ECS, GLYCOL 1 and 2; and under COMM, we have COMMANDER AUDIO IN, and PGNSs LGC/DSKY, IMU STANDBY, IMU OPERATE, and that's it. Okay, in the bottom row, EPS, we have the BAT FEED TIE both IN, and we have the CROSS TIE BALANCE LOADS IN, the X LUNAR BUS TIE, DESCENT ECA CONTROL, DESCENT ECA, and the DC BUS VOLTs breaker.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. We copy. - -

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: That completes it for panel 11. Okay. Stand by. Okay. 02 12 36 54 IMP As I see it, some of the short ones are - we need the DECA GIMBAL in sooner or later.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmed. Close the DECA GIMBAL.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: And probably - Okay, DECA GIMBAL, and sooner or later, we're going to need DECA POWER, I guess, also.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: All right, DECA POWER will come up later in the procedure, Fred-o.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. On your circuit breaker checklist, on panel 11 and 16, we want you to configure the panels as outlined in the checklist.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. You want us to configure as per checklist. Okay. We'll do that.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's right. Close the black ones and open the white ones.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes. I think we can manage that.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: With the activation power up, we're starting right now.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, we might as well leave our RCS TCAs IN, right?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Affirmative, Jim. Leave your RCS TCAs in - -

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Check that - -

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: - -on panel 11. 02 12 40 30 IMP - - Yes. I used my Pentel pen and made those white ones black ones.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Same on 16, Fred.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And you might look there, Houston, to see what circuit breakers aren't required, like the tape recorder.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We're looking.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. On panel 11 over there, you can also leave open the RENDEZVOUS HEATER breaker and the LANDING RADAR HEATER breaker, in addition to the tape recorder.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: They're out.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: I'm leaving a few in, Jack, too, like the SUIT FAN 1 is still IN, RCS SYSTEM is still IN, the TCAs. ATTITUDE DIRECT CONTROL is IN.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: How about if I leave the VHF A and B OFF?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Switch to FORWARD OMNI.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We can leave the VHF powered down, too.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And, do you want the SECONDARY S-BAND?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Negative on SECONDARY S-BAND. Leave them open.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: UP DATA LINK is IN. Do you want that in or out?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Leave the UP DATA LINK open. We'll call for it when we want you to put it in.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack, on panel 11 on the top row, do you really want the PROPULSION PQGS and ASCENT HELIUM REGs in?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: And, also the SYSTEM ENGINEER X- POINTER breaker.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Negative on the PQGS. Negative on the ASCENT HELIUM REG, and negative on the CROSS- POINTER.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. On the second row, I'm going to leave the FLOODLIGHT breaker open..

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Concur.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: And we're again up to - Do you want the CWEA enabled?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Negative on the CWEA.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Since we're - are we going to power up the AGS or should I concern myself with the ATCA breaker?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Negative on the AGS. However, Fred, we need the ATCA breaker in. 02 12 46 28 IMP Okay. ATCA breakers IN. Yes. I guess for the backup power supply. Hey, how about ATCA AGS.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Negative on ATCA AGS.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: And I'm leaving the SUIT FLOW CONTROL breaker open.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Let's close the SUIT FLOW CONTROL breaker - -

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And, now ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: - - so it doesn't take any current.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Without suits, it doesn't do us much good either though.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. And are we going to continue to be able to operate off the OMNIs, Jack. So can I leave the S-band antenna powered down?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Fred-o. We don't plan to use the steerable antenna, although we want to leave the heaters on. So it looks you ought to open up COMM S-BAND ANTENNA, but leave S-BAND ANTENNA HEATERS closed.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Roger. COMM S-BAND is OPEN, S-BAND HEATER breaker is still CLOSED.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: And, on the bottom row, Jack, I'm going to leave the HEATER DISPLAY breaker out, which we had pulled before, and EPS DISPLAY. But I question, do we want the ASCENT ECA breaker in, as prescribed?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Stand by. That's a negative on the ASCENT ECA breaker. Leave it open.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, Aquarius, we need P00 and DATA - -

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And that's a - -

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: - - and we'll give you state vector and target load.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. We need the UP LINK breaker in then now.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. And, Jack, will you give us that - how about the ORDEAL breaker? Can I pull that? We don't need that, do we?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Negative on the ORDEAL. Leave it open.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: And how about the ASCENT ECA breaker on panel 11? Jim has it in over there.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And panel 11 ASCENT ECA can be open.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: It's open.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Aquarius. We're GO on the circuit breaker configuration as you have it now.

transcript.speaker: SC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, Aquarius, tests in the simulator just showed that if you want to let the PGNS DAP hold your attitude for you, it will.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, very well.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And, Jack, because it will take quite a while to get back to the attitude, I think we ought to think about going there very shortly.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. I have a pad for you. I have a P30 maneuver pad.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger. Stand by.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Go right ahead, Jack.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We want you to hold your maneuver until we finish making the load. We haven't completed it yet. Are you ready to copy P30 maneuver pad?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: That's affirm.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Here we go. The purpose is midcourse correction for free return. NOUN 33: 061:29:42.84; minus 0021.3, plus 0004.1, minus 0031.2; HA and HP are NA; DELTA-V 0038.0; 031, 120, 298, minus 00213, plus 00041, minus 00312; COAS NA. And I have your LM GDA angles. Pitch 5.86, roll 6.75. Your DPS throttling, 5 seconds at 10 percent, burn the rest at 40 percent. Your ullage will be two jets for 10 seconds.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack, we have a P30 maneuver pad, a mid- course for free return. NOUN 33: 061:29:42.84; minus 0021.3, plus 004.1, minus 0031.2; HA and HP N/A; DELTA-V. 0038.0; 031, 120, 298; minus 00213, plus 00041, minus 00312. COAS N/A; GDA angles; pitch 5.86, roll 6.75; DPS throttle 5 seconds at 10 percent; burn the rest at 40 percent. And we need a two-jet, 10-second ullage.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's a good readback, Fred. I'd like to verify, however, in NOUN 81, in Vy, it's plus three balls 41. 02 12 56 14 MP Okay. NOUN 81, Vy is plus 0004.1.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Good readback. Let's press on with the checklist.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. And, Jack, find out about using TTCA to maneuver with.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We're finished with the computer, it's yours, and we recommend using the TTCA to maneuver with.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, I'm back on the checklist, page 6. Jack, under PGNS turn-on and self-test. We've done everything except the self test here on this page. Do you want to do that at this time?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Aquarius, negative on the PGNS self test. Page 7.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. I'll scratch page 6 and on page 7, we're not going to activate the - or rather we had the S-band activated, ECS Activation I have all done. And, at the bottom of the page, the docked IMU coarse aline is done.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: We've - Okay, we've also completed, I guess in essence, all of page 8.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative and page 9 to boot. Scratch VHF. We've done the Tephems.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. You've updated it, that's right. We cranked in the time.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And, Houston, let's go to activation - or get into page 10 and see what we did there.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. The only item on page 10 is to deploy the landing gear.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, we'll do that now.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. The landing gear are down and locked, Jack, and looking ahead now at page 11, we've done all of that.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We verify that. Page 12.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, and I assume in amongst all those numbers you pumped up, we got a REFSMMAT and STATE VECTOR, is that correct?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative. You've got that. So you can delete page 12.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Hey, on 13, you've read us up the fine aline angles and we've cranked those in.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Affirmative.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, so now we're up to - we've got to do DAP set, the gimbal/throttle test.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's - Okay, Aquarius.. We recommend omitting the DAP set, gimbal/throttle test - Just make sure the gim - DECA POWER and DECA GIMBAL circuit breakers are closed.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, we're going to proceed now with the DAP set, gimbal/throttle test, is that correct? Or did you say delete it?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, delete the DAP set, gimbal/throttle test. Just ensure that the DECA POWER and the DECA GIMBAL are closed.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Houston, DECA POWER is OPEN at this time. Do you want me to close it?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Affirmative, Jim. Close the DECA POWER.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: It's CLOSED. We deleted that.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Also out of that list. Jack, we need the COMMANDER'S THROTTLE set to THROTTLE and MIN.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Houston, if I recall the launch set of the gimbals, the GDAs are not correct here, and where are we going to get those set for the burn?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Stand by 1.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Here's the word on the DAP set, gimbal/ throttle test. Let's do step 1 and step 2, and that'll get our gimbal set.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack, we're going to have to back up on this, if we're going to follow the procedure here, which has us go MODE CONTROL; PGNS, AUTO, we're going to have to pull the TCA breakers to keep from firing jets.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Stand by, Fred.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Stand by on step 1, Fred. We're getting the word for you. How do you like this SIM?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: It's a beauty.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Aquarius, we recommend you do the DAP set and gimbal/throttle test as per the checklist. Go PGNS AUTO and proceed.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Well, we're going to fire our thrusters as soon as we go to AUTO because we've got those thrusters in - the thruster circuit breakers. Do you want us to do that and stop?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Aquarius, we're recommending you go to AUTO. Let the thrusters fire and settle down and proceed with the test.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: We're in PGNS AUTO.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, your DAP is set, you're in wide deadband. That ought to do the trick.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, we're looking at it, Aquarius. We're ready to proceed with the test. 02 13 07 26 IMP Okay, we're proceeding. 02 13 07 52 IMP Okay, and Houston, you - you're looking at the weights now. Those are still good, right?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: You're GO on the weights.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. We'd like you to recycle on the DAP load and change your DAP to 32021. Over.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Aquarius. We're looking at your gimbal and we notice that we got a four-jet ullage loaded in the DAP and we gave you two jets on the pad. But, let's go with what we've got loaded. It'll be a four?jet ullage.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Houston. How does the GDAs look now?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: The GDAs are GO as they are. Press on.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Houston, we're going to do the DPS pressurization and checkout.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Standby 1.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, your gimbals are within 0.3 and we're ready for the DPS pressurization and checkout.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Houston, do you want to follow up on page 15 with RCS checkout? In essence, we've kind of already done that.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: You're right, Aquarius. Let's delete the RCS checkout. And a DPS looks GO.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, we're going to do a PGNS AUTO maneuver to the attitude.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Stand by on that. Aquarius, we recommend driving it around there manually with a TTCA.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, we'll have to use the TTCA. Roger.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: We're going to AUTO now, Houston, to try to damp the rates. We're at the attitude.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, Jim. We verify the attitude.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: And, Houston, we'd like to confirm, do you want the VERB 65 ENTER in there?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Affirmative on the VERB 65. 02 13 23 49 IMP Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. I got another question on page 18. At 1 minute, I concur with MASTER ARM ON, but I wonder why I have to have the ABORT STAGE breaker in. We sure don't want any staging now.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, delete the ABORT STAGE circuit breaker CLOSE. Leave it open.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Roger. Will delete.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Also, Jack, since we have four-jet ullage versus two, do you want - still want 10 seconds ullage or do you want 5 now?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Aquarius, we'll use automatic ullage.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. We'll just let the 7-1/2-second AUTO ullage do it.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, and we'd like to do this in manual throttle, so on page 17 about two-thirds of the way down, THROTTLE CONTROL, MANUAL, vice AUTO. 02 13 25 35 IMP Okay. We're set to MANUAL.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: What's the 203 ... ?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: ENTER on the 203, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: We've got 203 in the DSKY now and it looks as though it requires work, can we pass it?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, ENTER on the 203.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Wait a minute.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, we'd like to verify that your throttle is in the MIN position.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: That's affirm.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, in the event that you have to do a manual takeover, turn the ENGINE GIMBAL OFF, MODE CONTROL to ATTITUDE HOLD, and use the hand - use the TTCA.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, l plus 30 to burn.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, MASTER ARM'S ON; 1 minute.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, Aquarius. You're GO for the burn.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: 40 percent.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Aquarius. You're looking good.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: AUTO shutdown. 02 13 30 40 IMP Okay. You're looking at 1685 now. Jack.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. You're GO in the residuals, proceed. 02 13 30 55 IMP Okay. When you say GO on the residuals, you mean don't trim them. Is that right?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative. No trim required.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger. 02 13 31 08 IMP Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, check your MASTER ARM OFF, please.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Houston. Burn's complete. Now we have to talk about powerdown, and what do you want us to do with the PGNS?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. We're looking at that right now, and you'll be the first one to get the word.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And, Houston, it's doubtful right now whether we'll be able to see the stars in this configuration. The only way we could possibly get alinement is with the Earth and the terminator or the Moon and its terminator and I'd sure like to have you look at a powerdown - keeping the PGNS if at all possible.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, Jim. We'll get the word for you.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And, Houston, we're in an ATT HOLD mode, can we turn off the buses?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Standby on that one, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Aquarius. We're working on what's going to happen next. In the meantime, we'd like to take some high-power items off the line, so on panel 11, open DECA POWER, and open DECA GIMBAL. On 16, open the ATCA breaker.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, on 11, we got DECA POWER, DECA GIMBAL, OPEN. On 16, we got the ATCA breaker OPEN.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And, Houston, while you're thinking, see if you can come up with a procedure of perhaps using the command module optics with manual drive to perhaps look for stars.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And, Jack, Aquarius. While you're thinking - before we had our C0MM problems, we were wanting to know what to - whether we should hook up the side hatch urine dump system. So ve wouldn't freeze up the normal urine dump system.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. We gave you a GO on that earlier. Sorry, you must have missed it. Use the side hatch for urine dump.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, how are the stars out the window now?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Well, I'll look again, Jack, but at this attitude, the Sun is reflecting off of - off of quad 4 so bright that it's ruining any night vision and we still got particles floating around us; I'll have to take a long look and see if I can see any star patterns.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. And Aquarius, we're going to have to hand you over to a different site now, and we think maybe things will work better if this time we turn off the S-band transmitter/receiver, and bring it back up in 5 minutes. You copy?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Stand by 1.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. I understand you want us to turn off the S-band transmitter/receiver and bring it up in 5 minutes. Is that correct?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Tell us when.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And you want us to maintain attitude control.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Affirmative on the attitude control.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: That's auto attitude control. Okay. You maintain auto attitude control.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack, I'm back on the line now. On the S-band, you want me to turn off the transmitter/ receiver and the power amps are off for 5 minutes. Is that - when you give me the word - is that what you want?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, leave the power amplifier the way it is. Turn the transmitter/receiver off for 5 minutes. Now. 02 13 44 19 MP Okay. You tell me - you tell me when.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Turn it off now. See you in 5 minutes. 02 13 44 26 IMP Okay. It's gone off. It's gone off for 5 minutes.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. How do you read?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. You're loud and clear there, Jack.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Same here. We're - We're still discussing the next move.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: I figured it. Let's just make it a good one.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We're looking real close at water usage profiles, and right now things are kind of swinging toward leaving the IMU powered up and powering down the LGC, but we'll have more word for you shortly. And we recommend for sleeping that you leave one guy on watch. We recommend you don't make any urine dumps if you can help it, because it'll make the debris problem worse than it is now. And we have some items that you might want to transfer to the LM, some towels, some penlights, fecal bags, UTS. And do you have any more items that we can help you out with at the moment?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Stand by on your latter list there, Jack. I understand no urine dumps. I guess we'll work through the UCD and all the bags we got; and real quick there, can you give a DAP load that we want in here now to conserve the RCS.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. For attitude control coordinates, we're recommending manual control VERB 76 and watch your middle gimbal angle. Your DAP load that you have now looks good.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. It's ATT HOLD VERB 76 for the guy on watch. And the DAP load we got right now is okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, our decision for the time is to leave the IMU powered up, power down the LGC, and power down other nonessential items. We'll be coming up with a more precise checklist as soon as we can get it. Over.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. The decision is to keep the platform, power down the computer, and we'll be standing by for further word on the powerdown. Jack.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, Aquarius, for your information, we now have 136-mile perigee. Confirmed by Doppler.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. 136-mile perigee now. That's very nice.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Oh, wait a minute, Jack. Did you say pericynthion or perigee?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: I meant pericynthion.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Ah. That's better.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And, Houston, we pulled out your UPDATA LINK circuit breaker, so if you want to update it for anything, let us know and we'll put it back in.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, Jim. We will.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, AFT OMNI, please.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: AFTOMNI.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Houston, do you read Apollo 13?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: This is Houston. Go ahead. Reading you weakly.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. We don't want to bug you, but you ought to be thinking - or what your thoughts are concerning what the next burn will be. I got to figure out a watch schedule and the sleep schedule and just how we can meet the next maneuver.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. We're getting you a flight plan update. We're still computing on your next burn, and we're getting ready to give you a procedure for powerdown.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, one idea on managing the OMNI antennas. It might make it easier on everybody if we disabled the UPLINK SQUELCH and managed the antennas by switching when we hear the noise. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger. Will do.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Aquarius. Here's what we're going to do. We'd like you to point the LM X-axis either north or south. That's the positive X-axis. It appears to us that it would be closer to orient the LM plus X-axis toward the south. Do that with the LGC powered up using the TTCA. After that, we propose to power down the LGC to save some power. However, this means that we lose the use of the TTCA, and we'll have to control the spacecraft with the hand controller in the DIRECT mode. Request your - your position on these two items.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. How do you read?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. Understand. You want us to point the LM X - plus X-axis to the south using the TTCAs with the LGC powered up. Then, by powering down the LGC, we'll lose a TTCA. I wasn't too successful in controlling the spacecraft in at- titude only, but I might be able to keep it out of gimbal lock.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative, Jim. We'd keep your ball powered up and go to DIRECT on the hand controller. And maintain attitude in a DIRECT position.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Understand; and do you want some sort of a PTC mode, Jack?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Affirmative. We'll take whatever PTC mode you can set up, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. And since you know our approximate attitude, how about just getting me something to find you on the DSKY for a southerly plus X-direction.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Standby 1.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And one other question, Houston. When you say power down the DSKY or the LGC, do you mean going into 06 or multiple circuit breaker?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Stand by on powering down the DSKY, Jim. We'll give you the procedure for that. The procedure that we- -

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: - - the procedure that we have is listed in several places. It's in the Contingency checklist under "Power down" on page 1, second paragraph.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And we'll give you that word when we want you to do that. That's LGC only, not to power down the IMU. But we'd like to have you hold off on that until we send you the word. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Understand.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, Aquarius, while we're working on this, we have a proposed flight plan update for your working and resting cycles. And - You ready to copy?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Do you want me to write this in the flight plan, per se. Jack?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: You can probably write it on a piece of scratch paper. This is pretty easy.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Go ahead. We got a lot of scratch paper.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We're suggesting that the LMP rest while the CMP and CDR are awake. LMP ought to hit the sack at about 63 hours, coming up in 25 minutes. And you get to rest for 6 hours. You get up at 69 hours. At 70 hours , the commander and the command module pilot sleep for 6 hours until 76 hours. Around 70 - 76-1/2 to 77 hours, we'll do a P51 and a 52. At 78:30, we'll load P30 and aline AGS to PGNS. Our ignition time for a second burn will be, presently, 79:25:26.5, and we'll have a pad for you shortly. We suggest that all of you eat after the burn. That'll be 8l to 82 hours. Let the CMP and CDR eat while you are sleeping. And that you grab a bite as soon as you can. Over.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. As I read that, the LMP is to goto sleep at 63:00 for about 6 hours. During that period, the CDR and CMP should try to get a bite to eat. I'm to awake at 69 hours. CDR and CMP sleep at 70 hours, and they are to awake at 76 hours. And we should plan on doing our P51, P52 at 76 hours or 76:30. At 78:30, we're going to load a P30 and aline AGS to PGNS. Second maneuver is to take place at 79:25:26.5 for ignition time. Then we're all to eat at 8l to 82 hours.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. With a minor modification, your P51, P52 will be about 77 hours, and that's the period of darkness. And the commander and the CMP ought to eat around 68 to 69 hours, and you should eat between 69 to 70 hours just after you get up. We have left an hour in there where everybody is awake together to talk things over. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. I'll eat after I wake up between 69 and 70.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: All right we have additional - -

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: - - and I've got the correction to P - -

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead, Fred.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes. We got the word the P51, P52 is going to be done around 77 hours, while we're in darkness.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative. And we have a work-rest cycle laid out for further on, which we can relay to you later.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. And, Houston, you have advice on what attitude you want me to go to.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. That'll be the next bit of information. I'll get that for you, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, Aquarius, just to get you thinking in that direction, we've run a fairly thorough analysis, and we've found out that it's going to be cheaper to keep the LGC and the DSKY up and turn the inverter and the ball off. It's going to save us 1 amp and also some water, so it looks like what we're going to do. And we'll have to monitor the middle gimbal angle. And we'll get the procedure on that, and it'll also be an easier control mode where we'll be able to use the TTCA through the - through the DAP.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: That sounds great, jack.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. We've got a procedure for you. Ready to copy?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Ready to copy.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. It's pretty easy. We see you've already got VERB 16 NOUN 20 called up there and so we want you to, in maneuver and PGNS ATTITUDE HOLD, use the TTCA. We want you to, on the commander's ball, pitch to 267.5 and yaw to minus 4.5. And when you do this in VERB 16 NOUN 20, on the DSKY, you ought to read plus 00120, plus 26750, and plus 00450. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. We're to drive the commander's ball to a pitch of 267.5, yaw minus 4.5. And we should have in 16 20 at that time, plus 00120, plus 26750, plus 00450.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's a good readback. We'll watch the maneuver.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger. You didn't mention roll on the ball. Do you want roll zero?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: The roll ought to be plus 1.2, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. We're just about there in pitch and in ... middle gimbal angle, but that other gimbal angle didn't look like it pulled the right way. I tried both methods.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes. I been looking at that, too, and we're asking why, and we'll get an answer for you.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes. Houston, I wonder if you're accounting for being a bit off the bellyband here, and I've gone through GASTA.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, Fred-o, I know you're supposed to start sleeping here pretty soon, but we got a new PC plus 2 pad, P30 maneuver pad for you.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Stand by.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Go ahead. Jack.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Fred. P30 maneuver purpose is PC plus 2, DPS to this time, we're going to the MPL. And NOUN 33, 079, 27, 4013, plus 08144, minus 00443, minus 02226, apogee is N/A, perigee is plus 00205, 08455, 420, 268, 26l, plus 08155, minus 00443, minus 02187, COAS is N/A. Your GDA ought to be okay as it is from the last burn, but pitch ought to be at 5.85; in roll, it's 6.74. Your ullage will be two jets for 10 seconds. Your DPS throttle will he 10 percent for 5 seconds, 40 percent for 21 r.r-conds, and thf remainder at full throttle. And for your information, this will put you in the water at 142 plus 47. Over.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. DPS, pericynthion plus 2 into the MPL, 079, 27, 4013, plus 08144, minus 00443, minus 00226, N/A, plus 00205, 08455, 4 plus 20, 268, 26l, plus 08155, minus 00443, minus 021, 2187, N/A. GDA should be okay as is, which hopefully is pitch 5.85, yaw 6.74. Two-jet ullage for 10 seconds, the DPS throttle 10 percent for 5 seconds, 40 percent for 21 seconds, 100 percent for the rest of the burn. And this should put us into the water at 142 plus 47.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Fred. I have a correction in NOUN 8l. DELTA-Vz is minus 02226. Read back.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. DELTA-Vz in NOUN 8l is minus 02226.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Good readback.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Somehow that didn't add up with the DELTA-Vx to give a DELTA-Vr of that magnitude. It seems like it'd been bigger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We'll take another look at it, Fred.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Houston. I'm not having too much luck holding this particular attitude.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. Stand by 1.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Aquarius. When you get her pretty much in attitude there, and it looks like you're as close as we need to be, we'd like to try a control mode and see if it will work; sort of a semi-PTC. We'll leave the ball powered up for this, and if this doesn't work, why, we'll have to revert to ATTITUDE HOLD mode. But - Stand by 1, please.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We'd like you to think about this control mode, Jim, and see if you think it might work from what you know right now. We're a little skeptical, but we'd like to put it to you. So, once you get in a pretty good attitude, monitor in VERB 16 NOUN 20, go to PGNS MINIMUM IMPULSE, VERB 76, as we have, and set up a yaw rate - yaw rate to the right. Monitor the middle gimbal on R3 on the DSKY and see if she'll kind of stabilize out. If not, the only other suggestion we've got is to go to PGNS ATTITUDE HOLD. We'll keep the ball up until you make this evaluation.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Houston. You cut out, say again.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Where'd you lose me, Jim?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I lost you when you said try the control mode; you're a little skeptical.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. From what you say, we have to be a little skeptical of this procedure, but we'd like to have you try it and have you evaluate it. You can monitor the middle gimbal on R3. Before we power down the ball, we want your evaluation. The next best choice is PGNS ATTITUDE HOLD. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. I'll try it.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Go ahead with the control mode procedure.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Hello, Houston; Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. I'm not ... you. I can monitor register 3. I can probably keep it out of ... - going into gimbal lock.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. How are pitch and roll?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. I think I can control the gimbal angles in 16 20 with the compressors the way they are, but I'll have to try MINIMUM IMPULSE - Just a minute.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. I've a question - one more question about Odyssey.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, I still have the PYRO A sequence A and PYRO B sequence B circuit breakers in. Do you want those out?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Standby 1.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Odyssey, Houston. The two circuit breakers you referred to, leave them in.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Copy. Leave them in.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Houston. I can control yaw in minimum impulse, but stand by on pitch.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, Fred-o, the DELTA-Vr resultant computes with the components.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Fred's off the C0MM now, Jack.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Your PAD is good.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: And, Jack, we didn't get that whole sentence there.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. I said that the DELTA-Vr that Fred questioned computes well with the component - its rms.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Copy.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, now. Jack, let's go over this once more. You wanted me to try out control of the space- craft in the PULSE mode. Is that correct?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative. Set up a yaw rate and moni- tor the middle gimbal angle.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. I can do that. I'm not too sure whether I can control roll or pitch in pulse, but I can control yaw in pulse - yaw in pulse on the ball.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. And remember we're not going to have a ball there, so that we're going to be monitoring CDUs on the DSKY, and if we get it off, it will be pretty hard to figure out where to fly back to; and, well, in addition, have to control the OMNIs while we're doing this. )

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Without the ball, I still have use of the TTCA for control of the - angles.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Affirmative. You'll have the TTCA for pitch and roll.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. I think I can do that without the ball, and if you just give me the TTCAs I think I can control the spacecraft using 16 20.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I'm going to yaw right.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. I am now - The REGISTER 1 is in the DECREASE mode.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And, Houston, do you see anything wrong with this spacecraft motion?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We have a data drop on right now, Jim; we'll look at it as soon as it comes up.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Aquarius. We're going to dispense with this control mode. We'd like you to fly the machine back to the original attitude that you had, and we'll go PGNS ATTITUDE HOLD, and then we've got to get that ball off the line to save some power. And then, in order to keep even heating, every 15 or 30 minutes, we'll give you a call to give us 90 or 180 degrees of roll - of yaw.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. You want me to go back to original attitude. I'll be going back to it now.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Houston; Aquarius. I'm flying it back over towards the initial angles you gave me of a pitch of 257. I'll get near the bellyband in roll and yaw; then I'll go to PGNS ATT HOLD.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative, Jim. And then we're going to have you go through a powerdown procedure.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And you'll need VERB 77 with ATT HOLD when you get there.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Will do.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. Have I gotten your 360 on yaw and roll? I'm going to go to ATT HOLD.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. And then we want to get the ball part down.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Stand by.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. I'm now in PGNS ATT HOLD. And are you reading my DSKY angles?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. We see them.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Now, you want me to power down the ball, and if you'll give me the procedure for that, I'll do it right away.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We'll buy what you've got on the DSKY there, and we'd just like to go through an overall powerdown procedure, and in so doing we'll catch the ball and inverter and it will only take a few minutes. So are you ready to start on panel 11?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger. Jack will copy, and I'll do the work.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Panel 11, top row, open all the circuit breakers.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: All circuit breakers on top row coming open.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: They're all open, top row.

transcript.speaker: CC

transcript.text: Okay. Third row, open up the next five - correction - Open up the first five on the left, close A0T HEATER, close SIG CONDITIONER 1. Close ATTITUDE DIRECT, and open the rest on row three.

transcript.text: Okay. I'm opening up ENGINE START OVERRIDE right now. And that row's taken care of.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. On the fourth row. Open - From the left, open the first five - correction - Close the first five, and open CABIN FAN 1. Close the three GLYCOL PUMP circuit breakers; open all the COMM breakers, except for COMMANDER'S AUDIO; close it. All the PGNS breakers, open - correction - Open the first three PGNS breakers, close LGC/DSKY, IMU STANDBY, IMU OPERATE.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Let's go over to panel 16, top row, and starting from the left - Open the first four. 02 15 37 27 Stand by, Jack.

transcript.text: Okay. Starting from the left, open the first four.

transcript.text: Okay. And close the IS0L VALVE, keep your TCA breakers closed, close the CROSSFEED, open the next two displays. Close the MAIN SOV and the PROPULSION breakers should all three be open.

transcript.text: Roger. The main valves are closed, and the DISPLAY ENGINE OVERRIDE LOGIC'S coming open, and the PQGS and ASC He REG are open.

transcript.text: Okay, Jim. SUIT FLOW CONTROL can be open, and ENGINE ARM - ENGINE ARM open.

transcript.text: Okay. Row 3 under COMM. Open DISPLAYS, close SE AUDIO, open VHF A TRANSMITTER and B RECEIVER, close the PRIMARY S-BAND circuit breakers, both of them. Open the S-BAND ANTENNA, PMP closed, TV open, and all the rest of them open under ECS, except CO2 SENSOR, closed.

transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Under row 4: under HEATERS, your RCS QUAD heaters should - four of them - be closed, open DISPLAYS, open S-BAND ANTENNA, open SEQUENCE CAMERA. Under EPS, open DISPLAYS, close DC BUS VOLT, open INVERTER 2, open ASCENT ECA CONTROL and ASCENT ECA, close DESCENT ECA, DESCENT ECA CONTROL, TRANSLUNAR BUS TIE, close CROSS TIE BAL LOADS, open CROSS TIE BUS, close BAT FEED TIES. transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. Looks like what we have to do is - In order to maintain even heating, we just have to yaw the whole machine about 90 degrees per hour in increments. So we'll give you a call when it's time to yaw 90 degrees.

transcript.speaker: CDR

transcript.text: Affirmative. Service module O2 supply off, Jack.

And we'll get some flow out the blue side, circulate up and around the command module and to keep the C02 level down.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger. We're thinking of that too, and one problem is that the C0MM is connected securely to the hose, so we've got to get the COMM.cable off somehow to get that - So we'll still have C0MM down here in the LM and you have the hose up there.

Now if you want to get some water, we recommend that you momentarily turn the SURGE TANK on to pressurize the system and then turn it off and take out water as required. Over.

transcript.text: That's it. Jack. And another note on taking water; if you don't drain enough water so that - -

transcript.text: Okay. One more note on the water. Jack. If you don't bleed the pressure off when you - don't take enough water to bleed the pressure off completely, the pressure that's left on there is going to drain away in a period of 1 to 3 hours. So it's a small amount of oxygen, but we might as well save it. So if you want to eliminate that problem you could completely drain the pres- sure off by putting the water in a water bag and saving it that way.

When we go to the new yaw attitude, we're thinking about powering up the steerable, leaving the POWER AMP off and, if we can get good COMM in that mode, we'll still save some power. So if you concur, why don't you go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Over.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Listen, Charlie Duke wants to talk to you - to you about the A0T star check; and, so that we can have good C0MM, I'd like to recon- figure with the POWER AMPLIFIER circuit breaker in and the VOICE FUNCTION switch to VOICE and while we're at it, we'd like the RANGING FUNCTION switch to RANGING. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Over. 03 00 28 49 IMP Houston, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, Fred-o. Reading you - -

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Fred-o. Reading you 5-by. The procedure I'm going to read up to you is a Sun check for the - to see if we're going to need an alinement or not. If you'll get out your G&N dictionary and open it to P52, page 34, we'll start at the bottom. Over.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Stand by 1.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Sounds like you broke out, Charlie.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes, finally, Fred-o. I've no longer got the red spots.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Stand by, Aquarius. We'll be back with you momentarily.

transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.text: Okay, Fred-o. At the bottom of the page, we want step 1, on the flashing 0406, we want an option 3, and that'll pull us over to 6; and, on the 5025, we want you to do the ENTER on the 5025, and that'll bring up flashing 0170, and load in Rl 200. Over.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Let me see if I'm with you. We call up P52 and, on the flashing 0406, we PRO on a 3 REFSMMAT which leads us to a flashing 5025. We ENTER on that. On the flashing 0170, we want to ENTER a 200.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative; and after that, you PRO on that, and you come up with a flashing 0688, and we'll have to load NOUN 88. And if you're ready to copy, I have the Sun half-unit vectors at 74 hours GET. Over. 03 00 32 47 IMP Okay. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. At Sun half-unit vectors, X, Rl, is plus 0.45498, Y plus 19024, Z plus 08250. Over.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. We PRO on - after entering the 200. We'll get a flashing 0688. We then load the Sun unit vectors for 74 hours, which are Rl plus 5 - correction, plus 45498, R2 plus 19024, R3 plus 08250.

transcript.text: Roger. That's good, Fred-o. And that'll bring you to step 8, and you get a flashing 50l8 when you PRO on the NOUN 88. Okay. At 5018, we want to do an AUTO maneuver to - to the attitude, so just do the - the PRO with the GUIDANCE CONTROL, PNGS; MODE CONTROL, PNGS, AUTO; and we'll take this attitude. Now, that's going to Put us at - at attitude for the Sun check. Now, we're being a 1.4-degree deadband in this program in a docked configuration; so, to help you out, you could call VERB 62 to get your needles - and it - when the needles go through zero or null out and - in that deadband - then you take a look in the AOT and see how close the Sun is. And we want within plus or minus 1 degree. Over.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. So we PRO on the NOUN 88, and we end up with a flashing 5018; and you want an AUTO maneuver here rather than using the TTCA, so we PRO with GUIDANCE, PNGS; MODE CONTROL, AUTO. Is that correct?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: I think that's a little tight; that's about a quarter degree. We can go a little bit out of that. Stand by 1. Fred, we'll get you an answer on that one. And also, if you'll stand by, we'll give you a DAP load for this maneuver. Over.

Okay. You should shut down, if any of the following happen. Thrust monitor readout, 77 percent or below; DPS propellant tank pressure - that's the inlet pressure - onboard readout, 160 or below; fuel to OX DELTA-P, greater than 25 psi - and that would have to be a ground call to you - attitude error plus or minus 10 degrees, with the exception of the start transient; attitude-rate limits, plus or minus 10 degrees a second. And you should shut down if you get any of the following alarms: ENGINE GIMBAL, ISS, plus PROGRAM ALARM, LGC, CES DC, and if you get an inverter light after switching inverters. Are you with me?

Now just general information. If you didn't burn PC plus 2, probably P - P plus 4 would be the earliest MCC. AGS is going to backup in a rate-fail mode only, which you know. We're talking over the star check. Will have to get back with you on that. If, for some reason, there is no PC-2, you have a free-return trajectory with the landing at 152:02:00, and that would be after a small midcourse-5, which would probably be around 4 feet per second at 93 hours. And you have recovery forces in the Indian Ocean; you're in good shape there. And the Indian Ocean is where this landing would be. Okay. You still with me?

At PC plus 4, the increase in DELT - in DELTA-V, or the penalty, would be about 24 feet per second, with a landing in the mid-Pacific at 142:46:30. transcript.text: Okay. Just some info. And this whole thing requires modifying a kit so that you can attach the home modifying a LiOH canister, so you can attach those to it. So, sometime in the future, we will be coming up to you with that procedure. Second point - Second point is, we're standing by to watch your maneuver for the PTC procedure. Over.

transcript.text: That's affirm. We have a lengthy procedure here; but, in short, you use plastic as a covering for the whole thing. You'll - You need gray tape to stick the whole thing together, and you need something like a sock to put in the - the bottom so that the outlet side is plugged up. As it turns out, the flow is rather U-shaped through the cartridge, Fred. It if you plug up the bottom, it comes in one side ' of the top and goes out the other.

transcript.text: The RCS ... attitude.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: ...ought to come up the side. Then, you got us in the right plane, Jim. We're in the right plane. We're pointed off and we'll swerve on again with the Earth, Moon, and Sun.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: In another respect, it might be easier to get a -

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Look in the rear detent now. Goto -

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: How's that?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Awful.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Oh, that's right. That blasted service -command module is back there. Scratch that one. That one?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: It's not much better. Okay, let's go this one.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Keep the ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jim, we have some status information for you, if you're ready to copy on a piece of scratch paper.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Stand by, Vance.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: We are ready for you.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Put that away and get some status paper here.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead, Vance.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. First, midcourse correction will probably be at GET 104 hours, and all we look for is a 4- to 6-feet-per-second DELTA-V. Okay. That's the first item. Now, I will give you a rundown on consumables. Okay. In the LM, you have 1498 - that is 1 4 9 8 amp-hours remaining. That means over 61 hours you'd - That would average out to 24.5 amps. We expect that, after powerdown, that you will use 1 4 or 14 amps per hour, and that would leave a reserve of 500 amp-hours at the end of the mission. Are you with me?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger. We're with you.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: I saved my - number was yesterday.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. In the LM, you have - -

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: We're with you.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. In the LM, you have 215, that is 2 1 5, pounds of water, usable. That would average out over 61 hours to 3.5 pounds per hour available. Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. And after you power down, we expect that you will be using water at the rate of 3.2 to 2.7 pounds - That's at 14 amps per hour electrical usage rate. One note, this does not - When we speak here of water available, this does not include CSM water and PLSS water, so that's added on. Okay, next, LiOH. Using the CSM cans, you will have 16 cans at 12 hours per can to give you 19 2, or 192 hours, of LiOH. And, in the LM, using its cans, you have 44 hours remaining.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Vance, is that with the PLSS secondaries?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirm. That's affirm. That includes PLSS secondaries.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay; oxygen. You have remaining 44 pounds in the LM. At a usage rate of 0.36 pounds per hour, that leaves you 120, or 12 0, hours of oxygen. Okay. Next, RCS. RCS A stands at 6 2 percent and B at 6 2 percent. We only expect 2 percent to be used for the PTC, so you're in good shape for RCS. Next, DPS DELTA-V. You have 1190 feet per second remaining. And, finally, CSM EPS We estimate that you have 99 amp-hours. That's an estimate. And that's it. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. I copy.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. And just a question. It would be interesting to hear from Jack to see if he thinks that main B bus is good. If he has any idea of how if whether it's good or not, this would influence our steps in the future; for example, we might want to try to test main B to see if it is in fact, good so that we'd know how to set switches for entry.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger. Just a minute. They want to know whether you think main bus B is any good for the command module.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Vance, while Jack's got on the loop let me pose the question of how we're planning on doing this midcourse, if we are going to power down the PGNS.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Would you stand by on that, Jim? We'd like to give you a procedure for that later on.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Get a midcourse at 104 hours. He's going to give us a procedure for that later on.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: In short, Jim, we don't expect any problem, but we'll explain further later on.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Deke says get a night's sleep. He says you've been working hard, and you ought to relax a little bit and be ready for tomorrow.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Vance, this is Jack.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead, Jack.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Let me give you my observations on main bus B. Things happened pretty fast there, and we first heard the impact or explosion or whatever caused it, I'm not sure. The next - About second later, there was a MASTER ALARM which was the MAIN BUS B UNDERV0LT. I looked at the voltage, and the voltage was good at his time so I'm suspecting it was a spike. Fuel cell 3 was also good, with good flow. However, Fred, at that point, was coming into the command module and got over into his seat. At that time, we shortly had an AC BUS 2 light about the time he got into his seat. He looked at the It, however, - and the fuel cell flows were ZERO. I'm kind of suspecting that perhaps we do have a MAIN - a current MAIN BUS B. But that's merely a guess. I never did try to reset it. We were having other problems with the MAIN BUS A, having an UNDERVOLT and a few other things like that. I'd kind of like to hear what your feelings are down there.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Well, Jack, we copy your information. And we'd like to hold off because we're still working the problem. So we'll have to give you information later.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Thank you.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, request AFT 0MNI.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Vance, are you back with me?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. We're with you.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. We lost lock there. We switched OMNIs. Just for my own - kind of to get my thoughts in order, I'd kind of hear what - I'd like to hear what kind of entry you're planning. EMS or PGNS or what?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. PGNS entry is being planned, and people are at work on checklist changes and that sort of thing.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Real fine.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And - we'll - We'll give you the CSM stuff tomorrow, but basically we expect that main bus B is good and we're going to work up a procedure to test it.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Those are my thoughts, too.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: But - -

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: You think main bus B is good, don't you?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirm. We think it is, but. we want to check it out anyway. We think you guys are in great shape all the way around. Why don't you quit worrying and go to sleep.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Oh, that - That's our boss, Deke.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Well, I think we just might do that - or part of us will.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: I mixed up. How many more of those - Are we hot mike? - -

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Yes.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Yes, I'm mixed up. You had 15? I mixed up seven more. So we got 22. By the way, there's still some water that's - it's not enough pressure to mix up another drink, but there is some water out of there, if you want to get some water out of the drink cup.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: That's good; I could use some.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: We ought to use that oxygen up and not waste it (Cough)

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: You monitoring right now?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Yes. Just stand by.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: What'll it take to...

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Yes.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: You only got two ... there, so ...

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: I will.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: You wouldn't believe it, but I'm now in commandd of the LM. Okay. Vance, I'm probably the only CMP that's ever witnessed a DPS burn sitting on the ascent engine head.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Did you get some? Is there any coming out still? They didn't answer. I think we made it. How's this working out?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. No problem.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: They are, huh? How are we going to get an alinement?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: We'll pull one out someways, I guess. We've gotta watch that one right there.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: It's decreasing now. It'll - it'll - It's cold. I noticed that in the command module. It'll wobble.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Switch OMNIs to TRANSMIT.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
