transcript.text: Go ahead, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger. Are you planned to set up here very shortly - a powerdown procedure?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative, if you'll take out your contingency hook and turn to page Power 6. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger. Stand by. Contingency Power 6. Get the book over here. Contingency Power 6.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Well, I hope this ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And while you're doing that, let's put ATTITUDE CONTROL, three, switches to MODE CONTROL.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: All three ATTITUDE CONTROL switches have been in MODE CONTROL.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. And when you get to Power 6, you ought to see a circuit breaker page, panel 11.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Have a pencil? Let's see it - thank you.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. I have Power 6, panel 11.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. On Power 6, panel 11 - The top three rows, configure them as you see them.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, now, Jack ... We have put the TCAs in for the previous procedure. Do you want those out, now?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative, Jim. Pull them out. TCAs open.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. I'm changing those to ... back again. First three rows. And you're pulling the ATCA PGNS, huh?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative. Pull ATCA PGNS open.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. I've done that.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Are you ready for the fourth row?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Affirm.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Now when we get in the fourth row, we're going to open the IMU OPERATE circuit breaker; and what that means is that we're going to lose the capability to watch your CDUs, so we're not going to be able to see your attitude. Therefore, we will not be able to advise you on which antenna to select for communications. The way we want you to handle that is to turn the LM UPLINK SQUELCH off, and when you hear the noise, switch antennas. We'll be able to see you switch antennas, and it's going to take us about 3 to 5 minutes to establish a lockon again after you switch. After each time that you switch antennas, we will initiate a voice check. And basically when you see the Earth out the window, you can be on FORWARD antenna, and when the Moon's up in the window use the AFT antenna. You copy?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. We're going to pull the IMU OPERATE circuit breaker, so you won't be able to see our attitude. Therefore, you won't tell us how to switch antennas and we'll enable the - I will turn the - up the SQUELCH OFF so that when we start getting any static, we'll switch antennas and as a thumb rule we could use - with the Earth forward, we use the FORWARD antenna and when we see the Moon we use the AFT antenna.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative, Jim. In other words, we're leaving the antenna switching up to you, and after you switch antennas it's going to take 3 to 5 minutes for us to establish a lockon again, and we'll initiate a voice check. And I'm ready to go on panel 11, row 4.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. On row 4, under HEATERS RCS SYSTEM A/B-1: open QUAD 1 through 4; under ECS, the only change is - under GLYCOL PUMP close AUTO TRANSFER; under COMM, the only change is: open VHF A RECEIVER, open COMMANDER AUDIO; under PGNS, the only change is: close and leave closed IMU STANDBY circuit breaker, so we can have heaters. Read back.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. On row 4, we're going to open all four of the heaters - the RCS SYSTEM A and B - the first four circuit breakers. We're going to close the AUTO TRANSFER. We're going to open the VHF A RECEIVER and the COMMANDER AUDIO. And we're going to close the IMU STANDBY. The LGC DSKY and the IMU OPERATE will be open.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative, Jim. All other breakers in that row are as you see them in the checklist. And on row 5, the only change is that we want you to, under EPS, open ASCENT ECA CONTROL. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger. I think we already have that opened - ASCENT ECA CONTROL is probably already open.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. So let me confirm. We'll have one COMM system, that will be the LMP system, and we'll have to do our own antenna switching; therefore, we'll have to wait about - Okay, why don't you switch? Aft antenna.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: We'll have to wait for you to get a lockon again. Is that correct?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative, Jim. You'll be working off of the LMP's panel over there.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. What else do you have for me?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Panel 16, that's on page Power-7. Top row, the only change is: under RCS SYSTEM B, open PQGS/DISPLAYS. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. I may go over this with you, Jack, be- cause this checklist I as been written over two or three times now on our various procedures. Top row, the first two are open, the next three are closed, and we're going to open now the QUAD TCA's 1, 2, 3, 4; CR0SSFEED will be closed. and the TEMP/PRESS DISPLAYFLAG will be opened, and we're going to open up the PQCS, MAIN SOV will be closed, and the ... will be opened.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative, Jim. And there's no change to the second row. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Again let me go through this with you. The first four are going to be closed. The next sev - eight will be - the next nine will be open from LOGIC POWER B through DESCENT ENGINE OVERRIDE. How about the CWEA? Is that going to be closed?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative, Jim. We want the next five closed.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. In the third row, under COMM: DISPLAY, open; SE AUDIO, closed; VHF A TRANSMITTER, open - That's a change - VHF B RECEIVER, open; PRIMARY S-BAND, POWER AMPLIFIER, open: TRANSMITTER/RECEIVER, closed; S-BAND ANTENNA, open; PMP, closed; TV, open. Under ECS: DISPLAYS, open; GLYCOL PUMP SECONDARY, open; LGC PUMP, open; CABIN FAN CONTROL, open; CABIN REPRESS, closed; and all the next four closed also. Read back.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. We have DISPLAY, open; SE AUDIO, closed; VHF A TRANSMITTER, open; VHF B RECEIVER, open; POWER AMP's going to he open; TRANSMITTER/ RECEIVER, closed; S-BAND ANTENNA, open; PMP, closed; TV, open; DISPLAY is open; next three are open; CABIN REPRESS, closed; and all the rest closed.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative, Jim. And in row 4, under HEATERS, we want them all - Correction - we want all the QUAD HEATERS open. Correction - we want all the QUAD HEATERS closed.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: All the - -

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We want DISPLAY, open; S-BAND ANTENNA, closed - to avoid a MASTER ALARM, CAMERA - SEQUENCE CAMERA, open; And under EPS, we want DISPLAYS, open; DC BUS VOLT, closed; INVERTER 2, open; ASCENT ECA, closed; ASCENT ECA CONTROL, open; DESCENT ECA, closed; DESCENT ECA CONTROL, closed; TRANSLUNAR BUS TIE, close; we want the CROSS TIE BUS, open; the BAL LOADS, closed; BAT FEED TIEs, closed. How do you read?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. The four RCS HEATERS will be closed; DISPLAYs, open; S-BAND ANTENNA, closedd; CAMERA SEQUENCE will be open; DISPLAY will, be open; DC BUS VOLT will be closed; INVERTER 2 open; ASCENT ECA will be closed, but the ASCENT ECA CONTROL, open; DESCENT ECA, closed; DESCENT ECA CONTROL, closed; TRANSLUNAR BUS TIE, closed; and CROSS TIE BUS, open; and BALANCE LOADS, closed; and the BAT FEED TIEs, closed. I have one question, Jack. On panel - on the second line there under LIGHTING, why are we keeping the FLOODS and TRACK closed? Or are they going to be open?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Negative. We have the LIGHTING breakers all closed. Control the lighting with the switches and rheostats. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. We don't need the floodlights, I don't think, but we can do it that way, I guess.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And under row 4, under RCS SYSTEMS A/B-2, QUAD HEATERS, you notice that we've closed those circuit breakers, but what we want you to do is to - on panel 3, turn the RCS A/B-2 QUAD switches l, 2, 3, and 4, off. Over.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And we're going to watch your quad temps for you, and when we need to warm them up a little bit, we'll tell you to throw those four switches on - on panel 3.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Now are we sure that this PTC mode is good enough so we don't ... get crossed up later and get out of configuration.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Stand by 1 on that, Jim. Okay, Jim, as far as we can tell right now, the PTC looks as good as any PTC we've ever seen in a CSM, so we're going to go with what we've got.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, and if you turn over the page on Power 8, we have the spacecraft functions remaining to you. We've got low bit rate TM. However, we don't have any VHF. We have CWEA. We have GLYCOL PUMPS. We have SUIT FANS. We have CABIN REPRESS for you, and stand by in ATTITUDE CONTROL here. Okay, in ATTITUDE CONTROL, we'll have hardovers for uses in emergency, and for normal usage we want to have a 15-minute delay to get the heaters on to warm them up before use. How do you read?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. For emergency, we have the hardovers and for normal use if requires a 15-minute request to get the heaters on.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim, that concludes our powerdown procedure, and we're waiting for you to get with it.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Jack, we'll start. I sure hate to lose ^ PGNS. I sure hope that procedure for the midcourse is a good one.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: It is.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: You want me to help you here?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Yes, you can -Okay. First we power down, panel 11. All of them open.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Closed.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Yes.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Stand by for a MASTER ALARM.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Here it comes.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: LTG. You just did it.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I'll give you this when I'm finished. After we go through this, then you can go through it again and doublecheck it.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Right.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Now, the flood lights are on, right? No, I kind of don't think we need them though, do you?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Don't pull those. Give me the - first of all We'll get back there. Those four are close, open, open, ENGINE ARM, open, ...

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Say, Houston; Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: It will take him a minute to ...

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: You're familiar with our particular spacecraft that on panel 16 HEATERS RCS SYSTEMS A and B, QUAD 1 HEATER circuit breaker has been pushed in, and sealed in, and if it's ever pushed out, it's doubtful if we'll ever be able to reset it.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim, on the four QUAD HEATER breakers, we want you to leave them closed. And we'll operate the heaters with the switches on panel 3. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: No.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. We'll do it right there.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. And I'm closing the HEATERS on panel 4, QUAD 1 through 4, OFF.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. It's time for you guys to get to bed and get Fred up.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: (Laughter) I still have one question, Jack. I still think that - I still say that the - on the LIGHTING in our panel 16, the FLOOD lights and the TRACK should be open. We're not using them.

transcript.speaker: F
transcript.text: Do you have any argument about -

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: No problem, Jim. Go ahead and open them, TRACK and FLOOD, that's all right.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, TRACK and FLOOD are OPEN.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Now, why don't you go through that, Jack, and make sure those - -

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Yes.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, I'll take this.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Jack, my only other concern now is the COg rise in the spacecraft. I guess you're keeping a handle on that?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmed, Jinm. We have you up to 10.6 now, and we're willing to go a little higher on that. We have another cartridge and we have a procedure for making the command module cartridge, up. We'll pass that on later.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Oh, yes. I'm not worried about that. I just wanted to make sure that von - -

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Are they going to - -

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: - - that - We just don't want to go to sleep here and forget about the rise in CO2.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Are they going to use ... - -

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. We're watching it for you - -

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Yes, they're getting it ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: - - We have it here. It's now 10.7 and we have a medical go to 15 millimeters.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: That's a new one.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: There's a new first for you.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay' Jim, estimate we've got 1 more hour on the primary cartridge, and 6 or 7 hours on the secondary. ' - ' -" - - .

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Fine. Say, it's a spare, primary cartridge back there, too, isn't it? So that's good for another, how long?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Yes. Yes. That's yours though, isn't it?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And you're right, Jim. We've got another primary cartridge back there behind the ascent engine cover.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Right, yes. We know. Thank you.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Yes, yes, I just -

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. I guess you've done everything right on that panel. Let me check the middle one Yes You powered down and then you leave me. Tell me, I've got it.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jack, we just thought it's about time you got a LM checkout. Tape 55/7 Page 371

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: But he's giving it to me inert. 01 course, I'm giving him my command module, too, which is rather [???] right now, too.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Well, you've got to walk before you run, you know.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Go ahead. Jack.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. For your information. Jack - -

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: You're loud and clear.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: - - all of our analysis is based on powerdown to 14 amps, but we're reading on you right now 12.3 and so we're better off than we were in our analysis.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: That sounds good.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Jack, I thought you were going to get the sleep shift where there wasn't any excitement?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Well, I tried, but I didn't make it. I thought you were supposed to be sleeping now.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Well, Fred-o is getting something to eat, and Jim is starting to pack out so I'm taking the C0MM here until Fred gets set.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: As I just - Yes, are you ready to take over? Well, he just - he just asked - said he thought I was supposed to be sleeping. And I told him that I was waiting for you to - Okay. You were off the NET when they explained the - But don't they - Can't we monitor our CDU's any more to tell when to switch antennas, so they've just - When they can see it switch - it will take a couple of minutes for tiem to get up. And they'll always make a voice check with you.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: It came out here. I caught it. Okay. Now, are you getting squared away, I'll give you the COMM here. 03 10 41 00 [???] [???] [missed to speakers here]

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. How do you read?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Hearing you loud and clear, Fred. 0MNI.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, I heard the - -

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: I see you luck out with all the good shifts.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes, I got all the good deals. I heard Jack brief you on the COMM mode so, you got any questions about that?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And how is your PTC going? I heard Jack tell you that we can't see your CDU's. How's it going?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Well, let's see, ve may be offsetting slightly, the Sun looks like it may be a little higher now. Here comes the Earth by and it looks about the same perspective. I'll have to wait to see the Moon on the other side. Jack. 03 10 43 37 cc okay, Fred, I can't hear you any more on account of the background noise. I assume that - I think I heard Jack tell you what we're going to do about COMM. UPLINK SQUELCH, off. You'll take care of the antennas because we can't see your attitude. We'll give you a voice check when come up. it'll take us 3 to 5 minutes to come up. And to make it astronaut-proof, when you see the Earth, use a forward antenna; when you sec the Moon, use the aft one.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes, that's pretty straightforward. Okay, I see the Earth so I've very wisely shifted to FORWARD.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Good boy.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Got another battery?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: ... really sick. Tape 55/9 Page 373

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Earth will be by over there in a minute.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: And, Jack, you still up? 03 10 47 28 Cc Still here, Fred.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, when I was upstairs, just a minute ago, 1 noticed what appeared to be some new ventings from down the service module way. I noticed that out window I, and also saw one chunk of metal - loose metal about 4 inches square that was tumbling around - silver in color, and it looked like it had come from somewhere down in the service module.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. You saw some venting out window 1 - -

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: And I -

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes, that's where I happened to be looking. The lighting was such that it showed up out there. What reminded me of it was I'm looking out the LM window now and I see a good part of the new star field it's created for us. There are about a thousand little sparklies out here.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, so you're seeing some venting out window 1, and you saw a 4-inch-square piece of loose metal which was silver, and - Are you still seeing the venting or has it zeroed out now?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: I don't know. I left upstairs, I'm down in the LM now, Jack. I guess when Jack goes up he can take a look and let me know. Okay, I'll think about switching aft here directly. I see the Moon, and the Moon looks pretty good, Jack, so I guess our PTC still doing pretty good.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, and we won't have any COMM delay if the PTC stays good.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes, sure enough the Moon is getting smaller.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Good, and we want to ask you another question about the venting. Is this - would you suppose - some new venting or is this venting that you just hadn't - that's been going on all the time, but which you hadn't looked at recently?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: I can't really say. Jack, we've been so tied up down in the LM, I guess we kind of forgot about the other half. But I've been upstairs several times and hadn't particularly noticed any flow by the windows before, so I - my first assumption was that it was some new venting. It really wasn't very heavy.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Copy. Thank you.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: And Jack's going up to take a look now.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. And for your information, all of our numbers are based on amperage usage of 14 amps. And we're using only 12.3, so we're a little fat on our analysis.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Very good. Way to be.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And we're in a- -

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: I'll tell you, this Aquarius has really been a winner.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Well, that's one of several. And we want to tell you something that I told Jim earlier, and that concerns control. Right now you have control in hardover if you need it, but when we go to some normal control modes, since we have the quad heaters off. We want to have a 15-minute notice for attitude control request. Over.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. Offhand, I can't imagine that since we got the platform powered down why we'd need to worry about the instantaneous control. But at any rate, we need 15-minutes warmup with the heaters before we can start using thrusters.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Right. And another thing we've done is to pull your ECS and EPC DISPLAY breakers and so - But we left your CAUTION and WARNING powered up. So if you get ECS-type or EPS CAUTION and WARNING you'll have to power up those meters with the DISPLAY breakers. And we are watching for you your PIPA temperatures, your ASA TEMP, your propellant temperatures except for the DPS propellant, and we're watching your quad temps for you.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. That's very good, Jack. You're watching them. That's good enough.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And everybody's fine at home El Lago.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Great.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, Fred, your CO2 is building up. It's at 11.3 on our gage, and we've got a medical buildup to 15 millimeters, at which time we'll switch over to secondary. Looks like we've got plenty of lithium hydroxide, about 192 hours including the CSM cartridges. And as you know, we've got a way to use those. And as soon as we get them written in some good words, why, we'll pass that, along. You might be able to make one.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Yes, we'll sure give her a try. And I'm showing onboard about 12-1/2 millimeters of mercury.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. And I have a flight plan update when you get a time to copy it sometime, I'll pass it along. There's no hurry on it.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Stand by 1. Jack's back now.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Jack just came back and he said it's still coming out; it's only coming out on the commander's side. So he saw it out the same window I did, window 1. And it's between the minus Y and minus Z axis.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. And of course - -

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Jack says it's definitely the service module which was - which was my impression, too.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. So you're sure it's the service module, and, of course, the thing we're interested in knowing, is it something that is residual from before, or is it something new. And if you have any ideas about that, why we'd sure like to have them.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes. Yes, Jack, I'll answer him your question in a minute, but make Jack's first impression here, is that it's not near the [???] that it was right after our mishap. And I'll have to agree with that. I'd say - he said it was a half and I said it was maybe down to a third. And Houston would like to know if you have any impressions as to whether it is still a residual from that or maybe something new.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: I don't know why after I felt that. Yes, I felt it was some new something - new venting, too.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Switch to FORWARD OMNI.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Fred-o, if you think it's practical, we're ready to give you some - we're working on some camera settings for pictures of the venting. And, if you have a camera out and ready to go, let us know which one it is so we can get the settings for that camera. What do you think about that?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Jack's got the one with the 250-millimeter lens on it. That's the standard EL. And I have a surface camera out that I've been shooting hundreds of Earth/Moon pictures with, camera 1. And we also have the Reseau upstairs that's pretty handy. The command module DC camera. So you can about - -

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. I copy that - - 03 10 58 0 1 LMP take your choice, because - -

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: I copy the 250 millimeter, the Reseau is avail- able, but I didn't get what other one is.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. I got my Hasselblad surface camera down in the LM here handy, too, camera 1.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: And, Jack, if we're going to do any picture taking out the command module windows, I think we'd better do that pretty quick, or hold up until Jim and Jack get their rest done.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We concur with that.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Fred, we're not going to bother the skipper up there. We won't be taking any pictures out of the command module window until after rest period.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Shifting to FORWARD OMNI.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Fred, for your information, your CO2 reading onboard is a little higher than what we're reading here on the ground, and so when it gets to 15 on your meter, switch to secondary. And we'd like to get a status about every 30 minutes - we'll give you a call on that. But just to let us know we're still thinking about you, we'd like you to go BIOMED RIGHT, please.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Going BIOMED RIGHT. 03 11 13 57 Hey, how do you read me on this COMM mode on S-band?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 5 square, Fred. How me?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We're still here, Fred. How's it going?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. My C02 reading is now just below 13.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Say again what it is.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: It's just - just below 13.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Just below 13. And just for your information, we've got people working on several subjects. We're working on the midcourse coming up to determine our control system and how to do it with the control system we select, what we should do about the alinement. We've got the LMS and a couple of crews cranked up working on that. And we're also working on our entry, how and when we ought to activate the CSM. And we're working on the CSM systems status. Tomorrow sometime we're going to have a MAIN BUS B checkout, so we've got a lot of people swinging pretty hard here and I've got some f-stop settings for you for the lunar-surface camera. At l/250th, we'd like you to take targets of opportunity. Each picture use three f-stops, because we don't know exactly which one is going to work the best, so use 4, 5.6, and 8 and l/250th for the surface camera. Copy?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Use the surface camera at l/250th, 4, 5.6, and 8. And I've been doing quite a bit of shooting at covering two of those numbers in the range 5.6, and 8. I've also been shooting some at 11, so I'll just drop it down a little more. The Moon is still so big and bright there that I got a feeling that the Moon is probably up around the f/8 to f/11 range.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, I didn't catch that last part. Maybe when the C0MM gets a little better you can say it again.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. How do you read now, Jack?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's a lot better, Fred.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, I just said the Moon is still so bright, that I think probably the higher range of f-stops will be better; f/8, maybe even f/11.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: I can just barely, on the left corner of the Moon now, make out the foothills of Era Mauro formation. We never did get to see it when we were in close, there.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. I'm reading on my monitor here, Fred, that you're 16214 miles away from the Moon moving at about 4500 feet per second.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: From the sounds of all the work that is going on and is still going on, this flight is probably a lot bigger test for the system on the ground than up here.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes, you've been - you've been working it out a little bit.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes. I've really got a tough job right now switching OMNIs.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Well, everybody down here is 100-percent optimistic. Looks like we're on the up side of the whole thing now.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes, I guess we had better be in good shape, particularly ourselves, rested for that entry day. I think that is going to be a pretty busy one.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Right, and we're working on procedures for that. Ken's been doing quite a bit of work on getting ready for entry.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Very good.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: How's it going, Fred?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Just fine.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We're considering a midcourse correction at 104 hours - about 20 hours from now - 18 hours from now, and it's only 7 feet per second. The other option is to keep PTC up, since we may not be able to get back into it again, and delay it. So, that's the type of thing we're thinking about, but - just wanted to let you know that you're pretty much right in the middle of the fairway there and our present tracking, with no midcourse, has you - with a Gamma of 7.11 opposed to 6.51. So, you're already in the corridor. You're just a half a degree between the center and the outer limits and we're going to tweek that up.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. That sounds good.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And - we don't - Well, we think there might have been a misunderstanding earlier on the potable water. Don't worry about drinking water. Drink all you want. There's plenty of it. There's 38 pounds, and the Surgeon recommends that you use some of the fruit juices as well. Over.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Yes, we went and - and used the procedure to pressurize surge tank, and Jack and I made up a total of 22 drinks of - drinking water.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And I assume that Jack is up there sleeping now too, right?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes. That's affirm. They're both up there.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: I hate to say it. Jack, but I think our PTC is about to wobble off a little bit. I've noticed that the Earth is coming by somewhat lower in the window and the Moon is going by somewhat higher.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Understand. PTC, Earth is coming by lower and Moon is coming by higher.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, Fred, on this jerry-rigged command module lithium hydroxide canister, what we're going to do is we're going to have to make at least two up and use two at a time - one on each set of hoses. What we'll do is we'll connect one of these jerry-rigged boxes to the red fittings and air will be sucked through the lithium hydroxide and then blown out the blue fitting. And we're also going to, when we do this, remove the LM lithium hydroxide canister from the suit loop, either the primary or the secondary, and we're getting the words together to make it easy to build one of these things, and it looks like it will probably take two guys, so, I think we probably ought to plan to do that later. In addition, we have to go up and get a couple of canisters out of the command module, so it looks like maybe a smart idea would be to delay a little bit and have you build a couple of these later on. What do you think?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes. I agree. Jack. Jack Swigert and I went upstairs earlier and both got a canister, and we were scratching around for some material and thinking about using them, and that's actually why - when we made up all the water to drink because we needed the plastic container that they were housed in in the pantry, and we had that ready to use with some material plus some of the - the extra porous bags that were going to be used for the dump control that we may just cut up and use, too.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Did you come up with a design or - -

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Plus we got lots - -

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: No. We just thought we'd see what we had in the way of material and stand by for your word. Of course, we also have lots of stiff-backed cardboard flight data.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes. We have decided to use a canister and, you know that the liquid-cooled garment has a bag around it that we think we can use, too, or that we know we can use. We've tried it. So what you have is the - a bag within a bag and inside that is the liquid-cooled garment. The bag that is closest to the liquid-cooled garment is the one we need, and we've got two of them. And then, of course, we've got to use some tape and, as you say, one of the backs to flight data file time line book or something like that, and, just using those materials, we can make this Jerry- rigged canister. So, the bag that we're looking for is the one that is right next to the liquid- cooled garment, and, if we're very careful about where we cut it, we can make a pretty good rig.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: It looks like we'll have to use that bag over again, though, because we only got two of them, and I expect that we'll have to make more than two of these canisters up.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Fred, in about 4 minutes, we're going to hand you over to a different communications site, and it's going to take us about a minute or so to reestablish uplink, so you can be prepared for that.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Fred-o, we've handed over now. How do you read?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Loud and clear. Jack.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Same here.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: In fact, you're coming in a little louder.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Fred, you'll have to say again. Can't read you there. There's too much background noise. Maybe we need a new antenna.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. I'm on the other 0MNI now. I just said that you're coming in even louder than previously.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Maybe it's because I'm standing up. You're coming in better now, too.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: And, for your information. Jack, I'm just going to tear into some beef and gravy and other assorted goodies.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: I presume that you're doing this with the full permission and - of the commander.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: And this - at this moment, who do you think is the commander?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: If I was him, I'd make you sign out everything you ate, so I'd know.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Well, I'm sneaking inside of the LM where he doesn't have ... Incidentally, this PTC must have some - must have a wobble mode around our X-axis there because now the Moon and Earth are

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Good. Let's see if it goes the other way.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: These guys down here are saying they knew it all the time.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Well, that's right. They do good work. Whoever heard of doing a P52 in the LM?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Say, Fred, sometime when you're not too busy chewing on that beef, how about telling us what the CO2 reads?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, I'm reading 13, 1 3.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. It looks like our reading is getting kind of close to yours.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes. It appears the wobble is going the other way, Jack, because the Earth is now rising and the Moon is starting to get lower in the window.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Could you give us an LPD number periodically?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: LPD number? Yes, okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: In fact, if you could give it two or three REVs in a row, why then we could predict where it's going and maybe help us set it up again if we have to.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. The center of the Earth has just gone by at an LPD number of 4.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. LPD 4, center of the Earth.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: And the center of the Moon is about LPD 21.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. LPD 21. Is that the center of the Moon, you say?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: That's affirm.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, Fred, we're doing a little better on our water than we had anticipated. Our numbers were designed for 3.5 pounds per hour; we're using about 3.0, and expect to go a little bit less.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Beautiful.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: When this flight's all over, we'll really be able to figure out what a LM can do.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Maybe it'll make the ...

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: If it had a heat shield, I'd say bring it home.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. The Earth went - just went by about - clear above the LPD index. It was - it was, if it were extended, the number would be minus 6.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Way up there at minus 6.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes, there's actually no such number. I just extended the line beyond zero which, for a negative rate, is what it would be if there was one.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Right. If minus 6 was there, that's where it would be. Right?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: That's right.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Do you still have that super-dense star field?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: It's still there. I'm looking at it right now. I can look at - the Sun is right behind me, then all these sparklies show up. Yes. It kind of looks like I'm right in the middle of the - of the Milky Way. There are several thousand little sparklies at various ranges out as far as I can see ...

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: They're kind of interesting. They're all moving ... and sparkling there. And I can ... - at least I think I can what will occasionally give you a real star from the bunch of sparklies, but it really does break up the capability to pick out a star pattern, particularly through ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. So far, we haven't identified what the sparklies are and what is venting.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes, I got a ... feeling that we probably won't get any ... until we power up.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: How you feeling, Fred?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Oh, as soon as I chug down this grape drink and grapefruit - orange drink, I think I'll be in pretty good shape.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: How much sleep did you get between the burn and the time you got up for this exercise?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Oh, I'd guesstimate about 4 hours. Jack. Wait a minute, which burn you talking about?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: It was the burn we just made. Did you get any sleep between it, and the time you got up for this watch?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Oh, no. I didn't - I haven't been to bed since all the action the night before, and I went to go to bed for about 4 hours then ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Well, we're just trying to figure out who's likely to be the most tired up there. You or Jim.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: I think we'll get caught up pretty good in the next couple of days.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Say again.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Me ought to get caught up pretty good in the next couple of days.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. The Earth has started back down. The hack on the LPD there was 1 degree.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. One degree on the center of the Earth.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That was a good TV show you put on the other night, Fred, during LM entry.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes. It would have been an even better one about 10 minutes later.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes. Things sure turned to worms there in a hurry after that show.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes. You're right.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. The center of the Moon now in about minus 2 degrees DELTA-V.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Minus 2 degrees, center of the Moon. 03 12 44 44 CO Charlie said to say hello.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Who's that?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Charlie.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Is he still around there?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Unless my watch is wrong, it says it's almost 2 a.m. back there.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: No. That's the bearded one.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Oh! Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Hey, tell Charlie that I'll be back down there personally to thank him for this baby.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Sure will. I did.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. The Earth went by there. Jack, at LPD about 18 degrees.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. We copy 18 degrees for the center of the Earth.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. The Moon - I'd estimate it up around minus - somewhere 17 to minus 20 degrees LPD.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Moon's minus 17 to minus 20.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: How would you like to spend a week on an air- craft carrier getting back?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: If I can get on an aircraft carrier, I don't care how long it takes. Jack.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: They're going to take you by helo to Samoa. You'll spend the night in Samoa, get on a 141, and be at Ellington shortly thereafter.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Kind of sounds like the original plans for the ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Had you worrying that you're going to spend the night on the ship, helo to Samoa and directly to Ellington.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Very good. 03 12 58 27 LMP Boy, these thrusters are sure

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Fred, I'm not reading you. Maybe we'd better wait until we change antennas or unless you can speak up a little louder.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: How do you read now?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Better.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. The thrusters ... and the ... outside ... and they hardly look like they

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Gee, I'm sorry, Fred. We're just not reading you right now. Maybe we'll have to wait a little bit.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Let's try it now. If you can speak up, the background noise has gone down a little bit.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. How do you read now?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: A little better.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: I was just commenting - I've been looking here at the thrusters on quads 1 and 4. We've got a slight discoloration on the outside of the barrel. The nozzles look like they hadn't ever been fired, - like they're brand new. ... of like those skinny things on the interior on the upper nozzle ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: You say the coloration of the thrusters appears they haven't been fired on quads 1 and 4?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: I'm saying all of them look clean again. I guess they've fired so clean that they don't seem to ... at all. ... different color, ... copper, bronze, color of the oxygen cell. They've been fired because I watched them fire. Okay. The Earth's going by at an LPD of 42.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Copy LPD 42. Is that affirm?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: That's affirm.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, Fred, that may be why the COMM a little bit degraded, more background noise, because we're getting out of attitude a little bit there.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: How do you read on AFT OMNI now

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: I'M reading you, Fred. I've got a lot of background noise. Looks like it might come and go with attitude.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes. I think that's probably - just looking through the command module at you now.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: How do you read now. Jack?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: About the same, Fred.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. And the Moon just went by at about minus 14 degrees.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, the Moon at minus 14.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: That - that's correct.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Your landing in - your weather in the landing area, which is about 560 miles south of Samoa, is now predicted to be about 1500, scattered, high broken. Waves are going to be 5 feet, the winds are going to be l5 knots , visibility 10 miles, showers in less than 10 percent of the area, and you will be landing at 08:00 local, roughly.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Hey, that all sounds pretty good.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Say, Fred, did you get the dope on the Saturn IV impact - S-IVB impact?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes. Just as we came around the corner, Vance, they told us that it hit - I don't recall the position now, but it was a ... impact ... and recorded it on the ... seismometer.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes. It impacted 74 nautical miles from the ALSEP, and the passive seismic detected major seismic activity on all long period channels and this was - this activity was dectected for 4 hours afterwards with [???]amplitude. And the impact also was detected by high-energy channels ... The high-energy channel of the SIDE.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes. That ought to add ...

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. The Earth LPD number that time was 32.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Thirty-two.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: How do you read now. Jack?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: I'm reading you, Fred. I've got a lot of background noise, though.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Jack, I can definitely tell we're moving away from the Moon, now. I got it all in the monocular at one time. We're right over the top of FPA 8 right now.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: You're right over the top of what?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: 0n a point between it and Censorinus - FPA 8 and - the point halfway between there and Censorinus.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Fred-o, would say the checkpoint over which you're right now?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. And incidentally, the DELTA-V on the Moon was zero, so it's coming back down. The point looks like we're just about straight over is around Censorinus and the point between it and FPA 8.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. And, Jack, the Earth LPD angle is 24 degrees.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Earth at 24. And it looks like you're getting up to about 15 on the CO2, so we want you to select SECONDARY and swap out the primary cartridge. Over.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. I'll select SECONDARY and swap out the primary cartridge.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Fred. And when you select - When you swap out the primary cartridge, don't reselect PRIMARY. Stay on SECONDARY until we use the secondary up. Over.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. I'm changing out primary and - stay in SECONDARY until we use it up.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: And the change out is complete. Jack.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Copy the changeout complete, and we're reading 4.5 on the CO2 here.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. I'm ...

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. And the Earth LPD was 8 degrees.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Did you - Did you say S degrees, Fred?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Affirmative.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Well, I missed the Moon on that one. Jack. But I would guess - estimating back a little bit, the LPD angle was somewhere around 42.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Fred, I'm having a hard time reading you, but I think you're giving me a LPD angle.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Roger. That's it. Jack. The Moon is about 42.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: You say the Moon is at 22?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Four two, 42.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, 4 2. Thank you.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: How you doing there, Fred? 03 13 50 33 CDR

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Fred. I can just barely hear you saying something in the background and I can't make out what it is.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Hello, Houston; Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Hello there, Aquarius. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger. And Fred is being relieved now. He's - went back to get some rest. This is Lovell here who's got the duty.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Gee whiz. You got up kind of early, didn't you?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: It's cold back there in the command module.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Well, what we were really thinking about doing was letting you sleep a little bit longer because we figure you're pretty worn out.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: well, I'll go back and forth once in a while to get a ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Is Jack up there with you?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: No, Jack's still sacked out.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. we're kind of watching this PTC a little bit. Fred's been giving us a few LPD angles as we swang by the center of the Earth - center of the Moon. We noticed that the COMM has been degrading just a little bit so you might have to talk up.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger. Understand.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And we just went on to the secondary C02 canister. Fred swapped out the primary, but we want to stay on the secondary until it is all used up.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. I'm going to use the tape ... C02.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We're reading a partial pressure C0^ of 4.2 millimeters. We're cleared to use the secondary until it reaches 13.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. That's good.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, in comparing our initial estimates of water usage and electrical power usage, it appears that we re right on the money on water usage, and we re using a little less amperes than we had originally expected in our first analysis, so we're either right on the money or just a little bit ahead of the game in that regard.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Well, that sounds encouraging, Jack.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And there are a few temperatures that we're watching for you. You have the heaters powered down. We're looking at them, and those include the PIPAs, the ASA, the quad temps, and your propellants, except for tie DPS propellant.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. I've got them here.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We have, as you probably know, several groups working on procedures from here on out. Wo have a group working on midcourse corrections to determine a system, the attitudes, how to do it, alinement techniques, and so forth. We have a group working on the entry, including how and when we're going to activate the CSM. We have a group working on the CSM system status, and in a few hours - Later on tomorrow, from where we see it, we're going to go to some base configuration on the CSM and we're going to conduct a MAIN BUS B check. Right now the C0MM is kind of degrading, and I can't hear what you're about to say very well. But I just want to keep you advised as to how things are going here. And remember you've got duty on the antennas.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, are you reading Houston? 03 14 05 04 CDR

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. I can hear you talking but I can't tell what you're saying because you're way down in the background noise.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Can you hear Aquarius now? Over.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Oh, yes. That's much better. Did you get my report on the various types of people and what they're doing around here?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger. Sounds like you had things well organized. You might also consider what kind of a stowage configuration ... and what we can leave behind in Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. I didn't catch that suggestion on account of the background noise; maybe we can pass it on when it gets more favorable.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I'm thinking in terms of stowage. Whether we would leave the suit, ... the Hycon camera in Aquarius, prior to ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. I heard you say something about using the Hycon camera in Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Negative, Jack. I'm thinking of reentry stowage attitude. Whether we should - what we should leave behind in Aquarius. Leave the suits behind; leaving such big items as the Hycon cameras in Aquarius. Over.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Oh, understand. You're thinking about stowage. What'll we leave behind in Aquarius when we fall back into Odyssey. Is that right?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: That's affirmative.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We've people working on that, too.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And we presently are tracking you at 22 500 miles from the Moon, moving out at 4400 feet a second.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Aquarius. Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, Jim, earlier in the evening, we thought there was a misunderstanding about the amount of potable water you can drink, but we want to advise you that you can drink as much water as you want to. There's 38 pounds in the potable tank, and that's about all you'll need. The doctors suggest you drink as much fruit juices as you want, too.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger, Jack.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jim, earlier in the evening, Fred-o reported some venting out of window number 1 in the command module. He also reported a piece of loose metal about 4 inches square, silver, floating by, and one thing we were trying to establish is whether or not this is a new venting or whether this is part of the residual venting of our original problem. Do you have any more words or comments? And one thing he was doing was taking some photographs and we authorized photographs, targets of opportunity, using the lunar-surface camera number 1, and use the setting of 1/250 of a second, and not knowing precisely what f-stop to use, we suggested taking three of each, using settings of f:4, f:5.6, and f:8. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger, Jack. The venting really seems to ... I reported earlier, I alsc spotted the large piece go by and prior to our ... burn ... The venting you see now is much greater ... went into the dark mode, you could easily distinguish stars and didn't have the bright articles and bright objects, and I also have the camera here to take photographs.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. Once again I hear you talking back there but I can only pick out a few words; maybe we'll have a better time.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, we're trying to improve our communications. Could you turn the BIOMED off and give us a voice check, please?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Voice check follows: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 5, 4, 3, 2, 1; voice check out.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. That seemed to be better.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: How are you doing there, Aquarius?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: We're doing good. Jack.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Sometime when you get two guys available there and you could construct one of these lithium hydroxide rigs, I'd like to have you get the materials together, and we'll go through the steps together.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Sounds good. And how do you read me now?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Well, there is a lot of background noise, and sometimes it is worse than others and right now I hear you better than 1 have in the past.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. I'm kind of curious the amount of perturbations our PTC attitude is taking. I notice that we are getting off attitude, and I'm just kind of curious how far we can let this go.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We were tracking the attitudes with Fred earlier and it looked like what we were doing was oscillating about some point, but coming back. Are you detecting some kind of divergence now?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Not too much. I notice that it's different than when I went to sleep. We are more at an angle now with the terminator of the Earth, so when we started out, we were just about parallel with the terminator, and now we are canted off somewhat. I haven't seen any trends, though, of going back and forth.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, Jim, our current plan is to not correct the PTC. We're going to take whatever we get and live with it. And we can kind of keep track of what's going on a little better if when you swing past the Earth and swing past the center of the Moon, if you could read off the LPD angles for the center of the Earth and the center of the Moon. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger. Will do. Jack. And I'm looking into the AOT now to the right - No, the number 4 detent, and we are venting something back there; I can see particles moving on past the command module. What it is, I don't know.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Can you identify the quadrant?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Well, I'm looking through the right rear reticle now of the AOT, and when I was back in the command module, I could see it out of the CM 1 window. The particles are rather small, but they are coming out with some force. That's probably what is disturbing our PTC attitude.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes, that sounds quite probable, Jim. That's about the same report we got from Fred, but we haven't been able to identify what they might be and probably won't be able to until we crank up the CSM. If there's any change in that status, why, we just want to keep advised of it.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger. Understand.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, Aquarius, we are setting a pretty good vector on you now. And it looks like you're a little bit outside of the corridor. We're looking at a 7-foot-per-second midcourse at 104 hours. We are going to come up with an entry interface minus 8 pad to use in the event of a loss of C0MM situatior

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger. Understand, and I hope you have that pro- cedure for attitude.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We are ginning up a procedure for attitude for you, Jim. For the no-COMM case, it may be a little different than what the guys working on the procedures come up with for the burn at 104 hours.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: What I'm saying, Jim, is the guys who are working on this attitude situation for the burns haven't made their final conclusions yet, but in the interim period, we want to come up with something you can use, in the event that you lose COMM.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I concur.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius. The Earth is going through the 10-degree line or angle of the LPD.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We copied 10 degrees. Is that Earth or Moon, Jim?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: That is Earth.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Earth 10 degrees. Thank you.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And, Houston ... As we ... No! ... has an angle of about 24 degrees on the LPD.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We read 24, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: That's affirm.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Jack, ... the LPD on the Moon now is 22 degrees.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. I'm reading you better, Jim. Say again, please.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger. The LPD now on the Moon is 22 degrees. 1 missed the Earth last time. I'll get it this time.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Twenty-two degrees, and looks like we've come up with a procedure for the attitude control on the upcoming burns. Probably the ones that we'll use from here on out.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. Standby 1.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: It's going to be a few minutes before I'm ready to read it up to you.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Jack, on the first of the LPD angles is about a minus 2 degrees and just slightly above the top line.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Just went by minus 2 degrees. Is that on the Earth?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: That's the Earth. Now, I don't know whether we're oscillating back and forth or not. Jack, or whether it's a continual motion. We'll have to see here.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. The Moon now has an LPD angle of 10 degrees

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. The Moon at 10 degrees.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. Just as kind of a lead-in to this procedure that we're going to use for the midcourse burn, I'd like to say that we're going to use AGS and it's going to be a manual burn. The attitude will be controlled manually; the start/stop on the engine will be controlled manually. So we have a pretty good vector on you now, and it turns out you're coming in a little bit too shallow. So what that means is we're going to make our burn to come in a little more steeply, and we're going to be coming in around the dark side of the Earth. Therefore, to come in more steep, our thrust should be in the direction of the Sun. Does that all make sense to you?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I think so. We're going to use AGS for a burn monitor. The burns are going to be manual, and they're going to be started manually and stopped manually.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. And your reentry is around the dark side of the Earth, and since we're coming in shallow, we're going to have to burn toward the Sun to make it steeper. Do you follow that?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: That's affirm. Especially these burns will be perpendicular to our flight path and to the Sun giving a steeper entry angle.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. I heard you say perpendicular to your flight path, which is affirmative, and I didn't get the rest of your statement.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I understand the technique. Jack. We're burning to give us time to steepen our entry angle, and it will be perpendicular to our flight path for corridor control.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. That's affirmative. So, in general terms, what we're going to have to do is to power up the AGS and bring up the AGS eight-ball, and then to set up your altitude, put the COAS in the front window, and guidance control will be in AGS, of course. But manually orient the spacecraft to place the center of the Earth directly out the Z-axis. Then rotate about the Z-axis to place the point of the crescent on the Y-axis of the COAS. And this will have your plus X-axis in the direction of the Sun as we discussed before. So the crescent will be up with the point down. Copy that?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. We'll have to over that again. The COAS will be out front window; we'll place the Earth in the center of the COAS, and, let's see, the center of the Earth right now is parallel to the LPD which is about parallel to our X-axis. And we'll have to rotate about 90 degrees to get our X-axis pointing toward the Sun.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. So we want to get the Y-axis of the spacecraft parallel to the terminator by putting the points of the crescent on the Y-axis.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger. Understand.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Seriously, Jack, when I stop the spacecraft looking at - at the Earth, I'm going to have to roll - in LM terms, roll the spacecraft 90 degrees to get the tip of the Earth all on the Y-axis.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative, Jim. You're going to have to roll 90 degrees to point your plus X-axis at the Sun and put the crescent - the points of the crescent on the Y-axis. The points of the crescent on the Y-axis with the COAS pointed at the center of the Earth will take care of your yaw and your pitch.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. After you get that orientation to come in a little more steeply, we perform an AGS body-axis aline which is at 400 plus 5 on the DEDA. If the AGS ball is up at this time, the AGS ball will go to 000. We can talk more about control modes later, but we'd recommend doing this, of course, in AGS ATTITUDE HOLD - ATTITUDE HOLD. Put your YAW to MODE CONTROL and leave PITCH and ROLL in PULSE, therefore, controlling your attitude with the TTCA. We don't want to use the gimbal, so have ENGINE GIMBAL OFF. We'll make these burns at 10-percent thrust. We'll use a Manual start and stop. For ullage, we'll use the PLUS-X TRANSLATIONAL button, and ullage will be for 10 seconds. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. I understand what you're saying, but you'll have to repeat it here.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We'll perform the burn in GUIDANCE CONTROL to AGS. And MODE CONTROL to ATTITUDE HOLD. Your ATTITUDE CONTROL switches will be ROLL to PULSE, PITCH to PULSE, and YAW to MODE CONTROL. So the AGS will control your yaw and you will use the TTCA to control pitch and roll. ENGINE GIMBAL OFF; 10-percent thrust. Start and stop manual. For ullage, use the plus-X translational button; 10 seconds ullage. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. For the burn there will be go to GUIDANCE CONTROL AGS, MODE CONTROL ATT HOLD, ATTITUDE CONTROL switches will be ROLL PULSE, PITCH PULSE, YAW MODE CONTROL. We'll use TTCA control for pitch and roll. ENGINE GIMBAL will be OFF; we'll be using 10-percent thrust; we'll start and stop manually, the ... control ullage will be a PLUS-X TRANSLATIONAL button. And also our thrust will still be, but before that we are going to do an AGS aline ... ball ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative, Jim. After you get oriented in the attitude you want to burn in, do an AGS aline which is - an AGS body-axis aline which is 400 plus 5. When you get ENTER, this will bring ball up to 000, and I want to confirm that you - that you said ENGINE GIMBAL OFF. 0-F-F. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger. Confirm that ENGINE GIMBAL will be off.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And, Jack, how long do you estimate the length of the burns will be?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. The length of the burns are going to be probably less than a minute. And we want you to have cut-off based on time. So we will give you a burn time. And I have a P30 maneuver pad for midcourse-7 in the event that we lose COMM if you are ready to copy.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. Ready to copy.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. P30 LM maneuver pad: the purpose is midcourse-7. NOUN 33 is 134:59:42.98. NOUN 81 is N/A. Ha is N/A. Hp is plus 0020.5. DELTA-Vr is 0019.3. Burn time, 0:39; 008, 000; the rest is N/A; thrust will be at 10 percent. Read back.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: All right. This is midcourse-7 corridor control, and it's in case we lose COMM: 134:59:42-98; NOUN 81 is N/A; 42, N/A; plus 0020.5; 0019.3. Burn time, 0:39; 008, 000. All the rest is N/A: thrust 10 percent.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. That's a good readback, and in the event of lost COMM, use the procedures that I gave you. It may be that between now and tomorrow these procedures will change a little bit, so we'll go with what we've got now, and stand by for something better if it comes. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. I'm looking at your burn pad and I see that the ... total gimbal ... 19.3 feet per second.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. We verify 19.3 feet per second for 39 seconds.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: The old midcourse technique sounds like something that we came up with on Apollo 8.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes, everybody wondered if you would remember that; by golly, you did.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Hey, Jim, I got a little bit more information - maneuver pad, I got LAT/L0NG range to go, VERB 10 and GET; if you got a place to copy that down, I'll give it to you for EMS.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Stand by.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. I just have the last three blocks. NOUN 61: latitude, minus 021.62; longitude, minus 165.37; range to go, 1162.9; VERB 10:36291: GET of .05g is 142:41:30; read back.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I didn't get the latitude, but the longitude is minus 165.67; range to go, 11629; velocity 36291; 142:41:30.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. The latitude is minus 021.62; I have a correction on the longitude - minus 165.37. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger, Jack. The latitude is minus 21.62; longitude is minus 165.37, and this goes in conjunction with that midcourse 7 pad you gave us.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative. That means no maneuvers between now and midcourse 7. And this is a horizontal in-plane burn, plus X, toward the Sun, 19.3 feet Per second.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger. ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, Jim, on the - Setting up the AGS, right after you do the 400 plus 5, you should do a 400 plus all balls. And one other point we want to clarify is that we know that you're surc that this burn will be made with the Plus X-axis pointing at the Sun to make the entry angle steeper. You got it?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: That's right. Jack. What I'm going to do is - We'll stop with the Earth in the commander's window, the COAS down, and then I'm going to maneuver the spacecraft so that I have the lighted portion of the Earth at the top of the window; that is, the COAS will be along the plus-Y of the spacecraft and the top of the window - of the rendezvous window, I should be looking into the Sun. That means I'll be burning towards the Sun and steepening the angle.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirm, Jim. I - You got the attitude right, and did you copy about doing a 400 plus all balls after - you do the 400 plus 5? That is, a 400 plus 5 and a 400 plus all zeros back to back.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger. I have copied that.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Jack - this is Aquarius. I'm not too sure how long or with what force the venting is going to do to our trajectory. However, you might keep a check on that. It may have been going on for sometime.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, Jim. We've been taking a look at it. We haven't been able to detect it on the Doppler, however.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: But we think it's pretty small.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And, Houston, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Jack, would you give me a time hack on an even GET so I can start my watch.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Coming up on 87 hours and 35 minutes, we will be there in 30 seconds. Set it for 87.35.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Just give me a hack at 88 hours.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. I'll give you a hack at 88 hours. That'll be another 25 minutes.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: All right. Thanks. 03 15 41 53 CLR Houston, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. Let's just talk over how I'm going to get to the attitude and then do the burn. What I'm talking about is the control techniques. The way it looks now I'll try to stop the spacecraft in yaw with the Earth out my window. aaen we'll be in GUIDANCE or we'll be AGS CONTROL; we'll be in - yaw will be in MODE CONTROL. Then we'll be using the TTCAs to control the pitch and then control the roll. I don't see another way we can control the combination that we have here without using the TTCAs. Then we will also use the TTCA during engine burn. Do you people concur with that technique?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jim, that sounds like the one that is best to use to me. Let me talk it over with the rest of the guys here, and we'll advise you.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jim, in that control mode, that sounds like the best way to go. The only thing you'll have to do is to get ATTITUDE HOLD in the AGS, and so before you start to maneuver, you'll have to bring the AGS up, and get a 400 plus all zeros in there, and then AGS will respond in yaw when you go to MODE CONTROL. That is, AGS will con- trol your yaw in MODE CONTROL and your pitch and roll can be taken care of in PULSE with a TTCA. After you get in attitude, then, you'll have to re-do an AGS body axis aline which is 400 plus 5, then go back to 400 plus all zeros again.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Right, Jack. That was my next question. I don't want to aline the AGS ball 000 until I am in po- sition, so we use that as a primary attitude burn monitor device.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, Jim, you can do a 400 plus all zeros any time you want to; that just tells the AGS that you want it to control your attitude should you go to ATTITUDE HOLD in MODE CONTROL.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger. I understand, but after we get to the attitude, we'll do a 400 plus 5 to ret the AGS aline ball, and then we'll do a 400 plus zero.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Affirmative.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Another thing, Jim, is while you're maneuvering to that attitude using AGS to control your yav. if you find out enroute to that attitude that you didn't quite have the yaw where you wanted it to be, you can use your ACA and tweak up the yaw, and your AGS needles go right back to zero because you zero the attitude errors.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger. Sounds good.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jim, you'll be splashing down about 560 miles southeast of Samoa at about 0800 local time.
