The weather forecast for the area is good; 1500, scattered, high broken, 10-mile visibility. The seas will be 5-foot waves, 15 knots, and you'll be going to Samoa by boat and/or aircraft. You'll spend either the night on the boat or in Samoa, and return to Ellington by 141 on Saturday, the following day.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger. Would you tell the people of the LRL to turn it off.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Oh, no. We're going to do the whole bit.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And don't forget my hack at 88 hours. Jack.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Say again, please, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I want to get my hack hack at 88 hours.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. That will be in about 6-l/2 more minutes.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jim, we got a couple of news-type items. President Nixon has chosen a judge from Minnesota for the position of Associate Justice in the Supreme Court. A bill giving federal employees a 6-percent pay raise passed the House and went to the President; includes the military. And the air traffic controllers returned to work.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Well, that's great. You think they'Il consider this. flight pay ?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Well, we might be able to work out some arrangement.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Standing by for the 88-hour time hack.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Say again, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Standing by for the 88-hour time hack.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We got a minute to go.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Coming up on the 88-hour mark. I'll give you a 2-second delay. Stand by to mark.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: MARK.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I got it.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: How are you doing, Jim?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Pretty good. Jack. Say, you might have the people look at our DPS burn card to see what changes have to be made on it for the burn.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Heard you say look at the DPS burn; you'll have to say what about it again, please.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger, Jack. You might take a look at our DPS burn card, our checklist card that we have in the LM, and see what changes might have to be put in that checklist.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, DPS burn card.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: How're you doing there, Jim?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. It appears that we're going - funny diversion here; the PTC attitude in - in pitch. I'm going to do a LPD check now, but the last time the Moon went around, it was above - way away above the LPD angle and I see the Earth coming around now which is going to be pretty low. They oscillate back and forth, but each time they seem to get a little farther away from the center line. You might think of some pro- cedure to reestablish PTC, if it's necessary.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jim, the only way we know of getting the as good or a better PTC than you've got right now is to crank up the G & N and we - We don't want to do that. So our plan is to just take whatever we get out of this, and later on, it may turn out by the time you get to burn attitude, you'll be right where you want to be.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. We'll just leave her go.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: What's our course of action to set up PTC after this midcourse at 107?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We thought you'd ask that.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: The only thing we can try to do, Jim, is to set the thing up manually and see what happens. There must be a better answer than that - -

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: - - and one course of action is to omit the mid- course and make a total midcourse, say, about 8 hours before entry. We haven't decided yet.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Right now we're talking about a 7-foot-per-second midcourse at 104 hours. And extrapolate that down to about 8 hours before entry. We gave you a pad for that - that's about, only 19 feet per second, so if it doesn't change too much - and we can get all kinds of DPS.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Understand. Sure like to keep this vehicle in the corridor though.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Can you think of any normal venting phenomena that might occur like maybe - a hydrogen tank that's over-pressurized relieving in the window?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes, we thought of that, Jim. 03 16 55 52 CO That ir, one possibility that we've thought of, Jim, because - We heated up that tank, and we haven't been using any hydrogen and, therefore. it could be venting in the overboard release.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Right. The only other thing I can think of when I look at it through the AOT is - it did appear to be coming from one spot; but that's the only difference although I can't see where it is coming from because it's beyond the curvature of the command module. But, it appears like it might be coming from more than this one spot.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Thank you. We hope that when we crank up the command module tomorrow that we'll be able to - or later on today - that we will be able to identify more closely what it's been coming from. But, the guidance guys say that they haven't been able to see the results of any venting in their data and it would take a very, very small amount to perturb their data.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Well, that's a note of encouragement.

transcript.speaker: SC
transcript.text: (Music)

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: You got a Chinese band going up there?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Oh, sorry. I forgot all about hot mike.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Sounds pretty good.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jim, we've had you scheduled for an eat period about an hour ago. I suppose you've taken care Of that. The other thing is we're kind of interested in knowing how long you're going to be at stick there, or if you're going to go back to bed or what?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. We're - We're going to set up a regular watch and sleep period here. Fred was up for a long time, so I got up a little bit early to relieve him. Jack and Fred are now asleep, so I'm going to let them sleep as long as they can, and then we'll have an eat period and then I'll go back to bed for a bit. And we'll separate the schedule.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We're right at the point now where, according to the flight plan that we made up for you, that you would have all finished eating and you and Jack would have the duty while Fred went to sleep. So, essentially, according to the plan we've got, you got up about 3 or 4 hours early. And - The next time that have that as a rest period for you is at 96 hours, which is 7 hours from now, and an hour before that, say at 95 hours, all three of you would eat, and then you and Jack would hit the sack again and Fred would have the duty until 102 hours. We'd be glad to take care of this work-rest cycle for you.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. That's good. Let me - Let me wait until they get up, or at least Jack gets up. He should be getting up before Fred. And we'll try to get back on the schedule. I hate to wake everybody up right now though, if they're sleeping.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Your choice on that. As soon as Jack gets up, I'd suggest we go ahead and break up these lithium hydroxide canisters and make a couple of them. Jack could work on that. It's going to take four sets of hands, I think.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. We'll make that the project, getting the lithium hydroxide canister squared away.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Hi, Jim. We've got a flight handover in about 2 minutes, and we'll have a temporary loss of COMM. You don't need to switch antennas. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay; fine.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston through Madrid for a C0MM check. How do you read?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Loud and clear, Joe. How me?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: ... asleep? 03 18 06 46 CMP I ... Maybe ... ... hydroxide ...

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: ... on secondary. We'll let it go to 15. Why don't you get on a headset, and I'll be down ... for ...

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Jack's up with me now and you all ... procedure for making these lithium hydroxide devices, and soon as he gets on his helmet, he'll be ready to copy, and then he'll get started making one.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger that, Jim. Understand - -

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: On second thought -

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I'll give Jack the headset for a while and he'll copy down your instructions.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. I didn't copy your second thought. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I'll give Jack the headset and let him copy the instructions.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. The way I thought it might be best to do it would be to have you gather the equipment and let us talk you through your procedure while you do it. Now, maybe you could give Jack the headset and - and - get the equipment together, and we'll talk you through the procedure. I think it'll be a little easier to do that way than if you tried to copy it all down - and then go do it.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Do you have any equipment listed? I'll just get it and give it to him and I can just sit here where I am.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. I think the equipment you'll need will be two command module lithium hydroxide canisters, a roll of the gray tape, the two LCGs, because we're going to use the bags from the LCGs, and one - one LM cue card - one of those cardboard cue cards which you will cut off about an inch and a half out from the ring. Now, I think that's all we'll need. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. ... Okay, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Hello, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. That's two lithium hydroxide canisters, one roll of that special gray tape, two LCGs which we're going to use the bags from, one LM cue card and ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. That's affirmative, Jim. If you'll just cut the cue card, which is a handy piece of stiff paper the right size, about an inch and a half from the rings. Just cut off the ring holes, in other words, and you'll have a card about 11 inches long and probably 6 inches wide, something like that.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, ... I'll have Jack gather up the stuff.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: ... that roll of gray tape.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: ... Okay. ... and ... plastic bags.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Yes. Bring it down here. One LM cue card. I get that.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. I got the canisters.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Houston; Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes. Aquarius, Houston. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: We have gathered the materials, and I can put Jack on the headset and he can copy the instructions ... do you see any need for - or should I copy it to give them to him, or do you think they're too detailed?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Why don't you put him on the headsets, Jim, and I'll read it out to him.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Joe. ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. Did anybody ever tell you that you got a 60-day extension on your income tax. Over.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes. I think - I think somebody said that when you are out of your country, you get a 60-day extension.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay; right. Okay. I'm ready to start into the procedure. When you answer me back, speak up - speak up into the microphone, because our downlink is pretty noisy. The first thing we want you to do, and we'll do this on one canis- ter, and then let you go ahead and repeat it on the second. So take one of the LCGs and cut off the outer bag. By cutting along one the heat seals; do it carefully and close to the heat seal, because we may have to use the outer bag if we damage the inner bag. So go ahead and do that, and then we'll do the next step.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Take an LCG, cut, the outer bag by the heat seal. Be careful not to damage the inner bag. Right?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Right. Just cut along one side.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Hey, Houston, Odyssey - or Aquarius. We've dene that.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. Now - now remove the inner bag from the outer bag, and cut the inner bag, also, along one of the heat seals down one side.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Remove the inner bag from the outer bag, cut the inner bag along the heat seal along one side.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. That's correct. Do that, and report,

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Joe. We've got that done.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. Now you can put the LCG itself; that is, take it out of the inner bag, put it in the outer bag, and stow it some place; we recommend U-1, but you can stow it wherever it's convenient.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: ... outer bag ... and stow it back in ...

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Joe. We've got that.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Now pick up one of the lithium hydroxide canisters, and let me describe which end is which. It's approximately square on one - one of the vented flat ends, has the strap, and that end we call the top, the end opposite we call the bottom. Is that clear? Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Right.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. I've got it, Joe.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Now then, we're - we want you to take the tape and cut out two pieces about 3 feet long, or a good arm's length, and what you're - what we want you to do with them is to make two belts around the sides of the canister, one belt near the top and one belt near the bottom, with the sticky side out; wrap it around, sticky side out, as tight as possible. It'll probably take both of you to get it nice and snug. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, now -

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Now we've got to make the belt real taut here.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: How's that?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Real tight. And then ...

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Joe.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. Did you have - -

transcript.speaker: SC
transcript.text: - - Hey. Houston, are you reading?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jack - -

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: - - We've got the two belts around the top and the one around the bottom all done.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, fine. The next step now is to anchor that tape, and the way we want you to do that is to cut about a 2-foot length off the roll and then tear it lengthwise so that you have two strips about 2 feet long and about a half an inch wide. And you'll wrap those around the canister at right angles, more or less, to the tape that you've got so that it goes across the top and across the bottom; and when it goes across the top and the bottom, put it so that it's outboard of the center hole and try to get it over one of the ridges between the screens, so that it won't block the flow. Is that clear? Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Yes, Joe. Very good.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Press on.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. I've got a cut length right hers and we'll tear it lengthwise ... and I'm going to go around right here at this ridge all the way around at right angles and anchor it ...

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Yes.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Joe, just to clarify that, sticky end down. Right? On the tape that I am putting on now?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: I didn't quite copy that. Jack. Say again.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. That will be the sticky end down on the container, right?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Oh, that's correct. I forgot to say that. That's right.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: ... hold that one right here, if I can set it.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Joe; Aquarius. We've got that done.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. The next step is to get the EVA cue card and use it to form an arch over the top of the canister; just tuck one short end under one ridge on the top the other one against the ridge on the other side so that it forms a rounded arch over the top of the canister. You see. Jack, what we're going to do is slip the bag over this whole assembly and the cue card will serve to keep the bag from being sucked down against the screen. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. I got the idea.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. And when you've done that, to hold the arch in place, just run a strip of tape across the side of the - that is, across the top of the arch, and anchor it down to the sticky strips along each side.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. I got the idea. Okay. Let me just repeat it here. Take a cue card, form an arch over the top, bringing it under the side here. When we're through, run a piece of tape from the sides across the top of that to anchor to the other side.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's correct.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. It worked.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: The top. ... Across the top.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Looks like you're going to have to cut the cue card slightly.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Doesn't have to be really ... over that the only thing we're ... we can just take the scissors and cut off the edge here. The only thing this does, Jim, is prevent this from being sucked down into the container.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Still going to need some more tape. Cut off the end. Okay. Whack off the bottom. ...

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Joe. We've got that arch built, and it's all taped in securely.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. The next step is to stop up the bypass hole, which is the hole inR the center of the bottom of the canister; we want to stop that up because we don't want to bypass the flow; and I forgot to tell you to get something to stick in that hole. We recommend that you either use a wetwipe, or cut off a piece of sock and stuff it in there, or you could probably even crumble up some tape and use that. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. We'll start plugging up the bypass hole.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Plug that hole. We can either - we can put some either - Let's cut a piece of your towel there.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Sounds good.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Houston; Aquarius. We have the bypass hole all plugged up.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Aquarius. The next step is take the inner LCG bag that you cut open, and slip it over the top of the canister, when you do that, orient it so that the ears of the bag, that is, the corners should stick cut on the closed end - are oriented along the open ends of the arch, because we're going to snip one of those corners to stick the hose in. Pull it down until it fits snugly over the arch. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Joe. Slip the bag over the canister so that the arch is at the bottom of the bag and that the ears are along oriented along, let's see - I guess it would be - would be at the sides of the arch.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Depends on what you mean by sides - over the - the open ends of the arch.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Right, the open ends of the arch.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Joe. We've got that done.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Now press the bag against the sticky belts that we put on the sides of the canister. If there is any excess material, just kind of pleat it, so that it makes a fairly tight seal, and then take another 3-foot strip of sticky tape and wrap it around the outside of the bag opposite the bottom - the bottom sticky belt - to make a nice tight seal.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. I'll do it. Okay. Now they want two strips around here to make a tight seal.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Joe. We've got the canister inside the bag, two strips around the sides of the bag, real tight, and both sealed.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay; real fine. Now there's probably a couple of inches of excess bag sticking our around the bottom of the canister. To prevent this from sucking in against the bottom screen, we'd like you to trim it off with the scissors, and when you've done that, we'd like you to cut two more strips of tape about 12 inches long or so, cut the - tear them lengthwise to get four pieces 12 inches long and 1/2-inch wide, and then use those four strips to secure the bag by passing the strips from the sides of the canister outside the bag around the bottom of the canister and back up the other side, and when you do this, just as you did on the top, make them go outward of the hole and in between the screens. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. You want me to trim the excess material. that's sticking off here; trim it at the edge of that canister? Or do you want any excess left over?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: No, you don't need to have any excess. Just trim it approximately level.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Let's do that first.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Now, Joe, you want to cut four strips, 12 inches long each, l/2-inch in diameter. Tape that along the outsides of the bag across the ribs.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's correct. Jack. That's just for additional security on the bag. When you get those done, you'll have - You'll have two strips going one way, and the other two will be perpendicular to them.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Houston; Aquarius. We've got the four strips in place.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We're in business now with the bag, and the next step to perform is to get ready to put the red suit hose, either the commander's or the LMP's because we're - we're going to want you to have both of these made up eventually, into the top of the - of the bag, and to do that you, first of all, have to assure that the - that the red hose is separated from the blue hose. But we'll be back to you with a procedure and discussion about that after you get the switch configuration set up. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, I'm going to go get the switch configura- tion done now before Jim goes to bed so I don't disturb him.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: (Laughter) Okay. Sorry about that.

transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, before I hit the sack, Joe, I just want to make sure - How are you still planning an MCC at 107 and what's the latest find?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. We are still gathering our thoughts on the MCC, but some of the considerations go like this: FIDO tells us that we can do that correction probably as late as 118 hours, with no significant DELTA-V penalty, and with plenty of tracking thereafter to make sure that we've done the right thing, and to set you up for a late MCC if we need it, which we probably wouldn't. We are happy with the PTC mode that you are in now, and, although we are working up a - an AGS PTC mode to use after the midcourse correction, we'd kind of like you to stay in this PTC for a while because it is doing good. We are looking at the weather in the landing area. We don't think we'll have a problem but we are checking it real close. and if there is any changing that we want to do, we want to get it into this midcourse course correction. And for reasons like that, we are considering possibly delaying the midcourse correction from 104 hours to some time between there and 118. We'd like to know what you think about it. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: We have no druthers. As long as we do the mid- course and there is plenty of tracking thereafter to correct for another midcourse; that's my only concern.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. Roger that. And based on FIDO's input that he'd like to do it not later than 24 hours before EI, we will be doing it prior to 118 hours.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Hello, Houston; Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Go.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Question, Joe. Jim has been talking to me about how we are going to do this midcourse, and awhile back when we went through this power up, we had pulled the STAB/CONTROL ASA breaker. I was wondering - we lost the heaters in the ASA - I was wondering how it looked? What kind of shape it's going to be in?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Stand by on that one, Fred.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Fred, Houston.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. I am told that we'd see 38 degrees for that package, and it'll be okay for the burn. We're massaging the detail procedures for this burn at this time and we expect to have a real clean setup to you in plenty of time.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, very good.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: And I don't know if Jack passed it on to you, but Jack and I just finished logging about 6 hours sleep, each.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, Fred. Copy that. Is it a little chilly up there?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes. We made the mistake of putting up the window shades, which we won't do again; and with this powered-down mode, we're not generating much internally, and it really did get chilly.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes. I guess you'll have to generate your own heat in there for a while.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Deke says unstow the Exer-Genie.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Over.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Go ahead, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Fred, just wanted to let you know in advance that we're coming up on the redline C02 value for the secondary canister, and we expect to get there in something like a half hour, at which time we'll be asking you to switch over to the command module canisters. I have the rest of that procedure ready and I just wanted to warn you a little bit in advance. Over.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. And I've got a question for you, Joe.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. The - I need to find out if the condensate container that we were going to use to strain some water in on the lunar surface - is that container also completely airtight? Okay to use it to put fluid in through here in zero g?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Fred, I didn't copy what you wanted to use it for. Over. 03 20 59 09 LMP

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Fred, Houston. We'll have to stand by for 1 minute. We are in a noisy state of COMM.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. How do you read now, Joe?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Oh, that's much better. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. I was just going to any we haven't had an overboard waste water dump since clear back around the other side of the Moon. About this time, we're running out of the bags we've got on board here.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. I'm - I'm stupid this morning, Fred. I'm not quite sure what you are getting at.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Joe. We need some place to put the urine.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. It sounds to me as if the suggested receptacle is perfectly satisfactory. Do you think you can use it in its present configuration?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Oh, yes. We got all the innerconnects - hookups we need, but I wasn't sure if that gadget was devised solely with the l/6g environment in mind, and whether it might leak somehow in zero g.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: I'll have them verify that, but off the top of my head, I'm sure it's going to be all right. We'll check it, Fred.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. How do you read, Joe?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Joe. One thing I've noticed, that a couple of circuits there now - the pulse ... - at least the number of them, is markedly decreased, and ... rather bad and, apparently, that added venting we had out of the service module was some overboard relief valve, maybe letting go, because it appears to have stopped now.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Fred. Copy that. Thank you.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: What do you read down there for partial pres- sure CO2?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Oh, let's see. We're reading 6.6 right now, Fred. What do you read?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: I'm reading about 12.5. I guess we've got a gage problem ... I did just get a MASTER ALARM and no caution light; we kind of figured that's what it was, with CO2 approaching its limit. Maybe it didn't quite come out here.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Let me get a go, and I think it's time for us to go ahead and put these other canisters on. Stand by 1.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. We went to 15 on the primary last night before 1 changed it and - - 03 21 24 16 CC Roger that, Fred. We wanted to 03 21 24 18 LMP I don't have a steady - I don't have a steady ECS light on at this time, Joe, so it must have just been a momentary.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We know when you went to 15 last night on primary. We want to switch out today at 7.6. Let me check and see if we're ready.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes. That's what it is, Joe. I've got something going on this alarm ... ECS light.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Fred, Houston. The C0MM isn't too sharp and I didn't copy.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Aquarius; Houston - -

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius. How do you read?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: - - Why don't you try it now? You're loud and clear now, Fred.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. I was just - I'm getting MASTER ALARMS every few seconds and I am catching a glimmer now of the ECS light. For the time being, I have ... - ... open. Okay, now we got the ECS light on steady.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Copy that. You have the MASTER ALARM, with the ECS light. We are ready to go ahead and get you on the command module canisters. And as the first step, I'd like to know whether you've inserted the commander's red hose to the second canister bag. Over. 03 21 27 29 IMP Okay. Yes. Sure enough; the commander's red hose is inserted into the canister bag.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Fred. The next thing I'd like you to do is to take some more gray tape and tape over half the outlet area of each of the blue nozzles; the commander's and the LMP's. The reason we're doing this is we're going to be running this loop through the secondary LiOH canister hole with the canister removed, and we don't have the flow restriction we need to keep the separator from overspeeding. Over.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Yes, that's right. So we want to tape over half of the - both the blue and the red commander hoses. Is that right?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Negative, Fred. That's half of the commander's blue hose and half of the LMP's blue hose - the outlet hoses.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Oh, okay. I'll tape over half of each of the outlets. Stand by.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. I'm going to turn off one suit flow valve at a time while I am doing the taping, Joe.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Say again, please, Fred.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, while I'm doing the taping, I'll have that particular suit flow valve in the suit DISCONNECT position momentarily.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Fine.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Row do you read now, Joe?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Fred. Reasonable COMM. Are you ready for the next step? Over.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. One correction - the red hose that's connected up right now to the lithium cartridge in the LMP's - Wait a minute.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Fred. Understand only the LMP's red hose is actually plugged into the canister bag. In that case, we would like you to follow the procedure for inserting the other red hose in the other canister bag as follows: you cut a diagonal hole in one comer of the bag. Look at the other bag and see how it was done. Stick the hose in about 6 inches. Try to get the outlet nozzle down if you can, or else sideways, and then just tape up the hose to the bag to make a nice tight seal. Over.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Jack's back in here. I guess he can do that. Stand by.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: How do you read, Joe?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Fred. Is that done? Over.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: No. That's still in works. I just wanted to comment you might pass on to Steve Grega, we thank you a lot for those rendezvous procedures. They went to making up these little boxes.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We appreciate your appreciating it. We're just having a ball down here working on all kinds of new procedures, Fred. The CPCB is in session, and we expect to have your entry procedures out here by Saturday or Sunday at the very latest.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Saturday or Sunday?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: At the very latest!

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Take your time. Jack.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Why don't you run that other hose back up in the tunnel so Jim can get some air.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes. I got it.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: And Joe, how you read now?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Satisfactory, Fred. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Back to the condensate container. I guess the only question I really need answered is will it leak?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Is will it leak? Oh, yes. Stand by l.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: And we've checked all the fittings and I know I can hook everything up to our UCDs. So, if it doesn't leak, we can transfer.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Fred. We still don't have a final answer on whether or not it'll leak. If you need it, I'd go ahead and use it; and standing by for your completion of the hose-insertion procedure.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. The hose-insertion procedure ... the second cartridge is complete.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. That's complete. The next step is to switch to the primary CO2 canister and remove the secondary canister and stow it. Over.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. I'm going to have to get off COMM here; I'll let Jack get the headset.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Hey, Joe. I'm on the headset now.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Is that secondary? ... secondary?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Both cartridges are out.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Joe. Fred has the secondary cartridge out. We're back on primary now.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. The next step is to place the command module canisters with the hoses attached in a suitable location to permit the bottom of the canister to be exposed to free airflow and tape them in place. Ideally, well, it doesn't matter. Just - just pick out your own spot.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. I'm going to tell yon where they are. They're both situated., as you say, with the bottom of the canister exposed to free air, and one is sitting right by the - the LMP's is sitting right by the EPS panel, and the CDR's is up in the tunnel.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jack, Houston. The COMM got real noisy there, and I didn't copy that. Stand by a moment.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Joe. How do you read now?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. That's real good. Jack; go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. The canisters are situated as you - as you would like with the bottom of the canister exposed to free air.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: The position of the LMP's canister - The LMP's canister is sitting on the EPS panel now, and the CDR's canister is positioned up in the tunnel.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Real fine. Jack. The next step is to physically separate both blue hoses a good distance away from the canister so that we don't short circuit the flow, and tape them in place; and the ideal location for them would be up in the tunnel so as to got some flow into the command module. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Both hoses in the - up into the command module?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Oh, you can use your judgment on that. Jack. We'd like at least one, and the recommendation that I got was to put them both up in the tunnel.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. We have the LMP's blue hose up by the LMP's window and the - Of course, the red hose is separated by some 4 feet. And the - Okay. We're going to - and the other hose - the - has the extension on it - The CDR's blue hose, of course, has the extension on it, and it's blowing way up in the command module. And the red hose is about - Oh, it's right at the docking ring where the blue latches are, so there's about 4 or 5 feet difference from there, too. Is this satisfactory?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. That sounds satisfactory. The next steps are - are suit-loop configuration steps, and the first one is to - -

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. SUIT DIV - -

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: - - is to place the SUIT DIVERTER valve to the PULL EGRESS position.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. SUIT DIVERTER valve to PULL EGRESS.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative - -

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: That's done - -

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. The next step is CABIN GAS RETURN to EGRESS. Over.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. Did you copy CABIN GAS RETURN to EGRESS? Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: No, I didn't get that, Joe. CABIN GAS RETURN to EGRESS.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's correct.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. That's done.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Next, SUIT CIRCUIT RELIEF to CLOSE. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: SUIT CIRCUIT RELIEF to CLOSE.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. I got that done.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. And the last step is select secondary CO2 canister. We'll let it flow through the empty hole, and let's see how we do.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Select secondary CO2 canister.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, Jack. That completes that procedure, and the next thing I've got for you is a procedure for going back into the command module and powering up the main buses temporarily using the BUS TIE switches. We want to do this for two reasons: first of all, we want it absolutely verified that there arc no loads on the main buses, that we've got everything off and that the buses look good; and the second thing we want to do is to Power the bus - the main buses, with the BUS TIE motor switches, and then depower them by pulling the circuit breakers, leaving the MAIN BUS TIE switches in the on position, just to assure that they'll be there when we need them, whether the batteries get cold or not. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Joe. How you read?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Better now, Jack. Satisfactory. Did you copy my rationale for the main bus powerup?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Yes, I did. You want to remove - You want to power up both buses, with the BUS TIE motor switches; first of all, to sec that there are no loads on the buses, and second, and then depower the buses by pulling the circuit breakers to insure that the motor switches don't - that the BUS TIES stay on so that they're there when we need them.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's correct. Jack. Are you ready to copy the procedure?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. As the first step, I have one change to the basic configuration that we gave you, and it's two more circuit breakers that we want open. On panel 225 - Are you ready to write that down? Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Yes. I'm all ready, Joe. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Joe, I'm all ready. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. On panel 225, we want the RENDEZVOUS TRANSPONDER FLIGHT BUS circuit breaker open, and the S-BAND I'M TRANSMITTER/DSE FLIGHT BUS circuit breaker open. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. TV RENDEZVOUS TRANSPONDER FLIGHT BUS, open; TV S-BAND TRANSMITTER/DSE FLIGHT BUS open on panel 225.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. That's correct. Jack. And now we'll go into the main bus powerup procedure. And the first step there, is on panel 5. We want the BAT CHARGER BAT A CHARGE circuit breaker closed, and the BAT CHARGER BAT B CHARGE circuit breaker closed. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. That's EAT CHARGER BAT A CHARGE, BAT CHARGER BAT B CHARGE, both closed on panel 5.

transcript.text: That's affirmative. We need them closed to power the switches. Next on panel 5, we want the EPS SENSOR SIGNAL MAIN A and MAIN B circuit breakers closed. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Panel 5, CB EPS sensor's signals MAIN A and MAIN B closed.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. That's affirmative. We need them closed so that you can read out your volts and amps. Next step, on panel 250, we want circuit breaker BAT A POWER ENTRY and POSTLANDING and BAT B POWER ENTRY and POSTLANDING, closed. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay on panel 250, CB BAT A POWER, ENTRY and POSTLANDING, closed; BAT B POWER ENTRY and POST- LANDING, closed.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative. And at that point, we'd like you to check the BAT bus voltages on both BAT buses to make sure we don't have any shorts. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Read the BAT bus voltages on BAT BUS A and BAT BUS B.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative. The next step on panel 275: circuit breaker MAIN A, BAT BUS A, closed, and circuit breaker MAIN B, BAT BUS B, closed. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. On 275, circuit breakers MAIN A, BAT BUS A, closed; MAIN B, BAT BUS B, closed.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative. The next step on panel 5: we want the MAIN BUS TIE A/C switch to the BAT A/C position, and verify proper voltage on MAIN BUS A, and read the amps on BAT A to make sure we don't have a short. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jack; Houston. We're in bad C0MM again; let's wait a minute.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. How do you read ...?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's better. Jack. Go ahead with your read- back;

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Place MAIN BUS TIE A/C, on, read MAIN BUS A current and voltage.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. That's affirmative. The next step will be the MAIN BUS TIE B/C switch to the on position and read MAIN B voltage and battery B amperage as above. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, MAIN BUS TIE B/C on; read MAIN B voltage and current.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. That is correct. Then to reconfigure from this configuration. Jack, we want you to leave the MAIN BUS TIE switches in the on position and pull the circuit breakers out in reverse order that we had you close them. Over; and do you want me to read them up individually?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: No, let me see if I've got it here. I go down to panel 275, open CB MAIN A, BAT BUS A and CB MAIN B, BAT BUS B. Then I go down to 250, and pull CB BAT A POWER ENTRY/POSTLANDING and BAT B POWER ENTRY/POSTLANDING and then up on panel 5, pull EPS SENSOR SIGNAL MAIN A, SENSOR SIGNAL MAIN B, BATTERY CHARGER BAT B CHARGE, BATTERY CHARGER BAT A CHARGE. And then close - I don't know whether you want me to close the RENDEZVOUS RADAR TRANSPONDER FLIGHT BUS and S-BAND TRANSMITTER/DSE FLIGHT BUS.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. We don't want you to close those last two. Those are changes to your basic configuration, and we want to leave them open for now. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. I'll do that. Was the rest of the readback okay?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's correct. Readback was 100 percent, and we'll wait to hear from you.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Joe. And just for confirmation, I went through the switch list you gave me. We are in exactly that configuration with one exception, and that is over on panel 382. I have not, the a - H2O ACCUMULATOR is in the OFF position so that if we need any more water, we can get it.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Roger, Jack. Copy that. On panel 382, you've left the Hl0 ACCUMULATOR valves in the OFF position, and we concur.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. And there's one other thing that I don't know whether you're aware of. We have no lithium hydroxide canisters in panel two fif- in - canisters now. So when we get ready to power up, you'll have to remind us when you want us to add some.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. We copy that. That's correct, and I'll add that to our basic checklist so that we won't forget it.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Real fine, Joe, and I'm on my way back into the command module.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Good deal.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Thank you.

transcript.text: How do you read, Joe?

transcript.text: Okay. Roger that, Fred.

transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Over.

transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Fred. We recommend that you push your MASTER ALARM circuit breaker in so you'll have audio and visual on that, and, also, we medical types are getting to feel left out down here, and we'd like you to give us BI0MED ... position, if you're plugged in for it, and we'll see whether it affects the voice or not. Over.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.text: Hey, Houston; Aquarius. On DOWN VOICE BACKUP S-band, how do you read me?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Read you now satisfactory.

transcript.text: Okay, And that's my

transcript.text: Okay, Thank you very much, Fred.

transcript.speaker: CC

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack just ... himself back down. And after he put on the 250 BAT A, BAT B breakers, he read BAT bus volts as 32.3 on A, 37.0 on B; he then punched in the 275 breakers, which tied the batteries to the buses, and at that time he read the A bus volts 32.0 on A, zero amps; 37.0 on B, zero amps.

transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. The C0MM got noisy there, and I want to make sure we get these numbers right, so I'd like to ask you to repeat them ...

In this configuration, MAIN A is at 32.0 volts, zero amps; MAIN B is at 37.0 volts, zero amps. So it looks like the buses are okay.

transcript.text: Okay, Fred. Copy those numbers and thank you very much. I assume you got them off all right.

transcript.speaker: CC

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: sounds better already. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. I'd just like to how's - how's our lith-o cartridge setup ... appear to be working down there.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We are reading 0.2 on our C02 sets here, and we're all delighted. It seems to be working fine.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Boy, that is great.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And Fred, Houston. In a Little while here, I'm going to have a procedure that I want to read up to you and have you copy down for future use. It's a procedure for powering the command module main bus off the LM, and it's something that we feel that's going to come in real handy later on for such things as popping off the command module entry batteries, and also possibly for doing some preheating and preliminary powering up of the command module before we get rid of LM. We'll have that for you in probably 10 or 15 minutes. Over.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, okay, Joe. That's good. Sounds good.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.text: Standby l, Joe.

transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.text: Okay, Joe. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Fred. This is a procedure for getting a read-out of the descent propcllant tank temps. It's no big problem, but our LM people say that the bottom of the descent stage is probably cooling off, and we just want to verify that the descent water tank will be okay. Right now, it looks as though it won't freeze until several hours after it's empty, but we want to have you read these temperatures out to us so we can see how good our predictions are. The procedure is, on panel 16, close the PROPELLANT DISPLAY/ENGINE OVERRIDE LOGIC circuit breaker. Over.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. The PROPELLANT DISPLAY OVERRIDE circuit breakers are closed. ... the propellant.

transcript.text: Okay. On DESCENT 1, I get a fuel temp of 66.5 degress, OX ... on DESCENT 2, I get ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Fred. We're in noisy C0MM here; I got DESCENT 1 fuel 66.5; stand by a second.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. How do you read, now ...?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's better. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. You got 66.5 on DESCENT 1 fuel temp, oxidizer temp is 66 degrees.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Copy - -

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: On DESCENT TANK S, fuel is reading 60 - Okay. DESCENT 2 fuel is reading 68 degrees; oxidizer, 65 degrees.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Copy that, Fred. Thank you. We'd like you to pull the circuit breaker, and we'll probably come to you again in 5 or 6 hours for another check. 03 22 40 14 LMP Okay. The panel 16 ENGINE ... OVERRIDE is open.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Over.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Over.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We're chasing a small glitch that we saw a while ago in the 02 flow rate which is now normal again, but what we'd like you to do is, first of all, to tell us whether, during that canister procedure, you moved O2 DEMAND REG A to any position other than CABIN, and then we'd like you to move it to OFF momentarily and back to CABIN for us.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. To answer your question, Joe, it's no. I checked the CABIN all the time. Qualitatively, when we switched to this configuration, it didn't seem like the frequency or the suit fan noise ... decreased ... logged down a little bit, but I'll follow your procedure. You want me to take REG A, go to close and back to CABIN; is that correct?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's correct, Fred.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. We're in close.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Thank you very much, Fred. I'll get hack to you if we see anything.

transcript.text: No. The question was, do you have a ... from the Moon burn.

transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP

transcript.text: We can't help them too much. Actually it isn't bad . .. but goddamned unfortunate. In part, I get a feeling ... now when I get ... Just before ... goes to zero in 1 second I'm going to pull them out ...

transcript.text: Go to the - Go to the technique for a lash and ... it's the burn technique.

transcript.text: ... I didn't realize that. That proves you've got a little bit above 50-percent odds that you're going to enter blunt end, and -

It lucked out twice and made a real peculiar ... They went to zero g ...
