transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Okay. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Joe. It - Our wobble in this PTC has picked up where the Moon is running by pretty high in the window and the Earth pretty low; so I expect - On the side where the Moon's present. we'.re having a little bit of trouble with the COMM ... breakout there in a couple of places.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Roger that, Fred.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: ... pressure gage as far as the noise ... get the thing from the AFT.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Go.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Joe, I'm all set to copy that procedure for powering up the command module from the LM, whenever you want to give it to me. When did you, I guess you want to put battery A out of the CHARGE, huh?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jack, we're not certain when the best time is to implement this procedure, and what we want to do at this time is read it up to you, so you'll have it and understand it and we'll - We'll be able to do it quickly when the time comes. And I don't have it for you quite yet. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: (Laughter) Okay. All right. I'll be standing by to copy it whenever you get it.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jack.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Joe, I got to switch antennas here. Okay, Joe, I read you on the FORWARD antenna.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jack, I have the procedure now to read up to you. Before I do, I want to mention something that will be of interest to Fred. We are looking at the SHe tank pressure rise and we expect it to blow. We don't know exactly what time it will go, somewhere around 105 hours or perhaps later than that. We've got plenty of blowdown capability. We just thought you ought to be informed.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Stand by. I'll tell him, now.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Fred, they said they're looking at the SHe tank pressure rise, and they expect it to blow somewhere around 105 hours ... Okay. Fred thought they did. ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Real fine. Are you ready for the procedure, now. Jack?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Yes. Joe, how long is it? Is it a big long one, or a short one, or a medium sized ... about how many pages?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: It's about - I'd say 15 to 20 steps. Jack. Some of it is LM stuff, and the rest of it is in CSM.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. I got a fresh page here, and I'm ready to copy.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. I'll give you the LM steps first. They have to be done first, and the first step is on panels 11 and 16, circuit breakers ASCENT CA, ASC ECA, two to close.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Panels 11 and 16 CBs ASCENT ECA to closed.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Next step: panels 11 and 16 CB ASCENT ECA CONTROL, two, to close. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. On 11 and 16 CBs ASCENT ECA CONTROLS to close.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. That's correct. The next step is BAT 5 and 6 NORMAL FEED to high; those are switches.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. BATs 5 and 6 NORMAL FEED, ON.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's correct. Next step: BATs 1 and 3 to OFF slash RESET. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: BATs 1 and 3 to OFF slash RESET.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's correct. Next step: wait 30 minutes for preconditioning.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. That's wait 30 minutes for preconditioning.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's correct, and the last LM step for now is BATs 2 and 4 to OFF/RESET.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. BATs 2 and 4 to OFF/RESET.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's correct. Now we'll go to the CSM, and the first step there in connect LM/CSM umbilical. Over.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. The next step, on panel 5, CB LM P0WKR-1 MAIN B [???] and POWER-2 MAIN B, both, closed. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. On panel 5, CB LM POWER-1 MAIN B and 2 MAIN B, both, closed.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's correct. On panel 5, CB EPS SENSOR SIGN.AL MAIN B to clone. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: EPS SENSOR SIGNAL MAIN B closed on panel 5.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's correct. Next step, panel 250: CB BAT B POWER ENTRY/POSTLANDING; closed. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. On panel 250: CB BAT B POWER ENTRY/ POSTLANDING , closed.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That' s Charlie. Verify MAIN BUS voltage; then, LM POWER switch on panel 2 to CSM. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. That's verify the MAIN BUS voltage, and switch LM POWER to CSM.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. That's correct. Then go back to 275, CB MAIN B BAT BUS B to open. Hey, Jack, that's the step I skipped for you, I'm afraid. Before verifying MAIN BUS voltage, you have to, on panel 275, close CB MAIN B BAT BUS B. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Joe. How are you reading on the AFT OMNI.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: You're okay now. Co ahead.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. After putting the BATTERY B POWER ENTRY/ POSTLANDING on, then I want to push the - on panel 275 MAIN B to BAT BUS B in, huh?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's right. Then you go to verify MAIN BUS voltage, LM POWER to CSM, and then, on panel 275, circuit breaker MAIN B BAT BUS B to open. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. After verifying the MAIN BUS voltage con- necting the LM POWER to CSM I want to pull MAIN B BAT BUS B, or MAIN B to BAT BUS B, open.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's correct. And then on panel 250, circuit breaker BAT B POWER ENTRY/POSTLANDING to open, and verify MAIN BUS B voltage.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Panel [???] BAT B POWER/POSTLANDING, open, and then verify the MAIN BUS voltage.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. That's correct. The last steps are to get the LM back on descent batteries. The first step is BATs 1, 2, 3, and 4, HI VOLTAGE, ON. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Then the next step is a LM step, BATs 1, 2, 3, and 4, HI VOLTAGE, ON.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's correct, and the last step in the LM, BATs 5 and 6 to OFF. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Say again; you cut out there, Joe.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. The last step in the LM, BATTERIES 5 and 6 OFF. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. BATs 5 and 6 go OFF..

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's correct. That should configure you. Note that circuit-breaker protection on that circuit limits the available current to 15 amps. We think we can do quite a bit with it though. And the LM/CSM umbilical will be hot and MAIN BUS voltage may be monitored by selecting MAIN B on the gage. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Real fine.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Good deal. Jack.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. And I'll be ready to implement this when- ever you call it up.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger that.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: And how do you read, Joe?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Pretty good, Fred.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. While Jack was on C0MM, 1 was looking out the docking window here, and I could see another good shower of particles coming out of the service module. And the position this time appears to be on the other side. Before, we'd always seen them out of window 1, and where I'm looking at it from here, it looks like it'd be down below window 6 somewhere in the service module. Jack's going upstairs to nee what it looks like up there.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Good deal. We copy that, Fred. And to show you how relaxed we are about the entry, Ken is looking at - giving you guys a chance to - prior to going into entry, PREP to snap a few pictures of the service module.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Ken is, huh? (Laughter)

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes, he's got all that film up there, and he doesn't want to waste it.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Oh, I thought maybe you'd want me to do a PLSS EVA to go shoot pictures or something.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: You're right; we got a lot of pictures.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: I guess I agree it surely would be nice to document it someway if we can, but it doesn't look like ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes, we think it'd be a lot of help.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Joe, how do you read me?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. The condensate transfer worked great.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Stand by a minute, Fred. We're in a bad C0MM mode.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Connect LM/CSM umbilical.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. How's that?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's better.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. The waste transfer into the condensate can works real well, Joe.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Good deal.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: So, I guess we can keep FIDO happy with no overboard dumps.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger that.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes, that brings up one more possibility, Joe.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Say again, Fred.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Brings up another possibility. Now that we've got all of that stowed into the bags and the condensate can, we could probably blow all of that through the PLSS ..., I wonder how the sublimator would work on waste water.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: It might work if we had to do it. Fred. Right now we're looking at a comfortable excess of water through the sublimator. We were talking among ourselves this morning about having you try out the PLSS to ascent tank water-transfer situation and we decided not to do it, not to recommend it, because we figure it'd take us 30 hours to empty one of the ascent tanks, which you have to do in order to get PLSS water to it, and we'd rather use the descent water and we don't think we've gotten any sweat. Over.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: It might work if we had to do it, Fred.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Joe. I don't think there's any question about it from the plumbing standpoint that we could do that if we had to.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Copy that.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: And, how do you read, Joe?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Read you pretty good, Fred. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: I think our PTC wobble is growing worse. The Earth now is really up to the top of the window. I have to get way down almost to the floorboards to view it. Conversely, the Moon is way down at the bottom of the window.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: A lot more wobble.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger --

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Far more wobble than I noticed on my previous watch.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Copied that, Fred. And our thermal people will be looking at it- One of the things we're talking about relative to the midcoursc correction is we'd like not to do it before the SHe tank goes, if it's going to go, just so it won't give us a problem reestablishing PTC. And right now our people think that the burst disk will Pop around l06 hours.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: The L-shaped bag is ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Over.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Fred. Since you went ahead and used the PLSS condensate container, we got the procedure in for using it. I'm not going to read it up to you except that it cautions a little bit about shaking it too much or about filling it too full, because they feel that if you do that the vent valve might unseat and the bag might leak a little bit. Over.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. We haven't removed it from its stowage spot. We just left it right in place, and just - he mated the tank at the end of the cable and hooked right into that.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Understand. That's satisfactory and recommended that you leave it in the stowage spot. That should help the situation.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: We got a - we got another flow shower going on outside. Particles, seeing them vented against the service module. Jack thinks it may be an H2 vent. ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Copy that. What window are you looking at it out of, Fred?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Out the LM docking window.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: The docking window. Roger that. Somebody just handed me your latest consumables status report, and you're using between 11 to 12 amps an hour real steady, and it looks real good.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Joe, what are you showing for GET now?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: I think you wanted the GET, Jack, and the present GET is 96 hours 21 minutes. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, thank you.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And Jack, Houston. For your information, FIDO tells me that we are in the Earth's sphere of influence and we're starting to accelerate.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: I thought it was about time we crossed. Thank you.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: We're on our way back home.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: There's something that puzzles me, Joe. Vance mentioned yesterday that the planned entry is a CMC-guided entry, so I'm kind of curious as how are we going to get the alinement.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Did you say how we're going to get guidance? Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: No. Row are we going to get a platform alinement?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We got a number of interesting ideas on that and the latest one I've heard is to power up the LM platform and aline it, and aline the CM platform to it.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. That sounds good.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. And we're working out detailed procedures on that, Jack.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Go ahead, Joe.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We are taking our final look at the mid- course procedures and we have a question as to the present position of one of the switches. The switch is the AGS STATUS switch on panel 6. We'd just like to know where it's at.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Stand by.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Joe. The AGS STATUS switch is OFF.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. OFF. Thank you.

transcript.speaker: SC
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: SC
transcript.text: Okay, Vance. I just heard a little thump, sounded like down in the descent stage, and I saw a new shower of snow flakes come up that looked like they were emitted from down that way. We've already decided though - I wonder what the SUPERCRIT pressure looked like now.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Understand you saw a thump in the descent stage and a few snow flakes. We'll take a look down here, see if we see anything.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Fred, we don't see anything wrong. For example, your SHe appears to be okay as far as we can see. The thing we don't have data on, is the ... tank down there.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. And I doubt if it would have been that anyway.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. While we have you on the horn - -

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: We're still getting -

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Still getting it.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: While you're on the horn, be advised our calculations show you might be running out of potable water in the CSM pretty soon. Also, that you might start to have hydrogen tank venting in the CSM and a question. Next time Jack looks through the sextant and telescope, we'd like him to see how it looks. Do you have anything on the optics, any specks or anything?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, ...

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius. How do you read?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, we read you 4 by 4. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. It looks like the PTC is deteriorated enough that ... the docking window of the LM, and...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. We got part of your trans- mission. Understand the PTC has deteriorated quite a bit and you'd like to know what to do about it. Is that affirm?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Negative. How do you read now, Vance?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. A little better.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. The only comment was that it has deterio- rated to where the Moon is now coming through the overhead docking window now, in a portion of each pass, and about that time I just lose COMM on either antenna, so there's going to be a short period of time on each revolution where we're not going to have COMM.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Fred. We understand that and one more item for clarification on the water. We don't really know what your usage of potable is. That was purely an estimate assuming a fairly healthy usage.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Hey, Houston; Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Jack just took a look through the optics - through one REV, and he said they look good, loud and clear. He doesn't have any current condensate on either the sextant or telescope.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Fred. Thanks for the info.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: How do you read, Vance?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. I'm reading you weakly, Fred. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: With all this other procedures you've been working on there, I thought I was going to have a new one for you. How to get four gingerbread cubes apart; I think they were stuck together with epoxy.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: This is in the food bag? 04 01 36 59 IMP Yes.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's to stand loads of launch and boost. 04 01 37 07 IMP Roger. Tool B did the trick.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Hey, Fred. John says you can use the dikes on it to get them apart.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes, that probably wouldn't have crumbled them as badly.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: I generally don't use the subtle approach. You can tell we're feeling pretty good, Vance, when we start complaining about the food.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes. That's good to hear.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: I think everybody's feeling better down here, too.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Fred, we have you on the Goldstone big dish now, and our C0MM is much better. If you'd like would you turn the BI0MED switch on to either crewman there.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Stand by. I'll have to plug in first.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Vance. How do you read on baseband.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We read you just - Stand by.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Fred. We're receiving your MED data; it was a little slow in coming in.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius. Are you calling?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Negative. No call from here.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: And, Vance, this is Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead, Fred. 04 02 26 23 IMP Okay. Jim's coming back on the line, and I'll be unhooking on the BIOMEDs, and you want us to go back to the SPA DOWN VOICE BACKUP?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Standby. 04 02 26 48 IMP Okay. Jim doesn't have his BI0MED rigged on right now, so ... DOWN VOICE ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Fred. You're too weak on that last. I understand you're disconnecting, and your BIOMED will be off. Say again about Jim, please.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. How do you read now?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. All I said was Jim doesn't have his BIOMED rigged right now so I'll go back to DOWN VOICE BACKUP SPA and Jim's coming on the line.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We copy you're in DOWN VOICE BACKUP.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Well, I'm thinking about the last 10 hours. We've lost our suit compressors.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Because we don't want to use the power.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Well, that's what I'm saying. We can use these fans right here and use the circulate air right through the use of those fans.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Are we on mike now?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Hello, Houston; Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, Jim. Good morning.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Good morning, Vance. How's things going down there?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Oh, quiet and smooth.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Oh, it's afternoon down there.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Right. We thought maybe it was morning to you.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Well, I've sort of lost track. But I had a good sleep.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Glad to hear it. Doctor just said he wondered how many hours?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Oh, let's say whenever I left Jack, and Fred came up and we ate for about an hour, and then I went to bed, so whatever that time was. It must be about 5 hours, something like that; 4 or 5 hours.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Good. Glad to see you catching up.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead, Vance.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jim, the next time that it's convenient, could you get the readout of the REPRESS package in the command module for us? Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Will do.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: When you go back there, Fred, they want the REPRESS package readout.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We don't want to wake anyone up to get it.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: No. No one's asleep now.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: It has? ...,was it? ... you get forward to it and a pretty good view of the venting.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And, Houston, Aquarius. It looks like service module venting has ceased, at least momentarily.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Understand service module venting has ceased momentarily. Row about the descent stage? Does Fred report venting down there? Do you still see that?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Stand by.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: What is your report on descent stage venting - Was it venting? Anything else going on? Any more venting?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: No.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: No. Fred hasn't seen anything else from the descent stage. And I understand that we can expect the - the SHe - tank pressure to build up to relief here about 105 hours.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. A little later than that - like 106 - 107.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Did you get some interior photos?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. I'd like to show them the arrangement of these hydroxide canisters. Do you have?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Did they give Jack any more procedures, on command module powerup? 04 02 37 16 IMP

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Did they give Jack any more procedures on com- mand module powerup?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Well, they think it might be up here.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: The main thing we got to think about, and when we have to get to them, is the procedures for LM jettison, the transfer of the LM to CSM mode (cough), LM jettison. 04 02 39 23 LMP

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Yes.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: ... the LM mode?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: All we have to do is turn the BIOMED ... on, and we'll be in there.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Go ahead, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: We would like permission to turn the BIOMED on to get off the hot mike mode. I don't think that we have to be on it now if you have the big dish on, do you?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes. Yaw's coming - or roll's coming up for it, and we were going to burn.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, Jim. We concur. Go ahead and turn it on.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Fine; thank you.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: One other point. The philosophy of timing this midcourse is based a little bit on doing it just before the SHe tank is supposed to vent. That way, we hope that we would have - - be powered up and you would have control when the venting occurs, in case you were tossed around a little bit. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Understand. Philosophy on the midcourse is doing it prior to venting of the SHe tank, which means we'll be doing this around 105 hours, I suppose, or 105:30 and so I'll have control of the spacecraft if it should give us some perturbation.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Then, after that, we would establish PTC again.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Our REPRESS package pressure is 820.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. REPRESS pressure 820. Thank you.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jim, could you switch your BIOMED switch to the position opposite to where it is now? We are getting a subcarrier, but no data. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Now you know, Houston, I don't have BIOMED on.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. And we have a small addition to the pro- cedure that was read up to you earlier, which involves power transfer from the LM to the CSM.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Stand by 1.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Houston. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. At the end of the procedure, after the step BAT 5 and 6, OFF, add the following: circuit breakers, panels - panels 11 and 16, ASCENT ECA CONTROL, both open. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. After the step BAT 5 and 6, OFF, step 3 will be circuit breakers panels 11 and 16 ASCENT ECA CONTROL, both open.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's correct, Jim. And this is to guard against a single-point failure that - a remote possibility that would preclude you from getting the batteries back on.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger,

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. We just had a battery warning ... Batery 2.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Stand by, Jim. The COMM's no good here right now.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius. How do you read now?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead. Loud and clear.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. We just had a battery warning MASTER ALARM, and it looks like it's battery 2.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, Houston - This is Houston. Could you close the POWER AMP circuit breaker, and we'll get some high bit rate?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: It's closed.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. And we need high bit rate.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Are you picking it up, Houston?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. And we want tc open the BAL LOAD CROSS TIE on panel l6. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Say again.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Open the BAL LOAD CROSS TIE breaker on panel 16. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Open BALANCE LOAD CROSS TIE breaker on 16. Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirm.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: It's open.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: If you're getting high bit data, we could do an OFF/RESET and go back on on battery 2. We're standing by for that.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Could you turn off battery 2, and leave it off and let us look at it?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Say again. You want us to turn off battery 2, and leave it off until you look at it?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Battery 2 coming off the line.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Aquarius. So you want to stay in this configuration for awhile, and let's look at the battery.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger. We'll stay in this configuration.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Want to close the BAL LOADS circuit breaker back now.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 13, Houston- We want to close the BAL LOADS circuit breaker on panel l6 now, again.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: We have it closed; the closed - BALANCE LOADS circuit breaker is closed.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Request RANGE FUNCTIONS switch to RANGE ...

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: All right. RANGE FUNCTIONS switch going to RANGE.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Right-o.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jim, on battery problem, we have determined that it is not overcurrent or reverse current. We suspect it's over-temp, but don't know for sure, so we're going to watch it for awhile.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jim, Charlie has some procedures to read up for you here; I think you'll need your activiation checklist, if it's handy.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, that's the contingency checklist.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. I'll just - Okay. Stand by, Charlie.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Charlie. I've got the contingency checklist, and standing by.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. We'd like you to turn to page - page 24, which is the "30-Minute Activation," and this is going to be a procedure for the midcourse burn that we got coming up at 105 with the AGS up. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger. On the midcourse at 105, and I'm on page 24.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay; "30-Minute Activation," omit steps 1, 2, and 3; perform step 4, "RCS system A/B-2." Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger. Omit steps 1, 2, and 3; perform step 4.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. And on the "EPS Activation," same page, perform step 1; and in step 2, perform line num- ber - line number 6, "EPS DISPLAY-CLOSE." Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. On "EPS Activation," perform step 1, and perform step 2, line 6 only; is that correct?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative, Jim. The rest of the stuff is already closed at this time, so that's all we'll have to do is close the EPS DISPLAY breaker.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: All right. Turn to pege 25. On page 25, omit step 3; perform step 4. On step 4, last line, scratch "CB(l6) EPS: INVERTER 2, closed." Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger. Omit step 3; perform step 4, except for the last line. Circuit breaker 16, EPS INVERTER 2, closed.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. That's correct. On step 5, perform step 5. Under "Primary Glycol Loop Activation," step 1, line 1, "CB(l6) ECS: DISPLAY - CLOSE." That's a crew option; you can have it if you want to. Omit the rest of step l and step 2. Perform step 3. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. On primary glycol loop activation, crew option on step 1, first line; the rest of it we'll omit. Step 2, we'll omit, and we'll do step 3.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative, Jim, with the following DELTAS on step 3, and if you'll turn to page 26, I'll give you the DELTAs on the activation circuit breaker list. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. I'm there.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. On line 1, correction, row 1, under AC BUS A: TAPE RECORDER should be open; DECA GIMBAL, open. All the other ones as shown on the page. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. On row 1, AC BUS A: TAPE RECORDER and DECA GIMBAL will be open. All the rest as shown.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. And we don't know the status of your windows. If you - During this burn, we're going to have to look out the forward window to get the alinement with the COAS, so you might need the commander window heater and you can, of course, use that breaker if needed, since we do have the AC power. On row 2 - Go ahead. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I don't think we'll need it, Charlie.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay; fine, Jim. On row 2, under PCS SYSTEM A: ASCENT FEED 2 and ASCENT FEED 1 should be open. Under FLIGHT DISPLAYS: MISSION TIMER should be open; GASTA, open; ORDEAL, open. Under AC BUS A: GASTA, open. The rest are as shown on the page. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. On row 2, we're going to open up ASCENT FEED 2 and ASCENT FEED 1 under RCS SYSTEM A. We're going to open up the MISSION TIMER, and FLIGHT DISPLAYS: the GASTA and the ORDEAL; and the AC BUS A: the GASTA.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative. Okay. Row 3, under PROPELLANT: DESCENT HELIUM REG/VENT should be open. Under HEATERS: RENDEZVOUS RADAR STANDBY, open; LANDING RADAR, open. Under STAB/CONTROL: ATCA (PGNS), open. Under ED and LIGHTING: all four open. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Row 3, under PHOPELLANT - propulsion: the DESCENT HELIUM REG/VENT will be open: the STANDBY RENDEZVOUS HEATER will be open and the LANDING RADAR HEATER circuit breaker will be open. I just changed antennas; and, keeping on down the line, ATCA PGNS will be open and the last four circuit breakers, two under ED and two under LIGHTING, will be open.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative. Okay. Under row 4, under ECS: GLYCOL PUMP AUTO TRANSFER, close. Under C0MM: UP DATA LINK, open; VHF B and VHF A should be open. Under PGNS: LGC/DSKY, open; IMU OPERATE, open. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Under row 4, the AUTO TRANSFER will be close. UPDATA LINK, open; VHF A and B, open; DSKY, open; and IMU OPERATE, open.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirm. On the last row, the only DELTA is under the CROSS TIE BUS and it should be open. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Say that again, Charlie.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Under the last row, under EPS is the only DELTA and that is under the CROSS TIE BUS. It should go open. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger. The CROSS TIE BUS should go open.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirm. Going on to page 27, Activation, panel 16. Under RCS SYSTEM Bravo: ASCENT FEED 1, ASCENT FEED 2 should be open. Under PROPULSION: PQGS should be open; ASCENT HELIUM REG, open. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Line 1, on panel 16, ASCENT FEEDs 1 and 2 will be open. And the PQGS will be open, and the ASCENT HELIUM REG will be open.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative. On the next three rows, we only get the nine DELTAs, so I'll go through the next three rows completely and then you can read those back. Under LIGHTING

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Under LIGHTING; FLOOD, open; TRACK, open. Under ED LOGIC - Correction, under ED: LOGIC, open. Under STAB/CONTROL: DESCENT ENGINE OVERRIDE, open. Under ECS: SUIT FLOW CONTROL, open. Under row 3, COMM: DISPLAY, open; VHF A TRANSMITTER open; VHF B RECEIVER, open. Under ECS: DISPLAY, that's crew option. Last row, under EPS: INVERTER 2, open. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. On the last three rows, we have FLOOD and TRACK circuit breakers, row 2, open; LOGIC POWER B, open; DESCENT ENGINE OVERRIDE, open; SUIT FLOW CONTROL, open. On the third row - row, DISPLAY, open; VHF A and - VHF - VHF A TRANSMITTER, open; VHF B RECEIVER, open. And under ECS: we have DISPLAY, open, at crew option. And the last one, INVERTER 2 under EPS, will be open.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. That's a good readback. Under that ECS DISPLAY, it shows it closed. If, with it closed, you can have some readout of - onboard readout of your ECS system - draws a lot less than a half amp so it's up to you whether you want it or not. Okay, on page 28.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: On page 28, step - perform step 4 with the fol- lowing changes in the warning light status. Under the warning lights, you will probably - you will have ASCENT PRESSURE and an LGC light. Scratch "RCS A and RCS B REG." Under caution lights, you'll have a PRE AMPS light. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger. Under warning, we'll have ASCENT PRESSURE and LGC; and under caution, we'll have a PRE AMP.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Affirmative. Under "VHF/S-band Activation and Checkout," scratch step 1. Under step 2, change "DOWN VOICE BACKUP" to VOICE." Scratch step 3. Under "PGNS turn on," scratch entire procedure. Under "DAP Set/Gimbal Drive," scratch entire procedure . Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Under "VHF/S-band Activation and Checkout," scratch step 1. Do step 2 with the following change, "DOWN VOICE BACKUP" to "VOICE." Scratch step 3. Scratch the entire remaining events that page. Over.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative, Jim. Going on to page 29. We've got - At this point, there's a write-in required. It's about a six or seven liner, and I'll try to go fairly slowly and let you write it down, if you're ready to copy. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Ready to copy.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. At this point, we'd like you to "Verify RCS heaters in AUTO for 15 minutes."

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Is that the first step, Charlie?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative. What we're trying to do here is we're getting you set up in an attitude so you can damp your rates and come out of FTC. And this is the configuration I'm reading you now, the next - in the next six lines, the procedure for getting you into a configuration to damp the rates and stop PTC. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. So the first thing will be to - "Go to AUTO on the RCS SYSTEM A and B"?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: It's the "Verify that the heaters have been in AUTO for 15 minutes." Back on the first page of this procedure, you put the heaters in AUTO and you pushed the breakers in, and we'd like for them to warm up the quads for 15 minutes before we start to - stop at - stopping PTC. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger, "Verify heaters RCS on for 15 minutes."

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Step 2: "BALANCE COUPLE, OFF; DEAD BAND, MINIMUM; ATTITUDE CONTROL: PITCH and ROLL to PULSE; YAW to DIRECT; MODE CONTROL: AGS, ATT HOLD; GUIDANCE CONTROL to AGS; damp rates; pitch and roll with the TTCA, yaw with the ACA with the Earth in the front window." Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, let's see if I got it. Step 2 is "BALANCE COUPLE'S OFF; DEAD BAND, MIN; ATTITUDE CONTROL: PITCH and YAW at PULSE; YAW, DIRECT. MODE CON- TROL will be in AGS, ATT HOLD; GUIDANCE CONTROL will be in AGS; we'll damp the rates; pitch and roll with the TTCA, and yaw with the ACA; and we'll probably have to have some reference point, so I have to try and stop on the Earth." Over.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, Jim. We were hoping that in your PTC that you occasionally see the Earth coming through the window; and, if that's true, then we'd like you to have to - just damp the rates with the Earth in the forward window. And then we'll give you the burn attitude via the forward window on the Earth momentarily. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. That was the entire procedure for damping the rates, only - though I only gave you - said it was step 2, that was the entire procedure. Now, continuing on to what's printed on page 29 - Correction, you had one error in the readback under ATTITUDE CONTROL. It was PITCH and ROLL to PULSE; YAW to DIRECT. Continuing on, on page 29 with the printed procedure, the first four lines, scratch. Step 3, scratch. Under "AGS Activation," one change: add a step. First step will be "Verify ASA CB(16) in for 10 minutes." The rest of the AGS activation is as printed. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. "Verify ASA circuit breaker 16 in for 10 minutes"; and, I take it, 10 minutes back in our procedures we'll have a note saying to put that in.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: It's - the circuit breaker goes in on the circuit breaker activation page, Jim. So, by the time we get here and have the rates all damped, we feel that - that the FIFAs will be up to temperature by this time, and we can go ahead and turn it - turn the AGS on at this time. Over. But we just want you to verify that.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. And one other question, Charlie. I'd like to know if the note you gave me about damping the rates is before the other information on page 29.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative. Add that in to the top of the page. The - What we're really doing - Let's - let's put it in to right before the "AGS Activation ." The other - the other procedure on the top of the page belongs with the "DAP Set Gimbal Trim," and we're just omitting all of that procedure. So the addition that - on the damping, the rates should really go in right before the "AGS Activation." Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Understand.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: What we're really trying to do is get you in a posture so that when you see the Earth come through the window, you can damp her out and hold - hold the Earth in the window. Proceeding on to the rest of page 29, under "RCS PRESS," scratch the entire three steps as printed. On page 30, scratch step 4 under the "RCS PRESS." Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger. Under "AGS Activation," well, I included that step on the ASA circuit breaker and we'll do step l and 2 under "AGS Activation." But then we'll scratch steps 1, 2, and 3 under "RCS PRESS" and, on page 30, we'll scratch step 4.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Affirm. Under "DPS PRESS," step 1, line l, scratch. Line 4, "DESCENT HELIUM REG 1, talkback barber pole." Under step 2, scratch; step 3, scratch! "LANDING GEAR DEPLOY," scratch. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Under "DPS PRESS," we'll scratch the first line and we'll have the "DESCENT HELIUM REG, talkback to barber pole." We'll scratch steps 2 and 3, and we'll scratch the "LANDING GEAR DEPLOY."

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Now we got, on the back of page 30, Jim, you've got a blank page in your checklist, or should have, and we'd like to add a procedure to get you to bum attitude. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. A procedure to get the burn attitude.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. First statement is a statement: "Verify AGS in OPERATE for 5 minutes." Then we go to "AGS address 400 plus 5, then 400 plus zero. ATTITUDE CONTROL: PITCH and ROLL to PULSE; YAW, MODE CONTROL. Maneuver using TTCA pitch and roll." The computer is controlling yaw, but you can override with ACA. You with me? Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Charlie. I'm with you so far.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. "When in attitude, ACA out of detent to zero error needle. Then set VENT TIMER," and we'll give you a countdown on that when you get to that step. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. "When in attitude, ACA out of detent to null needles, and set DET."

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Now, that - the burn attitude will be coming up on a pad, but, basically, we're looking for a local horizontal retrograde burn, which means, using a C0AS, if you put the horizontal line on the COAS on the horns of the Earth and then roll to place the X-axis in the direction of the Sun, we'll - that will put us in both burn attitude; and you can check that via the Sun which will be in the ACT detent 2. Should lie right along the cursor at the top. We'll have some more words on that for you momentarily. Now, I'd like to go on to page 31 if you're ready. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. I figure I have a handle on the attitude, the way the Earth should look in the COAS, and you're going to give me some words on what the Sun would look like in the A0T. Is that right?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative, Jim. We haven't got a picture of it yet. It's going to be in the top part of the COAS - Correction, top part of the AOT at the top of the - the top of detent 2 and the top part of the AOT, and it should, in attitude, if you're right on the Sun, should split the cursor, though that roll angle is not too critical; if we're in about 10 degrees, we'll be okay. We - but I think - we think you should be able to get it better than that. On page 31, under the "DPS Burn Technique," you can scratch the bottom part below the little diagram there since the gimbal is locked. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Understand scratch the bottom part underneath the diagram because the gimbal is locked.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative; and, since the gimbal was trimmed out at the big burn yesterday, we should be still through the e.g., and we'd like to make sure that Jack sits in the same place for this burn that he did yesterday. That way, we'll - you should have no trouble controlling attitude. Now I'm ready to go over to page 32. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Let me see if I have that right, now. You want Jack to sit in the same attitude so that the gimbals are the same place so you don't have trouble controlling attitude. I got it.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Now on page 32, top of the page, first line, scratch "VERB 76." Third line, "MODE CONTROL: AGS, ATT HOLD." At "Minus 6 minutes," scratch lines 1, 2, and at "Burn Attitude," scratch "VERB 40 NOUN 20." Scratch lines 2, 3, and 4. Now at "Burn Attitude," we want you to do a "400 plus 5" and then a "VERB - a 400 plus zero." And we have a caution note at this point. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. The caution i.i after "400 plus zero": Do not go out of detent on ACA again." Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. After the last "400 plus zero," "Do not go out of detent with ACA." Is that correct?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's a Roger, Jim. What happens is, of course, we set - when you go out of detent, you reset the AGS error needles and you - and you lose your attitude reference. You establish a new attitude reference, and it might not be the burn attitude since, at this point, we're controlling attitude with the TTCA. Now, picking up with the "VERB 37, ENTER," scratch. Scratch everything down to the "404 plus zero," and we want you to perform those AGS steps with 404 down through 470. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. We'll scratch everything down to "404 plus zero," and we'll perform those four steps.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Turning over to page 33. Minus 4 minutes. Okay. Moving down the page, it's about line 7, to "ENGINE GIMBAL": "ENGINE GIMBAL, OFF." Down to "MODE CONTROL," make that read "MODE CONTROL: AGS, ATT HOLD," and then scratch "PROPELLANT QUANTITY MONITOR, DESCENT 1." Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. At 4 minutes, "ENGINE GIMBAL" will be "OFF"; "MODE CONTROL" will be to "AGS, ATT HOLD"; "PRO- PELLANT QUANTITY MONITOR, DESCENT 1," scratched.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Picking up at minus 1 minute, scratch "MASTER ARM, ON." Minus 35 seconds, scratch first two lines. At minus 10 seconds, change that to "Minus 9 seconds"; so, at "Minus 9 seconds," it will be "Manual Ullage." At 2 seconds, scratch "CMC MODE, FREE," and scratch "ACA out of detent." At - after "IGNITION," at plus 1 second, "Terminate Ullage." Are you with me? Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. At 1 minute, "MASTER ARM," we scratch. At 35 seconds, scratch the first two lines. "Manual Ullage" will start at 9 seconds; we're scratching the blocks at 02 seconds; and the line beneath that, at plus 1 second, we "Terminate Ullage."

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirm. Picking up at plus 5 seconds; scratch the rest of the page. "TTCA, attitude control; and MASTER ARM, OFF." Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Scratch the remainder of the page.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Now, like to verify that under the 35 seconds, minus 35 seconds, the only thing you have remaining is "ENGINE ARM to DESCENT." Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: That's affirm. That's the only thing I have.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Turning to the next page and the last page, Jim, 34. Top of the page, "Monitor DELTA-Vx via 470." Scratch next two lines, "When propellant quantity equals 37" and the "DESCENT HELIUM REG." Scratch "TTCA commander, reduce to 10 percent." Now we want you to add a line; "shut" - It's a shutdown criteria, "shutdown on bum time minus 1 second." Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, "The shutdown is on bum time minus 1 second." Let me give you an example. If we have a 30-second burn, we're going to shut down at 29 seconds. Is that correct?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative. We'll give you the pad, be coming up here from FIDO in a couple of hours, I guess, when we stabilize out on our tracking. The reason for - If you're ready to copy out a couple of more steps, and then I'll explain the reason we want to shut down on this burn time minus 1 second. Picking up on "When DELTA-Vx - -

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: - - When DELTA-Vx equal to the final DELTA-Vx," scratch that line. Scratch "ATTITUDE CONTROL: YAW, to PULSE." Add - Correction, scratch "Damp excessive rates via LM Y, Z translation" and add at that point "Null" error needles. Trim address 470 to 0.1 foot per second." Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, going through. After the "Shutdown on burn time minus 1 second," we scratch the next line; and we scratch "ATTITUDE CONTROL: YAW, to PULSE"; we scratch "Damp excessive rates via LM Y, Z translation"; we add the line "Null" error needles, trim - Null the error needles and trim address 470 to - What was the value there, Charlie?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: "0.1 foot per second." The reason we are shutting down on the burn time is, since the ASA breaker has been out for so long, we're not real confi- dent that our AGS PIPAs are going to be super-sharp. So we want to make sure that we just get a burn time - no overburn; so we're shutting down on burn time minus 1 second. And then that will allow us a plus-X translation to trim 470 if it looks okay. If we had an overburn, we'd be in - -

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: - - if we had an overburn, we'd be impinging on our command module to try to trim it out, so that's our reasoning there. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Understand.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Picking up in the middle of the page, that - a block "CMS resume attitude control," scratch. Scratch the next line; "PRO VERB 96." Scratch the third line; "PROPELLANT QUANTITY MONITOR, OFF." Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. We'll scratch the blocks, and we'll scratch the "PRO VERB 96"; then we'll scratch "PROPELLANT QUANTITY MONITOR, OFF."

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Now, at the bottom of that page, I have a procedure for you to reestablish PTC. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: To reestablish PTC. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. First line, "ATTITUDE CONTROL, three to PULSE"; line 2, "Roll with the TTCA until attitude is roll, plus or minus 90; pitch, 0; yaw, 0." Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Step 1, "ATTITUDE CONTROL, three to PULSE"; 2, "Roll with the TTCA ... pitch is 0 and yaw is 0," and I think that will be on the AGS ball.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative. You broke up there for a minute, Jim. We'll do that on the AGS ball from the burn attitude. We just want you to roll either way 90 degrees, keep pitch 0 and yaw 0. Now, step 3; "When at - when at attitude, ACA out of detent." Step 4; "ATTITUDE CONTROL: YAW, to MODE CONTROL. When rates are less than 0.05, ATTITUDE CONTROL: YAW, to PULSE."

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Charlie. Can you hold up here a second? I lost you.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Start with step 3 again. "When attitude - When at attitude, ACA out of detent."

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's Roger. Next step, step 4: "ATTITUDE CONTROL to YAW" - Correction, "ATTITUDE CONTROL: YAW, to MODE CONTROL." Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Step 4 is "ATTITUDE CONTROL: YAW, to MODE CONTROL."

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Step 5: "When rates are less than 0.05 degrees per second, ATTITUDE CONTROL: YAW, to PULSE."

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. "When rates are less than 0.05 degrees per second, ATTITUDE CONTROL: YAW, to PULSE."

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Step 6: "Spin up to 0.3 degree per second in yaw," and that takes about 21 pulses. Step 7 - Yes.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Step 7: "MODE CONTROL, AGS, OFF."

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Step 6 was "Spin up to 0.3 degrees per second in yaw"; that's about 21 pulses. Step 7 was "MODE CONTROL, AGS, to OFF."

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirm. Step 8: "Power down per power" - Correction, "Power down per contingency checklist page Power 5." Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. And step 8 is Power down per contingency checklist Power 5," and I take it that's been revamped considering our situation. Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative, Jim. That's the one we gave you last night after the big burn, and we'll use that one as modified by - by us. This - we tried this PTC under AGS in the simulator and, of course, no slosh or anything, but it seemed to work pretty good by nulling the rates using the TTCA in pitch and roll and letting the AGS do it in yaw. You null the rates by looking at the error needles and just watching those, and when they don't - when they stop moving, then you got it within the limits of what we want. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. And 1 guess, Charlie, you have no - Do you have a ATT hold mode in pitch and roll at all in this configuration we're in, or do wo have to use the TTCA?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We feel like we have to use the TTCA. The AGS gains are not too good in pitch and roll in this configuration. It'll hold it in yaw but it won't in pitch and roll. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And you'll have - During the burn, of course, you'll be controlling pitch and roll via the error needles with the TTCA also, and it's the little scheme that we've practiced in some of the SIMs. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Right. Understand.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And, Houston, want to make sure that we allow enough time to get to the proper attitude for the burn so that we can be sure we establish the proper attitude and don't have to rush the burn.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, Jim. We - we're looking right now, tentatively, at starting this about 45 minutes before the burn and our sensitivity is - not too bad on this burn. We can go 30 minutes either way and not affect our DELTA-V. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Fine. And do you have a handle on just how long the burn will be? In time?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: It's looking like at about 7.8 seconds and about 15 - Correction, 7.8 feet per second and about 15 seconds. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: In about 18 seconds?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Negative. 15. 1 5.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: 1 5. Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And one other point is that we'd like to remind you that this is going to be in blowdown and both REGs B closed but we've got plenty at the 10 percent.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Understand.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, Jim, in the simulator with our configuration that we had here, the thing is real stable at lO percent, so we don't think you'll have to tweak very much at all using the TTCAs. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Understand.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And I'll give you back to Vance. Thank you.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And thank you.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jim, regarding your number 2 battery, we think that it's probably a sensor failure, a temperature sensor failure that's caused this alarm, rather than an actual overternp of the battery; the reason being that we haven't seen any higher temperatures in the glycol loop. We expect to put the battery back on about 101 hours. That'll be about 10 minutes, and then we'll look at it some more there. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Concerning number 2 battery, you think it might be a sensor failure because you haven't seen any changes, and you're going to put the battery back on the line in about 10 minutes.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirm.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: For information, Vance, about a half hour ago, I guess. Jack and I couldn't see constellations at certain spacecraft attitudes, stars. We could see the - Scorpio and Sagittarius and we could see Altair or Acrux and Alpha Centuri, Vega, stars of that magnitude, and our venting has stopped which allows us now to differentiate between the particles and the stars.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger; copy. Understand you can see the stars pretty well. Were you, at that time, in an attitude facing away from the Sun? I presume this is very attitude critical.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Yes. It is somewhat, Vance. If we have the Sun shining off the quads, it sort of ruins our vision; and also, if the Earth or the Moon are in the general field of view, we can't see anything.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Thank you.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead, Vance.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jim, we're ready to put that battery back on the line. Request you open the CROSS TIE BAL LOAD circuit breaker, panel 16, and then put back - BAT 2 back on the line.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. First of all, we'll open the BALANCE CROSS TIE breaker on panel 16.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirm.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. The CROSS TIE BALANCE LOAD circuit breakers is in now, Vance. Now you want us to put battery S back on. Is that affirm?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Did you say it was in, or did you pull it out?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: No. It's in; do you want it out?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirm. We'd like it out, and then BAT 2 on the line.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Corning up. BAT 2 is on the line. We have a MASTER ALARM and a BATTERY light.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Copy. And - and we think that's probably an in- dication of the sensor problem, but stand by.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jim, it looks to us like your battery is good, that this is in fact a sensor problem; therefore, request you close the CROSS TIE BAL LOADs on - circuit breaker on panel 16. Advise - -

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: - - advise that you will not have any malfunction indication on any of your batteries now, but we can watch it from the ground. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. We'll close the CROSS TIE BALANCE LOAD circuit breaker at this time.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Copy.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: That's closed, and we don't have any warning on any of the batteries, but you can monitor from the ground.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirm.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, Jim, we have a lengthy procedure here for powering up the CSM and turning on instrumentation so we can check the TM, and this will take a large piece of scratch paper whenever you're ready to copy.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirm.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. I'll tell you what, I'll have Jack get configured. He can copy that down and I'll have him - we'll get the stuff. Stand by.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, read you loud and clear, Aquarius. Is it cool in there now?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Yes, it's pretty cool. This is the third officer on this LM crew here. Ready to copy.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Jack, this is a lengthy procedure, take probably two or three pages. It assumes that you are in your nominal configuration, which was sent up - or in your day-flying configuration, which was sent up to you earlier today.

transcript.text: Okay. I can verify that we are in that config- uration with the exception of panel 382, the water accumulator, which I've left off in case we wanted to get some more drinking water out of the command module, and I'll put those in the proper configuration before we do anything.

transcript.text: Okay. Ready to copy?

On panel 5, close the following circuit breakers: ECS, PRESSURE GROUP 1, MAIN B; ECS, PRESSURE GROUP 2, MAIN B; ECS, TEMP, MAIN B; ECS, SECONDARY LOOP TRANSDUCER, MAIN B; ECS RAD, CONTROL/HEATERS, MAIN B; BAT RELAY BUS, BAT B; BAT CHARGER, BAT B; INVERTER CONTROL, 2; INVERTER CONTROL, 1; EPS SENSOR SIGNAL, ACl; EPS SENSOR SIGNAL, MAIN B; EPS SENSOR UNIT, ACl; WASTE/ POTABLE HO, MAIN B; INSTRUMENTATION, ESSENTIAL, MAIN B.

transcript.text: Okay. That's all correct. Is that reading rate okay for you?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Next, panel 3: TRANSPONDER, PRIMARY; POWER AMPL, to PRIMARY, that's a verify; POWER AMPL, HIGH; MODE, VOICE, to OFF; POWER, SUE, to NORMAL; PMP to NORMAL; S-RAND ANTENNA, OMNI D, that's Delta. Okay, why don't you read that one back ?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. On panel 3: TRANSPONDER to PRIMARY; POWER AMPLIFIER to PRIMARY; POWER AMPL, HIGH; MODE, VOICE, to OFF; POWER, SCE, to NORMAL; IMP to NORMAL; S-BAND ANTENNA, OMNI D, D as in Doggy.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Hey, very good. Okay, panel 225: circuit breaker FLIGHT BUS, MAIN B, to close; circuit breaker CTE, MAIN B, to close. Panel 250: CB BAT C BAT CHARGER/EDS 2 to close.

transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.text: Okay. Let me give you all of panel 225 again. CB FLIGHT BUS, MAIN B, close; CB CTE, MAIN B, close. On panel 250: CB BAT - B BAT CHARGE, that should be BAT C, Charlie, isn't it? BAT CHARGE/EDS2 closed?

transcript.text: Okay, Vance. The following steps are sequence critical. Panel 250: CB BAT B POWER ENTRY/ POSTLANDING, closed. That's BAT Baker. MDC 3, AC INVERTER 2, to MAIN B; AC INVERTER 2, ACl, on. ...

transcript.text: How do you read now. Jack?

transcript.text: Okay, Vance. Did you - how far did you - did you copy any of my steps there?

transcript.text: Okay, I heard you through AC INVERTER 2, AC BUS 1 to on, and you were cut out by noise. Go ahead.

transcript.text: Okay, Now comes to one I didn't understand. You said go over to MDC 5 and A in - AC INVERTER, AC BUS 1, RESET, then center, and then back to MDC 3; UP TELEMETRY, COMMAND RESET then OFF, and then select best OMNI.

transcript.text: Roger. The readback's correct, but let me recheck that. Stand by.

And standing by for readback.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. You want me to read out on MDC 3: BAT B voltage, PYRO A voltage, PYRO B voltage, SPS HELIUM PRESSURE. On panel 101: command module RCS injector temperatures; 5 Charlie, 5 Dog, 6 Alfa, 6 Baker, 6 Charlie, 6 Dog. The battery manifold pressure, 4 Alfa.

transcript.text: Okay. Now, that - that complete procedure for getting into it, as far as getting into it's concerned. What I will give you now is how to back out of it after you're through with your readings. Are you ready to copy?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Now you'll back out fairly quickly after you go into this procedure. All we'll need is about 5 minutes of TM, and so if you're ready to copy, here it comes.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Panel 3: POWER AMPL to OFF. incidentally, copy this down on a piece of scratch paper as I read it, and then later I'll refer back to your first list where you can write things in the right- hand margin.

transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay - -

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Go ahead. You want - Repeat the one on panel 3 again, Vance.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. POWER AMPL, OFF.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: TRANSPONDER, OFF. AC INVERTER, 2, to OFF. Okay. Next, panel 250: CB BAT Bravo, POWER ENTRY/ POSTLANDING to open. Stand by 1.

transcript.text: Okay, Jack. What I just gave you now on the backout is the only thing that's order critical. From here on, you can go to the steps for initiating the procedure, and backtrack. transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, now here's - to accent, here's the sequence-critical sets: POWER AMPL, OFF; TRANSPONDER, OFF; AC INVERTER, 2, OFF; and the last one on panel 250, CB BAT Baker POWER ENTRY/ POSTLANDING, open; and then hit the steps in reverse order that you gave them to me, and back out, like then I would start on MDC 3 UP TELEMETRY, OFF - to OFF; and then AC INVERTER - ACl BUS 1 to OFF; and then AC INVERTER, 2, OFF; AC INVERTER, 2, MAIN B to OFF. Is that the type of order that you want to back out of?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirm, but - just for kicks, let's go through these panels again, and I'll give you the - the position, just to make sure there can be no doubt.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. And once again, in the - in the area where I said order was; not critical, it's still not critical when you back out. But now I'll, go ahead. transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CMP

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirm. The two circuit breakers on panel 250 will go open; the two circuit breakers, panel 275, will go open. transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. 'The two switches - two circuit breakers on panel 250 will go back to open; the two circuit breakers on panel 275 back to open; the POWER ENTRY/POSTLANDING circuit breaker, we already took care of earlier; AC INVERTER 2; we took care of earlier; AC INVERTER 2 to AC BUS 1 will go to OFF; and AC INVERTER, AC BUS 1, we took care of - No, that'll go to OFF; and UP TELEMETRY, COMMAND RESET will go OFF.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's correct. Jack. Okay, that's it. And I think we're about ready to go with this procedure whenever you are.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. First we got to go through that procedure to power the CSM from the LM, is that Charlie?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: No. No, this is independent of power from the LM. This is a - this is purely a CSM - -

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: This is purely a CSM powerup so we can take a look at your telemetry and see how cold the vehicle is and that sort of thing.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. It's going in work.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, now I won't - I won't have any voice with you, so - Is that right? You don't want me to get connected up - you want me to just take these readings and come back and tell you what I have, huh?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirm. There'll be no voice. And - -

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Okay. In work.

transcript.text: I - we presum, though, that there'll be somebody in the LM that we can call if we have to get, word to you.

transcript.speaker: CMP

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, and let us know when you start.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. I'm going to start right now, Vance.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Houston; Aquarius. Switching watches, and Jack's going up into the command module.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. We have four steps here to give you to request that you get back on DOWN VOICE BACKUP, if you're ready to copy?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Ready to copy.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Bit rate to L0 bit rate. VOICE, FUNCTION switch to DOWN VOICE BACKUP. POWER AMPs CB, open; RANGE FUNCTION switch in RANGING; that's verify.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Bit rate, LO; VOICE FUNCTION, DOWN VOICE BACKUP; POWER AMP S-BAND, open; and RANGE FUNCTION to RANGE; and that's a verify. And I still have the BIOMED on RIGHT here, so we don't have hot mike.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Thank you.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And, you want that in work, now?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirm.

Second point: when you're in the burn attitude, you should see the Sun at the very top of the A0T. It'll be splitting the cursor, when your cursor's set at zero. One thing to be aware of though, that it'll slip right out of the AOT very easily since it'll be very sensitive to roll and yaw. Understand that's in detent 2, by the way. Next point: the burn is very insensitive to burn time and attitude. In other words, if necessary, we can slip it if there's any problem at all, and attitude isn't too critical. So that brings us to the point that we only have one real burn rule; that is, if - rate about any axis gets to 10 degrees a second, that's the limit to stop the burn. Next point, after you finish the burn, and before you trim, request that you leave DEDA in address 470 up a while so we can take a look at it, and let us holler when we've seen it, and then proceed on. Over.

Jim and I'd already been talking about that, and just eyeballing the terminator in the Earth, we figured the Sun at about something like a 70-degree angle - 65-degree angle, so that'll be right up there. We get one burn rule that says if the rates are greater than 10 degrees per second, shut her down. transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Negits on my last, Fred.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack- How do you read now?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. I thought you called. Jack. We're maneuvering around here to fish for the Earth.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: And, Houston, Aquarius. How's the ASA package temp look now?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Fred. The ASA package temp is looking good. It's around 98 degrees, and we'd like to see it go up about 15 to 20 degrees.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Why don't you give me the word before I proceed with the AGS. We really don't need it right this instant.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. We'll be watching it.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. The ASA package temp is up now so you can activate the AGS.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Very good.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. So we can make sure and get our timer set here, I wondered when your - you've got about 48 minutes to the burn which should be coming up pretty quick - you'd give us a hack so we could set our event timer at 12.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, Fred. I understand you want a mark at 12 minutes prior to the burn. Is that affirm?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Roger. We think we got it set now. We just wanted to cheek it. If we don't, then I'll set it to 13, and you can give me another hack at 47 to go.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We got 33 to go.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: MARK.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: My mistake. It was 33 - -

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Right on.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. It was reading 33 on my mark. Right?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. You got about 105:03 GET now down there?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative, Fred. Going through 105:03:45.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: MARK.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. Give me the next number you want me to set then, and I'll take another hack here.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. You're counting up, right?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Fred. On my mark, be 35 minutes to the burn.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Standing by.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We missed her, Fred. Let's get it on the next minute.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Aquarius. On my mark, it's going to be 34 minutes to the burn, and you'll be reading 36. Stand by.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: MARK.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. We got it cranked up.

transcript.speaker: CDR
