transcript.text: Okay, Houston. We have our attitude set.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I hope the guys in the back room who thought this up right knew what they were saying.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: And I'm looking through the AOT there, Jack, and the Sun's right in the top and it's about maybe 2 degrees to the right of the cursor. So that looks real good..

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Good going.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Aquarius. The attitude looks good here and your choice when you want to start the burn.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: We're counting down, aren't we, or do you want us to start any time?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Your choice.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: You guys are getting easy.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: It's not time critical, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I understand.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: And, Houston, we reset our clock and we're making the burn in about - I'll give you a hack here at 2 minutes to go.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, Fred. And let us know when you're going to ullage, will you?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Stand by. 2, 1.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: MARK it.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Three minutes to go. Correction, 2 minutes to go. Jack.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Two minutes. We got it.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Check engine gimbal off, please.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: It's verified to off. And - 04 09 17 28 IMP MARK it.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: One minute.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, Fred.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: ENGINE ARM to DESCENT.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: ULLAGE.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. You're looking at 470.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. We copy 7.4.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Roger. 7.4 and I had about 0.2 showing, I guess, when we started.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. We verify that. Okay, Aquarius. Trim it to 7.6.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. You want plus-X now to get 7.6. Is that correct?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. You're looking at it, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Looks good. Nice work.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Let's hope it was.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Aquarius. We're ready to follow you through on setting up PTC and powerdown. Your choice. 04 09 20 30 IMP Okay. We're pressing into getting PTC established right now.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. We'd like to change the num- ber of yaw pulses we gave you before as 21. We'd like to reduce that to 12. Twelve pulses yaw right, and that'll take you about 3 seconds to get them in if you don't want to count them.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. We'll make it 12 versus 21.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Houston. I'm just about there now and as soon as I get 90, we'll start damping rates.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Houston. I'm trying to damp rates now. We're at the proper roll attitude and pitch.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Working a little bit better this time.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Are you copying any attitudes down there, rates, et cetera?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Aquarius. We're seeing some extremely low rates at this time, really below our capability to measure them.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, I think I've got pitch and roll just about squared away. I let yaw just slightly drift; it's drifting in a clockwise direction and I'm about all set now to put in my 12 clicks to the right.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, Jim. Ready to look at it with you.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Twelve clicks right.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. Are we clear now to proceed with the powerdown?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative, Fred. We're ready to press on with powerdown. I've got two changes for you. Step 1 of the emergency powerdown on page power - 5. Over.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Leave your POWER AMPLIFIER switch in PRIMARY vice OFF and put your RANGING switch to RANGE, vice OFF/RESET.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. We're in PRIM in the POWER AMP and RANGING on RANGING.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Affirmative.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. I'm going to pull. Well, here, let's just look at the checklist. 04 09 39 14 IMP Okay. Configure CBs. There you go.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston, hold off 1 on powerdown, please. 04 09 39 23 IMP Okay. We'll hold off. And we're looking at a SHe pressure, incidentally, of about 1830 now.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. We concur with that. And it looks like you got a little pitch rate going on here. Do you copy the same?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. My pitch needle is just slightly up now. I could try to take it out if you want me to.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Not - Wait, wait. There you go.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Just hold off on it 1, Jim. We'd like to take a look at it.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, we'll need high bit rate, please.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Flashlight, Jack. Jack, flashlight over here a minute.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, we need the POWER AMPLIFIER back in high bit rate, please. 04 09 40 37 IMP You got it.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: You got a couple in the roll pretty soon.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: What is it, 1.7?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: You have another set of them by the PGNS.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Now we got to turn on the heaters you want to save -

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: What's that flitting out there in the breeze? Are we venting again? Take a look, Jack.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Well, once we get squared away, Joe, I think I am going to have to go to the space center and take a good healthy one and leave just about everything. I've held up long enough.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: That's coming from above. Another one just - is just coming down right over here- Well, there's the old terminator at Fra Mauro. We'd been landing about 2 hours ago, huh? Right on the - -

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: - - to the right of the terminator.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Just for information, although l thought I'd never have to use it, that technique looked like it was a pretty good one.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, Jim. And we'd like you to give us your idea of how the PTC looks- We're not sure we're seeing what we ought to here.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. I still have my ball powered up and I'm coming around past 270 right now. I've got a slight roll and pitch offset in there. My pitch needle about halfway up and my roll needle is about 4 degrees over now.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. With that info we'll go on PTC, and let's proceed with the powerdown.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. We'll proceed with the PTC and proceed with the powerdown. I guess if we have to we can reestablish PTC at a later date. Okay. Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: First row. Ullage. AGS.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Your AGS on?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: My what? My what? Oh, yes. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. The four INVERTERS of this AC BUS volt, Fred.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Let's - give the last thing to Jack and I'll keep it all out. Okay? RCS SYSTEM A. That's in. TCAs are going off- Why do they need the ISOL valves in the ASCENT FEED in?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: You're not sucking any power unless you take these switches and move them.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: How come we pulled them out, then, in this burn?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Because you didn't want them to get moved inadvertently, I guess. It doesn't matter, Jim, they can be out or in in terms of powerdown. They just don't count.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. I got l, 2, 3.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: ISOL valve should be in 2.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Yes. Okay. Third row. Attitude DIRECT CONTROL I still have in.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Jack, how do you read now in baseband?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Reading you 5-square, Fred. How me?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. I'll stay this mode, if it's all right, so we won't be hot miksd.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. You're cleared to open the POWER AMPLIFIER circuit breaker and go to LOW BIT RATE, leaving the POWER AMP switch in PRIMARY.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. I'll pull the prime S-BAND POWER AMP breaker and go LOW BIT RATE.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: About how far out are we now. Jack?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Aquarius. You're 150 000 miles and you're coming in at 4500 feet a second. That's from the Earth.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, we're at 100 - Yes. 150 K, 4500 feet a second.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, Aquarius, how much TTCA control did you have to do in the burn?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: How much - What was that. Jack?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: How much control of the TTCA did you have to do during the burn?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: I wasn't noticing Jim too much. I'd say I put in maybe about six or seven inputs. I don't think it ever got off more than a couple of needle widths.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, Fred. Thank you.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: I think it's probably the same for Jim. I wasn't noticing his input but the - his needle was hanging in there pretty good.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Thank you, Fred.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Now do you read?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: I read you loud and clear. Jack.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. What's your status, who's sleeping, and who's working?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Well, right now we're all three kind of working. Do you have any recommendations?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes, looks like to us from here that you and Fred ought to get some sleep, and that you ought to eat in about 6 hours. And that the Skipper ought to go to bed about 113 hours.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: I've got some other information. We shouldn't have some good dope on your trajectory for about 2 hours. Looked like to us that the burn was real good, however, and we're taking a close look at it, and we'll get back with you on that in about 2 hours from now. Another thing that we're expecting to have happen is that the SHe tank is going to reach its burst limit. The earliest time we predict this will happen will be at 107 hours on about 25 minutes. And the latest probable time is at 110 hours, and this is supposed to be a nonpropulsive vent, but you might hear it and you might see something.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. That's good news. We were wondering about that. And I'll relay all the other information you gave me.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. And if the SHe tank does burst during this time frame before we get trajectory info, why, that will delay our trajectory info somewhat. Your consumables, your water is now good through 152 hours.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Jack, wait a minute. Let me copy some of this down.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. I'm ready now.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We're predicting that you still have more water than you need. And one thing we'd like for you to do is when you're going to sleep up there in the command module take a look through the optics and see if you can see any stars.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack, I will do. Jim and I were able to spot constellations from the windows of the LM when there's no venting taking place. Could you give me some time on these consumables, what you're predicting they're good for? I think you started to give them times, didn't you, or was I just hearing things.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We started to give you some times. We think we might be able to give ycu some better ones pretty soon. But it looks like your water is good through 154 hours, and you've got takusan 02 through 272 hours, plenty of lithium hydroxide, and your amp-hours ought to be good through 199 or 200 hours. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay; good. Copy that.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We expect that your water rate is going to drop off and at the time, DELTA will go up to 160 - 165 hours quite shortly. Another thing we're interested in is what's your status on rest and medication.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. None of us, I know of, had any medications, and right now as far as rest, I suppose we're no tireder than normally in this situation. I'm going to relay the work-sleep cycle.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. And don't forget to look through the optics when you go up in the command module.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: (Laughter) Okay. I'll do that.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Jack, as luck would have it, we just now started to vent a little from the command module ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Sorry about that but there's too much background noise to read you. I think we'll have to wait until you come up on a new antenna. Over.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Aquarius. Go ahead now. I think I can hear you.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Okay, Jack. I was going to say, as luck would have it, the command module picked this time to start venting again, so I probably won't be able to get a good hack out of stars out of the telescope.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Thank you. And if you can think of it, when the time comes up, when you're not venting, how about remembering to take a look through them and give us a word?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Will do.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead. Over.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Did you call?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Yes, Jack. I just got a question. How long are you predicting our command module canisters to last in here?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. We've got 14 cartridges that'll last 157 hours, plus we've got the LM primary cartridge with 23 hours, and we've got two PLSS cartridges with 7 hours apiece.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. I was just curious as to how much time we've got out of these two cartridges.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Stand by 1. I'll get a prediction on that. By the way, I hope you're keeping track of the ones you've used and the ones you've not.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Yes, right now, we have numbers 7 and 8 in the LM here.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: They were two brand new fresh ones.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. In regards to the C02 canisters, by the way the PCO2 is reading 1.6 down here now. We expect that we can get 6 more hours out of the two canisters that we have there - 6 hours at least. However, at 112 hours, ! when we've got several people up, we're going to rig up two more and we have the new simplified procedure for doing this. However, in the meantime, should we need to have a canister change, we plan to switch to the LM primary canister. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Copy that. Jack.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, Aquarius, how's your PTC holding up?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Well, we got a little bit off Jack. The - It starts high in the LMP's window and goes low in the CDR window.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: So we've got a little bit of a wobble on it. Of course, the command nodule venting doesn't help, either.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Jack, in reference to your question about the PTC, on this last complete revolution, the Sun first appeared in the very top right corner of the LMP window, passed over the CDR window, and was visible through the overhead window, and now the Moon is - came pretty well through the center of both windows this last time.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Thank you. Jack. Copying that.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. We'd like to get a little better idea of how PTC is going. So, what we'd like for you to do is what we did last time. That is to give us a reading on the center of the Earth and the center of the Moon on the - LPD.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: On the LPD. Okay, It's shifted. Let's see, the Moon's gone by and the Earth didn't come into the LPD last time.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. But when it goes by the plane of the LPD, tell us where it was. Okay?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Will do.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. This pass, the Earth came into view at the top left-hand corner of the LMP's window

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay Jack. This pass, the Earth came into view at the top left-hand corner of the LMP's window and was going down. However, when it passed it wasn't as high up as the last pass. It did pass into view at the CDR window, but too high up to get an LPD reading.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Understand it went high in both windows then.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Yes, last time it wasn't even visible in the CDR's window; this time it was visible if you squatted down, but too high up to get an LPD reading.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. That's good. Thank you.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Houston; Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. The moon came into view at the middle of the LMP's window, passed through the CDR's window at an LPD of 5 degrees.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Understand.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. On this pass, the Earth came into the view at the top part of the LMP's window, and we got an LPD angle on it as it passed through the CDR' s window of a minus 4 degrees. 04 ll 36 16 CC Okay. A minus 4. Thank you. Jack

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: It's - it's above the - Okay. Are you familiar with the minus 4 being halfway through the sky part, huh?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Affirmed.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Houston; Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. On this pass, the Moon came into view at the top part of the LMP's window, came across higher. Jim estimates the LPD angle at a minus 15 degrees.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. A minus 15 on the moon, and sounds like it's set up pretty well.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Everybody's happy with it down there?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, it's a little too early to tell exactly how the PTC is going. We'd like to get a few more points, so keep reading them off, and we're still looking for that SUPERCRIT to go anytime.

transcript.speaker: SC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: The Earth was just fairly high in the LMP's window and across the lh-degree LPD line.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Skipper; l4 degrees. Thank you.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: The Moon went by the IPD at 6 degrees, plus 6 degrees.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Barth at plus 6. Thank you.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. The Moon. Thank you.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: The Moon passed by at a minus 8 degrees on the LPD. No, that's the Earth. The Earth passed by at a minus 8 degrees.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. The Moon went by at a minus 8 degrees.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. We got it. The Earth went by at a minus 8 degrees. On a basis of the data - -

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: That's right.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: On the basis of the data we have so far, your entry angle is 5.99. The block data we gave you on the pad for a no-COMM midcourse-7 last night is no longer valid because we made this midcourse.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Understand, the no-COMM pad is no longer valid because of the midcourse. Entry angle based on the last 2 hours' tracking is 5.99, and I take it you're going to keep tracking for some time now to see whether we need another midcourse or not.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Are you planning any no-COMM midcourse at 133 and change anyway right now, or are you going to wait?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We're discussing that now, Jim, and it looks like we're going to wait on the tracking. For the time being, since you're in the corridor, why, there's no need to pass it up. But we're going to keep looking at the tracking, and we'll probably come up with one.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: All right. I'm not too sure what the venting is going to do to us so - when this SHe tank ruptures, what it's going to do for us.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. We don't presently expect the SHe tank to have any effect on your trajectory, and the pressure's up to 1921 now.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Hey, it's going a lot better than we ever expected. What a way to get a data point.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And, Jack, just think. You thought you we'-e going to sleep through all your watches.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Say again, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I said, you thought you were going to sleep through all you watches.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Well, you keep waking me up.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Sorry about that.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. You notice anything?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Yes, Jack. I was just about ready to call you. Underneath quad 4, I noticed a lot of sparklies going out.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Can you hear or feel anything?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: No, I sure can't, but I think it changed our - it changed out PTC. Let me check and see what the drift is.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. She's going down through 600 now.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I think we're probably going to have io reestablish PTC Yes, we got pretty fast yaw drifting, Jack.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius. What are your plans?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We're thinking about them right now. Did you say it yawed some?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Yes, I was in a right yaw and now I'm in a left yaw; at a much faster rate than the one we put in PTC.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. We're talking it over. Stand by.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: What's the SHe tank down to now. Jack?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. It's going through 125 pounds now. And we understood you to say - -

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: - - that it reversed your yaw. Is that affirmative?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Sure did. Jack. It reversed my yaw completely and put in a little pitch, I think.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: But more than anything, it reversed my yaw.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Have you effectively established PTC in the opposite direction then?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Well, you could say that. I'm not too sure just what kind of pitch or roll I've got, coupled with the yaw. I just saw the Earth go by the LMP's window here, not too long ago at a rather faster rate than we had going the other direction.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Perhaps you can tell Low fast I'm having to shift OMNIs.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes, we can tell the C0MM cycling back and forth.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Is that what they call a nonpropulsive vent?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Right. I'd hate to see a propulsive one.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: You and me both.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: It's going through 50 pounds now. So, are you seeing fewer sparklics?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Yes. Much fewer. Not any at all, now. I'm not sure whether that vent gave me reverse yaw and roll - left roll - that's - if that's what it gave me.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: You say you think it might have given you some left roll as opposed to opposite yaw.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I'm sure it gave me the yaw. Jack, but I'm not too sure ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We'd kind of like to watch it, sec what happens for a little while before we make a recommendation. However, we'll need some inputs from you on that.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Well, we're in no trouble up here as far as as far as the yaw goes. Everything's fine. It's faster than we had set up before. We just wanted to get into proper thermal constraint, and it's going to take me 15 minutes to get the thrusters up anyway.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Skipper. We don't see any thermal problems as a result of this change. If we see some communications problems, we may have to do something different, but so far, so good. And we'd kind of like to hear from you on LPD numbers, if you get anything going by the window.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Will do.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. The Earth just went through at an LPD of 26 degrees.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. The Earth went through at 26 degrees going the opposite direction this time - left to right. Is that right?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: From left to right. That's affirmative.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Of course, the only other thing that we'd be concerned about is what change in your velocity this might have had and what DELTA-V it imparted, and we'll have to look at that for a while before we are able to determine it. And, if there is no significant change, why, we prefer just to leave it the way it is.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. We're going to get a, time on a revolution here, and maybe that'll help you out.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Right. And, for your information, the tank went at 1937.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: That's two thousand - 1937?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Right.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. The Earth went through again at 18 degrees on the LPD.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Earth at 18. Thank you.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. And we didn't see the Moon that time.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. The Moon vent through that time at 32 degrees on the LPD.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Moon at 32. Thanks.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. Well, we didn't get the Earth that time. The Moon came back through at about 10 degrees, and now we're getting to the Earth again. Stand by.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. The Earth came through the LPD at 62 degrees that time. And the total time for the two revolutions, - I missed the Earth revolution before, but the total time for the Earth's two revolutions was 3 minutes and 50 seconds.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Say again the time and the - and also the LPD number. You're in the background noise. Jack.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Okay, Jack. LPD that time was 62 degrees and that was for two revolutions , being at that distance we missed the Earth - The time before we didn't see it. And the time was 3 minutes and 50 seconds.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Three minutes and 50 seconds. Is that rate uncomfortable for you?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Jack, Jim said it isn't uncomfortable. It's a little annoying as for the OMNI switching, and also he said it's kind of - He said this Earth/Moon relationship's kind of ... because he doesn't know when to ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. We've got a MASTER ALARM and we've got a battery light flickering.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Copy a battery light. What battery?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius , how about cycling the power temp monitor to find out which battery it is, please.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes. That's in work, Joe.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. It's that same old ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Fred. I can hear you now. Say again, please.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. It's the same old - same old one. The only light I'm getting is on BAT 2.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Fred. We copy your same old friend, battery 2. Could you give us high bit rate for a while, please?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. High bit rate, please.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: How you getting it now. Jack?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We got it.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Aquarius. You can go low bit rate, POWER AMP, OFF and DOWN VOICE BACKUP now. Voltages and currents look normal on battery 2; so ignore the battery light.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. POWER AMP, OFF, back to low bit rate, and I'll go back to sleep.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: The battery light staying on?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Yes. We got a steady on BAT 2, BAT FAULT LIGHT and the battery caution light.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. And the Skipper in the sack now?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Say again?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Is the Skipper in the sack now?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: okay. Hold on a minute, jack.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. Since the antenna switch is kind of annoying, we've talked them into buying only half of the data. If it gets too troublesome for you to switch antennas, why, just leave it on one antenna and we'll listen to you half of the time.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. It's not really much trouble. That's all we're doing about it. We'll try to keep up with it. And you're satisfied with this attitude so far. I guess you're going to watch the thermal and find out whether perhaps we're going to some other PTC attitude.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Thermal appears to be no problem. We're looking at what DELTA-V might have been imparted due to this, and it looks like we're not going to change the PTC attitude.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Then DELTA-V was a part of it; I hope it raised that angle a little bit.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes. We'll he looking at the data here, and give you a better answer in next 30 minutes or so.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Meanwhile, back to the drawing board about nonpropulsive vents.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, with your kind of luck, it probably lowered the angle some more.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Thanks for the confidence.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, Jim, we're going no have a handover here pretty soon, about 3 minutes, we may lose uplink for 30 seconds or a minute.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. We're handed over. How do you read?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Read you loud and clear. Jack.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. I'm hearing you now, and the noise has come up again, but it will go down.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: How do you read now?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. That's a lot better, and we figure your battery glitch was just that thermal switch triggered a mal - a CAUTION and WARNING, just cycled once, and triggered a MASTER ALARM again. We'll watch the batteries for you, since you don't have any CAUTION and WARNING on now. ' 04 13 31 13 CUR Okay. Appreciate that.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim.- Your luck is holding. Tracking shows that your entry angle has gone up to minus 6.24. This is on the basis of all the data we've col.lected between the midcourse up to the time the SHe tank went. So, we'll continue to look at it, and see if SHe tank did any anything to it at all. So it's - The data has gone from 5.9 to a. minus 6.24.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: That sounds pretty good. We're really getting in there.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: How are you doing, Jin?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Not bad. Not bad at all.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Is Jack in the sack, or is he with you?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Jack and Fred both are going to sleep. It's sort of humorous; Fred's sleeping place now is in the tunnel, upside down with his head resting on the ascent engine. Jack Is on the floor of the LM, with a restraint ... wrapped around his arm to keep him down there.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: You say Jack is on the floor, and Fred is with his head on the ascent engine.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: That's right, with his feet up into the tunnel.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Skipper. Your luck is really hanging in there. Your water's good up to 161 hours now.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Hey, that sounds great.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That doesn't include PLSS water or command module water.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Jack, I'd just like to know what - what plans or thoughts being contemplated for the PLSSs or the OPS, whether we're going to use their LiOH canisters or take the devices back in the command module with us, or just what will be your plans.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes. We're talking all that over now. We haven't decided.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Everything's running real smooth over Timber Cove, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Sounds pretty good. How about at El Lago?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Same. Everything's smooth there, too.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Good.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jim, we've had a lot of people working on the entry procedures, and they'll be continuing to do so. We got a few ideas we'd like to toss at you so you can start thinking about them if you think you're in a position to discuss them without waking up the other guys. What do you think?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Yes, go ahead. It's okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. One of the first things we want to do is charge the battery in CSM, so we can get some LM power over there to do that, and we have procedures ginned up to do it. In regards to reentry, we're planning our last midcourse at 5 hours before entry interface, and, if we have to make one, that is. And then we'd like to jettison the service module at 4 hours and a half, roughly, before entry interface, and take the next 3 to 3-1/2 hours for taking pictures, cranking up the command module G&N, taking care of stowage, and other odds and ends. And we'd hang on to the LM until 1 hour before entry interface, and then we'd jettison that. And these procedures are going to be run integrated in the CMS and LMS tomorrow morning, and, hope- fully, later on in the day, we'll do it again with Mission Control on the loop. A couple of other things we'd like to toss at you: one question is what do we do with the OPS. The thought is that there is adequate 02 in the command module and that the OPS represents high pressure source and a stowage problem, and people are thinking about leaving them in the LM. The other thing is that we think you might want to make this a suited entry, suiting up prior to LM jettison, because what we're doing is, when we jettison the LM, we're going to do it like we did in Apollo 10 - just let the beauty go, and if we weren't suited, why, we'd be betting on the hatch seal to take care of us. So we thought we'd toss these few ideas at you. Some of them are ones that are particularly pertinent questions at this time.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. A suited entry would sort of ... the 1-hour LM jettison back and ... back and forth up to that time. ... impede our progress back and forth. ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We're losing you, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. I think I've got you back. I guess the midcourse at 5 hours prior to ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Affirmative, Jim. Midcourse 5 hours prior to entry interface.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: If that's the case, all I'm worried about is having that all squared away. It's long before that ... 1 want everything in its place. All the stowage cleared away, all the ... ready to go and know exactly what to do and ... so that we can do the midcourse, and ... get into the command module ... jettison the service module, and then know exactly how to get into the LM.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. All those procedures will work - will be worked out precisely, and we agree that the stowage and all of those peripheral details ought to be taken care of before midcourse.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And, I guess, that last midcourse, we'd want to start looking at midcourse fairly early, if we have the power to do so, mainly because of attitude control. This last time was fairly easy, but I'm not too sure how long we can continue to ...

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I have ... in, and it seems about as cold as it is now, we'll probably be going into suits long before entry.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes. That's what we were thinking.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: I guess the two things which are somewhat unresolved at the moment are what to do with the OPS and what to do about the suited entry. We thought we'd toss those at you to see what you thought about them.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. As far us the OPS is concerned, we have- enough oxygen in the spacecraft ... to get us through. I have no ... command module ... suit loop prior to entry. I was looking at ... OPS ... sources of oxygen ... also in the - in the front of the suit loop or ... circulate ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jim, I'm sorry. We're not catching what you're saying. The C0MM is getting kind of bad right now.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. How do you read now?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: I've still got you with quite a bit of background can hear you.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. My only concern about leaving the OPS and/or the PLSS in the command module is how soon do we have to live off the command module consumables prior to entry, and the PLSS has a fan and has a lithium hydroxide ... use the com- mand module system. Also, the OPS ... right now ... command module ... command module oxygen and electrical power is ... but I had just as soon be ... back in the LM.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: It sounds like the general gist of your comments are that if things remain pretty much as they are now in the command module, you'd just as soon leave the OPS in the LM. Is that affirm?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: That's affirm.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. And maybe you'd like to think over the suited entry bit a little while.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay ... How we aline the command module right for entry, especially if you have the LM in back. Over.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. That's one subject that's been getting a lot of attention, and let me see if I can get

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jim, I can give you the general idea of the proposed procedure for bringing the command module G&N up. It's the presently proposed one. We may come up with a better one, but here's what we're looking at right now. First thing we plan to do is to - using the LM COAS, sight on the Earth with the LM just as we did in the midcourse. Then we'll do a body-axis aline, 400 plus 5 on the AGS, to put the AGS ball at 000. And then we can give you an AGS ball attitude to fly to, to point the CSM optics at the Moon. And, if you can see stars, why, we can use those too. Then we can give you an equivalent set of CDU angles to put into NOUN 20 and to torque the platform over. So, now we're coarse alined. Then we do a fine aline by shooting at the Moon and then at the Sun. Do you follow all that?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. Let me see if I have it. What we do is point the LM at the Earth as we did for the midcourse COAS, and we do a body-axis aline on the AGS. Then you give us an AGS ball attitude to fly to. ... the LM, and then we ... point the ... at the Moon. Then you would update the - give us some CDUs to coarse aline. ... fine aline ... on stars or the Moon or the Earth. Stand by. Okay. We had another MASTER ALARM, Jack. I don't see any lights down there, except the battery light's still there. You want - - ... display ECS. Okay. And the number 2 battery still has a light on it. I suspect it may be the same problem that we had before

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Let us talk it over a second, and we'll tell you what to do.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jim, is the battery light kind of flickering?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Yes. That's affirm. Jack.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Yes. The battery light's flickering, and it triggers off the MASTER ALARM.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Well, that - temperature sensor on bat- tery 2 is kind of cycling back and forth and every time it does, it triggers a MASTER ALARM, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Same old problem, huh? 04 14 39 39 CO Yes.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, Jim, finally on the P52, we're considering using the - the Moon and then the Sun for the fine aline.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. The Moon and the Sun for the fine aline. Understand. We'll go through this again here ...

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. Once - Once I get the spacecraft, at the proper attitude ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jim, I didn't copy your last question due to background noise.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Once - Once you get the AGS ball alined ... command module ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: After we do the body axis aline on the AGS, we can tell you what attitude on the AGS ball to fly to in order to pont the CSM optics at the Moon or at some star. And then we can, knowing where the optics are pointed, give you an equivalent set of CDU angles to put in NOUN 20 to torque the platform.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. I see.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's the current thinking. It may change between now and tomorrow, but right now, that's the way it looks, Jim. It'll probably be some take-off on that anyway.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Are they planning on a G&N entry or using another system, like EMS or something like that?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: It will be a G&N entry.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Nothing like going first class.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes. That'll be a switch, won't it?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jim, arc you broken into the food locker in the LM yet?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: That's affirm. Jack. I sure have. ... away.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: You say you did find everything in order in there, huh?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Yes, everything was great.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. I'll pass it.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: I had a question about that earlier.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Right.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I understand that one of your reasons for a suited entry is the fact that the command module hatch ... hasn't been good. It doesn't seem to be any different, but in the other ... our hatch is no better than other spacecraft.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: No, the situation, Jim, is that your hatch is as good as any other hatch but that we won't have a chance to verify it until so late in the game, like 1 hour before entry interface, in this case; whereas before, why, we had a chance to evaluate it in lunar orbit. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Oh, okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And that might make your time line a little too crowded, getting your suits on there at the last minute; say, less than an hour before entry interface.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jim, the next action item we want to pursue is transferring some LM power up to the command module MAIN B so we can start charging battery, and I guess what we ought to do is start on that one when somebody else gets up to help you there. So, when you decide to get the other guys up, or to have someone help, why, let us know and we'll start working on that.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. I'll let you have Jack, and Fred's ... When in the time line ...?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Say again, Jim. I didn't catch that

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: When in our time - What's the GET do you plan on ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jim, I didn't catch all of what you said, [???] i think you wanted to know when the procedures [???] entry are going to be available and read up to you. If that's the case, why, we're talking about 120 hours or so. As far as the - charging battery A, we want to do that as soon as the other guys get up to help you. We've already passed up some of that procedure, and we have a couple of DELTAS to it.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger. Ja.ck's already up. He asked ... curious when you wanted to do it. Did you understand that? ... Is that correct?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jim, we're having trouble hearing you. The next order of business is to charge battery A, and when you get somebody to help you there, why, we'll go ahead and get done with it.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Sounds good.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, before you start working on it let us know. because we've got some DELTAs to the battery charging procedure.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger. I'm putting Jack on the line now to copy down the DELTAs ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, did you call?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Yes, Jack. I'm on the line.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Go ahead now. I can hear better.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. Joe Kerwin passed me up the procedure for powering the CSM from the LM. Has it changed?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes. If you'll get that out, I'll read you the DELTAs.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. I've got it.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. The second step was in the LM circuit breakers panel ll and 16: ASCENT ECA CONTROL, close, two of them. Cross that out. In the next line, we had BATTERY 5 NORMAL FEED, on; cross out BATTERY 5 anl put BATTERY 6 in there. In the next line was - -

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: ... Jack ... Hey, Jack; I have for step 3, I have BAT 5 and BAT 6 NORMAL FEED, on. You just want BAT 6?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative. Just BAT 6, Jack. And the next line, you had BATTERY 1 and 3. Make that BATTERY 1, 2, 3, and 4. Just add BATs 2 and 4. All four descent BATs. And then the next two lines about waiting 30 minutes, cross that out. And the next line about BATTERIES 2 and 4 OFF/ RESET, cross that out, too.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And Jack, the - -

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Let me read -

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Let me read you all steps as I've got them. Jack, and make sure we've got them right. ASCENT ECA, two, closed. Step 2 will now be BAT 6, NORMAL FEED, on. Step 3, BATS 1, 2, 3, and 4, OFF/RESET.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. That part's all right. Jack. And we had - about 11 or 12 steps for the command moule. They go as is with no change. And then we had a couple of more procedures for the LM. Stand by 1.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Jack, let me read you command module procedures just to make sure I have them right, also.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Go ahead with the command module procedures.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Connect LM and CSM umbilicals. Step 2, panel 5: LM POWER 1 AC and - AC, closed, circuit breakers. Step 3, panel 5= EPS SENSOR SIGNAL, MAIN B, closed. Step 4, panel ... closed. Then there's step 5: MAIN B BAT BUS B, closed. Verify MAIN BUS voltage, then switch the LM power to CSM. Step 7: CB MAIN B BAT [???] B, open. And on panel 250, BAT POWER ENTRY and POSTLANDING, open. Verify MAIN BUS voltage.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. The CSM procedure's okay, and then we had to go back to the LM and do something. And the first line is okay, cross out "BAT 5 and 6 OFF," delete that. And delete the next line also, that says "Panel 11 to 16 ASCENT ECA CONTROL, open." Then we had a couple of notes which remain the same. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. I didn't get the notes, but I'll read you the steps as I have them now. One step, BAT 1, 2, 3, and 4 ... and at this point should have BATTERIES 1, 2, 3, 4, and 6 ON. Is that affirmative?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative. So now we have BAT 1, 2, 3, 4, and 6, ON, and I got two notes. Number 1 is: your circuit breaker protection limits - your circuit breaker protection - limits the current to 15 amps. Number 2 note is: now the umbilical between the LM and the command module is hot. And the MAIN .BUS voltage can be moni- tored by selecting MAIN B.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. These notes are: circuit breaker protection limits current to 15 amps. The tube, the umbilical between the CSM and LM is hot. I can monitor MAIN B for the bus voltage.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirm. Jack.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. One question here. If we transfer power like this, we're not going to cut us short on power remaining in the CSM ..., are we ...?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Say it again, Jack. I didn't get it.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Stand by. If we configure the CSM for powering up the LM, we aren't going to cut it short on LM power requirements to get us back in the entry interface, are we?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's a negative. Jack. According to the latest update, we've got ampere-hours out to 203 hours.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Stand by. ...

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. One question from Jim is, he wants to know whether the procedure has been tried ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Try it again, now. Jack. What did Jim want to know?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. He would like to know whether the proceure has been tried and whether it has been found to be okay; and there's no danger of shorting out any of our batteries or anything we have on board the LM now.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. This procedure has not been tried out as such; however, the hardware paths through which the current flows are the same ones which we used during translunar trajectory, and there's not a problem with shorting out a descent battery. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. I'll relay that to Jim.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jack, of course, the reason for all of this is that we see we're 20 amp-hours short on one of the entry batteries, and we've got to juice that up to get you home with.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. What we owe you from here on out is the actual battery A charge procedure, and then a procedure to turn this all around, again.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Do you have it there, and how long is it ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. I have the procedure in front of me. It's about 18 steps, and the reason it's so long is because we're starting from this basic configuration which we gave you earlier. It concerns a charge on battery A, of course, which is our low one. So, when you're ready to copy it, let me know.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Let's go at it.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Are you ready to read - copy it?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. On panel 250, circuit breaker BAT A, POWER ENTRY/POSTLANDINC, close; on panel 275, circuit breaker INVERTER POWER 2, MAIN B, close. Next several circuit breakers are on panel 5; circuit breaker PAT RELAY BUS, BAT A, close; circuit breaker EPS SENSOR UNIT, AC BUS 2, close; CB EPS SENSOR SIGNAL, AC2, close; CB BATTERY CHARGER, MAIN B, close. Are you still with me?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. I'll read back those steps you gave me so far. Panel 250 CB BAT A POWER ENTRY/POSTLANDING, close; panel 2751 CB'INVERTER POWER 2, MAIN B, close; panel 5, CB BAT RELAY BUS, BAT A, close; CB EPS SENSOR UNIT, AC BUS 2, close; CB EPS SENSOR SIGNAL, AC2, close, CB BAT CHARGER, MAIN B, close.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Good readback. Jack. The only one is number 1 - number 4. I didn't get your readback, but it's EPS SENSOR UNIT AC BUS 2, close. You got that?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Yes. 1 read that back CB EPS SENSOR UNIT, close.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. To continue - to continue on - the same panel, panel 5: circuit breaker, BATTERY CHARGER, AC POWER, close; circuit breaker BATTERY CHARGER, BAT A CHARGE, close; circuit breaker INVERTER CONTROL 2, close; circuit breaker INVERTER CONTROL 3, close; I've got a switch for you, MAIN BUS TIE, BAT A/C, OFF; and another switch, BATTERY CHARGE to AC2. Read those back.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. CB BAT CHARGER to AC POWER, close. Stand by. Okay. 1 had to get a light here. CB BAP CHARGER, BAR A CHARGE, close; CB INVERTER CONTROL 2, close; CB INVERTER CONTROL 3, close; the two switches, MAIN BUS TIE, BAT A/C, OFF; and the second one, BAT CHARGER TO AC2.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: How about reaching over there on your right-hand side and turning the BI0MED off? See if we can improve the C0MM a little bit.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. How do you read, now?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. I'm reading you real good now, and I want to verify that the main bus tie that we switched OFF was BAT Alfa Charlie.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: That's verified; MAIN BUS TIE, BAT Alfa Charlie OFF. And that should ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. And in panel 3, I've got a switch for you. AC INVERTER 2 to MAIN B.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. AC INVERTER 2 to MAIN B.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. And switch INVERTER 2, AC BUS 2 to on; and another switch, AC BUS 2 RESET, to reset and center; switch BATTERY CHARGE to Alfa; switch DC INDICATOR select BAT CHARGER; and then what we want you to do is to report the charger current and voltage to MSFN every 10 minutes for the first half hour, and then once every 30 minutes after that. And that'll be on our call. Jack. Read back the switches that I just gave you.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. It's panel 3, AC INVERTER 2, MAIN B; INVERTER 2, AC BUS 2, on; AC BUS 2 RESET to reset and center; BAT CHARGER to A; AC INDICATOR select to BAT CHARGER. Report amps and volts to MSFN every 10 minutes for the first 30 minutes, and then every 30 minutes on a MSFN call.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. That's a good readback. Jack. Now the only thing we owe you is a turnaround from this, which we will have.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Let me ask one question, here. About how long do you think it'll take to charge these batteries?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: It's going to take you about 15 hours.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Jack, about how many amperes of LM power will this 15 hours ... ? 04 15 15 21 CC Stand by. We'll get it for you

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: How many, jack?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. He got it. He got the question.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. That's going to take 120 amp-hours out of the LM, which is equivalent to 10 hours, which will put us back to 193 hours, and that's plenty.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Let me relay that to Jim here. It'll be 120 amp hours, which leaves us - which puts us back from 203 hours ... to 193 hours.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes, there's that much to spare.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. One question here. If we have any problems setting up this LM power to the CSM, is the quickest way to get out of it, return to the normal configuration, as it is for me to just switch the LM POWER to CSM to RESET then OFF?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Stand by 1.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: I would like to give one quick step in case that gave Jim report some sort of problem for us to get out of it quickly.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Let us talk it over for a minute, Jack.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Real fine. And while you guys are talking it over, you might read back - Have you got the procedure for reversing this? I'll copy that.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. Are you with me?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes. We're still here. Jack. What we want to do is follow you through on this, so we're going to get high bit rate to do it. In answer to your question, to undo this procedure quickly, in the event a problem develops, be sure that you don't touch the LM POWER switch because it's got a RESET position. But the way to undo it is go into the CSM and on panel 5 open two circuit breakers. And they're some of the first ones we read to you. Open LM P0WER-1 MAIN P, and open LM POWER-2 MAIN B. You copy that?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Understand. If I want to get out of this real quickly, I have to open just two circuit breakers in the CSM; that's on panel 5, LM POWER-l MAIN B, LM POWER-2 MAIN B.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. And before you go ahead with this, let's establish high bit rate and wait 1 on that. And then as we go through the procedure we want you to wait when you get power on MAIN B so we can take a look at MAIN B without any loads on it before we start charging the batteries.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. I understand you want high bit rate on the LM or CSM just before we start this?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That will be high bit rate on the LM, and stand by for it.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. Before we go ahead with this, what we want to do is read you the reverse - the normal reverse procedure.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. I'm ready to copy.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. I got the start on how you reverse this procedure. Ready to copy?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Go ahead. Jack.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. First you want to reverse the battery charge procedure. To do that, on panel 3, switch BATTERY CHARGE, off; AC INVERTER 2, off; panel 5, MAIN BUS TIE BAT Alfa Charlie, on, up; panel 250, circuit breaker BAT Alfa, POWER ENTRY, and POSTLANDING., open. Read back.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. On panel 3, BATTERY CHARGER, off, AC INVERTER 2, off; on panel 5, MAIN BUS TIE Alfa Charlie, on; panel 250, CB BAT A, POWER ENTRY and POSTLANDING, open.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative, jack, and then if you'll go back to the rest of the circuit breakers on that list, and just opposite - Open them all up. Stand by 1.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. Go back to the battery charge pro- cedure I gave you. And, in order to terminate charge, just - You'll just have to write "Open" or "Off" next to the circuit switch that I gave you. So on panel 250, that circuit breaker you've already opened; on panel 275, INVERTER P0WER-2 MAIN B, open; panel 5, BAT RELAY BUS BAT A, open; EPS SENSOR UNIT AC BUS 2, open, EPS SENSOR SIGNAL AC2, open; BATTERY CHARGER, MAIN B, open; BATTERY CHARGER AC POWER, open; BATTERY CHARGER, BAT A CHARGE, open; INVERTER CONTROL 2, open; INVERTER CONTROL 3, open; you've already done the MAIN BUS TIE; and then BAT CHARGE switch to AC 1. Over on panel 3, you have already set the AC INVERTER 2 to OFF and then INVERTER 2 AC BUS 2, OFF; AC BUS 2 RESET to OFF. You have already put the BATTFPY CHARGER switch to OFF; and your DC Indicator select to MAIN B. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. Do you want me to read it back to you?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: No, if you've got something in the right-hand column for all of those, we don't want to have to do it. And now one mors thing I owe you is how to untransfer LM power to the CSM, and I'll get that for you in a jiffy.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. I'll be standing by to copy it.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We have a last minute change to that.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Houston, 13.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay Jack. One thing - I guess you probably all considered it, but what heavy things can we store down there where the SRCs normally go to help increase our L over D?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: I understand the question is what kind of heavy things can you store where the SRCs go.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Yes. They go down in the LEB underneath the computer, and the heavier things you have down there increases the L over D. We don't have any SRCs , so I was just wondering what heavy things - We could probably put some cameras, television cameras, things like that that normally pretty heavy down there in - that, in our SRC. No, we can't put the in our SRC, but we could put them in that container down there which would help decrease our L over D. Anything else you can think of would be greatly appreciated because we don't even have a throwaway station, so we're down a little bit in L over D.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Let me pass that question along, and get somebody working on it.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Souvenirs, I guess.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: What souvenirs? (Laughter) All I've got is a Marine Corps foxhole-digging shovel.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: You've got all you need then, buddy.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Ready to copy the power removal from the command module/LM umbilical.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: I'm ready to copy. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. This assumes that all the descent batteries are on line and ASCENT BATTERY 6 is on NORMAL FEED, as we said earlier. First thing you do is go in the CSM and look on panel 5 circuit breaker LM POWER-2 MAIN B, open; LM POWER-l MAIN A, open; circuit breaker EPS SENSOR SIGNAL MAIN B, open.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Hey, Jack.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: ... you got just a little bit scratchy there because of the antenna problem. Let me read this back to you.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: okay. What I got, Jack, was the procedure assumes that all DESCENT BATTERIES are ON, and BAT 6 is on NORMAL FEED. Now we're going into the LM and on panel 5, we take LM, or CB LM POWER-2, MAIN B open. And that's as far as I got.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, the second one is on panel 5 also. Circuit breaker, LM POWER-l, MAIN A, open; circuit breaker EPS SENSOR SIGNAL, MAIN B, open. Okay, read those back for the CSM, and I'll give you some steps in the LM.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. CB LM POWER-2, MAIN B, open; CB LM POWER-l MAIN A, open; CB EPS SENSOR SIGNAL, MAIN B open Stand by 1, Jack.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Jack, I don't think we ever closed CB IM P0WER-1 MAIN A. We closed LM POWER-2, MAIN B, and LM POWER-1, MAIN B. Both of them on MAIN B.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes, you're right. Both of them should be MAIN B.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Copy that.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Ready to copy the LM?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. On panel 16 circuit breaker, EPS, BAT FFED TIES, two, open; and now you've got to listen real carefully for high volts and low volts. BATTERY 1, HIGH VOLTS, to OFF/RESET; BATTERY 2, LOW VOLTS, to OFF/RESET and then ON; BATTERY 2, HIGH VOLTS, to OFF/RESET and then ON; BATTERY 1, HIGH VOLTS, ON; and then the circuit breaker on panel 16, EPS: BAT FEED TIES, both of them, closed. Read back.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. On the LM side of the house is on panel 16. CB EPS BAT FEED TIES, two, open; BATTERY 1, HIGH VOLTAGE, OFF/RESET; BATTERY 2, LOW VOLTAGE, OFF/ RESET then ON; BATTERY 2, HIGH VOLTAGE, OFF/RESET then ON; BATTERY 1, HIGH VOLTAGE, ON. Panel 16, UP BAT FEED TEES, two, clused.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. That's a good readback. It concludes the procedure going both ways and now we just have to stand by.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, when do you plan to start this?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Darn soon.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Did you say not soon?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: No, we're going to do it pretty soon, but we want to have high bit rate, and we don't want you to give that to us until we tell you.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. I think I'll go back and try to undamp up there. Do you have anything more for the command module?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We're discussing two items, but we don't have them ready right now.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: One of them, I hope, is a foolproof alinement procedure.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. Just for curiosity's sake, does FIDO have any information as to whether that helium - that helium tank dump affected our trajectory at all?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Aquarius. Our tracking data shows that since the helium dump, our ertry angle has not changed from its; value of 6.24, and somebody calculated that if we had a propulsive vent, that helium could roughly, at the maximum, only impart a DELTA-V of a half a foot per second or less, anyway. But we're continuing to track and as soon as we get some more info, we'll pass it along.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. That's swell, Jack. Thank you.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Sure.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Your 6.24 sounds good.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I'm still awake, I guess.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: They said that it would be a while because they want to get high bit rate. They don't want to put high bit rate.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Aquarius. We're ready. So we want some high bit rate. To do that, go over to panel 16 under C0MM and close the PRIMARY S-BAND POWER AMPLIFIER. On your C0MM panel -

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Okay, Jack. Wait 1. While - I'd like to get the whole crew up for this if you don't mind.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: ... they're ready to start. Yes, you want to get Fred-o up.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: We want to transfer some power - I want to go to high bit rate here first, then want to transfer LM power to CSM, Fred.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jim, I'll give you the COMM.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, there's no great big rush. If you want to let Fred come up to speed slowly, why maybe that'll help out.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. ...

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And Houston, Jack is showing Fred the procedures before we start up.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Say again, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, how do you read?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Loud and clear.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. I'm hearing you now. I think I missed your last transmission, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Jack is showing Fred the procedures. Want to get him familiarized with them, and how to get out of any problems before we proceed.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. No rush. Just let us know when you're ready. Me don't want old Fred-o to slip a gimbal there.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Yes. We're watching him.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Boy, if you took 120 hours out. Oh. ... Okay. ...

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Hello, Fred. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, I guess the only question I have is in the first - the very first portion involving the LM here where it has me turn on the only BAT 6, and then turn off all the DESCENT BATTERIES. Are you still reading me?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. I read you until after turn off BAT 6 - Correction, turn on only BAT 6.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, the question is "Only one ASCENT BATTERY BAT 6 on the line," immediately followed by turning off four DESCENT BATs. Is that correct?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative, Fred. That question has been banged around and we decided to go that way.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Let's see, we will be powering other BUS via the CROSS TIE BALANCE LOADS breaker. Is that correct?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative, and we're reading a current of 11 amps right now.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Okay. I guess I'm ready, then. That's 11 amps?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And after you turn BAT 6 on the line, you might as well take a look at the BATs 1 through 4 and so forth, and make sure that it's okay to turn them off.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Roger. Are you ready, gang?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes, we're ready for the POWER AMPLIFIER and the HIGH BIT RATE, and NORMAL VOICE, on the FUNCTION switch, please.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, we see BAT 6, ON, and it looks good, Fred-o.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Am I cleared to proceed with the next step, getting 1, 2, 3, and 4, OFF/RESET?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Affirmative. You're cleared for BATs 1 through 4, OFF/RESET.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Still looks good.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Houston. We need a call from you when to have Jack to proceed up into the Odyssey and start up there.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Aquarius; and Jack can get with it right now.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Houston; Aquarius. We've completed the powerup and things look good upstairs. Are we GO for proceeding with battery charge?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Aquarius; you're GO on the battery charge.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Boy, this is really a switch, isn't it. Jack?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's an understatement. You're not known for that.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes. I think if you add up the - Yes - if you add up the operating time, I think the LM beats the CSM by a considerable margin on this flight.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Grumman just hired you.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: You're out there at 134000, coming in at about 4900 feet a second. 04 16 08 58 LIMP Very good.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: The SUPERCRIT tank went off at about 19:37, just

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes. It - it also must of not did very much, except the rates. I was asleep then and I didn't hear a thing.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Is the command - service module still venting?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Jack said it was just before he went up. Right now, the Sun's over there, and I can't really tell - -

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And - -

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: - - I'll look again in 1 minute.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We asked him a long time ago if he was able to see any stars out the optics. I don't think we ever got an answer.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: That's a pretty good sleep station I had rigged up, Jack. I took one of the sleep restraints out of the command module, zipped up in it, and then hooked the tie, right at the top of the zipper, onto the LM upper hatch handle. So it kind of held me there, and then just drifted up in the tunnel upside down with my face toward the hatch, so the sunlight didn't get in my eyes and that worked pretty good.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Did you sleep pretty well that way?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes, no problem at all.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Is Jim sleeping that way now, or is he standing next to you?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: He's standing next to me.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: About time for him to go to bed.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. The voltage upstairs is 34.3 and the charge is reading 2.5 amps.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay 34.3 and 2.5. And ... says ... - -

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: - - pretty cold. Good.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Say again your last.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: They came - both came down here rubbing their hands, shivering. It's pretty cool upstairs.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Are you keeping warm in the LM?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes. It's pretty reasonable down here.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. And right now, it looks like ... right now, it looks like the command module isn't venting. Jack, so I'm going to try to take a look at the optics.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. You say it is not venting?

transcript.speaker: LMP
