transcript.text: Yes. That's the word. We've just looked through the A0T and you can't see anything back there.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. And everything's fine in El Lago.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Very good.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, we're ready to secure the high bit rate.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius; how do you read?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: I'm hearing you with a lot of background noise Fred-o.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. How now? I just switched OMNIs again.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, could you get a - amps and volts readout from Odyssey, please?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, stand by. 04 16 24 08 LMP The CMP is dotting across there. You'd be amazed at how proficient you get at transfering to the tunnel after the first 1000 times.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: I didn't get your last there, Fred-o. We'd like you to verify that your POWER AMPLIFIER circuit breaker is open.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. That's verified. POWER AMPL breaker is open. 04 16 24 48 Cc Roger.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack; that's 34.6 volts and just a little bit under 2.5 amps.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: okay, Fred. I copied 2.5 amps. Say again the volts, please.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: 34.3 and that was just a little bit below 2.5.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 34.3; thank you.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. ... point ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Fred-o, I didn't copy the last. Say again the volt age, pie as e.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, and the voltage is 34.6 - 34.6 amps, slightly less than 2.5.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 34.6 and a little below 2.5. Thank you.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: We're - the way we are torquing around to the side here, Jack - We are getting some intervals where I can't hardly get to it with either of the OMNIs.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead, Hous- Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: okay. Jack reports from upstairs that he can see stars and constellations out of the optics but the Sun angle is such that it is reflecting off the LM - portion of the LM quad and other thruster ... right now. ... really moving around ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. The part I got was that he can see stars and constellations and there is some sunlight reflected off the quads. That's all I got.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes. The point being that, at least in the present orientation, you have to kind of wait until Sun isn't reflected off the LM to see them.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: okay. What you're saying is you kind of have to wait until the - there is no Sun reflection on the LM to see the stars. Is that right?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes. That's for the present orientation, of course.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: But later on, if you can stop it moving around and

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay - -

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Fred-o. And we need a volts and amps reading.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. And bring it back upstairs.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. The volts, 35.0; amps, 2.4.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. 35.0 and 2.4. Thanks, Fred.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: The weather prediction for your landing area is still good; 2000 scattered, high scattered; 4-foot seas, 15-knots wind. There's a hurricane 500 miles to the west, which doesn't pose a problem.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: A hurricane or a typhoon?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Delay my last. It's degraded to a tropical storm.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. We need another readout amps and volts , and that will be our last one for a half hour. Over.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. The reading is 37.8 volts, 2.3 amps.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Say again, Fred.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: 37.8 volts, 2.3 amps.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 37.8 and 2.3. And that will be our last one for a half hour. Thank you. And I'm about to exercise my fifth general order here, and pass it along to Joe.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes. It must be getting around a mealtime-

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Over. 04 17 13 53 SC

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. This is your friendly do-it-yourself- kit COMM with a suggested procedure in the lithium hydroxide situation. You're looking good. We read 1.8 millimeters, and you do have sufficient LM ... to last you the rest of the flight. However, being on the conservative side, we would like to use one more set of command module canisters to guard against some possible problems with the LM, primary canister. And I have a simplified procedure for doing that, if you want to listen to it now. Over.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. I think I read that you were ready. I forgot ... earphones. This simply consists of getting a second pair of cartridges out of the command module, putting one band of sticky tape, that is the gray tape, with the sticky side out, around the sides of each new canister near the top, taking a piece of EVA cue card and cutting it into four squares about 2 or 3 inches on a side, bending those at a right angle to form corner support , attaching them to the sticky tape, so that they'll stick up and overlap the old canister, and then simply putting the old canister next to the new canister and taping it up real good so it sticks together. The only other procedure is to remove the towel plug from the old cartridges and put it in the bottom of the new cartridge. And that's it. Over.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. As I read you, we get the gray tape and fold it so that we get - the back sticks around the outside of the canisters, then we mount to that four sides of our ... cards like our EVA ... cards; then we overlap those cards down around the base of the canister. Then we - then we ... over the ... at the top. ... Then we take the towel from the old ones and put them in the bottom of the new ones

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Fred. I think you got it. I didn't completely copy your readback, but it's just that simple. We're just putting the new cartridge - the top of the new cartridge against the bottom of the old one, moving that towel plug, using the cue cards as little corner stiffeners, and taping her up.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. The top of the new against the bottom of the old.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger that. That way you don't have to touch the hose.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Hey, for a change, I took the ... LM ... this morning, Joe.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: I got ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: I'm afraid I didn't copy that, Fred, and while I was listening, EECOM told me that he'd like another battery charge ... readout.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Go.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: You want us to start on this lithium right now, Joe, or is it necessary?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: It's not time-critical, Fred, but if you have the people awake now, you might go ahead and do it. Incidentally, you probably know this, but the next several hours are going to be pretty quiet from our point of view. We're working on the entry procedures and should be ready to read them up to you in about 8 hours; and between now and then there's not an awful lot going to be going on, so you guys could be catching up on your sleep schedule. Over.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Joe.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And we would like another readout on the amps and volts.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. The volts, Joe, are 38.9 and the amps are 1.9.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Copy that, Fred. Thank you very much; 38.9 and 1.9. And EEC0M is simply making as smooth a plot as he can to verify the amount of amps we're putting back into the battery. That's why he wants it at half-hour intervals. If that schedule begins to interfere seriously with your rest cycle or so, give us a call. Over.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes. Jim's sleeping now, and Jack and I are awake and I just finished sleeping around, I guess, about another 5 or 6 hours, so I'm not particularly inclined to go back to sleep right now.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. We've got one of them ready to go, and it looks like we could do a pretty good job just using the tape strips. First combining them together and then just using a piece of paper and the bag ... get a pretty good seal ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Hey; okay, Fred. We suspected that you'd gotten at least one on. We've noticed a partial pressure drop from the 1.8 to 0.8, which is real good.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. You might run that by the CPCB and see if they approve our in-house ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger that.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Go ahead, Joe.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. We're convening the CPCB on that change, Fred, but FLIGHT has given you an interim go- ahead. Over.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: And, how do you read now?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Not too bad, Fred.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. We've got both canisters completed now.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Roger that, Fred. And you're reading 0.1 again on the C02. Incidentally, are you guys having good luck getting water out of the command module?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: We - We haven't tried that yet today.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes. This is quite an apparatus hanging on to these hoses now. And that ECS design engineer ... because it sure seems to work.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger that.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, Aquarius, Houston. At your convenience, we'd like another volts and amps readout.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: How do you read, Joe?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Pretty good, Fred.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Volts, 39.0; amps, 1.7.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 39.0, 1.7. Thank you.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Go ahead. You're pretty weak.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: I didn't call you, Joe.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Say again.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: I didn't call.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Oh, sorry about that. Incidentally, Fred, if switching OMNIs every couple of minutes bugs you, you can skip it for now. We can always wait until you come around.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: No, it doesn't. This is Jack, Joe. Fred ... It doesn't bother me at all.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Just happy to know that you're standing by.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger that. Except I'm sitting by.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Did that CO2 drop?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Joe, how far out are we now and how fast are we closing?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. The plot shows you about 130 000 miles out, which is about, gee, 10 000 closer than you were when I came on a couple of hours ago. And let me check with FIDO for your rate of closure.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Hey, Jack. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Your smiling FIDO says you're making 5040 in a 5000-mile zone

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I can't ... I ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Go ahead, Joe.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, Jack. Hate to keep bugging you, but we would like another volts and amps reading. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. We'll get it for you.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Good show.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Joe, did our sticky MOD on that - those CO2 canisters work? I'm sorry - ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jack, I think you asked if the canister MOD was working and the answer is, it sure as hell is.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Joe. I got the voltage. It's 39.0 amps and 1.75.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Houston, do you read Aquarius?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. That's affirmative.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. We had a dropout there for a few minutes. ... on either antenna.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Gee whiz. Jack, I - when did it happen? Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Just now. I just got you back.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We had a handover, but that was about a half an hour ago, and I didn't call you on it. Let me check with INCO and see if he thinks everything's okay. Your C0MM sounds just as good as it's ever been.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Yes. I'm in real good shape.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jack, Houston. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. We're checking into it. We think we lost lock in Madrid for a while, and we've got it back now.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Real fine. ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: You might also check with FIDO whether we ... perigee ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: You're getting a little weak. Did you say you wanted to verify what - what your vacuum perigee is? Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Yes. ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jack, Houston. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. The good FIDO gives us a vacuum perigee at the present time of 23.6 with a flight path angle of minus 6.25 degrees. That's without a midcourse. He's kind of tossing around the idea of doing a midcourse-7 maneuver at 5 hours before entry. If we do it, it looks like it won't be more than 2 feet per second. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, Jack, Houston. We verified that that C0MM problem was a ground problem.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Thank you. That FIDO is really cooking today.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Oh, he's having a ball.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: It must be because we haven't made any waste water dumps.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: (Laughter)

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: You can tell Jay and David that I went for a whole flight and didn't use the bathroom.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: (Laughter) He copies that. David's here; he says you've kept him so busy he hasn't had time to work on his stereo all week.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jack, we'd like another volts and amps reading at your convenience.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Houston. It's 39.2 volts; 1.6 amps.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Thank you. We copy; 39.2 volts, and 1.6 amps.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Right.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Go.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I just relieved the watch; just thought I'd find out how things are going.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. Good morning; and understand you relieved the watch, and the rest was kind of blurry. Did you have any questions?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: No questions, Joe. Just ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. That was - That was loud and clear, that one there. Now we don't have a heck of a lot going on as you know we're working on the entry procedures. I've got preliminary copies, but we're not ready to pass - to pass it up to you. Looks like you're about 125 000 miles out, starting to - starting to really pick up speed, and the Astros won last night, and that's about all I've got. Over.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. It's about time, at your convenience, for another volts and amps reading on the command module. For your information, we put 6 amp-hours back in the battery already and we've got about 14 to go. It's looking real good, and I also just got the word that the entry weather tomorrow is looking better all the time. Really looks great.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: That's good. When I went to bed last night, ... a lot of rain ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Couldn't copy that, Jim. Sorry.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius. 04 19 44 14 cC Aquarius, Houston. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger. 39.2 on the volts; 1.4 on the amps.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 39.2 and 1.4. Thank you. 04 19 44 54 cc Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead, Joe.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Just for your information, in case it happened when you were off watch, the master caution circuit breaker is still pulled, and we're seeing the - the malfunction indication on the descent battery now, but all the param eters still look just as good as ever, and that's just for information.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. I see the battery light flickering now.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Recommend you ignore it.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Over. 04 20 26 44 cDR Go ahead, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jim, it's volts and amps time again, at your convenience.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. If you gave me those readings, I didn't copy them. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius. Do you read?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Okay; go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Volts, 39.3; amps, 1.25.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Copied 39.3 and 1.25. Jim, did jack tell you what your trajectory looks like? Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Haven't got up to ... on it. How about giving me a rundown?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We are looking at a vacuum perigee right now of 23.6; flight path angle of minus 6.25; and if we decide we want to trim that up, we're looking at a midcourse of about 2 feet per second. Your consumables, of course, are getting better all the time; we've got 163 hours of water, 230 hours of oxygen, and 172 hours worth of electrical power. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: That sounds good.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. we would like to get another check from you on the propellant tank temperatures, as we did yesterday. And the procedure is to, on panel 16, circuit breaker PROPELLANT, DISPLAY/ ENGINE, OVERRIDE/LOGIC to close. Then go to your display and read the tank 1 and tank 2 tempera- tures for us, and then open the circuit breaker again. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. I'm closing now - the DISPLAY/ENGINE, OVERRIDE/LOGIC.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. And the reaction control temperatures are 65 in A and 65 in B.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. We'd like the descent tank temperatures, too. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: 67; oxidizer is 63; descent tank 1 ... is 64; the oxidizer is ... Did you copy? Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Hello, Houston. Did you copy the - the DPS display temperatures?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jim, I copied 63 and 64, which I think were the descent 1 temps, and that's all I got.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. I'll go over it again. I'm on descent 1, now and fuel is about 64, and oxidizer is 65, and I'll go to descent 2 - -

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Thank you very much - -

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: - - our descent 2. Okay. I've got descent 2 now right up on 67 and 66.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. We copy that, and once again we'd like to get the volts and amps check in the command module. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. I'm going to go up there and get it. Jack is - and Fred are asleep, so I'll be off the air a minute.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Real good.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Go.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Volts, 39.3; amps, 1.2 zip.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We copy 39.3 and 1.20. And, Jim, I've got one more item for information for you. At - In about 45 minutes or so, you will get an H2O quantity caution light on the descent tank. We expect this. It occurs at 16 percent. And it's no problem, because we intend to run the tank dry just for drill. To reset the - the light, on panel 2, just set the O2 H2O QUANTITY MONITOR to the CAUTION/WARNING RESET position and the light will go away. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. I understand. We're going to get a H20 warning light here shortly, and I'll reset it.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Good deal.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, this is Earth. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead. Earth; Aquarius here.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Earth is here, also; and, Jim, it is time for another one of those volt/amp checks. For your information, we've got that battery back up to 30 amp-hours now. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Hey, that sounds great. Jack's gone up to check it.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Aquarius, Earth.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: You know, I think Aquarius is ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We've got garble now, Jim; I'm sorry.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I said Aquarius ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Voltage 39.3, amps 1.26.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Copy that, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jim, Houston. Have you guys put on any extra clothes to try and ward off the nip of Jack Frost? Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Well, the lunar boots and two pair of underwear, and everyone is ? crawl into their sleep restraints.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: We're a little reluctant to break out the suits.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes, that's understandable. You can always use them if you have to. I guess it's pretty hard to get extra coveralls on, huh?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Well, Joe, I didn't think we had any extra inflight garments aboard, but we're going to check right now.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Well, standby.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Jim, we noticed you just vent to AUTO and back to CLOSE on the SUIT RELIEF valve. Is everything okay?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: We didn't do that intentionally. Stand by.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, maybe you didn't. Incidentally, you're less than 24 hours to go.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger. What happened was, our lithium hydroxide device here got caught in the suit relief valve. It is closed now. That's where you want it, right?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And, Joe, just a reminder; now that you mention it - that it's less than 24 hours to go, what I'd like to do, and I have aboard all the Procedures that you are working up; so I can run through them with the crew, and make sure that we get all our signals straight.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger that, Jim. We are trying to get the procedures finished and up to you as quickly as we can. They exist. What's going on now is the guys are running them in the CMS/LMS, integrate, to make darn sure that the attitudes are correct and the time line is nice and relaxed and all that good stuff. And they won't be finished that run for another few hours. However, we expect to have an overall time line and a sequence of events for you before that time, and we'll start with the procedures as soon as they get ready. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. That's good. I think ... ought to go back to the original procedures we have on board and modify them as we have the time to.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. Roger. We're going to do that to the maximum extent possible. And it looks reasonably feasible. To begin with in the command module we're going to have to send you some separate sequences for powering it up a little bit at a time. The closer we get to entry the more we get on the checklist. By the time we're about at EI minus 45 we're on the checklist all the way.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And just as a reminder, don't forget our stowage problem. We - We still have to do quite a bit of stowage of the drogue and probe in the LM, and, et cetera.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger that. We've got a team working on that, and incidentally, one of the information items that they want to know is which lithium hydroxide containers in the command module are empty. They just want to know that for weight and balance - and there's no rush about it - - o4 22 47 18 CDR

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Another note of interest to the crew systems people - Tell them that they don't have to bother putting the refrigerator onboard. I just brought out some hot dogs, and they're re practically frozen.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: (Laughter) Okay. We copy that, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We'd like another volt, amp reading, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Stand by, Joe.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Volt 39.4, amp 1.23.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Roger that. And, Jim, we ought to have a - an entry time line to discuss with you in one hour.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Guess what.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: What?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Your volts and amps time, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: That goes like the Amos and Andy show.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius. Guess what.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. What? Over.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Are you really going up there, and looking at them?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: That's what the meters say.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We copy, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. We show the SUIT CIRCUIT RELIEF valve is back in the AUTO position, and we'd like to have it off for good scrubbing. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Have you seen ... out there?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Thank you, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: ... up there - about ... of the scrubbers. If you think ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. No sweat. Jim, in a few minutes I'm going to be coming at you with the - with the overall time line for tomorrow morning. You might want to think about taking a few notes, although we don't have detailed procedures for you at this time. Maybe you want to have Fred or Jack listen. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Right. We're all set to copy.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: For our benefit while we do this briefing, Jim, we'd like to have the, the C0MM better, and we can sure spare the power; so we'd like you on panel 16 to close the POWER AMPLIFIER circuit breaker, and on panel 12 we'd like you to move the VOICE FUNCTION switch to VOICE. Over.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Aquarius; Houston. How do you read?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Read you loud and clear.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, and you're real good. It's a - It's a pleasure not to have all that noise. Let me tell you what I want to do, Jim. As I said, we're not going to give you detailed procedures, now. What we expect to have for you shortly are procedures which we'll try and get up to you in the following form. First, we'll have a time line, sort of a flight plan thing, which will have the times of all the major events and any configurations, switch settings, and so forth which are peculiar to our configuration and which, therefore, you won't find in the checklist. This, for instance, will be true of the way we power up the command module; and second, of course, we'll have any redlines to the checklist so that you can enter the checklist where possible to - to perform functions, and the time line will simply refer you to the checklist when that's appropriate. Okay?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Sounds good. You're going to give me an overall time line now, I take it; is that right?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirm. I'm going to first of all just quickly run through the times of the major events, and then we'll go back and fill in some of the details. Okay. Entry interface is at 142 hours 40 minutes; 6-1/2 hours, roughly prior to that or at about 136:10, we'll start this whole thing going by applying IMU HEATER POWER, by checking the CM/RCS temperatures and preheating the CM/RCS if required, and we suspect we'll probably want to do that. We'll have detailed procedures up for it later. At about 6 hours prior to EI or about 136:40, we will commence powering up the LM, powering up the AGS, using the modified LM/DPS RCS 30-minute checklist, which you have used for the previous midcourse. Then shortly, just before 5 hours, prior to EI or at about 137:49, we'll want you in the attitude for a LM AGS body axis alinement, using the Earth terminator like we did before; and as soon as we have that, we'll perform MCC-7, which looks like, now, about a 2-foot-per-second burn or about 15 seconds of RCS. And I'm told that it's down to 1-1/2 now, so it's comfortably within the RCS margin. Okay. When we do that, we'll immediately start the maneuver to the service module jettison attitude, which will be in plane since we're jettisoning it earlier than we usually do. We don't need, and don't want, the out-of-plane component. So it'll be in plane with the service module pointed back out along the radius vector. We will then commence to get the command module ready for service module SEP, including command module RCS checkout and hot fire, and at approximately 4 hours and 30 minutes prior to EI or 138:10, we'll Jettison the service module. We'll pitch the LM up until we aquire the service module in the ... and try and get some photographs, but we're not going to fool around with LM translation maneuvers for pictures because we don't want to screw up - foul up your flight path angle at that time. Okay. That gives us 2 hours to - of more or less open time here to finish up, if we're late on that, to go on over to checklist and prepare for powering up the command module. We're going to start the command module full powerup at EI minus 2 hours and 30 minutes or 140:10 GET. We'll get the computer on the line, we'll get the IMU up, we'll start uplinking your state vectors, and so forth, and alining the command module platform. At about 1 hour and 30 minutes at the latest, giving us an hour to do this command module stuff, we will start the maneuver to the LM jettison attitude. You'll then start to close out the LM. Of course, we don't have our stowage all configured way before this. We'll close the hatch, do a pressure integrity check, and at EI minus 1 hour, or 141 hours and 40 minutes, we'll jettison the LM. As soon as we do that, you can start the maneuver to the entry attitude. When you're there, do a sextant star check, take down the optics, and at that point we'll be giving you your final entry pad. You can initialize the EMS, and you'll essentially be right back on the checklist at that point. There's one - one little difference from your nominal entry. You're a little bit earlier in the morning, so it going - it's going to be nighttime when you get to EI. However, we're fortunate enough to have the Moon in a perfect position for a horizon check. We'll give you a Moon check instead of a horizon check, and you can track it right down to moonset, which is going to be at EI roughly minus 3 minutes. And that's it for the quick time line. Do you have any questions right now?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I don't believe so, Joe, right now. We'll have to look at those time lines, and think about it for a little bit.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Real fine. We're ready to talk in some more detail about the alinement procedures, the CM powerup procedures, and so forth, but why don't we give you a few minutes to digest what you've already heard.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Two questions so far on heating up the CM/RCS. We assume that's LM power, and we assume that we're going to have to power up both CM buses, right?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. I didn't want to talk about that because we're not quite ready to recommend a procedure. We can't power up the CM/RCS per the normal checklist on the LM power because we haven't got quite enough amps. It may be that we'll want you to heat - to do the preheat one ring at a time and we're looking at that. Another possibility is that we may want to take down LM power at that time, do the preheat, and then go back to LM power until we have to take it down finally. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Understand. Second question: when we finish MCC-7, that maneuver to SM JETT attitude will be angles given to us, by you, using the AGS aline ball, right?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative. Once we get that AGS alined and get a time hack on it, the good people down here will be able to give us AGS - AGS, 8-ball attitudes for the service module separation attitude, for the command module alinement attitude, which we are going to pass you up the - a Moon/Sun P52-type alinement. We'll have AGS 8-ball attitudes for those, and we'll be able to uplink through the command meidule once we get the computer up a preferred REFSMMAT, which will be identical to the LM attitude at the time of the burn. And we'll go into details on that later.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Just stand by 1. I'll give it to you.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Will do.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: We would like to have plenty of ... the control characteristics are of the LM/command module, and whether we can use the attitude control - controller only to maneuver the combination to photograph the service module at 4 plus 30.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Good thinking. We are - it's - There has been a lot of consideration of what kind of maneuvers to let you do to photograph the LM, I mean the service module. We consider it quite low priority; the feeling is that it will be real nice to get pictures of the service module, but they are not required for our troubleshooting program. As far as the - the attitude control authority, and so forth, we will get you more detailed word on that later; we are working it. It appears that using the ACA instead of the TTCA after service module JETT will give you excellent attitude control authority, and that's what we recommend.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. And I'm ... - use an AGS ATT HOLD configuraption to keep the attitudes - turn the LM JETT attitudes.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirm. We are - We are probably going to recommend a tight deadband AGS attitude hold for that.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. The star check at the entry attitude, is it a sextant star check or a C0AS star check?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: It'll probably be a sextant star check, Jim. It really depends on how good that platform is that we get. And we expect it to be plenty good enough for a sextant star check.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: While we are on that subject, Jim, I want to mention one thing to Jack. As I said, this CSM alinernent procedure we are going to recommend is a Moon/Sun, and there are Sun filters stowed; they are stowed in compartment R-l; however, they are for the telescope only, of course, not the sextant. One is for the long eye-relief piece, the other for the normal eyepiece. And if he has any questions about that, we'll be glad to talk about it.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And because it will be too late to do much about a hatch integrity check if it fails, you want us to have our suits on sometime during this period?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. We are laying for you on that one; it is a subject that we wanted to - to bring up with you. We have been considering it, and our feelings are - Of course, it is up to you, but as we see the pros and cons, you just put your finger on the pro. We do a hatch integrity check shortly before EI minus I hours, and if we bust it, you would have a hard time scrambling into the suits. On the other hand, the disadvantages of wearing the suits are that they might slow you down considerably, not even counting the time to don them, and someone is even very concerned that after such and such a period of time in the suits, you might get too warm, and we might have to power up the SUIT LOOP to ventilate the suits and we don't particularly want to do that because it cost quite a bit of power. Consequently, our recommendation was going to be that you not wear the suit, since we have no reason to believe that the integrity check will show us anything but a slightly increased leak rate, and we can certainly hack that. What do you think? Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Well, I have confidence in the hatch, as long as it goes in and locks in smoothly; I see no reason why we need the suits, and one thing we are going to do during our spare time is to practice putting that hatch on, make sure we get it on and locked.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Real good. And with that precaution, think we can concur on that decision.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And that's all the questions we had about the time line you gave us.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Let me take a check here and see if there is anything anybody else wants to input to you, right now.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Hourston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. One detail that I thought you ought to know about the service module JETT is that we're going to recommend a push-pull maneuver, that is in the attitude I described. We'll want you to go half a foot per second plus-X on the LM, then jettison the service module, then go half a foot per second minus-X, which will be less time be- cause you're suddenly a heck of a lot lighter. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Understand. You want me to go a half a foot per second plus-X, JETT the service module, and go a half a foot per second minus-X.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirm. We think that will give you plenty of separation, and also will be a slow enough rate so you'll have a chance to get some photos.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. 0ne more thing we want to update you on with a little detail. As we told you, the ascent SEP attitude was in plane and the LM JETT attitude will be more similar to a normal service module SEP attitude, that is it will be LM up, out the radius vector and 45 degrees right, out of plane toward the south. We are going to recom- mend that prior to JETT, the configuration be with the LM overhead hatch closed, with the vent valve open, and we'll JETT with the tunnel pressurized. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Joe. Understand that the LM JETT attitude will be similar to service module normal jettison, which will be up and out of plane, and as soon as I finish maneuvering to left JETT attitude, I'll scramble up and close the LM hatch, making sure the vent valve is open, and then we'll vent it - or jettison it with the tunnel pressurized.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative. And Deke says don't forget to close the command module hatch on your way in.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I'm already scared that Jack will have it closed before I get up there.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: (Laughter)

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. I think that's about all we have for you right now. Whenever you feel like you don't have any more questions at the moment, we'd like you to reconfigure for down voice backup and we'd like you to do that to move the VOICE FUNCTION switch to DOWNV0ICE BACKUP as usual, but instead of pulling the circuit breaker, we'd like you to throw the POWER AMP switch to off.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Joe. I have one more question, here. If we get a little bit ahead of time on the command module full powerup after we jettison the ser- vice module, I'd like to go to LM JETT attitude early, and make sure we get that part squared away and sit there for a while before LM JETT of 1 hour. Now, will we be using LM power up to that time? There's two cables which we'll probably have to disconnect oh the way up through the tunnel if we're still going to use LM power?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative. Let me get word on when we expect to go off LM power.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. We expect to go off LM power at the time we start powering up the CSM or about minus 2-1/2 hours. That is not a hard number, and we'll be updating you on it. As far as going to the LM JETT attitude, that's completely permissible as soon as you have a powered up command module and a satisfactory platform, you can go there immediately. We're giving you a maximum of 1 hour just for grins. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Fine. And that will be a LM maneuver, I assume, because we lost the service module, so no strain there.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Affirm.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And, Jack , would like to know what entry angle the midcourse-7 will give us?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Oh, it'll put us right in the middle of the corridor, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 6.50 degrees. And, Jim, Houston. I guess, as a last i tern, we expect that it will take us about an hour to update your checklist and your time lines sometime later on today, and we'd just like you to consider that. I expect it'll be 3 or 4 hours before we have all that stuff ready.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. We'll be standing by for that, and now POWER AMPLIFIER switch is going to go off, and then we'll be going to DOWN VOICE BACKUP.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston. Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, Jim. We're receiving you now. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. I thought you were calling, but I guess we had a ground switching problem down there.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes. We lost the lock for a little while there, Jim. Well , good day. Could you give us battery A voltage ... reading, please, and battery charger current, as you have been doing.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Vance. Standby.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Volts are 39.5; amps, 1.25.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Copy 39.5; and 1.25. Thank you.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Aquarius here. Go ahead, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Say, Jim, could you give us another reading on the Battery A voltage and BAT charger current on the CSM, please.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: BAT amps coming up.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. And sometime when you have some time to copy I have an entry stowage list to give you which specifies which equipment will be moved between vehicles before splashdown.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. I'm - I'll bhe able to copy that in a minute.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Volts, 39.4; amps, 1.25.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 39.4, and say again amps.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Copy. Thank you.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Vance. We're ready to cover - to copy the stowage list.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. Now, I'll give it to you in two parts. The first is LM to command module equipment transfer. The second part will be the reverse, command module to LM equipment transfer. And both parts represent Deltas from the launch stowage, and here comes the first list, LM to command module equipment transfer. First, DSEA, and I'll give you the stowage location, too. That goes in R-13.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Vance, what was that again?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: DSEA; that's recorder in - will go in the command module; it's recommended you stow it in R-13. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, the DSEA - that 's the recorder - will be stowed in R-13.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirm. Next. LM flight data file. That will go in R-l, R-2, and R-3. Next. Three PPKs in A-8.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. 16-millimeter and 70-millimeter exposed film in R-13. Okay, next. O2 hose screen caps on the 02 hoses. Next: two 70-millimeter Hasselblad cameras, and stow these in B-6 in the empty LiOH volume.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, next. Black-and-white TV camera, and recommend stow that on top of A-7 and A-11 in decontamination bag. Next: flag kit, stowage location A-8. Next: LM fecal bags, used, R-9, waste management system chute.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, that's the first list, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, if you want to read that one back, why then I'll - I'll give you the second one.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: This is the LM to command module transfer, and this is the Delta from the launch stowage. Number 1: DSEA ...; number 2: LM flight data file in R-l, R-2, R-3; three PPKs in A-8 ... -

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: ... A-8; and used LM fecal bags in R-9.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, that's affirm, Jim. We had a lot of noise, and we didn't get the middle part, but I think that's fairly - should be fairly clear to you, and don't bother with the readback of that that we missed, unless you have any doubts. And then I'll, if you're ready to copy, I'll give you the second list.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. This is CM to LM equipment transfer. Cabin fan filter and bag, and that, in the LM, should go in the ISA. Okay, next: decontamination bags, except for the ones used to wrap camera, should go in the ISA.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Two LGGs, if you don't have them on already, to the IS - ISA. I realize you wouldn't have them on, because you're cold enough already.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: That's right.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, and finally, four LiOH cans, the ones used in the LM, and those can go in the jettison bag in the LM. Okay, a couple of notes. After loading the ISA, recommend secure it to the right-hand restraint system.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And secure the jettison bag to the PLSS on the floor. And that's all.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Vance. This is command module to LM: cabin fan filter and bag in the ISA; decontamination bags, except for the ones we use for the TV camera, in the ISA; two LCGs in the ISA; four LOiH [sic] cans in the JETT bag; and we'll secure the ISA on the right-hand side - on the right-hand restraint system, and we'll secure the JETT bags to the PLSS on the floor.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. That's it.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Over.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jim, would you give us PCM to HI bit rate. We think maybe we might be able to lock up on your high bit rate now. Over.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. We're getting it intermittently. We think we might get it steady and improve circuit margins if you would, in addition, on panel 16, open the PRIMARY POWER AMPL circuit breaker, and I'll give you next step in a minute.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. PRIMARY POWER AMPL is opened.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. And on panel 12, POWER AMPL to PRIMARY.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: POWER AMPL to PRIMARY.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, 13.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Or rather, Houston. Jim, it looks like we got a lockon, which is going to improve our data flow here. Only thing is, we'll probably lose data and probably voice, too, during a portion of each roll. So you might expect that. The other thing is, if anyone has on any BI0MED, would you switch your switch to - your BI0MED switch to that position.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Understand the first, Vance, and no one has on any BI0MED

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: - - Fred and Jack are maneuvering things around right now, and mine is long since departed the scene.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Copy.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Vance, you might be interested - the way we're - the way we got this thing arranged, we have one helmet attached to the C0MM lines attached to the LM hoses, and the guy that's got the duty wears the helmet, so the other people are free to maneuver.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Right. That's understandable. One guy's on the leash, huh?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Yes. ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jim, when you get finished moving your stowage around and it's convenient, we'd like to terminate the battery charge for a little while to bring up the CM TM so we can take a look at the temperatures again, like we did yesterday. Advise that right now on your batteries, you have 111 amp-hours; and, eventually, we hope to have them up - peaked up to about 116. One other point, we - we can either read that procedure up again which involves cranking up the telemetry, or, if Jack still has it, we can use his notes and - but I have one or two changes to - to make on them. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, understand that you'll want us to terminate battery charge for a while, and crank up the CM TM to read out temperatures. And you have a few changes to Jack's checklist, and I'll turn the COMM over here to Jack shortly, as soon as he's finished, and we'll get along with it.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, we'll be standing by for - there's no hurry on it.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Just out of curiosity, Vance, what's our distance and velocity now?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Hey, stand by 1. You're speeding up, I think.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jim, we have you 101000 miles out, and your velocity is 5848. Starting to speed up.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Thank you.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: sure enough.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Houston; Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead, Jack.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Vance. Jim said that you want to terminate battery charge on battery A.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirm, Jack. Request to - Before you terminate it, get the usual readout on voltage and current; and we'd also like a time of termination, and understand you have the termination procedures. Is that affirm?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. That's affirm. Stand by. Let me just make sure I've got everything here before I go off on a tangent.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jack, and your battery-charge termination procedure remains unchanged, but when we go to power up the CM and look at your TM, we have a couple of additional steps.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Vance, I do have the procedure for stopping the battery charge. And do you want me to copy this procedure now, or do you want me to come back and give you the volt, amps, and time and - after I complete this termination?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, just - just give us the volts and amps just before you start the termination of the procedure, and understand you say you have the charge - the procedure for taking the charge off. Is that affirm?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: That's affirm.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. And just give us a hack on the time - -

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: And you want to - you want to review it at all?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Negative. Unless you want me to. I'll tell you what; I could run through it very quickly just to verify that we're getting started off on the correct path here.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Yes. Okay, the first four or five things that I have is panel BAT CHARGE to OFF on panel 3; AC INVERTER 2, OFF; panel 5: MAIN BUS TIE, BAT A/C ON; panel 250: CB BAT A POWER ENTRY/POSTLANDING, open; panel 275: INVERTER POWER 2, MAIN B, open; and then, the - just to go ahead and reverse the position of the switches and circuit breakers that I started out with, and these don't have to be in reverse order. Is that Charlie?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, that's - that's Charlie. Have at it.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, we'll get a volts and amps right now.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Vance. The volts and amps: 39.4; amps, 1.25.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. We copy that. Incidentally - -

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. We're going up to termin - Go ahead, Vance.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Never mind, Jack. I'll bring this up later when you've finished the procedure.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. I'm going off the air; I'll put Fred-o on. I'm going to stop the battery charge.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Now, how do you read, Vance?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Hey, loud and clear, Fred. Understand you've been doing some spring housecleaning, moving stowage around up there.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Boy, you wouldn't believe this LM right now; it's nothing but bags from floor to ceiling.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Hey, that brings up a question. We were wondering where you guys plan to stow the probe and drogue? It occurred to us that one possibility was to stow it in the LM, down about where the LMP normally stands, underneath the IS - ISAer. Perhaps you have a better idea. Over.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes, I do, Vance. ... would go in the LM, but I thought maybe we ought to stow it where the CDR stands. How's that?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. I can tell that you're just getting - getting that one over because Jim just got off the loop.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes, he's sleeping. No, that's - that's actually where we normally had been stowing it for normal LM JETTs.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, and - Hey, we just - we'll record that, and figure that you'll stow the probe and drogue over in the - where the CDR stands. We have a - a change to this - equipment transfer list that I just read up to Jim. Why don't you make a note of this one item? Forget about the LM - -

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Stand by; stand by l.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: I think Jack hauled off the piece of paper with that - all that on it. Why don't you hold it until Jack gets done doing the battery charge?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, Fred, request PCM on L0 bit rate, now.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. And there was one piece of flight data that we needed that we didn't bring along this time.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: What was that?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: That's a big book with a lot of just plain old blank pages in it.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes, when you - when you get off nominal, why you just need scratch paper, don't you?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Vance. I got the stowage list now.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, I gave you two lists - -

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: And Jack's got - and Jack said he's completed - the - secured the battery charge now.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, and we're recording the time that that was complete. You have two lists there, one is LM to CM equipment transfer and the second list is the reverse. Request you scratch the last item on the first list, which is returning used bags to the CM.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. We didn't have any of those, so that didn't pose any problem anyway.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Vance. Aquarius is back on.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. Understand you completed securing the battery charge. Now if you are ready to copy, Jack, I would like to give you the two changes that we have to the powerup for the CM procedure. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Stand by 1.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Vance. You say you have some changes in the procedures that I used before to get telemetry and to check out the CSM system?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes, that's correct. Jack; they're pretty simple. About halfway through the procedure, we have a step on panel 3, which is POWER AMPL, HIGH; we'd like to change that to POWER AMPL, LOW.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Copy. POWER AMPL, LOW.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And the next change, Jack, is panel 275. Scratch the step "CB MAIN B, BAT B, close - BAT BUS B, close."

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. You want to delete the step "CB MAIN B BAT BUS B, close."

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. As you know, we're going to do this on LM power, so this reflects that.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Real fine.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, and have at it. We - we'd like to have the TM up for about 5 or 10 minutes to look at the data from the CM; look at your temperatures, et cetera. And after that, we'll go back to charging the battery again, and the charge will probably go until around GET 126.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Do you want the same readouts from me that I gave you before?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative, Jack. And just to make sure that there is no mistaking the procedure, it starts out for the backout part: panel 3, POWER AMPL, OFF; TRANSPONDER, OFF; AC INVERTER 2, OFF; then goes to panel 250, et cetera.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: That's - that's the way I read it.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay; going back up into the refrigerator.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Hey, I thought it was the bedroom.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Well, it's got a new name now, because it is about 30 degrees cooler.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Returning to the deep freeze - -

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: - - Hey, Vance. One thing that I wanted to ask you - is on the stowage list where you have us putting the black-and-white TV camera on top of A-7 in an A ... decontamination bag, I was wondering if it would be possible or if you - there would be any problem in putting it into B-6 along with the two 70-millimeter Hasselblad cameras?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jack, I don't think there'll be any problem, if you can get it in, but let us get - work that and get back with you. Okay?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: All right. I was just thinking. I'm trying to get as much weight as possible down there in that LEB. We have no SRCs and then our waste tank is - you know - rather depleted. I think it's about down to 40 percent or so. So I'm trying to get as much L over D as I can, and any heavy items we can get down there, I'd be greatly appreciative of you bringing it to our attention.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We copy that, and ve owe you an answer on your last question.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. And I'm in work, going to give you some telemetry.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. We're receiving CSM data now.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Say again, Vance.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Fred, we just lost data on Aquar - on Jack. Would you have him select best OMNI, please?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: All right. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Fred, we have enough data; recommend that Jack take off the TM and power back down again, using his backout procedure. Just let us know when he does it.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, after that, we'll start the battery charge, and we'll have to know when he starts that.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. He's starting to back out now. Just out of curiosity, what - did you all get a readout on what the cabin temp was up there?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes, we're getting 45 to 46 degrees.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Now you see why we call it the refrigerator.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes, it's kind of a cold winter day up there, isn't it? Is it snowing in the command module yet?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Is it what, Vance?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Is it snowing in there yet?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Oh, snowing. No-no, not quite. The windows are in pretty bad shape, and I guess the service module - we'll be trying to shoot out of the LM window, because every window in the command module is just covered with water droplets. It's going to take a lot of scrubbing to get those cleared off.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Understand. Pete says to tell you that you'll have some time on the beach in Samoa to thaw out after this cold experience.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Hey, that sounds great.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Vance, have you all thought about what cameras you wanted to use? Right now, we've got configured a Hasselblad with a 250, and I've got the lunar-surface number 1 Hasselblad, and I've got the lunar surface sequence camera, also, rigged and ready to go. Did you have any other druthers about the ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: You are referring to the photography of the ser- vice module, is that right?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: That's right.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We have some procedures in work, and I've seen them, Fred. I think pretty soon we'll be shooting them up to you to specify which cameras and settings. But that - that sounds pretty close.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, you might let them know that, if they hadn't thought of it, that we got this lunar-surface sequence camera on board which has its own battery pack setup, and to shoot quite a few pictures with, and that could also be used for this.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. I know we are planning to use that camera, among others.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Houston; Aquarius. Jack has backed out of powering up the CM, and now he's proceeding to restart battery charge on BAT A.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Real good, Fred. We copy.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. And we are charging battery A now.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Charging battery A, Fred.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, Fred, request now first reading of voltage - BAT A voltage and charger current. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Vance. I can give it to you. I read it right after I started it. BAT A voltage was 39.4 and the current had jumped up to 1.4.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. 39.4 and 1.4. Thanks, Jack.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. How about - You ready for some other readouts, that you wanted there?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Ready to copy.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. BAT B, 37.0; pyro A, 37.0; pyro B, 37.0; SPS helium pressure, 3400; and nitrogen A and B - just for throwing it in for kicks, 2200 and 2400, respectively; and the injector temperature - stand by - The Sun went down. Okay. The injector temperature, 5 Charlie, 3.9; 5 Dog, 3.2; 6 Alfa, 3.6; 6 Baker, 3.9; 6 Charlie, 3.5; 6 Dog, 3.4; the battery manifold pressure, 1.4.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We copy all that, Jack. Thank you.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: You say, you figure you are going to be charging BAT A until about 126?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. About 126:30 is an estimate, Jack.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. You figure it will be fully charged then, huh?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes. That's right. We'll have all the batteries up to about 116 amps-hours.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: That's good news.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's better than 99, huh?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: You're right.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: How did all our systems look on Vance?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: I didn't hear any complaints, but just a minute; let me make a detailed check.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jack, it's a general statement. It looks like temperatures have cooled off in the ballpark of 6 to 8 degrees cooler than what they were yesterday. Looks like everything is still within tolerance, but we're working up a detailed sheet of temperatures to send up to you, for your interest.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. That sounds good.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Vance, Joe brought up the alinement at EI minus 2 plus 30. Were you going to send up or have a discussion about that later on.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's correct. Jack. We just about have procedures in hand detail checklist-type procedures to send to you. In other words, a time line with reference to entry checklist and any changes in the entry checklist. So, if you have a few pages of scratch paper, why, I think we'll have that to you within an hour.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. I'll be standing by. 05 03 30 38 CO One other thing. Jack - You still with me?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Yes, go ahead. The stowage people have tried out this black-and-white TV camera into B-6 idea and they say even with the lens off, they can't get it in. So, I still recommend that it be stowed where we had it on the list. That's A-7.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: No problem.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: All right, go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jack, request another voltage/readout on BAT A and current on BAT charger.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Vance. The volt 39.3, amp 1.3.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Copy 39.3 and 1.3.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Go ahead, Vance.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jack, looks like the LM suit release valve has been bumped to AUTO again; request it - -

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: - - closed. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: In work.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: How's that right there?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. They say it looks good.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. We need another one of those voltage amps readouts and then maybe we will get off of your back for a little while.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Oh, don't worry about it. I'd like to have you talk with us. Volts and amps coming up.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Vance. Volts 39.4, amps 1.25.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. EECOM's got it duly recorded.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Is John Aaron on?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: No. Gee, I don't know what shift he is on. But he comes in later, I guess.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Actually, all the shifts are morning. Shifts to us.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Say that one again - -

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: The Sun is always shining - All of the shifts are morning shifts to us, because the Sun is always shining.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That was a short night.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Just for curiosity's sake, are we still holding entry angle at 6.25?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Jack, right now we're told that it's closer to 6, and - But they would like to track it some more. Looks like your next midcoursc will be in the order of 2 to 3 foot per second.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: I just got a good view of the Southern Gross, Alpha and Beta Centauri , and Atria.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Houston, 13.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead. Jack.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. We're still in good chape as far as water goes in the LM?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We copy.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: The reason I ask is I'm assuming that we are, and I have no idea each time I pressurize the surge tank to get water out of the command module, how much I drop that surge tank and if we are in good shape as far as water goes in the LM, we'd like to fill a couple of drink bags to get some water for drinking purporses.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Have you run out of CM drinking water yet, Jack?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Oh, no, we've got plenty of drinking water. I think the - I don't have any idea, what the surge tank pressure is.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. It's 750 - -

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: - - and I don't have any - -

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: It's 750, Jack.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. 750.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Go ahead, Vance.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Stand by 1, Jack, and we'll give you an indication of how that water situation on the LM is - which is your question. Right?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. But I guess what I was really asking is, if you'd have any violent objections if we filled two drink bags from LM water rather than repressurizing the surge tank.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Stand by on that.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Also, Jim is asleep up there and we didn't want to bother him, either.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We understand.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, Jack, we'll be changing stations in 1 minute; so, we may have a temporary dropout in COMM.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Vance. Go ahead. Loud and clear.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. We're going to bargain with you on this one. Instead of two, would - wish that you would just get just one bag full. That shouldn't do any harm; however - -

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: - - we are not all that fat on water that we want to do any drinking out of the LM as a regular thing after this one bag. So would you let us know when you get the water out and give us a mark on it so we can watch the TM. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
