transcript.text: Okay. Fred-o is about to withdraw the water now.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Vance. We've withdrawn - oh, about 8 ounce of water.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. How's it taste?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: It's - good. It's not quite as gaseous as that in the command module.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Apollo 13, Houston - or rather, Aquarius, Houston. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Hey, Jack, we need another reading. Volts and amps.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. They're coming up.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Vance, you won't believe this, but Fred-o says it's 39.4 and 1.245.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Our EEC0M is recording those numbers. Charlie Dumas, this time.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Oh.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Not changing very fast, is it?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: How far out are we?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. 953 and 6068 on velocity, per FIDO.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Bill Stoval.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Thank you.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius. Over

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Are the flowers in bloom in Houston?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: No, not yet. Still must be winter.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Suspicions confirmed.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes, I doubt if they will be blooming even Saturday, when you return.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I concur. 05 04 39 07 Hey, Jim, we have some photo information to pass up to you. Discussed this briefly with Fred earlier. It's instructions or suggestions for which photos - which cameras and lenses to use during your service module photography. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Stand by 1.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We have three cameras here, two oft them to be used for picture taking from the LM, one to be used form number 5 window of th CSM. First, Ill hot the LM cameras. And this camera that I mention now has first priority. It's considered the one to give you the best results. That's the 70-millimeter DC Reseau camery, Hasselblad, that is, with the 80-millimeter lens, from box A-13. Suggest fresh magazine of 3400 black-and-white film.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Suggest either magazine R of magazine S from A-13. Transfer all of this to the LM and recommend the following settings: LM/DC/80/BW 3400 (f:5.6 at a 250th).

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And that's all for that one.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Vance. Let me see if I have it here. For the LM, want to use the 70-millimeter DC Hasselblad 8O-millimeter lens in A-13, using 3400 black-and-white film MAGs R or S. Prepare to take camera to the LM, and the setting would be the LM/DC/80/BW 3400 (f:5.6) at a 250th 05 04 42 28 CC That's correct. Okay. Next: the next camera - Stand by 2. I've got noise here. Okay. The next LM - The next camera for the LM will be the 16-millimeter, and these photos are considered to be priority 3. Okay. One, get the 16-millimeter DAC and powerpack from A-8 Get the 10-millimeter lens, and remove it - remove the 10-millimeter lens, and take the l8-millimeter lens from B-3 and attach it to the camera. And attach the power cable transfer to the LM, set frame rate at 12 frames per second, and the same data line that I gave you before reads this way this time. LM/DAC/l8/CEX, battery (f:8 and l/250th). Okay. Now looking at these two cameras in the LM, it's recommended that you use the 16-millimeter for the first 2-1/2 minutes and then switch to the 70-millimeter. That's partly because the frame's been - or the - They've been optimized for closer and longer range. Okay. Read back, please.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Vance. Essentially, what you wanted to use as far as the movie camera in the LM goes, is our lunar sequence camera which is attached to the powerpack. We use the l8-millimeter lens, set it at 12 frames per second ... f:8 at 250th of a second.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. f:8 at 250th.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Right; f:8 at 250th.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Would you believe that we have a correc- tion now to the last camera I gave you? Correct that 18-millimeter lens to 75-millimeter lens.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. The 18-millimeter to the 75-millimeter lens. Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Right. Okay. Next for the command module pictures , it may be a little hard to see the service module from the command module, but if you can see it, it will be through window 5, people down here think. Recommend for that the CM 70- millimeter. These photos have priority 2. So this is 70-millimeter EL, with - which has the 80-millimeter attached, and this is all in B-3. Take off the 80-millimeter lens and attach the 250-millimeter lens. And the 250-millimeter lens can be found in U-4. Use CEX film from A-13. Ring sight from A-7, and these pictures will be f:8 at a 250th. And I think probably by now you probably all have - already have these cameras configured, and this may be redun- dant information, but here it is anyway. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Vance. You're right. We do have cameras almost configured like you said. For the command module, you think that the EL with the 250 lens, CEX film, f:8 at a 250th is the best bet, and you're saying now that where you think you'll see it is out window 5? Is that it?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's right, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. My procedure, now, after service module JETT is going to be to pitch up, in order to try to get the service module into the - to get the center window in view of the service module, which we are going to have somebody there - to photograph. Why do you think window 5 will be it?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Stand by on that one. This is a question of geometry, and I'll get right back.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jim, regarding window 5, I have a drawing here; and, when you're docked, you have approximately a 60-degree angle between the Z-axes of the two spacecraft. It appears that peering out window 5, you would be looking at the rendezvous radar on top of the LM which would, if you pitched, more or less give you a view of the service module. That is, if you pitched, so - from - and I think that this has been run by quite a few folks here; so, offhand. I can't see where any other window would be as good or perhaps even possible.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. I understand. Yes, you're right- When we look out window 5, we can see rendezvous radar, and we'll try - We'll try window 5.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. It presumes, though, that there has to be a pitch to be able to see it. You guys sound a lot more rested today.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Well, I just went back and sacked out for an hour or so and didn't get back up.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Very good.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, Jim, Houston. We really are going to get those checklists up to you.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Over.

transcript.text: Okay. Understand.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Basically. that is correct. Let me just run through it hand-waving-type for a minute, and then I'll read you the steps. I think it will make more sense. The scheme is that the LM can fly to a set of ball angles that will point your optics at the Moon. Now, at any time, in any attitude that we happen to be at, if you can look in the telescope and recognize star patterns sufficient that you believe you can make an alinement all on your own, that's the place we'd like to break off and let you go ahead and take over with your own alinement. However, we are giving you a procedure which will give you things we know you can see in the telescope without worrying about any reflections or anything of that nature, and it's not intended that this procedure has to be followed past the point where you know you've got good definition of star patterns in your telescope. If you need to go on, we'll maneuver, take a look at the Moon, we'll take a mark there, and then we'll maneuver with the LM/FDAI angles again and take a look at the Sun, and get yourself another mark on the Sun and that will complete the alinement. Now, the alinement scheme is that we are going to give you a set of angles that you can coarse aline the ball through when the LM is pointing you at the Moon. Now, this set of angles will agree with the REFSMMAT that you have in as a nominal REFSMMAT in you CMC. You can coarse aline to that, set a drift flag and REFSMMAT flag, and you'll have a good platform and we'll be within a couple of degrees of a good alinement. And, if we have to, we could break off at this point and go ahead with an entry; however, in an attempt- to get a good platform, we are going to have you then do a P52 option 1, and what you are going :c find in the option 1 slots in the entry REFSMMAT. You'll come up with the NOUN 22 values, and we intend to go ahead and coarse aline the ball to the entry REFSMMAT attitude, and then we'll go ahead and take marks through a normal P52 sequence. So that's the general scheme that we are going to use. If you think you have a handle on that, I will go ahead and read you the steps.

This is an inertial attitude; it won't be changing, and you'll put the 36-degree window line on the Moon, and then just sit there and watch it. And just prior to EI, the Earth will come up and occult it, and you will then have a good horizon check. And I have some times, and I'll give you that later. And if you just look at this thing now, at that point you can set the GDC or whatever you desire. And you will have a known attitude reference. It's just like a horizon check.

transcript.text: Okay. After BAT 2, LOW VOLTAGE, OFF/RESET, I'll - then ON, I'll wait for a MSFN GO before proceeding.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Right-o. Okay. Next, at - Under the section of "EI minus 1 hour and 45 minutes" - No, change that. Correction, "EI minus 1 hour, 35 minutes," refer to the ECS section, and we have a change.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: All. right. Go ahead, Vance.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim's right. We should cross out all this stuff with a couple of exceptions . FORWARD DUMP valve, closed, the first step, should remain. All other steps should be scratched, except for the last one, which is OVERHEAD DUMP valve, closed. That leaves two steps.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Under ECS, we delete all except the first step, FORWARD DUMP valve, close, and step 10, which is OVERHEAD DUMP valve, closed, and leave in verify transfer list .

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirm. Leave in what follows, which is verify transfer list and IVT and all that.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: IVT, of course, meaning CDR transferring to the CM.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: We wouldn't forget it.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Fred-o. That's - That's the changes. Not quite as extensive as the CSM had, but still pretty long. Any comments or questions to the house here?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: No, it looks pretty good to me, Vance.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Very good. Only other comment, aside from the checklist, we've been watching your descent stage water, and it looks - or your ascent stage water, and it looks real good.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Fred. We're going to try to refrain from calling you from now on, so that you can maybe get a couple of winks. We're getting a status around the room first, to see if anybody has any comments for you and, after that, we'll try to leave you alone for awhile.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Thank you.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Hey, Fred-o. Are you there?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: All right, go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We polled the room. We don't have much for you. Only comments as follows: your consumables are looking good; your entry gamma right now is minus 6.01. We're expecting a midcourse of 2.81 foot per second which should be about 21 seconds of RCS.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. It sounds good.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Fred. See you in the morning.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Request you open the POWER AMPLIFIER circuit breaker and DOWN VOICE BACKUP, please.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Complete.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Fred, are you sleeping?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Fred, in a couple of minutes we're going to hand over the Honeysuckle, so there'll be - Our uplink will be terminated. We'll contact you when we get it back.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: After that, I've got a couple minutes of work for you.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: All right. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Let's wait until after the handover.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Are you there. Jack?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes, I'm hearing you loud and clear. How me, Fred? 05 12 30 28 LMP

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We want to get some ranging data on you for about 15 minutes. So close the POWER AMPLIFIER circuit breaker and go to NORMAL VOICE, please.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. You ought to have it now. Jack.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. You're coming through good now, Fred. I've got three DELTAs to the checklist. They're minor changes. I'd like to pass them along now. One of them is to the CSM checklist. So if you'll pick that up, I'll give it to you.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Which one?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Stand by 1.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Is it the one Jack wrote them all in? The big long readout? He also wrote something in the G&N book.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: It's in the big, long one he wrote out at about EI minus 02:30. EMS entry check.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. He's coming back down with it.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Meanwhile, Fred, I've got two for you on the LM PREP checklist.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Jack's here now. I'll hand it to him.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Houston; Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Hello, Aquarius. I've got a couple of changes for you on your CSM checklist.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Stand by 1.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. The time line between EI minus 02:30 and 1 hour is real crowded, so you're really going to have to hustle, and we've decided to delete the EMS entry check at minus 02:30. That'll give you a little more time in there. What we've decided to do with it is wait until after EI minus 1, just before you initialize the EMS. If you have time, and only if you have time, do the EMS entry check. Otherwise, forget it and go right on into EMS initialization. You understand?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. You're going to delete between 2 hours and 30 minutes and 02:15 there, and you're going to add it, if there is time, only if there is time, at EI minus 1 hour where the EMS initialization occurs.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's right. You got it correctly. Okay, Jack. One other item. Just before EI minus 2 hours and 15 minutes, we need an E-memory dump VERB 74 ENTER. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Stand by 1, would you, please?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Right before 2 hours and 15 minutes, I assume that's before MS'?N gives their P27 update, I do a VERB 74. Right?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative. Jack.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: How much sleep did you get, Jack?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Oh, I guess - Stand by. I guess maybe 2 or 3 hours. It was awful cold, and it wasn't very good sleep.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. You plan to try to get any more?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: What GET do you have?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We got 132:37.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Well, if I - If I get everything done, I'll try, but I tell you, it's almost impossible to sleep. All of us have that same problem. It's just too cold to sleep.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. The way we're looking at it, looks like you ought to have a couple 3 hours here before you have to really get with it.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: We'll - we'll take it easy, but I - and we'll try to sleep, but it's just awful cold.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Present data indicates that your entry angle is minus 6.03 degrees. Your DELTA-V at the midcourse is going to 2.8 feet a second.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Copy.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Jack, this is Jim. I understand this is going to be an RCS burn.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative, Jim. It's going to be an RCS burn.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And we need the SUIT CIRCUIT RELIEF valve back to AUTO. Correction, back to CLOSE.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Hey, Jack, that's in work. And one thing, comparing Jim's checklist with my own, I find one difference there at EI minus 02:30. His checklist has me changing a - opening a EPS SENSOR SIGNAL circuit breaker right prior to turning off LM power. Is - I'd like to find out which checklist is correct.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Hey, Jack. The LM checklist is just for infor- mation to Jim. It's just to tell him that - that you're changing back to command module power. Your checklist is correct. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. And when do you figure that you'll be sending up the pads that you have?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, all of your pads will be coming up in about 3-1/2 hours, at EI minus 06:30. And one thing we want to remind you of, when you remove power from the command module LM umbilical, is to be sure that you open the LM POWER MAIN B circuit breakers, both of them, before you start throwing switches and circuit breakers in the LM. Do it as we've outlined it in the procedure, in that order. Over.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. That's the way we planned on it. We'll let Jack do his three and then he'll tell us when we're GO from there. What pages are those changes on?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Fred. The one I've got for you is at the end of power removal from the command module LM umbilical. And just for your information, after you go through that entire procedure and about the time you're ready to transfer to the command module, at that time, power will be removed from the umbilical, and it's okay to disconnect it. That is, after you've thrown the switches in the LM. Is that clear?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Roger. That's where I've got a remark here to check with you to see if it's all right to proceed.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. And that would be just after, on panel 16, you opening ASCENT ECA CONTROL breakers.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Which step number is that?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: The confusing thing is, Jack, where they told me to wait for MSFN GO before proceeding was that BAT 2 LOW VOLTS OFF/RESET, then ON.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. That's still affirmative. We'll give you a go after waiting 5 seconds, and then down from there just a few steps, after you have opened the ASCENT ECA CONTROL breakers on panel 16, at that point, the umbilical is not powered, and it's okay to disconnect them should you care to do so.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. After the last step then, I'm free to disconnect.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Right. And one other change we have is, shortly after that, where we're configuring for jettison, we have closed both the FORWARD DUMP valve and the OVERHEAD DUMP valve. And we don't want to get in a locked up position like that, so one way to get around it is to - After we close the FORWARD DUMP valve, turn the DESCENT OXYGEN valve off. Over.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. After the FORWARD DUMP valve, add a step in that says the DESCENT OX valve, off.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Fred. That concludes the DELTAs. And perhaps you heard that our GAMMAs are still minus 6.03 and our DELTA-V will be a 2.8-foot-per-second RCS burn.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Fred-o, we've got one more change we'd like to give you to clarify a question that Jack asked earlier. At EI minus 02:30 - -

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Hold on a minute. Jack. I meant to call Jack back down. I'm not familiar with the previous discussion.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Negative. This is on your checklist.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: At E mi - EI minus 02:30, during power removal from the umbilical, first thing we do is two steps with the CSM. We open the MAIN B, the LM POWER to MAIN B circuit breakers, and then there's a third step which says "Circuit breaker EPS SENSOR SIGNAL, MAIN B, open." Just delete that step. Over.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Delete the third step.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, Aquarius, for your information, as far as our water supply is concerned, including our plans for powerup, we have an additional 18 hours of water remaining from this point.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Eighteen hours of water remaining from this point. Jack.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Hello, Houston; Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Hello, Aquarius. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. This is Jim. I just want to make sure that you're filtering the changes to the checklist that come up to make sure that they're absolutely essential. When we learn our procedures, we can only do it one time, and we can't make changes at the last minute. We'd like to do the best, the safest way possible, but unless the changes are really essential, don't bother sending them up.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. We won't. The chairman of the CPCB is still active, and one thing we're trying to do is to save you all the time we can between EI minus 02:30 and 1 hour.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: That's affirm. That's a real important time.

transcript.speaker: F
transcript.text: Yes. For your information, Jim, I don't know whether you heard that originally, but that time from 2-1/2 to 1 in there has been run about three times, and it's pretty tight, so we've tried to weed out what we could, which isn't much, but I think the other message you might impress on Jack when you get around to alining that platform, don't try to get it down too neat. It doesn't have to be all that good. Just do a nice quick and dirty one, and that's going to be good enough anyway.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I concur. I think for reentry we don't have to have a real accurate platform, but I haven't told Jack that.

transcript.speaker: F
transcript.text: Roger. Hey, Jim, while you're up and things are nice and quiet, let me give you a couple of other things to think about. One specifically. I know none of you are sleeping worth a damn because it's so cold, and you might want to dig out the medical kit there around 01:35 or in that ballpark, and pull out a couple of Dexedrines apiece and try one about then, and another around 01:39 to 01:40.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Well, I hadn't brought that up. We might - We might consider it.

transcript.speaker: F
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: F
transcript.text: Wish we could figure a way to get a hot cup of coffee up to you. It'd probably taste pretty good about now, wouldn't it?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Yes, it sure would. You don't realize how cold this thing becomes when it's in a PTC mode that's slowing down, and I just clocked the cycles on my ... And it's about 11 to 12 minutes now, and the Sun is directly overhead, so it's shining on the engine bell of the service module and not getting down to the spacecraft at all.

transcript.speaker: F
transcript.text: Hang in there. It won't be long now.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Yes. That's right. As a matter of fact, doing this alinement on the Earth this time will be like making a landing with a fogged-up windshield.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Skipper. We figured out a way for you to keep warm. We decided to start powering you up now, and what we want you to do - what we want you to do is take your entry LM PREp checklist and start at the top where it says "BAT 5 NORMAL FEED on," and then jump over as it says to your 30-minute activation, and do all of the 30-minute activation up to, but not including, the burn. You copy?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. If I understand you correctly, then that gives me leeway to maneuver when we get up to activation complete, and we can be in position for the burn, but we will not burn. We don't have a pad anyway.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirm, Jim. You could maneuver to burn attitude, or you could maneuver to an attitude which should put the Sun in the windows to warm the place up.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Sounds good, and you're sure we have plenty of electrical power to do this?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative. We've got plenty of power- to do it. I can get you a number, though.

transcript.speaker: F
transcript.text: Jim, you've got about 100-percent margins on everything from here on in.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: That sounds encouraging.

transcript.speaker: F
transcript.text: Roger. That's in the LM. We're not talking about the CSM right now.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I understand.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Question. This short turnon step 3 on page 24 has us only turning on the RCS SYSTEM A/B, two quads, and the breakers are still out on panel 11. Did you want those in, too, or are we just going to use one set of heaters?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Stand by.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Go as the checklist recommends for now. When you get into the circuit breaker panel configuration, you're going to get the number 1 set of heaters on anyway.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Houston. We'd like to get a hack to set our mission timer here, Jack.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Fred-o. Set it at 133:35 straight up. You've got about 30 seconds to set it.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Standing by.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. I'll give you the 2-second delay in there. Stand by to start.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: START.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. We've got it.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. I'm counting 133:35:10.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Right on.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. One other way to warm things up in a hurry in there is when you get your AC on to turn on the window heaters.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. I guess the only question I have is what it's liable to do to us with the - looks like almost a frost on it now.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Understand this. Jack. I'd like to let it maybe warm up just a little bit more before hitting it with the heat load. 05 13 36 33 CO Not a bad idea.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: And, as you can see, Houston, at turnon we got our old friend downlink 2 back.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. We're seeing it, Fred.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. It looks like you're proceeding toward the gimbal lock there. We'd like you to check that, please.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger. Not much we can do about it. We can't use the thrusters, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Forget it now; we'll get it later.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: And, Houston, Aquarius. I guess the next thing for the PGNS will be a coarse aline 000, but I guess we ought to hold up now until we get enough time on the RCS thrusters.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. We're looking at them. We'll give you the GO on them. Okay, Aquarius. Your quads are 120 to 133 now, so you're cleared for - Cleared for thrusters.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Did you get my GO for RCS?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: That's affirm. We're GO. What we're doing now. Jack, is letting the spacecraft drift in this mode to pick up the Earth again.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I don't want to just go blasting around the sky and get high rates, because I don't have anything to null the rates on until the Earth comes back up again. And - Once I get the Earth in sight.., we have no strain on nulling rates. That part of the Earth, that is.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: It's going to be interesting today. Jack. The Earth's a lot bigger; the crescent is a lot more pronounced than it was yesterday.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Well, you're going in the right direction.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: That's right.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: And, Jack, I guess we haven't changed our angle much with respect to the Sun 93 million miles away, so it ought to be in about the same place in the A0T, isn't that Charlie?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Hold l on that, Fred. I'll get an answer for you.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, your ASA is warmed up now. You can activate the AGS.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. When you look out a detent 2 in the proper burn attitude, what you ought to see is the Sun at 12 o'clock, about halfway between the top of the A0T and the center of the pipper. And you ought to see the Earth - -

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: - - at 6 o'clock.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And, it's getting a little warmer in here now. Thank you.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Duck blinds are always warmer, Jim, when the birds are flying.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Right.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Jack, I've gotten so used to flying attitude with the TTCA, I won't be able to do it normally. 1

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Say again, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I said I've gotten so used to flying attitude with the translational control, I won't be able to do with the ACA.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, we see your glycol temperature getting up there. If you want to make it a little warmer, or you can try putting your SUIT TEMP valve to HIGH, if you haven't already got it there.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, something we're thinking about right now is, if we can do it without using a lot of RCS, it would be to our advantage timewise to try to get an alinement.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. You mean a P52?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We're - -

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I'lll ... around.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: A combination of 51 and 52.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I'll see what we can do. Jack.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. And we'd planned to use the Moon and the Sun for that.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. On panel 16, we'd like for you to close the CROSS TIE BAL LOADS breaker, please.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. It's closed.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And it looks like we could support a - an alinement in a few minutes, if you'd be willing to go ahead with that.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Jack, it sounds good. I think from our position here, we know where the Sun and Moon are and it's strictly going to be a pitch maneuver. But I think we can save some gas. I'll see what we can do.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: We're all set to go. Are you going to ship us up a REFSMMAT?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes, we are. Stand by 1.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: The Sun feels wonderful. It's shining in the rendezvous window.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, Aquarius, before we can ship you a load, we'll have to have, on panel 11, under COMM, the UPDATA LINK circuit breaker closed.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: It's closed.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. It'll be a few - -

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: ... closed ... -

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. And it'll be a few minutes yet, Jim. We're still cranking it up.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Stay with it. Jack, and I'll go back to data.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: I got BAT in about 33-1/3 percent on that uplink. Too fast alarm.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Say again on that, Fred.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: I just got another uplink too fast when I took the DATA switch back off - It's happening, I guess, about a third of the time.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. We're ready with your load if you'll give us DATA please.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Going to DATA. You got it.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. After the uplink, you'll have to set the drift and the REFSMMAT flag as on page 8 of the contingency book, steps 5 and 6.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Page 8, steps 5 and 6. Roger.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Are you done with the computer now. Jack?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Negative. We'll give you the word.

transcript.speaker: F
transcript.text: Roger. Aquarius, we're through with it, it's your computer.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Thank you.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, Aquarius, Houston; take option 1 on a P52 when you get to it. And I've got some ball angles for a Sun and Moon.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. We want an option 1 and you've got some ball angles for Sun and Moon. And right now, Jim has the Sun pretty well squared away right in the middle of A0T.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: And have you got some plan in vectors for us, Jack?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Fred-o. For the Sun, I've got 246; for the Moon I've got 250.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Are you talking about ball theta angles?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Negative. I was - I was reporting the code for NOUN 70.

transcript.speaker: F
transcript.text: They're in the computer, Fred.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Oh, okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Houston. We have the Sun marks and I'll start up at pitch now to go over and pick up the Moon.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Just as a note of interest, in this dock con- figurations for P52s, the command module docking probe is right down the middle of - the docking light, rather, is right down the middle of the detent. And when the Sun flashes on, it really makes it difficult.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Just like the simulator.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes. It was good training.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Well, Jack, that's what it says the torquing angles are.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We haven't got them yet.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, hold on to torquing angles, please.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: We're doing that.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jim, the reason for the delay is that we're not seeing the data yet. We're having to check a point here; and as soon as they come up, we'll let you know what to do with them.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. We had a large NOUN 105 of - what - 112, and our torquing angles, Jack, are minus 01713, minus 03278, minus 01395.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Minus 01713, and we see them now.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, torque them.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, do you have a star close by there you could check?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I'll look around. Jack. I was just trying to get a cheek on the Moon, again, to see if those angles were indeed true, and we got the Moon back again and centered.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. What you're reading now the angles? We had the Moon centered, and it's pretty close to what we have on the 8 ball, I guess. Close enough for any entry that we'd like to do.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. And I'm told that Denubla - Denebola and Regulus are nearby if you wanted to make a star check.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. I'm going to start pitching around again, and I'll see if I can pick them up. I have Orion out here to my left a little bit, but it's pretty close to the - oh, here. I've got Sirius. That's a nice one. How about that?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Sounds good here.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, is Jack sitting on the rumble seat there?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: He was. He just headed upstairs to take another look around.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. I got a minor addition to the entry checklist for him. This time it's in the - -

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Stand - -

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: - - entry book.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Stand by 1. He has that in his pocket.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: What I'm doing, Jack, is just - I'm pitching over now. I'm going to pick up another star. Sirius was just too far off. I thought I was going to use too much gas getting there.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: By the time I get alined in the - in the AOT - be nice if we didn't have Odyssey attached, we could just AUTO - AUTO maneuver over to these things.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Looks to us like you've got her alined, Jim, so I wouldn't worry about it too much.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Yes. I'm pretty confident that the platform's fairly descent.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. We need an E MOD VERB 74, when you've got a chance, please.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Coming to you.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. On your entry checklist, on page 2-5. Down there on step 9, where it says 152 degrees pitch at .05g, adjacent to that, so that Recovery can see you better on the way down, we want you to turn your S-BAND, POWER AMPLIFIER to HIGH. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Turn S-BAND, POWER AMP to HIGH at .05g time.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Is that it?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's it. Jack.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. We're considering doing the midcourse with PGNS, unless you'd rather do it in AGS.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: No. PGNS is fine with me. I just aline myself up with the old ball again. So I've got you foresighted again, but any way you want to do it.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Like you say, you might as well go first class.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I guess you're right.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Now wait a minute, Jack.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: I just lost a lot of friends there.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: And, Jack, you can tell. Owen Morris that the RCS SYSTEM A/B 2 QUAD 1 breaker is still nicely in.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. We'll pass the word.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. We think we've figured out a way to save you some time at a very critical. - very full schedule. And that's by doing a docked coarse aline, since we got the LM up now. That would save you a maneuver or two.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius. It seemed to me a docked coarse aline might be quicker for - for Jack.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes. We think it would be, and it'd save quite a bit of time at a place where you're going to be pretty busy. Also save you some petrol.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Affirm.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. We're looking at doing this in the service module SEP attitude, and the optics will be pointed away from the Sun. So it should be a good attitude for a P52.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. So, we'll be going to the service module SEP attitude, at which time we'll do a docked coarse aline, and -

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Then you want - You want Jack then to do a P52?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: The way we'll do that in our time line Jim, is to go ahead and do the service module JETT and then we'll just stay in that attitude and when it comes time in our time line as we've outlined, to bring the platform up, we'll proceed with the P52 - coarse aline, and then the P52.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Are we going to use the same techniques that we normally do for LM activation? In other words, I try to maintain an attitude, and give him some angles and then - Are you going to give him the angles? Then he does the 52.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Basically, it's the same procedure just reversed, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Another nice thing about this, is it's one we've done before.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, Aquarius. One thing, however, that we do not plan to do is to proceed with the command module powerup prematurely.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Understand.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Houston. This is Jack.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead. Jack.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. I just wanted to talk over with you, it looks like we've had some changes in the flight plan here, due to Jim's P52. Do you have - Can you talk over with me what your plans are?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, Jack. Since we've got the PGNS up, we plan to use that information to give the CMC a dock coarse alone, and then we're in the service module jettison attitude, we'll wait until it comes time to power up the CMC, and we'll get the CMC a dock coarse aline, and we'll pick some good stars to give you a fine aline with, and it looks like we can pick some stars that are looking away from the Sun in which you can find in that service module jettison attitude; so, we'll save you quite a bit of gas, and save you some time in a very busy time.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Hey, that sounds good. Really fine.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Keeping warm?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Hey, it's warmed up here now. It's almost com- fortable.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I'm looking out the window now. Jack, and that Earth is whistling in like a high-speed freight train.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We're clocking you at 48 000 miles and coming in at about 9000.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I don't think there's many LMs that have seen it like this. I'm still looking for Fra Mauro and Cone Crater.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: You're going the wrong way, son.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. It looks - Just looking over what I may expect here, it looks like I'm just going to get three angles to do a VERB 4l NOUN 20, right?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's what it looks like from here, Jack. It's pretty much the opposite of the LM activation procedure where we do the dock coarse aline.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Yes, except in a way we did a lot of VERB 06 NOUN 20, ENTERS, simultaneously, and then you all shipped him up post-torque values. You're not going to do anything like that are you?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Say again, please. Jack.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. During the activation part, we do a lot of VERB 06 NOUN 20, ENTERS simultaneously, reading you out the difference in the angles, and then MSFN furnishes the post-torquing angles, in order to get the platform fine alined. Do you plan something like that or just three coarse aline angles.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jack, we're going to give you three coarse aline angles, and then you can go right to your checklist as we're giving it, and start in with the VERB 40 NOUN 20.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Real fine.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: And, Jack, how do you lead?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Fine - square.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: I was around shooting pictures of all the debris inside here, before we left, and I inadvertently changed the settings on the DC command module Reseau camera that we need for the service module pictures. I wonder if FA0 can dig them out again - what we need, f-stop and speed.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Fred. Stand by.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Fred, in regards to the camera settings, for black-and-white 3400 film, the settings were f:5.6 at l/250th. Over.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. I'd guessed right after all, but thank you.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. I got MCC-7 pad when you're ready to copy. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Stand by.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. We're in luck, I got one pad left.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We'll take care not to change this one. Ready to go?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Go ahead, Joe.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: MCC-7: 137:39:48.39, ninus 0003.l, plus all zeros, plus 00001, N/A, plus 0020.5, 0003.1, 0:23, 008, 359; the rest is N/A. Remarks: plus-X, four jets, RCS; and your weights for the DAP load: LM weight, 25l8l; CSM weight, 62468. Over.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Joe. MCC-7: 137:39:48.39, minus 0003.1, plus all balls, plus 0000.l, N/A, plus 0020.5, plus 0003.1, 0:23, 008, 359; the rest of pad N/A. Remarks: plus-X, four jets, RCS, ullage; the LM weight, 25181; CSM weight, 62468. Over.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Readback correct.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, Aquarius; Houston. I have a service module SEP pad if you want to copy that, now. Over.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Say again, Joe.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, Fred. I have a service module SEP pad with the attitudes. You don't need a pad sheet for it; just any old blank sheet will do.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. I was going to say I don't - We don't hardly carry a service module SEP pad.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes, we'll have to change that.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. I'm using a P27 here. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. The pad reads as follows and then I'll re- peat the angles for you so you can copy them. The following MCC-7, maneuver the LM to the following FDAI attitudes: roll, 000; pitch, 91.3; yaw, 000. Now do you want those attitudes repeated, Fred?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Following MCC-7 we're to maneuver to the following attitudes: roll, 000; pitch, 091.3; yaw, 000.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. That's correct. And the last part of the pad is at GET 138:10:00, which is EI minus 4.5 hours, execute a push of 0.5 feet per second, four jet, plus-X; perform SM SEP; then execute pull, 0.5 feet per second, four jet, minus-X. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius. Jack's entering the command module, now.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. That last Joe was execute at the GET at 138:10:00 which is EI minus 4-1/2 hours; execute a push of 0.5 feet per second, four-jet ullage; then execute SM SEP followed by a pull of 0.5 feet per second, with respect to a nomenclature on the TTCA; I think we really need an up of 0.5 and then a down of 0.5.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's correct, Fred.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Aquarius. The last pad I had for you right now is the LM jettison pad. Similar to the - Stand by 1, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Aquarius; Houston. Request P00 and DATA for a data load. Over.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: You got it.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. And I was about to say the LM jettison pad is similar to the SM SEP pad, Fred, when you're ready to copy.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Just about the same number of lines?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. Go ahead, Joe.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Fred. Prior to 141:40:00, which is EI minus l hour, maneuver the LM to the following FDAI angles: roll, 130; pitch, 125; yaw, 012.4. The corresponding CSM gimbal angles will be roll, 291; pitch, 196; yaw, 045, and that's the pad. Over. And the computer is yours, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Thank you.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. A LM SEP pad prior to 141:40:00, EI minus 1 hour, maneuver to following attitudes: roll, 130; pitch, 125; yaw, 012.4. The corresponding CSM gimbal angles are roll, 291; pitch, 196; yaw, 045.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Readback correct.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Go ahead, Joe.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We're so efficient down here that we got an entry pad ready, Fred. Do you want to copy that for Jack? Over.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Stand by. I'll have to try to borrow his book from him.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Can we hold off on that a little bit, Joe?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: 0h, absolutely, Jim. We're well ahead. I just wanted to let you know that we had it.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: okay. I hope that when you send up all those uplinks to Jack that you could get them up to him quickly.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We're shooting for less than 5 minutes.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Sounds good.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: And are you still using the computer?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's a negative, Fred. The computer is yours.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, Fred, the computer has your target load in.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. I just want to clarify one thing on the LM SEP pad. It appears to me that in my configuration, I could probably use a VERB 49 loading in 622, yaw, pitch, and roll, in that order; and then being able to fly out at 5018 in roll, pitch, and yaw. Is that correct?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Stand by; I'll verify it, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Joe. And while you're doing that I've got a question about the command module checklist.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jack. Go ahead with your question.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Either I copied the circuit breaker wrong, or - I can't read it. Comes down just about the oh, about the 20th one down, after panel 276, where it says CB INSRUMENTATION POWER CONTROL 3 and 4, open. The next circuit breaker on panel 5 - I - Would you give that to me again?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. That's CB ESSENTIAL INSTRUMENTATION POWER, MAIN B. Over. And it's, closed.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. I just can't, right - I just can't read my writing, ESSENTIAL INSTRUMENTATION POWER MAIN B, closed.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Go ahead, Joe.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. The word we have is that you can't make a VERB 49 maneuver to the LM jettison attitude because those are FDAI angles we gave you; they don't correspond to the gimbal angles for the load; it'll have to be a manual maneuver. Over.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And mind out for gimbal lock.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: We will.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. We're looking at LM current, to see if Jack has started his preheat, and we haven't seen it yet. Is he doing okay down there?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Jack said he's already started it, and he said that in 1 more minute, he'll be up to 20 minutes.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Oh, Roger that.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jim, Houston. Have him let us know what his test meter reads when he's done.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: He says that he had a batteiy A voltage drop of 2 volts, and he'll try to look at the test meter for you right now.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: He's been looking at them, but they haven't been coming up, no far.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We copy.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Do you see a current now. Houston?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Stand by 1 on that, Jim. That's affirmative, Jim; it looks like we are seeing one now.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. And thanks for keeping us on it.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Reminder P41 for the RCS burn.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Thanks for keeping us honest.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We got to protect our jobs. Jim.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: We've been DPS-ing so long here.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Houston. I finished up the maneuvers, the AUTO maneuver in 41; but my roll and yaw needles seem to be offset. Pitch is okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. We copy. Standby. Aquarius, Houston. We recommend PGNS MODE CONTROL to ATT HOLD. Save a little gas and stand by on the error needles .

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Did you call?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Roger, Joe. Figured, if we're going to do this burn in PGNS now, I ought to give you an update on the contingency book pages 32, 33, and 34, because the last time we went through this portion, we were burning it in AGS.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay,Fred. Stand by. We've been talking about possibly having you do it in AGS. We recommend at this time that you do AGS to PGNS, aline, the 400 plus 3 procedure only. Over.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. We recommend that you perform this burn in AGS, as you did the last midcourse maneuver; we think it will save gas. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Joe, do you want me to line up the same way we did the last one, too?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Stand by on that.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: And, Joe, Jack just handed me some injector temperatures, if you want to read these on ... so I can plug them in.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Go ahead with those.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. 5 Charlie, 4.0; 5 Dogs, 3.7; 6 Able, 3.5; 6 Bravo, 4.1; 6 Charlie, 4.2; 6 Delta, 3.8.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Copy those, Fred.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. Our recommendation on this burn is that you maneuver to the burn attitude, in PGNS MIN IMPULSE, then do a body-axis aline, 400 plus 5, followed by 400 plus 0, and then do the burn in AGS. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Now we're spinning it with the PGNS, what you gave us for a PGNS attitude. Is this the wrong one? Do you want me to just to aline up the Earth as I did before in the last midcourse?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: No. We don't want you to do that. Read me your FDAI angles, and let's compare them with what we have down here.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. You're looking at them in the DSKY. I've got roll of 8.47; pitch of about 0.51; and yaw looking at about 3.750.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. Those are very close - I guess all you need to do is trim them up a bit.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I plan to do a final trim - AUTO trim, and then a four-jet translation.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. For fuel conservation, we'd prefer you to trim it up MIN IMPULSE, and there's really very little trim required; and then go ahead and do it AGS. We're on the expected fuel usage, but we're just being old ladies about it.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Understand, My only question, Joe, is the fact that both the roll and the yaw needles did not go to null when I did an AUTO maneuver. I'd tried to go manually to the attitude; and then went to AUTO, but the roll and the yaw do not come in at all.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. I haven't got an answer on that yet, but your attitude looks very close.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. I can take it on ...

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And, Houston, Aquarius. I'm not sure that if I follow and null the needles, that will be the proper attitude.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Stand by 1, Jim. We're talking about it. It's going to be very close; in any event, close enough.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, Jim, just for your information, I have the entry pad. I have the landing area weather summary, which you probably don't even have to copy, but which I'll read up to you when you're ready; and some stars for Jack that I'm holding for him for later on.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: And, Joe, Jack says all the injector temperatures, he just checked them again, and they're all over 3.9.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That they're all over 3.9 now. Thanks a lot.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: You can tell him that it's looking good to us. They were even happy with the previous ones.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And, my only question, Houston, is do you want me to null the PGNS needle manually?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Stand by 1 more minute, Jim.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes. I guess the basic question is comparing the balls here and out the window it doesn't look too unreasonable, and I guess Jim says the C0AS is yawed and roll slightly off from what he might eyeball; but yet, the FDAI air needles for PGNS are showing a full scale left in roll and full scale left in yaw.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes. It appears if we track those we, obviously, aren't going to be on the attitude that we burned the last midcourse.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Well, this attitude we passed you is not quite alined to the terminator, and stand by on this.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: It should be off about 8 degrees, FLIGHT. END OF TAPE

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: How you doing, there, Houston?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Oh, we're getting there, Jim. We're - we're all agreed that you're almost, but not quite, in the proper attitude, and we're just trying to get you one firm recommendation on how to proceed from here.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. I have nulled the null - roll needle and the pitch needle now and I'm yawed - rolled left now. I'm rolled left about 9 degrees.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Understand the needles are nulled.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: The yaw isn't, but the pitch and roll are.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger that.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Here's the big story. Your attitude really looks quite good except in roll, and we'd like you to do the following. In MIN impulse PGNS, we'd like you to trim to zero pitch, which is about where you are now; to 008 degrees in roll, which is about 16 degrees from your present roll attitude; and to zero degrees in yaw, which is about where you are now. Then we'd like you to do the body-axis aline 400 plus 5, 400 plus 0. PITCH and ROLL to PULSE, select AGS, do the burn in AGS. How does that sound? Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. I'm rolled the wrong way; that is what you're saying, right?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's right.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And you know I can't roll in minimum impulse. I've got to use TTCAs.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's right, Jim. Sorry.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And you don't want me to automatically trim 5018, I take it.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirm, Jim. Don't trim 5018.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We just want you to cycle on through P41 to get the average g and burn it out.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Just for your information, we see 3.0 in regis- ter 1. We read you up 3.1 on the pad. The actual DELTA-V was 3.05, and they warned me that it might come out 3.0.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. That's a little burn.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Right.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Your attitude looks real good. We will give you a mark at 10 minutes to the burn, which is in 28 seconds.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. We'll burn it in AGS and use the AGS ball.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Right. I was looking at the wrong clock, and we're a little under 10 minutes now. I'll give you a mark at 9 minutes. Okay?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: That's fine.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. We have 10 seconds until 9 minutes to the burn. 3,2,1 -

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: MARK.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Nine minutes.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Very well. That agrees with our event timer.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Houston. About 3 minutes to go, and we're all squared away.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, Aquarius; Houston. Roger that. And we're standing by for your body-axis aline and your zeroing 404, 405, 406, going to 470.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. You'd asked - you'd asked me before, Joe, to go 400 plus 3, which I did. I assume you've changed the script again.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Fred. We did tell you to do that awhile ago, and it doesn't matter; you're looking good.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes. It looks like we had a minus 0.2 bias at 470. We're burning.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Copy that, Fred.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Good show, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: We're tweaking now, Jo.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Aquarius, Houston. You're good right where you are.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. That's it.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. If you're happy, can we maneuver to service module SEP attitude now?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And I'm pitching up to the proper attitude.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We're looking at it.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And it's again necessary to use the TTCA to pitch.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Affirmative.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Recommend you terminate P41.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: F
transcript.text: Hey, Jim, have you broken into the medical kit per my recommendation a few hours ago?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Yes. Everything is taken care of Deke.

transcript.speaker: F
transcript.text: Okay, fine. You might hit it again in about 2 hours.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. AFT OMNI.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I beat you to it, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Yes. I thought you did, but 1 thought I'd say it anyway.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Aquarius; Houston. That attitude looks pretty good. How's Jack getting along?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: He's getting along, all set to go. And I'm going to go into PGNS ATT HOLD.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Again for fuel-consumption reasons, we'd like you to go back to the AGS mode you were in rather than PGNS ATT HOLD. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. I'm in PGNS MINIMUM IMPULSE right now while we're firing. And I'll go back to the AGS mode.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. PGNS MIN IMPULSE is okay; AGS is okay too. It's your choice.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Soon as we get rid of the service module, Joe, I think I'll be able to maneuver a lot better.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Sure thing.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Jack just reported that all thrusters fired on both rings.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Real fine. Real fine.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And SM JETT at 138:12.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. Understand; that's SM JETT, 138:12. It's not that time critical, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Can we do it at any time, Joe?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: I think so, but let me check. Aquarius, Houston. That's affirmative. You can jettison the servire module when you are ready; no big rush, but any time.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Sounds good.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. We recommend that you use the AGS for the separation maneuver, because we'd like to get the proper weight in for the DAP before we use the PGNS again.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger. Me will. Stand by.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: SM SEP.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Copy that.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Do you see it. Jack?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Aquarius; Houston. I recommend you terminate AVERAGE G. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, I've got her, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Beautiful, beautiful. And for you information, Jim, you'll be coming up on an RCS caution light for helium. No sweat. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And there's one whole side of that spacecraft missing.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Is that right?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Right by the - Look out there, will you? Right by the high gain antenna, the whole panel is blown out, almost from the base to the engine.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Copy that.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Yes, it looks like it got to the SPS bell, too, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Think it zinged the SPS engine bell, huh?

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: That's the way it looks; unless that's just a dark brown streak. It's really a mess.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. We'd like you to get some pictures, but we want you to conserve RCS. Don't make unnecessary maneuvers.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, Jim; Houston. In particular, of course, we don't want any translation maneuvers.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Right on that. Joe, you realize that when I went up to the SM SEP attitude, I had to use TTCA to do it.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirm. We know that. That's okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: All right. She's drifting right down in front of our windows now, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay, Joe, I'm now looking down the SPS bell, and it looks - looks okay on the inside; maybe it is just a streak.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Copy that, Fred. Was the bell deformed on the outside or just nicked or what?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I think the explosion, from what I could see, Joe, had - had stained it. I don't know whether it did any actual deformation or not.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Man, that's unbelievable!

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And, Joe, looks like a lot of - a lot of debris is just hanging out the side near the S-band antenna.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: I know you're busy, but when Jack gets a chance, we'd like BAT C current and MAIN A voltage in the command module.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Co ahead, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. I've pitched up to about 180 degrees now, and do you want me to go to the LM SEP attitude for his alinement?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Stand by on that, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. We want you to go to the service module SEP attitude.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, Jim, when you have leisure to copy, I have your NOUN 46 and NOUN 47 DAP data load numbers.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. NOUN 46, 31021; NOUN 47, plus 25248 and plus 09050. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger; 31021, plus 25248, plus 09050.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's correct.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And now, Houston, do you still think that AGS is going to be less expensive than PGNS mode?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. I'm in AGS pulse right now. It's the ...

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We concur.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Going back to LM SEP attitude - or CSM SEP attitude.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger that.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Stand by. Jack's on the line and he says that he can't get the computer to go into standby.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Have him tell us what he's - what he looks at. And remind him that he won't see the light. He won't see the STANDBY light - -

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay - -

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: - - because it's not powered - -

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: - - Joe - -

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead, Jack.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Joe. Okay, I get a flashing 37, I am in PROGRAM 06. There is no STANDBY light, but when I ENTER, I don't get the three balls 62 displayed like I'm supposed to.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jack - -

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: And this - -

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead - -

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: - - and this occurs on both DSKYs.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Understand. We're - we're thinking about it. Stand by 1.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jack; Houston. We'd like you to go VERB 37, ENTER; 06, ENTER again. Over.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. In work.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Houston. I'm back in the service module SEP attitude.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Copy that, Jim. Looks good. Do you know whether Jack got any pictures out of window 5? Was it still fogged up? Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I don't think so. I think he came right down here, because I think he saw it first in the - in the LM.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Good deal. And whenever you get cleaned up, we got the entry pad and the landing area summary for you.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Vance. This is Jack.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Doing a VERB 37, ENTER; 06, ENTER does bring up the three balls 62 display, but I can't PROCEED on it on wither DSKY and a VERB 33 doesn't work either.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: It's still just a flashing 5025 with a code 00062.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Copy that, Jack. Stand by 1.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jack, Houston. How long did you hold PROCEED before you quit on it?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Well, it was varying lengths. Is it suppose to be a long-time PROCEED?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: We think it may be, Jack. We think it may be 15 to 20 seconds, and our recommendation is that you PRO and hold it down for a good period of time, probably half a minute or more, and see if the DSKY blanks.
