transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. All right, I didn't hold it in that long. Maybe 2 or 3 seconds is the longest I held it.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Jack just came down the tunnel again and said the computer's okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Good to hear it. And did you ever get that BAT C MAIN A reading for us?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I guess in the heat of the battle, I forgot to to give it to you, I guess. Stand by.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: BAT C current was 2 amps and BAT A voltage, 30.2.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Copy, 2 amps, 30.2. And that sounds good to us, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We'd like to have Jack verify that. the PYROs in LOOIC are SAFE, and we'd like to remind him to do no further powerup of the CSM until EI minus 2 plus 30.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger. He reports that the PYROs are SAFE, and we're standing by for 02:30.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Real good.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Well, I can't say that this week hasn't been filled with excitement.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Well, James, if you can't take any better care of a spacecraft than that, we might not give you another one. Hey, Jim; Houston. You might ask Jack, while he's down there, to take a peek through the telescope and tell us whether he can see any stars. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Joe, Jack tells me that there's still a lot of particles floating around and he's - he can't pick out any constellation that he recognizes so far. But it might clear here in a little while.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, understand.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. EECOM is looking at that battery amperage that you gave us awhile ago. He'd like to see it about a half an amp to an amp lower. Like you to ask Jack to just check the circuit breakers and switches that he's pulled in so far and make sure he doesn't have any extra loads on MAIN A; specifically, the FLOODLIGHT configuration, and his CAUTION AND WARNING circuit breakers, and his ESSENTIAL INSTRUMENTATION POWER circuit breakers. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Thanks.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Jack reported that he turned out all the floodlight.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Okay, we copy that. Like to have him check the amperage on there; see what you have now, and give us a voltage reading, too.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, will do.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Joe. This is Jack.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. I've been not reading any voltage at all on BAT C, and the amperage looks like about 2 amps, but that could be kind of noise-level stuff. I've got all the floodlights off and I - Can you think of anything - I could power dowr. to lower MAIN A.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. How about reading the voltage off of MAIN A?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Oh, this is Ken. Okay. Ken, it was 30.2.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We're checking out the floodlights we gave you. Actually, Jack, you ought to be able to go ahead and use the lights we gave you. There's no reason to sit in the dark. They're supposed to be coming off of MAIN B, and we're checking that now.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. It's not bad down there. We're in - got plenty of light. But should I be reading the voltage on BAT C?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jack, you should be reading BAT C voltage. That circuit breaker should be open.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Okay, can you think of anything else you want to get turned off to lighten load on MAIN A?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We're perusing that subject right now, Jack. It's really not that big a thing, just something we wanted to dress up.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Aquarius; Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Say, Jim, as something to try, you might have Jack turn off the RING 1's AUTO coils, which are probably on MAIN A. Have him turn those off and take a look at the readings.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Jack has turned off RING 1 that was on MAIN A, and he's still reading 30.2 volts.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger that, Jim. What's his amperage? Did he read that off?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I guess. He says it's down in the mud; it's less than 2 amps.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Down in the mud. Okay, understand that. Request he turn them back on and - Okay, Jim, that's the AUTO coils back on RING 1, MAIN A, and when you get that done, I'd like you to copy the entry pad.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Joe. Standing by to copy the entry pad.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, here we come. Entry pad: Mid-Pacific, 000153; 000. The next two lines will be the GET of moonset and the Moon-check attitude; 142:38:17, 178; NOUN 6l, minus 21.66, minus 165.37; 06.7; 36211, 6.51; 1168.9, 36292; 142:40:40; 00:28. The next four are N/A; Do is 4.00, 02:04; 00:17, 03:22, O8:l4; 33, 353-1, 29.9. Boresight star is Sigma Libra, down 08.8, left 0.4; lift vector up. Comments: GDC for entry alinement, stars 31 and 23. The roll aline 04l, pitch 245, yaw 024, use EMS nonexit pattern. Maintain Moon-check attitude until moonset; then go to entry atti- tude or track horizon with the 36-degree window mark. Last comment: constant g entry is roll right. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Entry pad as follows: Mid-PAC, OO0153, 000; 142:38:17, 178; minus 21.66, minus 165.37; 06.7; 36211, 6.51; 1168.9, 36292; l42:4O:4O; 00:28. Next four columns are N/A; D^ is 4.00, 02:04; 00:17, 03:22 08:l4; 33, 353.1, 29.9. Zebra Libra, or something like that, Beta Libra is down 08.8, left 0.4; lift vector up; GDC entry alined, stars 31, 33. Roll 04l, pitch, 045, yaw 024. EMS nonexit pattern to be used; maintain Moon-check attitude until moonset, and if all else is lost, the constant g entry is right - Roll is right.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Roger that, Jim. I want to verify a couple of things I'm not sure I heard you read back. The first one was Zebra Libra (laughter) that's Sigma Libra. The set stars 31 and 23. Did you get that? Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. No, I had 31 and 33, and I got Sigma Libra now, and it'll be 31 and 23 for the set stars.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. And your GDC pitch aline, I wasn't sure whether that was - whether you read back 245 or 045. The correct number is 245. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Good show, because I have 045 down. 245.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. And the Moon check here, unlike the horizon check, is on the 36-degree window mark all the way. Just wanted to repeat that.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Moon check on 30-degree window mark.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's 36-degree window mark, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Three six. Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Readback correct. And, Aquarius; Houston. If you want me to read you the landing area summary, I'll do that.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Sounds good.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. In the mid-Pacific landing area, the weather is good. The cloud cover is 2000, scattered; visibility, 10; winds 060 at 10; wave heights are 4 feet, and the altimeter 2986, if you care. Scattered showers less than 10 percent of the area. Recovery forces are as follows: the Iwo Jima will be at the touchdown point, the aircraft call sign will be Recovery 1, on station with swimmers on board. The - we have the constant g backup reentry area covered with the USS Hall, the Good Liberty Ship, and the other recovery aircraft whose call signs you may hear are Samoa Rescue C-130s.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, fine. We have the Iwo Jima as the prime recovery ship.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's correct.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Joe, Jack tells me he is still having trouble looking through the optics. I'm just going to pitch up a little bit more here to see if he can get into the dark spot.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, real fine. You might tell him when we get to that point, we have some - some stars with corresponding shaft and trunnion angles to pass to him as backups in case the computer doesn't happen to point him straight at one. And it's the Summer Triangle.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: And are you tracking us, and do you have any results on that last midcourse?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Stand by. It looks good. I'll try and get you numbers.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: It feels nice to use the hand controller again.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I just said, Joe, it feels nice to use the hand controller again.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Oh. Roger that. FIDO says he's got you nailed within a half a foot per second; the midcourse looked real good.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And I've got two things we'd like Jack to do in the command module to ease the load on MAIN A. One of them is to verify or turn the CM/RCS HEATER switch to OFF. We're done with that, and even though the circuit breakers are pulled, the switches might be drawing a little current. And the second one is, we'd like him to turn SCS LOGIC POWER 2/3 to OFF; we don't need it now. It's called up in the checklist at the appropriate time, and we'd like him to turn that off. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. I'll tell Jack to check that the CM/RCS HEATER switch is off, and, if not, we'll turn it off; and also to turn off the SCS LOGIC POWER 2/3 switch, OFF, since it comes up later in the checklist.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's correct.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius. We're recording MAIN A voltage up to 31.0.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. That's 31.0. We're smiling.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. How about if I hold a pitch attitude of about 115 instead of about 91. I think Jack can use the optics a little bit better at that angle.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Jim, that's perfectly okay with us, if it looks good for stars.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: He just looked at them briefly; I'll down and look at them a little bit better here.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. With the new attitude, our shaft and trun- nion angles we were going to pass him don't mean anything, but it's more important to have a good star field.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. We - We've been talking about your going to a different attitude than the pad attitude for better star field vision out the command module, and what we'd like to have you do is this. If you can predict now or sometime soon, what attitude it is that you would like to hold at that time, and go to that attitude now, we'd like to be able to compute the coarse aline gimbal angles for the CSM, and we can do that if you go to the selected attitude, hold it, call up a VERB 06 NOUN 20, and read us your LM gimbal angles, we can take those and compute CSM coarse aline gimbal angles on the assumption that, when we get back into the CSM coarse aline, you will return to that selected attitude. Does that sound okay? Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Yes. I'll try to hold the attitude we select directly, while you're giving us the coarse aline attitude. We're not too sure what - what's the best attitude. I'm going to ask Jack again if 115 is sufficient for him.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. You can take some time figuring out the best attitude, and then you won't have to hold it all the way from now until then, if you just get back to it.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Jack would like to know what constellations are in his sextant, or scanning telescope, field of view at an attitude of about 105 pitch, zero roll, zero yaw. Can you give that to us?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We'll sure give it a go. As I said, we - We have some stars. They're not - They're not centered with the shaft and trunnion zero. Let us take a quick look at 105 pitch, shaft and trunnion zero, and see if we can get you an answer.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. These - None of these stars will be exactly centered, but, at a pitch attitude of 115, we had computed that Vega, Altair, Rasalhague, and Deneb would all be in the telescope field of view, and the first three were also in view at the 91-degree pitch, so he should be able to see one or more of those four stars. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Thank you, very much.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. And, Jim, I can give shaft and trunnions if - if he's interested.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. Why don't you give us the shaft and trun- nion for - say, Altair at 115, and I'll go up there, and I'll see if he can pick it up.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Real fine. At 115 degrees of pitch, Altair, shaft 274, trunnion 22.2. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger. Shaft is 274, trunnion 22.2.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirm.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead, Joe.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. In the LM, there we have - We show battery 3 only drawing about an amp, and we think it's probably time to get it off the line; battery 3 to OFF/RESET. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Battery 3 is OFF/RESET.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Just how's our power consumption, Houston, just out of curiosity?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: I'll verify it, Jim. I'm sure it's okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Aquarius; Houston. With the present amount of power you've got in the LM, which is over 500 amp-hours, and the rate you're using them, we figure you've got almost 12 hours of power left. 1

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Twelve hours, huh? We could reenter with it.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirm.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's enough for two touch-and-goes and a full stop, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: That's right, Joe; if you could dig a crater like Cone Crater, I could might hit it.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: (Laughter) Okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Jack reports that he thinks he can see Altair.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Very good.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: He says, he thinks he can see Altair.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. I'll take back the "very," but I'll leave the "good."

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Go.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I ran back there to take a look and see what I could see in the - in the scanning telescope. It looks pretty grim back there right now. It might be that we have to go with the coarse aline, and maybe computation of some fine aline docking angles, if we have time.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We'd like to do that, too. Wait a minute; stand by, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. How do you read?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: I read you loud and clear.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. What we'd like to do, Jim, is - We'll go ahead and get the coarse aline to the gimbal angles that - that you're going to be holding for us; and we'll get the platform up, and then when you call P52 and you use PICAPAR, it prob- ably won't be close enough to put the star in the sextant, but if you can see any kind of a bright star in the general vicinity, - and like general vicinity, I mean 2 to 3 degrees from the center of the telescope, so that you have some clue as to which way to go, then the identifica- tion problem shouldn't present much of a - of a difficulty. And once you get the thing in the sextant, then you can go ahead and treat it like any other PECAPAR.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: That sounds great, Ken. One little problem: there's all sorts of bright objects floating around us, and also that just staring at part of Aquarius; it's just reflecting light like mad. We can give it a try. There's no problem there; if we can see it, we'll get it.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. And in - in the event that that doesn't work, we're standing by with the original scheme, a set of LM FDAI angles to fly to that'll point the command module optics at the Moon and the Sun; so we can always go back to that.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And, Aquarius, Houston. We'd like you to verify the SUIT RELIEF valve to closed. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Stand by. It's closed.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Houston; Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Go.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: We'll go with your original 91-degree angle, if you have the stars figured out, and the coarse aline angle for it.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Roger that, Jim. Then at - at your con- venience here, we'd like you to go to that attitude, as close as you can get, and call up a NOUN 20 for us.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. In work now.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Houston, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead, Aquarius.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. I take it that, if - if Jack cannot see stars at this attitude after you give him the coarse aline angles, we're just not going to read down to you our gimbal angles and have you figure out a target angle for Jack, but you want him to do sighting on the Moon and the Sun. Is that correct?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's roughly correct, Jim. Jack will coarse aline at that attitude. This is what we're having you maneuver to the - to that attitude for. We're going to compute coarse aline gimbal angles and pass them up to him, and the first thing he'll do when he gets there, per his checklist, is to coarse aline his platform. Then he'll go into the P52, and, if he can't see stars, we will quickly pass up to you the - your FDAI angles to put him in the Moon-view attitude, and he'll do his P52 on the Moon, and then have you maneuver on the Sun and complete the P52 of the Sun.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. But I'm going to have to maneuver to the Moon to help him out.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Oh. That's - That's affirmative. If he can't see stars at the - at the SEP attitude that - that you'll be holding, you'll have to maneuver to the Moon attitude and then to the Sun attitude for him.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Just like to mention that, even if, for some reason, we run out of time or something and don't complete the Moon-Sun P52, Jack will have a platform coarse aline to the entry REFSMMAT, which we feel will be plenty good enough.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Roger. That's my feelings, too.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Hello there, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Hi! Jim, we - We've gone ahead and computed the CSM coarse aline gimbal angles based on your being at the service module SEP attitude at the time that Jack cranks up the computer and - and coarse alines the IMU. That is, we assume that you're going to he at roll, 0; pitch, 091; yaw, 0; and, if you concur on that, I'd like to pass up the angles for - for Jack to have.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. I'll be there to the best of my ability.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Good show. You ready to copy?

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. CSM coarse aline angles: ROLL, plus 298.95; PITCH, plus 271.30; YAW, plus 000.20.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. The command module angles will be: ROLL, 298.95; PITCH, 271.30; and YAW, 000.20.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirmative, and that's for his VERB 4l NOUN 20 when he gets there.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead, Houston; Aquarius here.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. We're getting about 9 minutes from the commencement of command module powerup, and we wanted to just mention to you for Jack's benefit that, although the batteries are looking real good, in case they're cool and have a little difficulty hacking the load just at first, we'd like him to monitor main bus voltage to 24 volts or above during the powerup procedure and, if it falls below, we'll have a couple of circuit breakers for him that - that will solve the problem.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay. And I take it you're also monitoring main bus voltage.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Negative. Not in the command module at this time, because we don't call up telemetry until a little bit later on.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Ah so. That's right; I forgot. Okay. I will tell him.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Thank you.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. You're GO to start powering up the command module.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Right-o. We're starting now.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. We have LM power breakers. 05 20 11 20 IMP Okay. Houston, you're looking at it.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Roger. Stand by.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Press on, Fred.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay. That'a - That's it, Joe.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Real good.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. We have command module AOS. Request OMHI Charlie tn the CM. Over.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: OMNI Charlie. Okay. Standby.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Coming up.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.text: That was sent through a new onboard communication system known as yelling through the tunnel.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: (Laughter) The one MC.

transcript.text: Understand, Jim.

transcript.text: Roger. Okay. Verify the POWER AMP talkback is gray, Jim.

transcript.text: Okay. That's verified.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.text: Roger. Thank you.

transcript.text: Okay. Read you, babe.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Copy that, Jack.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Understand you are in P00 and ACCEPT. Verify OMNI Charlie.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Stand by.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Odyssey: Houston. Select your own best OMNI and then repeat VERB 74 ENTER. Over.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Odyssey:. Houston. We are locked on solid high bit rate now; repeat the VERB 74 ENTER. Over. Delay that; hold the VERB 74 1 minute. Wait.

transcript.text: Okay, Odyssey: Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We are going to skip the E-MOD dump for right now and get the uplink in.

transcript.text: Okay. P00 and ACCEPT. And, Jack, you can go ahead with the IMU and optics powerup. Over.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Roger. It's in work.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.text: Okay. Copy that, Fred.

transcript.speaker: LMP
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.text: And I think the reason you don't read voltage is it's a circuit breaker that we have called as being out.

transcript.text: All right.

transcript.text: Odyssey, Houston. The uplink is going well. We have one more load to get in.

transcript.text: Okay. Real fine.

transcript.text: Stand by 1 second.

transcript.text: Okay, Jack. We'd like the VERB 74 ENTER, and it'll take less than a minute for E-MOD dump.

transcript.speaker: CMP

transcript.text: And, Jack, Houston. It'll be 100 seconds on that.

transcript.text: Odyssey, Houston. You can go to UP TEL BLOCK. Over.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. We're coming up on time for the coarse aline, Jim, so you can hold your attitude real good.

transcript.text: Copy that.

transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. I copied that you - that he's completed the coarse aline; he's going into the P52 now? Is that right?

transcript.text: Okay. You're staying at your present attitude, aren't you?

transcript.text: Roger that.

transcript.text: Roger that. 05 20 44 37 CMP ... ...

transcript.text: Odyssey, Houston. Have you set the drift light and the REFSMMAT light? Over.

transcript.text: Odyssey, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: ... flag.

transcript.text: You were noisy; I didn't copy. Have you set the drift and REFSMMAT flag?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger that, Jack.

transcript.text: That's affirmative. Vega and Altair should be good. Vega is 36, Altair is 40.

transcript.text: Okay. We'll give that a try.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. And you might look for them in the tele- scope if they're not in the sextant right off. They should be close to the crosshairs.

transcript.text: Roger that.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. That's the one we warned you about some time ago. Low helium; no sweat.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Oh, okay.

transcript.text: Okay, Houston. There's a star angle difference with stars 36 and 40.

transcript.text: How about that, baby.

transcript.text: An odd maneuver, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger that. Copy you're maneuvering to the LM JETT attitude. Is that right?

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: That's affirm - -

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: That's affirm.

transcript.text: Torque them, babe, full stroke gimbal.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Odyssey. You're suddenly ahead of the time line.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Odyssey, Houston. Request OMNI Bravo.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.text: Say again, Jack.

transcript.text: Find out LM gimbal lock, Jim.

transcript.text: (Laughter) Okay.

transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. If you concur, we would be inclined to recommend that you go to AGS for the maneuver because you'll have to be there later on anyway.

transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: And AGS PULSE is the recommendation.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: We're having trouble maneuvering, Joe, without getting it in gimbal lock. 05 20 55 50 CC Okay. You can - -

transcript.text: You picked a lousy attitude, though, to separate.

transcript.text: Well, we apologize. Just take your time. Jim, we've got time now.

transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.text: Stand by on that, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Over.

transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Our recommendation is that you stay in AGS for the LM JETT simply because we've thought it through. We've got the right deadbands and all set up. Over.

transcript.text: Okay. It's a lot easier for me to maneuver in PGNS , Joe, than it is AGS .

transcript.text: Yes. You can maneuver in PGNS, Jim. I'm sorry, I thought you were talking about the ATT HOLD and the LM JETT afterward. You can maneuver in PGNS if you want to.

transcript.text: I want to get way over here, Joe. To prevent him into gimbal lock, I have the yaw at about - I'd say about almost 50 degrees.

transcript.text: Roger that. Just stay out of gimbal lock and that 45-degree isn't critical - the out of plane, that is.

transcript.text: Odyssey, Houston. Request OMNI Charlie.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Going OMNI Charlie.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Thank you.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: There.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Good.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Roger. That's VERB 46. Roger. Aquarius, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Jim. The particular DAP configuration we have set up now is using more fuel than we'd like out of system B. We'd like you to reconfigure the DAP to 30021. Over.

transcript.text: Thank you.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Odyssey, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CMP

transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.text: Got it. Thank you.

transcript.speaker: CDR
transcript.text: Okay, Houston; Aquarius. I am at the LM SEP attitude and I'm planning on bailing out.

transcript.text: Okay. I can't think of a better idea, Jim.

transcript.text: We recommend that, Jim.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay, Aquarius; Houston. In AGS ATT HOLD, we recommend WIDE DEADBAND. Over.

transcript.text: Roger.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Aquarius, Houston. Don't forget the ...

transcript.text: Odyssey, Houston.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Go ahead, Joe.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Our troops would like to have you go to the SYSTEMS TEST METER and read out the injector temps on RCS for us.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. Okay. In work.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay, Houston. Let me read out the injector temperatures for you.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Go ahead.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: 5 Charlie, 4.2; 5 Dog, 4.6; 6 Alfa, 4.3; 6 Bravo, 4.3; 6 Charlie, 3.6; 6 Dog, 3.6.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Copy that. No complaints.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Okay. We're ready to proceed with hatch closeup.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Did Jim get the film out of Aquarius?

transcript.text: Yes. We - You mean the film we took this morning?

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: That's affirm.

transcript.speaker: CMP
transcript.text: Yes. We've transferred that.

transcript.speaker: CC
transcript.text: Okay. Good deal. Jack, let me mention something about the hatch integrity check. You're going to vent the tunnel until you get a 3-psi DELTA-P. If it holds pressure for a minute or so or even gets down there, you know you've got a good hatch. Over.
